HEADLINE: Real Estate;
Business Aid For Districts In 5 Boroughs

BYLINE: By Richard D. Lyons

 BODY:
EIGHTEEN New York City neighborhoods have formed Business Improvement Districts, in which assessments paid by commercial properties and businesses support a variety of services and programs. Ten such districts, called BID's, are being developed and 18 others in all five boroughs are considering forming such local civic groups.
This year the existing districts have raised more than $10 million to support street sweeping and security services, beyond those provided by the Sanitation and Police Departments, as well as other programs. The amounts collected and the programs are increasing in volume and sophistication. 
From midtown Manhattan north to Washington Heights and east to Jamaica, Queens, and Flatbush in Brooklyn, BID's are raising funds from their assessments and from government and private grants. In the Grand Central BID in Manhattan, for example, $8 million raised by local assessments is being spent to restore the viaduct that carries Park Avenue traffic around Grand Central Terminal.
In this district, the agreed-upon annual assessment is 10 cents a square foot on commercial properties. The district is also developing programs to help the homeless in the area.
''BID's are incredibly positive neighborhood programs and the proliferation of their number in the last several years demonstrates their proven value,'' said Commissioner Gary Kesner, who heads the city's Office of Business Development. The agency assists in the creation of BID's. Mr. Kesner noted that since legislation allowing them was passed in 1982, their number and influence have grown steadily.
One embryo BID embraces the Metrotech area in downtown Brooklyn, where three large colleges and commuter and communications companies are seeking to broaden the concept.
''We are looking forward to the time when the Metrotech BID will play a major role in offering day care to workers in our area, as well as programs that would help train people to both operate and maintain such equipment as word processors and computers,'' said Bob Ohlerking, the acting director of the Metrotech BID.
One company involved in Metrotech is the Securities Industries Automation Corporation, which is to provide computer services for the New York and American Stock Exchanges and employ 800 workers when its 500,000-square-foot building at Myrtle Avenue and Lawrence Street opens about a year from now.
Mr. Ohlerking also noted that Nynex has two large buildings within the Metrotech BID boundaries, at 360 Bridge Street and 101 Willoughby Street, that are scheduled to be used to train 40,000 management and technical workers a year in the 1990's.
In addition, it is hoped that the Metrotech BID will provide extra street and sidewalk cleaning, put up holiday lighting and other seasonal promotions, and provide assistance to merchants on signs and window displays.
Mr. Ohlerking said he expected that the budget of the Metrotech BID would be about $2.2 million in its first full year, which might be as early as 1991. It takes an average of three years to create a BID, according to officials of the city's Office of Economic Development.
Jack Rainey, the city official in charge of fostering the BID's, noted that under local law a plan for a BID requires about a year to educate merchants and property owners on the value of the concept and how the assessments would be used. Legally, 51 percent of the property owners and merchants in a proposed BID must agree to join before the district can be established. In practice, however, the founders seek 90 percent agreement.
Once the BID is created, the assessments take on the legal force of taxes on all property owners and businesses in the area. The assessments are based either on the value of commercial buildings or on the business generated by their tenants. Yearly assessments average $350.
The next step is at least a year of approval processes, during which public hearings are held and the proposal is reviewed by the City Planning Commission, the Board of Estimate, the State Comptroller and the City Council. Then it takes about a year to carry out the plan agreed upon by the property owners, often with a small amount of start-up funds from the city.
Mr. Rainey said that at times there had been local opposition to the creation of a BID, in some cases by residents who believed erroneously that such municipal services as street cleaning would be reduced if an improvement district was created.
''What we're trying to do is supplement services, not reduce them,'' Mr. Rainey said. He added that in the 1960's and 70's there had been a decline in interest in community improvement almost citywide, in part because of changes in neighborhood social patterns, and that this had undermined local interest in improvements. But with a resurgence of such interest, support for BID's has grown.

HEADLINE: A MAN OF INFLUENCE: POLITICAL CASH AND REGULATION - A SPECIAL REPORT;
In Savings Debacle, Many Fingers Point Here

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH with PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8

 BODY:
To his critics, Charles H. Keating Jr., the Phoenix financier who built and lost the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, represents all that is wrong with a political system in which wealth grants access and influence. To his defenders, Mr. Keating is simply a hard-driving entrepreneur who is being made the fall guy for the savings industry's plight.
But there is no dispute that Mr. Keating has become the central figure in the savings and loan crisis, a breakdown stemming from lax regulation and speculative excess. The Federal bailout of the industry will cost taxpayers more than $100 billion over the next decade, and Lincoln's collapse alone will cost at least $2 billion.
Mr. Keating has never minced words about buying political influence in defense of his financial interests. 
''One question, among many raised in recent weeks, had to do with whether my financial support in any way influenced several political figures to take up my cause,'' he told reporters in April after Federal regulators had taken over Lincoln, with its $6 billion in insured deposits, almost $4 billion of which went to speculative investments in real estate and high-risk ''junk bonds.''
''I want to say in the most forceful way I can: I certainly hope so.''
Mr. Keating, who is scheduled to appear before the House Banking Committee soon to discuss the Lincoln failure, stands accused of fraud and making illegal loans. And members of Congress, many of whom have been the recipients of his largess, are left deeply embarrassed.
For his part, Mr. Keating protests his innocence, denying any wrongdoing, saying that if you do not have money your chances of being heard are greatly reduced. Influence is the way the political system works, he says, and he intends to use it. If regulators had permitted him to keep running Lincoln, he argues, he could have earned his way out of the hole.
By all accounts, he was a frenetic and effective advocate for his business interests - here distributing campaign funds, there offering a former chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board a job or pushing the Reagan Adminsistration to appoint one of his business associates to the bank board. Mr. Keating was for years almost ubiquitous in Washington and at the state and local level.
Regulators maintain that the contributions came almost entirely from the federally insured deposits of Lincoln Savings; they have accused him of looting Lincoln for his own personal gain, and have referred the case to the Justice Department for a possible criminal investigation. The Securities and Exchange Commission, the Internal Revenue Service and the Federal Bureau of Investigation are also conducting inquiries.
 
Driving Up Cost of Crisis
And though in the end the intervention by five Senators to whom Mr. Keating had contributed $1.3 million did not halt the Government takeover of Lincoln Savings on the morning of April 14, his contributions were successful in delaying the process almost two years, driving up the ultimate cost of the failure.
Friends and employees call the 66-year-old Mr. Keating shy, moral and devout. Many in Phoenix, where he still runs the lavish Phoenician Hotel, remain faithful.
In a surprisingly candid statement, Mr. Keating said he found out in early April that regulators were going to move in and commandeer Lincoln. In an effort to shield as many of Lincoln's assets as possible from the Government, he put the American Continental Company, Lincoln's parent company, and almost a dozen Lincoln subsidiaries into bankruptcy, protected from regulators.
But the crisis at Lincoln and his ongoing battle with regulators has beaten him down, he said.
''It's ruined me and my family,'' he said last summer. The regulators ''have taken everything that I have, my family has.'' He added: ''If Lincoln and American go down, there is nothing left for me. I have every nickel I have tied up in this thing.''
 
Cincinnati Beginnings
 
Making His Mark In Nixon Years
A thin 6-foot 5-inch former Olympic swimmer, Mr. Keating has his roots in a prominent Cincinnati family.
A lawyer by training, and with good Republican connections, Mr. Keating came to national attention in September 1970, when as President Richard Nixon's sole appointee to the Federal Commission on Obscenity and Pornography he successfully sued to delay publication of its report.
Later, Mr. Keating was one founder of Citizens for Decency Through Law; he continues to contribute heavily to antipornography groups.
It was also in the 1970's that Mr. Keating became right-hand man to Carl H. Lindner, the Cincinnati takeover artist. As Mr. Lindner was amassing vast holdings, Mr. Keating rose to become executive vice president of Mr. Lindner's American Financial Corporation.
 
Run-In With Regulators
It was at American Financial that Mr. Keating had his first major run-in with regulators. In 1979, after a three-year investigation, the Securities and Exchange Commission charged Mr. Lindner and Mr. Keating with using company funds for their personal benefit, including making large preferential loans to Mr. Keating's family and others.
Both men, without admitting or denying guilt, agreed to a consent order not to violate securities laws.
They had already parted ways. By that time, Mr. Keating had bought Mr. Lindner's struggling real estate development company in Phoenix for $300,000, which became the basis for American Continental.
 
Getting Into the Big Time
 
From Real Estate To Savings
As American Continental was becoming a major real estate developer, Mr. Keating began seeking to buy a saving and loan association.
With Federal regulations rolled back, states loosened their regimes even more, and in California a savings and loan owner could take all insured deposits and channel them into investments far riskier than home mortgages.
In 1984, Mr. Keating bought Lincoln Savings for $51 million and began using Lincoln deposits to buy junk bonds to finance the development projects of American Continental, one of which was the $250 million Phoenician resort.
''We looked around and saw that California had deregulated the S.&L. industry in a way we felt was the salvation of the industry, so we bought Lincoln,'' Mr. Keating said.
 
Problems With Gray
But almost immediately Mr. Keating ran into problems with Edwin J. Gray, then chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, who had begun a big push to limit the direct investments by the savings industry in real estate projects to only 10 percent of an institution's assets, arguing that a rash of such investments had left scores of institutions insolvent.
Mr. Keating went into high gear, hiring, among others, Alan Greenspan, then a private economist and now chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, to do a study that concluded that direct investments were not jeopardizing industry stability.
Indeed, Mr. Greenspan wrote the Federal Home Loan Bank of San Francisco in February 1985, supporting an application by Mr. Keating for an exemption for Lincoln to the 10 percent rule.
 
A Growing Conflict
But an exemption for Lincoln was never granted, and the Gray-Keating conflict grew. In late 1986, Mr. Keating said, he became aware of an opening on the bank board, and proposed a business associate, Lee Henkel Jr., a former chief counsel at the Internal Revenue Service, for a seat on the board, to counteract Mr. Gray. Federal regulators say that with the help of Donald T. Regan, then White House chief of staff, Mr. Henkel got the seat.
But Mr. Henkel's tenure was short. Soon after arriving, Mr. Henkel proposed a regulation that would have granted Lincoln relief on its direct investments. When Mr. Henkel's business dealings with Mr. Keating surfaced, the Justice Department began an inquiry, and he resigned. Mr. Henkel was later cleared of wrongdoing.
Mr. Keating tried other avenues to neutralize Mr. Gray.
''We heard Gray had announced his intention to resign,'' Mr. Keating said, adding that a friend called him and said, ''Why don't you talk to him.''
Over a lunch with Sharon Fairbanks, Mr. Gray's assistant, Mr. Keating told her, he said, that if Mr. Gray ''wanted to come on board, we would at least talk to him about it.'' According to some reports, Mr. Keating would have offered Mr. Gray $300,000 a year.
Mr. Gray rejected Mr. Keating's overtures.
 
Stepping Up Contributions
 
Large Sums Given To Key Politicians
With Mr. Gray apparently at the bank board to stay, Mr. Keating began to step up his contributions to those he considered key members of Congress.
Regulators note that to get around individual contribution limits, Mr. Keating would pay high salaries to his employees and either directly or indirectly instruct them to contribute to certain campaigns; Keating family members would also make contributions.
Deborah Karbo, a former vice president at American Continental, disputed this suggestion. ''There was no pressure,'' she said.
Large sums obviously went to Arizona politicians - $112,000 to John McCain, the state's Republican senator, and $55,000 to Dennis DeConcini, his Democratic colleague. Three Republican House members from the state also benefited handsomely -Jim Kolbe getting $14,000, Jon Kyl $24,900 and John J. Rhodes Jr. $9,000.
He also contributed to other key members of the House and Senate Banking Committees - $10,000 to Senator Timothy E. Wirth, Democrat from Colorado; $76,000 to Donald W. Riegle, Democrat from Michigan; $41,000 to former Senator Chic Hecht, Republican from Nevada, and $20,000 to Representative Douglas Barnard, Democrat of Georgia.
 
Liberal Causes, Too
In defense of his financial interests, Mr. Keating cast a blind eye politically. Not only did he contribute to the re-election campaign of Senator Alan Cranston, the liberal California Democrat, but in 1987 and 1988 Mr. Keating and associates gave $850,000 to three political organizations championed by Mr. Cranston that were aimed at registering minority voters in California. Mr. Cranston, running in a tough race for re-election, was next in line to head the Senate Banking Committee.
In 1987, the five senators, who received a total of $1.3 million, arranged and attended two meetings -one with Mr. Gray - in which they leaned on the bank board to give Mr. Keating a break.
In early 1987, Mr. Keating sued both the bank board and Mr. Gray, alleging intentional leaking of confidential Lincoln documents.
 
Home Base in Phoenix
 
'Commitment To Decency'
In Phoenix, where he has created the lavish Phoenician Hotel to his own design, Mr. Keating has a strong base of support.
The 130-acre resort, with a spectacular view over the Valley of the Sun, has 605 rooms, including two 4,000-square-foot presidential suites, an 18-hole golf course, seven swimming pools, two croquet lawns, a 165-foot water slide for children and a cabana pool lined with mother-of-pearl tile.
Mr. Keating is often seen around the resort, welcoming guests, chatting with the staff, many of whom are local college students, and stopping in at afternoon tea.
''He is one of the great men of the 20th century,'' said Benjamin W. Bull, a corporate counsel of American Continental. Mr. Bull said he has long been associated with Mr. Keating through Citizens for Decency. Mr. Keating's anti-pornography campaign, Mr. Bull said, ''has to do with his deep spiritual commitment to decency - which I realize is contrary to the popular notion that he's something just short of Attila the Hun.''
Mary Jo Colucci, one of Mr. Keating's personal secretaries until she resigned earlier this year, said Mr. Keating often arrived at the office by 3 A.M., at times leaving for a 6 A.M. mass.
She recalled traveling with him through some of the poorest parts of Mexico. ''He would occasionally stop his Jeep and walk out to the people, these poor people, and hand them money,'' she said. ''I think he handed one lady a $100 bill.''
James J. Feder, a Los Angeles lawyer for American Continental in recent months who is dealing with its Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing, argued that Mr. Keating was being treated unfairly by regulators with a ''vendetta'' who intended ''to bury'' him.
Mr. Feder disputed regulators' assertions that $34 million in salaries, bonuses and proceeds from stock sales went to the Keating family, saying that compensation levels were not excessive.
But not everyone in Arizona is a Keating booster.
Edward Korrick, a city councilman in Phoenix until his resignation last year, calls him ''amoral.'' Mr. Keating, he said, started handing out money to local politicians almost as soon as he arrived in Phoenix, back in the 70's, and by 1983 was providing city council candidates with more than $100,000 in donations.
''We'd never experienced anything like that before,'' Mr. Korrick said.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 14, 1989, Tuesday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article on Thursday about Charles H. Keating Jr. and the rise and fall of his Lincoln Savings and Loan Association misstated the participation of Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr. in meetings on proposed disciplinary actions against Lincoln. Senator Riegle attended the second of two meetings with the regulators; four other Senators attended both meetings.

HEADLINE: How France Is Providing Child Care To a Nation

BYLINE: By CAROL LAWSON

 BODY:
AS the debate on how to meet the growing need for child care intensifies in Congress, corporate headquarters and communities across the nation, a panel of experts says the United States should look to France for ideas.
''Coming from a country mired in turmoil over child care, it was striking to see in France a shared consensus about the importance of children and the willingness to put the necessary financial resources behind it,'' said Faith Wohl, director of work and family programs for E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company.
Ms. Wohl was a member of a delegation that spent two weeks in France this year studying that country's extensive child-care system. Sponsored by the French-American Foundation, which promotes understanding of issues of common concern to the two countries, the group was made up of 14 professionals in economics, medicine, business, education, labor, law and other diverse fields.
The delegation is to issue a report today on its findings, which are to be distributed to members of Congress, governors, business and union leaders and child-care experts. It concludes that France is ''a country at a level of economic development similar to that of the United States, but far ahead of us in insuring that its young children are well and safely cared for.'' 
The report describes a system largely financed by tax revenue: a blend of child care, education and health services based on free full-day preschool programs, subsidized day-care centers and licensed care in private homes for infants and toddlers. The noncompulsory preschool programs, which serve nearly 90 percent of French children 3 to 5 years old, offer language arts, exercise, crafts and play.
The report says the system also features intensive training and fair compensation for preschool teachers and others who take care of younger children, a free preventive health program for all young children, and attention to the architecture and safety of day-care centers.
''It all adds up to a systematic approach to young children,'' said Hillary Rodham Clinton, a delegation member who is a lawyer and chairwoman of the Children's Defense Fund, an advocacy group. ''The problem in the United States is that we have no approach.''
Despite their enthusiasm for what they saw, delegation members said the system in France was not without flaws. They expressed misgivings about the ratio of preschool teachers and child-care workers to children, and the Government's firm, centralized control of the system. They also said France has a shortage of infant-toddler care, although the problem is much less acute than in the United States.
The report acknowledges that differences between the nations ''rule out simplistic imitation'' of the French child-care system.
It also points out that a comprehensive child-care system does not develop overnight. The French system has roots that go back 175 years, to shelters that were created for children of the working poor.
Nearly 80 percent of the cost of French child-care services are covered by public funds. Parents provide the rest. The French manage to finance their child-care system ''because of their priorities and political leadership,'' said Barbara R. Bergmann, a panel member who is Distinguished Professor of Economics at American University in Washington.
The report says the French spend 49 percent of their per-capita income in taxes, compared with 31 percent in the United States. France spends the equivalent of 7.1 percent of its gross national product on public education, including preschool programs, compared with 5.5 percent for the United States.
Delegation members said they found in France that child care was not a subject for political debate, as it is in the United States.
''I was surprised that the commitment to child care has support across the political spectrum,'' Mrs. Clinton said.
The observers also found that unlike child-care services in United States, those in France are intended for children in all strata of society. ''We tend to target programs for poor children, for children at risk,'' said Barbara Reisman, another panel member who is also executive director of the Child Care Action Campaign, a national advocacy organization based in New York City.
Members of the panel said they were particularly struck by the quality of workers who teach or care for young children. ''In France,'' their report says, ''staff training and experience are considered the foundation of quality care.''
French preschool teachers are required to have the equivalent of a master's degree in early-childhood education. The directors of infant-toddler programs are pediatric nurses or midwives who have additional training in public health and child development. Staff members must have a degree equivalent to two years of college in the United States and two additional years of training in early childhood education and child development. The salaries are competitive with those for other jobs in France requiring similar credentials, like elementary-school teachers or nurses.
The report concludes that the level of staff training and compensation has enabled France to create a stable child-care system. It says that in the United States, by contrast, ''trained caregivers are in short supply and their wages are low,'' and that ''child-care centers lose, and must replace, 40 percent of their staff each year.''
One member of the delegation, David Edie, said that while he was impressed by the ''comprehensive'' nature of the French system, he objected to its centralized control by the Government. ''I did not like the lack of parental involvement, the sense that the professionals know how to do everything and parents should stay out of it,'' said Mr. Edie, day-care coordinator for the Wisconsin Department of Health and Social Services.
There was also criticism of the ratio of preschool teachers and child-care workers to children. Each preschool teacher is assigned an average of 22 students. In infant-toddler centers, each worker tends to eight toddlers or five infants.
''We feel in the United States that children need more adults,'' said Bettye Caldwell, Distinguished Professor of Education at the University of Arkansas, who served on the panel. ''But the children we saw were happy and engaged. The French have a trade-off between these ratios and the high level of staff training.''
One problem France shares with the United States is a shortage of child care for infants and toddlers now that more mothers are entering the work force. ''But they have a plan to fix it,'' Ms. Wohl of the panel said.
In Paris, new infant-toddler centers are being opened at the rate of two a month, and the French Government is giving municipalities money to expand the availability of centers and family day care.
France also has a widespread system of adults who care for infants and toddlers in their homes. The report says that about 75 percent of these family day-care providers are licensed, compared with 10 percent in the United States. France also offers incentives for providers to become licensed; these include retirement benefits, disability insurance and a minimum wage.
Parents pay for care at infant-toddler centers on a sliding scale, depending on income and where they live. In Paris, parents typically pay annual fees ranging from $1,750 to $4,000 per child, or about 14 percent of their annual income. The poorest families pay $195.
Licensed family day care costs parents from $11 to $18 a day per child. Parents receive a special tax deduction for using licensed rather than unlicensed family day care.
To meet the needs of working parents, preschool programs offer additional care before and after school and during vacations. While most of the schools are free, parents pay $210 a year for these special services.
The delegation visited programs in Paris, and in Nantes and St. Herblain, in Brittany. The group also met with Government officials, business leaders, doctors, nurses and parents.
''We have seen the future,'' Mr. Edie said, ''and we're behind.''

HEADLINE: Manila Journal;
From a Life of Privilege, a Woman of Substance

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANILA

 BODY:
Daughter of one of the Philippines' most respected men and the sister of another, Leticia Ramos Shahani has had a privileged life. It has also been one of extraordinary accomplishment and self-discovery.
Currently chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Mrs. Shahani freely admits that she has been a beneficiary of the clannish, male-dominated and semi-feudal society that the Philippines remains. But in both her personal life and her career, she has made significant efforts to break out of traditional patterns of insularity to become one of the country's most cosmopolitan voices, one of an influential group of respected women politicians.
In the process, she has become a model for some women, with a set of credentials that owe little to her late husband, an Indian writer and professor who died suddenly 20 years ago, leaving her three small children to raise. 
 
Adopting a Major Role
Now, in her Senate position, she will play a substantial role in the heated debate about the renewal of a military bases treaty with the United States, an accord that requires ratification in the Senate, where 12 of 23 Senators have already declared their opposition.
Mrs. Shahani, 60 years old, was born to an elite household. Her father, Narcisco Ramos, served in the first congress after independence in 1946 and became Foreign Minister before the rise of Ferdinand E. Marcos, Mrs. Shahani's second cousin. Her brother, Fidel V. Ramos, made his way through the military and is now Defense Minister under President Corazon C. Aquino, whom it is said he would like to succeed.
Mrs. Shahani was sent to Wellesley College, where she majored in English; she went on to earn a master's in comparative literature from Columbia University in 1954 and a Ph.D. from the Sorbonne in 1961.
It was not until then that she agreed to marry Ranjee Shahani, an Indian with whom she had fallen in love 10 years before. Women who want to establish themselves, she says, are probably best advised to delay marriage.
She returned home to teach and wrote a book about the Philippines, then joined the foreign service, serving with the Philippine Mission to the United Nations. She then joined the United Nations Secretariat, focusing on women's issues, which at the time, she said, were ''a big joke'' among male colleagues.
In time, she headed the United Nations Commission on the Status of Women, before being named in 1975 as her country's first ambassador to a Communist country, and also, as it happened, the first woman Rumania had received as ambassador.
''They didn't know what to make of me,'' she said. After three rather lonely years - ''I couldn't make friends with Rumanians, so as not to harm them'' - she was named Ambassador to a rather more carefree nation, Australia.
It was there, she said, that she ''started to see signs of Marcos's desire to muzzle everything and everyone,'' preventing any open criticism of his Government while lining his own pockets and those of his cronies. #1985 Conference on Women In 1981 she returned to the United Nations, to become Assistant Secretary General for Social Development and Humanitarian Affairs, based in Vienna. In 1985, she ran a world conference in Nairobi to evaluate the United Nations Decade for Women.
''But I was becoming very concerned about matters back home,'' she said. And she was becoming disillusioned. ''At the U.N., despite all the talk about 'one world' and 'the global village,' unless your own country is strong and has developed its own stance, it doesn't have much say in international affairs.''
She talked of returning to run for Mayor of her hometown in Pangasinan Province, a Marcos stronghold. ''I thought there should be some corner of democracy, and that even if Marcos cheated, I would probably win,'' she said.
But events moved quickly, with Mr. Marcos calling an early presidential election. Visiting the YWCA in her hometown, she was asked whether she favored Mr. Marcos or Mrs. Aquino. ''I said rather casually: 'Well, I'm for change. I'm for Cory.'
''It turned out I was the first high-ranking Filipino official to come out for her, and it was quite stunning, and I didn't, honestly speaking, realize the drama it would create,'' she recalled. ''It spread like wildfire, because that is really Marcos country. I got word from him, my second cousin - What was I doing? - and he tried unsuccessfully to suppress it.''
Mrs. Shahani returned to Vienna. A week after the military-led popular uprising that followed the presidential elections in February 1986, Mrs. Aquino, now President, asked Mrs. Shahani to return to Manila as deputy to the new Foreign Minister, Vice President Salvador H. Laurel. Mr. Laurel has long since broken with Mrs. Aquino and is now a leader of the opposition.
After the passage of a a new Constitution in 1987, Mrs. Shahani said, ''I felt I should take a crack at politics. Maybe that would give me a better base.''
With Mrs. Aquino then at the height of her popularity, Mrs. Shahani secured a senatorial slot on the President's slate, one of two women.
The arena of politics, she says, was yet another revelation. Campaigns require a sort of theatricality she found distressing, but also, despite herself, rather fun.
''As a diplomat, you develop certain reflexes. You learn to be proper and sober and show no emotion, and of course that's fatal for a politician.''
It seemed she did not smile enough. ''I'd say to them that I was grinning from ear to ear, but they'd say, 'You must smile all the time, it's expected of you.' And I'd look at the others, and it was true. They have a permanent smile. They all do.''
She was also told she needed a jingle for television and radio, and that her Indian name would be a disadvantage. So to the tune of a cha-cha-cha, she was plumped as ''Sha-Sha-Sha,'' and the jingle became popular.
''I think it was one of the main reasons I won. It wasn't my program! It's one of the reasons Imelda Marcos did so well for so long: she would smile and sing. So I discovered politics as theater. It was very humbling.''
 
Seizing the Middle Ground
Mrs. Shahani has proved in politics, too, to be a quick learner. She has distinguished herself in the Senate, and has worked to balance her support for Mrs. Aquino with criticism of governmental inefficiency, corruption and lack of planning.
But her critics say that in the flamboyant atmosphere of Filipino politics, Mrs. Shahani seems too cerebral and cautious, following too closely the professionals in the foreign service.
Mrs. Shahani has tried to argue a middle ground on the issue of the American military bases here, saying that Filipino sovereignty and maturity require their removal, but not before a carefully planned handover to reduce security risks and economic disruption.
She has also been outspoken on the need for an effective program of population control, an unpopular position in this largely Catholic country. Without one, Mrs. Shahani says, all the gains made in the economy and against the Communist insurgency will come to nothing.
''The policy is there, but the capacity to deliver to the people isn't,'' she said. ''Part of the task of leadership is to lead.''

HEADLINE: 2 Superpowers Failing in Geography

BYLINE: By WARREN E. LEARY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8

 BODY:
People in the Soviet Union and the United States know there is a world out there that the superpowers want to influence. They just can't place it.
The first survey of geographic knowledge conducted in the Soviet Union, made public today by the National Geographic Society, shows that Americans and Soviet citizens share ''an astonishing lack of awareness of the world around them,'' the organization said.
Soviet adults scored slightly lower than Americans, who took an identical survey last year, in being able to identify the locations of other nations of the world, an unexpected result that a Soviet pollster termed ''a shock'' for a nation that prides itself on education. 
''The results are unbelieveable,'' said Vladimir G. Andreyenkov of the Soviet Academy of Sciences, which conducted the survey with the Gallup Organization. ''They will have very great repercussions in the Soviet Union.''
 
Younger Russians Do Better
A bright spot for the Soviet Union is that younger people, between ages 18 and 24, did significantly better than their American counterparts. Young Americans scored in last place for geographical knowledge among the 10 nations where the test was given.
The young Soviet citizens correctly identified an average of 9.3 of 16 locations on a world map, ranking fourth along with Canadians and Italians. Young Americans came in last, with an average of 6.9 correct selections.
Soviet citizens in general identified an average of 7.4 of a possible 16 locations, which put them at the bottom, tied with Mexico. American adults ranked sixth among the 10 nations, with 8.6 correct.
The overall scores were Sweden, 11.6; West Germany, 11.2; Japan, 9.7; France, 9.3; Canada, 9.2; United States, 8.6; Britain, 8.5; Italy, 7.6; Mexico, 7.4, and the Soviet Union, 7.4.
Thirteen percent of the Soviet citizens could not find their own country on a map, and 14 percent of the Americans could not find the United States.
 
'Mostly Discouraging'
Gilbert M. Grosvenor, president of the National Geographic Society, said at a news conference that the surveys showed that people in the United States and the Soviet Union ''have little understanding of the world around them.''
''We have learned a lot from this process, mostly discouraging,'' Mr. Grosvenor said. ''In today's world, if you don't know where you are, you are nowhere.''
An indication of the depth of geographical ignorance, he said, was that only 38 percent of Russians surveyed could find Afghanistan on a map, even though it borders the Soviet Union to the south and Soviet soldiers fought Afghan rebels for nearly a decade before pulling out this year. The Afghan question was added to the Soviet survey but not included in the previous one.
Just as surprising, the survey said, was that only 32 percent of Americans could find Vietnam on a map.
Almost 11,000 people in nine nations were tested in their homes in the spring of 1988 and asked to locate the same 13 countries, Central America, the Pacific Ocean and the Persian Gulf.
About 1,500 Soviet citizens took part in the survey last spring in Moscow and Kursk, an industrial city of 425,000 people, 300 miles south of the capital. Mr. Andreyenkov and Neil A. Upmeyer of Gallup said the results might not apply to all of the Soviet Union because of its size and cultural diversity, but were accurate for the European section of the country. A wider survey would have been impractical, they said.
 
Opinion Polls Allowed Now
Public opinion surveys were banned in the Soviet Union for decades, but the practice has been allowed again under a recent liberalization of policies.
Russians and Americans were good at locating each other. Seventy-six percent of Russians could find the United States on the map. For Americans, 66 percent correctly identified the Soviet Union.
Nearly 90 percent of the Russians surveyed - compared with 47 percent of the Americans - said they had taken a course devoted entirely to geography. Mr. Andreyenkov said total school education was the biggest independent factor found in determining who would be best at identifying locations on the map.
In examining attitudes on what subjects people considered important to be well-educated and competitive, participants were asked a series of questions. Knowledge of geography was rated absolutely necessary by 52 percent of Russians, compared with 37 percent of Americans. Computer skills were rated higher by Americans than Russians, 64 percent to 42 percent, and knowledge of history was rated necessary by 72 percent of Russians, compared with only 36 percent of Americans.

HEADLINE: Without Braniff, Nebraska City Suffers

BYLINE: By WILLIAM ROBBINS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GRAND ISLAND, Neb.

 BODY:
Of all the cities served by Braniff, this city of 45,000 people in central Nebraska now has a distinction no one wanted.
With the airline suspending all passenger flights as of Tuesday and putting itself up for sale, travelers in many cities now face more difficult flight schedules and higher costs. But Grand Island's situation is more troublesome: the city has lost its only direct link with a major airline. It had a passenger exchange and ticketing arrangement with Braniff through two commuter carriers. 
Before Braniff sought protection from creditors in bankruptcy court on Sept. 28, the two commuter carriers made six flights a day here, and passengers who continued on Braniff jets from Kansas City received fare breaks. Now only one carrier, Midcontinent Airline, offers service to Kansas City, with two flights a day out of Grand Island. But it does not provide the passenger exchange and ticketing arrangements or the fare breaks that were available before.
 
'Has a Big Impact'
''Braniff offered through fares for the entire trip, including the flight from here to Kansas City,'' said Dick Brown, owner of First Holiday Tour and Travel in Grand Island. ''That kept us competitive. Now if you fly from here, the fare is an add-on to whatever the major airline charges. And if you drive over to Lincoln or Omaha, that's 95 or 150 miles, and more expenses.''
''All that has a big impact,'' Mr. Brown added. ''When you are in rural America, and you want to promote economic development, your airport is one of your more important assets.''
The broadest impact of Braniff's collapse, of course, has fallen on Kansas City. Through much of the 1980's it had enjoyed superior air service as Eastern Airlines established one of its main route centers there. After Eastern withdrew most of its operations a year ago, Braniff moved in and rapidly expanded a hub-and-spoke system of its own.
From Kansas City, it offered direct flights to 32 cities, including Orlando, Fla., the company's headquarters. All told, it offered 93 flights a day on its major routes.
Then, on Sept. 28, Braniff, which has been owned since 1988 by a group represented by Paine Webber Inc., ran out of operating money. It halted most flights and sought protection from creditors in bankruptcy court while it reorganized. When it resumed flying, it offered a schedule shrunken to 46 flights. Then, on Monday night, it suspended the rest of its flights and said it would run only its charter operations.
 
Fewer Nonstop Flights
Kansas City still has service from a dozen other major airlines, among them American Airlines and USAir. But Braniff offered the only nonstop flights from Kansas City to major airports at these 14 cities: Albuquerque, N.M.; Boston; Cleveland; Indianapolis; Miami; LaGuardia in New York; Ontario, Calif.; Orlando; Philadelphia; San Antonio; San Diego; Seattle; Tampa, Fla., and Tucson, Ariz.
Other airlines, though, have scheduled nonstop flights to begin soon to three of those: LaGuardia, Cleveland and Indianapolis.
 
Impact on Business Travelers
''The big impact was on the business travelers, people who want to get there as fast as they can,'' said Marcy Moreno, an agent at Heart of America Travel in Kansas City. ''We had been spoiled. Often they could get there and back the same day.''
''Take flights to Boston and Philadelphia, for example,'' Ms. Moreno continued. ''Before Braniff's troubles you could get there in less than three hours. Now, with connections through Chicago, St. Louis or Detroit, you're adding one to three hours, and the fares have gone up, too.''
But it is in the smaller communities that had depended on Braniff's commuter lines where the cuts became more than an inconvenience. In that way the Braniff failure has been similar to the cutbacks at Eastern in March. The Eastern retrenchment forced four commuter airlines to eliminate routes serving 20 cities.
Braniff's collapse has delivered its harshest blows to the commuter lines Air Midwest and Midcontinent Airline. Both, operating under the name Braniff Express, had generated passengers for Braniff's major routes, and Braniff had shared its revenue with them.
When Braniff filed for bankruptcy-court protection, Air Midwest cut its flights from 74 to 48 and Midcontinent temporarily grounded all its planes.
In addition to cutting the number of flights, Air Midwest eliminated service to seven cities. Besides Grand Island, they are Joplin, Mo.; Sioux City, Iowa.; Moline, Ill.; Madison, Wis.; Peoria, Ill., and Tulsa, Okla.
When Midcontinent resumed flying Sunday, it had eliminated three cities from its schedule: Sioux Falls, S.D., Fort Smith, Ark., and Springfield, Mo.
Except for Grand Island, those cities have passenger exchange and ticketing arrangements with other major airlines in other cities.
 
'Problem Is the Lost Time'
Doyle Hulme, general manager of the Ford New Holland farm machinery plant in Grand Island, explained what the changes will mean for his company. His employees, he said, must make about 15 flights a month to Philadelphia to get to a home office in Lancaster, Pa. Now, Mr. Hulme said, instead of flying out of Grand Island, they have to drive to the Lincoln airport 95 miles away or the Omaha airport 150 miles away.
''The biggest problem is the lost time,'' Mr. Hulme said. ''In the past you could get there in three hours and still get half a day's work done. Now you blow an entire day just getting there.''
The only one benefiting at the moment from Grand Island's trouble is George Poullos, owner of GP Express, a commuter line that flies from Grand Island to Lincoln, Omaha, Denver and several neighboring small cities. Its traffic has increased as the competition faded.
''In the short term we are benefiting,'' Mr. Poullos said. ''In the long run, though, it could hurt us. We could wind up losing that business to other airports.''

HEADLINE: Minimum Wage Rise Wins Final Senate Vote

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8

 BODY:
The Senate gave final legislative approval today to a bill raising the minimum wage to $3.80 an hour next year and to $4.25 an hour in 1991. The increases would be the first since 1981.
The bill, adopted on a vote of 89 to 8, is the product of months of negotiations between Congress and the White House. The measure now goes to President Bush, who has said he will sign it. Under an agreement worked out last week, Democrats accepted a smaller increase in the wage floor than they sought initially, and Mr. Bush accepted a more narrowly defined subminimum wage that would apply to teen-agers in the first 90 days of their employment. 
''Both sides in this controversy have compromised,'' said Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the Massachusetts Democrat who was the chief sponsor of the measure. ''The amount of the increase is much less than I wanted and much less than the working poor deserved.'' #8 Conservatives Oppose Bill If the wage rate had been adjusted for inflation each year since 1981, he said, the minimum would now be $4.79 an hour.
All eight of the Senators voting against the compromise were conservative Republicans, several of whom offered amendments to permit new migrant and seasonal farm workers to be paid at the subminimum rate and to prevent the Federal Government from mandating future increases in the minimum wage or other employee benefits. Both amendments were defeated on 64-to-34 votes.
Senator Jesse Helms, a North Carolina Republican who was one of the opponents, said the rise in the minimum wage would hurt the very workers that supporters of the increase were trying to help. In a view echoed even by some of the Republicans who eventually voted for the bill, the Senator said the higher hourly wage would eliminate job opportunities for poor and unskilled workers while forcing price increases in the goods and services they purchase.
About 4 million of the 60 million American workers paid by the hour receive the minimum wage, which is now $3.35 an hour. Several million others earn more than the current minimum but less than $4.25 an hour. According to the Labor Department, more than three of every 10 workers earning the minimum wage are teen-agers, and 70 percent of the minimum wage earners are women.
 
Election Campaign Pledge
The first 45-cents-an-hour rise in the minimum wage will take effect next April 1, and the second installment will take effect on April 1, 1991.
Mr. Bush, making good on an election campaign pledge, initially sought legislation that would raise the minimum wage to $4.25 an hour over three years and create a new subminimum wage that employers could pay to all newly hired workers for as long as six months. Earlier this year he vetoed legislation that would have increased the minimum wage rate to $4.55 an hour over three years and limited the subminimum wage to first-time workers for a period of 60 days.
Under the compromise urged by Republican leaders in the Senate, the President accepted a modified version of the subminimum wage applicable only to workers between the ages of 16 and 19 and then only for the first 90 days of their employment. The submininum would be $3.35 an hour beginning next April 1, and 85 percent of the regular minimum wage rate thereafter.
The measure approved today also expands an existing exemption from the minimum wage law for certain small retail and service businesses. It also increases the percentage of earnings received from tips that can be counted against the minimum wage.
As the outcome of the final vote was announced, there was a burst of applause and cheers from lobbyists for labor organizations who were waiting in a room outside the Senate chamber.
In a statement issued afterward, Lane Kirkland, the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., said he was delighted with the result and urged the President to sign the bill promptly.

LENGTH: 357 words

HEADLINE: New Jersey Chooses Continuity

 BODY:
New Jersey voters, leaving no doubt about their choice for governor, elected Representative James Florio over Representative Jim Courter by a 24-point margin. The outcome was a triumph of Democrat over Republican, of an activist philosophy of government over a minimalist view. Mostly, though, it was an expression of a widespread desire for continuity and moderation. 
When Mr. Florio takes office in January, he'll succeed Tom Kean, a Republican who narrowly defeated him in his first bid for governor eight years ago. Party labels aside, Mr. Florio and Mr. Kean are more alike than different in their approaches to government. In exit polls many voters described themselves, Mr. Kean and Mr. Florio as moderates, and the personable Mr. Courter as unacceptably conservative.
Under Governor Kean, New Jersey's state spending doubled. The state pioneered in welfare and education reform and began formally pursuing regional and statewide development. All of that was made possible by an economic boom that produced jobs in abundance and made New Jersey's per capita income among the highest in the nation.
Mr. Florio comes to office as the boom has started to fade and with the state facing a deficit of as much as $600 million. He'll need all the imagination and perseverance he showed as a Congressman to close that gap and still pursue new solutions to problems like pollution and solid-waste disposal.
In addition to the governorship, the voters gave Mr. Florio a legislature of his own party by returning a Democratic majority to the State Assembly. The Senate was already under Democratic control. That could be crucial in contriving a solution to New Jersey's most vexing problem, if not necessarily its most important: automobile insurance.
It was in their approaches to the auto insurance issue that the differences between Mr. Florio and Mr. Courter were most vividly demonstrated. Mr. Florio wanted tougher state regulation of insurance companies; Mr. Courter wanted to foster more competition to bring prices down.
The voters decided that the business of government is to govern. Mr. Florio is their quite sensible choice.

PUB-DATE: November 9, 1989

SECTION: Section A; Page 34, Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 473 words

HEADLINE: How We Can Help Gorbachev and Ourselves

 BODY:
To the Editor:
A. M. Rosenthal, in his column of Oct. 20, fears that Mikhail S. Gorbachev is using perestroika, his policy of restructuring, to save ''the Communist system.'' Four facts, however, indicate that the Soviet President is trying to change the system into something resembling a Scandinavian combination of social welfare and democracy: (1) The adoption of regular and competitive elections to national and regional legislatures that debate and pass new laws rather than passively rubber-stamping them. (2) Much greater (although not complete) freedom to express unorthodox, antigovernment ideas. (3) His repeated emphasis on the need for the rule of law under a new constitution being drafted by the Supreme Soviet. (4) The cautious encouragement of private enterprises, including foreign ones.
These steps are all loosening the Communist Party's noose around the Government, the press, private lives and the economy. They have also opened a Pandora's box of unrest and protest by consumers, workers and non-Russian ethnic groups, as well as resistance by party members, whose privileges are threatened. 
President Gorbachev walks a thin line between moving too fast and moving too slowly. If he gives away power too soon by conceding every economic or political demand, he exposes himself to a counterperestroika coup by conservative party members. If he moves too slowly, he risks total collapse of the Soviet economy and the breakdown of law and order.
Perestroika, as Mr. Gorbachev defines it on page 255 of his book of that title, means ''democratization, economic reform and transformation of the political system.'' Give him credit where credit is due. He has initiated positive changes in all three areas, changes that have considerable potential for long-range growth.
There is one big way we can and should help encourage further the evolution of the Soviet Union toward a freer form of government and a market system that can meet the people's economic needs. That is by cooperating with Mr. Gorbachev in promptly reducing spending by both our countries on unnecessary military hardware and personnel.
This will transform us into a freer people as well - less enslaved by a crippling national debt, huge annual budget deficits, unfavorable balances of trade, paralyzing fears of Communism, and preparations for an unlikely war that could destroy us all.
We have but to follow Abraham Lincoln's advice in his 1862 annual message to Congress, and recognize that ''the occasion is piled high with difficulty, and we must rise with the occasion.''
''As our case is new,'' he continued, ''so we must act anew. We must disenthral ourselves, and then we shall save our country.''
 
STEPHEN HAY
 Santa Barbara, Calif., Oct. 24, 1989
The writer is a professor of history at the University of California.

HEADLINE: Errors in Management Preceded Our Deficits

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In noting the disadvantages of United States companies competing with Japan, and their failure to get ready for the long haul, you state that ''Federal budget deficits have raised interest rates and forced U.S. companies to seek quicker paybacks on their investments'' (''Rights and Wrongs of Blaming Japan,'' editorial Oct. 16).
It is undoubtedly true that many American companies (that is, those that are publicly held) are willing to sacrifice long-term growth for short-term profits. Federal budget deficits, however, can't be blamed for this shortsightedness.
The preoccupation of United States managers with today's bottom line predates huge Federal deficits by 30 to 40 years and is traceable, I believe, to the practice of compensating management with stock options. In my experience, the overriding concern of management engaged in making a corporate decision is not the long-term corporate benefit, but ''What will it do to the price of our stock?'' Until this situation is addressed, the quick fix will probably remain the preferred choice of United States managers.
 
CURTIS D. FORSLUND
 Minneapolis, Oct. 17, 1989
The writer is a lawyer.

HEADLINE: New York Housing Officials Redefine Family to Block Evictions

BYLINE: By PHILIP S. GUTIS

 BODY:
New York State housing officials expanded the definition of family yesterday to block landlords from evicting unrelated people from the more than 1 million rent-stabilized apartments in the state.
The new definition follows a ruling in July by the state's highest court that said two gay men who had lived together for more than a decade could be considered a family under the city's rent-control regulations.
In announcing the new rules, the Housing Commissioner, Richard L. Higgins, said that emergency action to expand the court's ruling is necessary to prevent any evictions from going forward.
''We must assure that nontraditional family members of tenants, especially those most vulnerable such as the elderly, disabled and persons infected with the AIDS virus, are not unfairly subject to eviction,'' Mr. Higgins said in a statement. A broad range of people would be affected by the new rules, including many poor and elderly people who often form nontraditional households out of economic and social need. 
Reaction to the emergency regulations, which take effect immediately, came swiftly as gay- and lesbian-rights organizations hailed the state's decision while representatives of New York City landlords promised to file suit against the new rules in State Supreme Court today.
''The government is basically saying that property owners must bear the brunt of the societal question of what is family,'' said John Gilbert, the president of the Rent Stabilization Association, a lobbying organization for landlords. ''What they are attempting to say to a property owner is that you don't have the right to determine who lives in your building.''
David A. Hansell, the legal director of the Gay Men's Health Crisis, the country's largest AIDS service organization, said the state action was ''fair and compassionate.''
''Many times the eviction cases that we handle involve survivors, usually lovers, of people who have died of AIDS and who themselves have been diagnosed with AIDS,'' he said. ''This removes from them the dual burden of dealing with their illness and the threat of eviction.''
Paula L. Ettelbrick, the legal director of the Lambda Legal Defense and Education Fund, which had joined with many other gay-rights and tenant organizations in lobbying the housing department, called the new regulations a ''tremendous step forward for the gay and lesbian community.''
''They have taken seriously the Court of Appeals instruction that we look at the reality of family life in this country,'' she said. ''And the reality of family life includes gay and lesbian life partners.''
The regulations, which had been the object of intense negotiations throughout the summer and fall, specify that people unrelated to a tenant can remain in a rent-stabilized apartment if they meet two primary requirements, including living with the tenant for no less than two years or for one year for elderly or disabled people.
Tenants would also have to show ''emotional and financial commitment and interdependence'' between themselves and the person on the lease.
Under the new regulations, a tenant may - at any time - advise their landlord of all people who live in the apartment and whether anyone is entitled to be named as a tenant on a renewal lease and when their relationship began. If the do not provide the landlord with such information it could be more difficult for their partner to remain in the apartment.
 
'Reality of Family Life'
In July, the Court of Appeals wrote that protection from eviction under rent-control rules ''should not rest on fictitous legal distinctions or genetic history, but instead should find its foundation in the reality of family life.''
Because the apartment in question in that decision was regulated under rent-control rules, the decision did not affect the state's rent-stabilized buildings.
Rent-control guidelines in New York, which cover apartments built before 1947 that have been occupied by the same tenant at least since 1971, affect about 167,000 apartments, most of them in New York City.
The rent-stabilization laws, in contrast, are less strict. They affect residents of more than 900,000 apartments in New York City as well as 74,000 apartments in Nassau, Westchester and Rockland counties. Another 162,000 apartments throughout New York State are also affected by the housing department's decision.
 
Subject to Public Hearings
The new regulations will be subject to public hearings before they are finalized by the department.
In addition to expanding the definition of family, the new regulations also change a provision of the current rent-stabilization law to allow tenants to remain in their apartments even if the original lease holder moves. Since 1987, even people related by blood, marriage or adoption could be evicted if the leaseholder moved from a rent-stabilized apartment.
Throughout the summer, the housing department was criticized for not issuing the regulations immediately after the Court of Appeals decision.
 
Omnibus Housing Bill
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo had proposed legislation very similiar to yesterday's emergency regulations as part of an omnibus housing bill before the Legislature this year, but the bill died in the final days of the legislative session.
The new regulations are expected to have broad implications for many unrelated people living together in rent-stabilized apartments. The rules were seen as a particular victory for gay-rights groups, however.
The new rules ''represent the most far-reaching recognition of lesbian and gay relationships ever granted by any government agency in the United States,'' said William B. Rubenstein, staff counsel to the Lesbian and Gay Rights Project of the American Civil Liberties Union.
''It is an important recognition that lesbians, gay men and other functional family members are threatened by eviction from their family homes in the very same way other New Yorkers are,'' he said.

HEADLINE: The 1989 Elections: Seattle First Black Is Elected Mayor, Defeating Busing Opponent

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Nov. 8

 BODY:
Norman B. Rice has been elected Seattle's first black mayor, defeating an opponent who built his campaign on a ballot measure to end busing for school integration.
The voters split so evenly on the ballot measure that its fate remains undecided.
Mr. Rice, a three-term City Councilman, won by a wide margin yesterday in a city with a black population of 10 percent. In the campaign he favored a tax increase to pay for more police officers and trumpeted his managerial experience. 
Mr. Rice, a Democrat, carried all but a few precincts of the city with 93,491 votes, or 58 percent. His Republican opponent, City Attorney Doug Jewett, received 67,276 votes, or 42 percent.
 
'Seattle Set an Example'
''Seattle set an example for the rest of the United States,'' Mr. Rice said. ''This is a can-do city and a thinking city.''
His campaign manager, Charles Rolland, said: ''We made history. The conventional wisdom has always been that a city needs to have at least 40 percent minorities to elect black mayor. We proved that wrong.''
New York City, where blacks make up 25 percent of the population, also elected its first black mayor, David N. Dinkens, on Tuesday.
Mr. Jewett had built his campaign around an initiative to end busing of schoolchildren to achieve racial balance. Mr. Jewett's strategists had hoped the initiative would bring out Republican voters and those dissatisfied with busing.
 
Busing Measure Is Dead Even
With several thousand absentee ballots still not counted, the busing measure was running dead even.
Mr. Rolland said the anti-busing measure failed to carry Mr. Jewett to victory because about 35 percent of those who favored the initiative also voted for Mr. Rice. Mr. Rice had called the measure divisive and ''a terrible ingredient'' in Seattle politics. And in an effort to draw attention from the issue, he proposed his own plan to phase out busing over four years.
Unlike the mayoral contest in New York or the Virginia gubernatorial race, where surveys had overestimated the support of black politicians, the Seattle race proved just the opposite. Mr. Rice's margin of victory, 16 percentage points, was twice the margin of his lead found in polls completed last week.
Mr. Rice said in an interview today that crime proved to be a much bigger issue than race or busing. A central platform of Mr. Rice's campaign, a measure to raise the city's business and occupation taxes to hire 102 more police officers, passed easily Tuesday.
''There was a feeling in the neighborhoods that people were threatened, that they wanted more security,'' Mr. Rice said. ''The feeling was widespread.''
 
No Watermelon Buttons Here
Mr. Rolland, a former Chicago resident who was the Washington State campaign manager in the Rev. Jesse Jackson's two Presidential bids, said Mr. Rice's candidacy brought out only a few racial slurs. ''It was pretty minor because racism here is much more hidden and subtle,'' he said. ''It's not Chicago, where people were wearing watermelon buttons during the last mayor's race.''
Mr. Rice, who is 46 years old, has always been a low-key politician. In fact, his caution was blamed by some for his loss four years ago to Mayor Charles Royer, a three-term Democrat, and in an unsuccessful Congressional race last year. Mayor Royer is leaving Seattle to head the Institute of Politics at the Harvard University's John F. Kennedy School of Government.
During the campaign Mr. Rice often spoke of his skill in helping to balance the city's budget in the recession during the 1980's. As a Councilman, he was the chairman of the finance committee.
This year, Mr. Rice entered the mayor's race reluctantly, he said, considering his two previous failures and announced his candidacy on the last possible filing day. His campaign began slowly, but he picked up momentum in debates with Mr. Jewett.

HEADLINE: A Year of Tribulation for Pan Am

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
Pan Am has been vigorously searching for a buyer or partner for several years. The last thing it needed was a year like the last one.
More than 10 months after a terrorist bomb destroyed a Pan American World Airways jetliner over Lockerbie, Scotland, many travelers, particularly business people, continue to avoid the carrier. The Scottish tragedy and subsequent introduction of time-consuming security checks will have cost the airline up to $250 million in forgone ticket sales by the end of this year, said Thomas G. Plaskett, the airline's chairman, chief executive and president.
And in recent months, regulators have advocated new restrictions on investments in American airlines and sales of international routes, making it more difficult for Pan Am to find a foreign partner or raise money. American carriers have not expressed interest in buying Pan Am. 
 
Buyout Limits Proposed
Also, members of Congress have called for limits on airline buyouts, which could help deter both domestic and foreign deals.
During this year Pan Am has gone through an expensive and unsuccessful attempt to take over Northwest Airlines and has seen the collapse of partnership talks with KLM Royal Dutch Airlines. And while Pan Am obtained concessions from its unions last year totaling about $500 million over three years, its accumulated losses have left it with debts exceeding assets by $458 million. The airline also has an unfunded pension liability totaling $550 million at the end of last year.
Troubled labor relations, the lack of a well-developed domestic route network and growing competition on trans-Atlantic routes have also made it difficult for Pan Am to find a financially strong partner.
Some people are not optimistic about Pan Am's future. ''They have gone through eight of their nine lives,'' said Edward J. Starkman, an airline analyst with Paine Webber. ''One bad winter and they could run out of cash.''
Pan Am said yesterday that it earned $458,000 in the third quarter, its peak season, compared with a $67.4 million profit in the corresponding quarter last year. Quarterly revenues, at $1.02 billion, were down slightly from $1.04 billion.
In the first nine months of this year, Pan Am has lost $158.3 million on sales of $2.66 billion, compared with losses of $21 million on sales of $2.73 billion in the first nine months of 1988. Pan Am's operating losses have been the largest and most consistent among American airlines.
While Pan Am needs help to prosper, it remains a viable business, Mr. Plaskett said. ''How much longer can we go on without a partner? Years,'' he said. But he added, ''My objective is to do something and do it soon.''
Although most industry experts say that recent sales and leasebacks of aircraft have given Pan Am enough cash to survive this winter, some are predicting that the airline may have to sell its shuttle, which flies between Boston, New York and Washington, to raise money for the following winter. The shuttle, which competes against the Trump Shuttle, has 50 to 60 percent of the market.
The financial thunderstorms now towering over Pan Am have cast a shadow on an airline that once symbolized America's dominance of international aviation. Pan Am was the world's first international airline, the first to offer scheduled service across the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans and the first to democratize international air travel after World War II with economy-class fares.
In the 1970's, Pan Am became an efficient air bridge between New York and Europe, ferrying up to 375 passengers in each Boeing 747. But it relied largely on other carriers to bring Americans to New York first.
Partial deregulation of international air travel in the late 1970's allowed more of Pan Am's competitors to fly across the Atlantic from more American cities. Many business travelers now fly directly to Europe from their hometowns, starving Pan Am of traffic through New York and leaving it with tourists who buy discounted tickets that generate scant profits.
 
A Troubled Domestic Operation
Even worse than the lack of passengers fed to the international flights is the huge cost and inefficiency of operating planes on a limited domestic network without a hub, Mr. Plaskett said. The typical narrow-body plane at Pan Am is operated only six hours a day between just two cities, while rivals with hubs can put a plane on a succession of routes that keep it busy for 9 or 10 hours a day, he said.
In 1987 and 1988, Pan Am had operating profits of $207 million on its Atlantic and Latin American routes but lost $395 million domestically.
Pan Am ticket sales continue to be affected by the Lockerbie disaster, Mr. Plaskett said. After the crash on Dec. 21, which killed 270 people, many large companies warned their executives not to fly on American carriers because of the risk of terrorist attacks. Lingering fears continue to hurt Pan Am's efforts to attract business customers, Mr. Plaskett said. Analysts agree. In September, nine months after the bombing, Pan Am flew 11 percent fewer first-class passengers and 9 percent fewer business-class passengers than in September 1988, a company spokesman said. Declines in previous months were even worse, he said. Economy-class travel fell 3 percent in September and 7.2 percent for the first nine months of this year , but overall bookings are up for this winter, he said.
By comparison, British Airways P.L.C. had a 5.5 percent increase in trans-Atlantic first-class traffic in September and a 17 percent gain in business class from a year ago, a spokesman said.
 
Lost Ticket Sales
In the first six months of this year, Mr. Plaskett said, the Lockerbie disaster caused Pan Am to lose at least $100 million in ticket sales from passengers who chose to fly another carrier or stay home. That total for the year, he added, is likely to be about $150 million.
In addition, Mr. Plaskett said, the increased security measures required of American carriers after the bombing have irritated business travelers, who dislike the delays involved. Many of them are flying on foreign carriers, which are not subject to the new requirements. This has cost Pan Am $50 million to $100 million in revenues this year, he said. On top of all that, Pan Am faces numerous lawsuits over the Lockerbie crash.
What Pan Am really needs is a partnership or merger with another airline, or a significant amount of fresh cash from outside the airline industry, Mr. Plaskett said. Pan Am has two big assets not reflected on its balance sheet: an internationally recognized name and the right to fly many flights into some of Europe's most heavily used airports, like Heathrow, outside London.
Pan Am is actively pursuing all possible ways to raise money or form alliances, Mr. Plaskett said, but he declined to elaborate on progress.
Two prospects crumbled last spring. Partnership talks with KLM broke up in mid-March when the Dutch carrier realized that it would not be able to exercise the strong influence over Pan Am that it sought, Mr. Plaskett said.
But Peter van Vliet, KLM's vice president and general manager of United States operations, said, ''With respect to Pan Am, KLM's analysis was based primarily on the fact that the financial risk was, in KLM's opinion, unacceptable.''
Pan Am then made an unsuccessful bid for Northwest Airlines, losing $28 million in fees in the process. An investor group that includes KLM bought NWA Inc., Northwest's parent, for $3.65 billion in August.
 
Government Actions
Mr. Plaskett's alternatives have since been sharply limited by two moves by the Department of Transportation, and could be further curtailed by legislation now in Congress. Samuel K. Skinner, the Secretary of Transportation, sent a letter on June 13 to the presidents of 28 commercial air carriers, expressing concern about the buying and selling of international routes, which are granted to airlines by the Government.
In 1985, Pan Am sold its Pacific routes to United Airlines for $900 million. During labor negotiations last year, Pan Am threatened to sell its Latin American routes. Mr. Plaskett said Pan Am currently had no plans to sell more routes.
Then in September the Transportation Department developed a new interpretation of Federal legislation prohibiting foreign companies and individuals from owning more than 25 percent of an American carrier. Mr. Skinner decided in a case involving Northwest Airlines that the law pertained not only to the percentage of voting stock owned by foreign companies but also to the percentage of equity, which includes nonvoting preferred stock.
The department's willingness to change an already completed deal affected the decision of British Airways to pull out of a buyout bid for the UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, said Lord King, the chairman of British Airways.
British Airways' decision on UAL was the ''death knell'' for Pan Am because no other foreign carrier is likely to be as adventurous in pursuing American carriers as KLM and British Airways have been, said a European airline executive who asked not to be identified.
But Mr. Plaskett said the Transportation Department's action had not diminished foreign carriers' interest in buying into American airlines.
 
A Possible Exception
The Government may be willing to make an exception for Pan Am because if the airline goes bankrupt, the Government would face difficult negotiations with foreign governments over Pan Am's international routes, said L. John Eichner, an airline economist and consultant. A Department of Transportation spokesman declined to comment.
Another potential hindrance to Pan Am's plans is legislation before Congress that would require the Transportation Department to disapprove any acquisition of more than 15 percent of a United States carrier if it would reduce the carrier's ability to compete, to operate safely or to stay in business without asset sales, or if the deal would eliminate jobs or cut wages. Mr. Skinner has said he will recommend that President Bush veto the legislation if Congress passes it.
