HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Heavy U.S. Debt Sales Awaited

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Dealers in the credit markets are scrambling to cope with a rapid-fire succession of Treasury auctions.
When they conclude on Tuesday, $56 billion in securities will have been brought to market.
The Treasury, which would have run out of cash today had Congress not raised the nation's debt limit on Tuesday night, yesterday auctioned $16 billion worth of three- and six-month bills that had been delayed since Monday. Today, the Treasury will hold the first of its quarterly refunding auctions, a $10 billion offering of three-year notes.
Meanwhile, the Federal Reserve Board, which surprised market participants on Tuesday when it appeared to sanction a drop in the overnight Federal funds rate to 8.50 percent from 8.75 percent, did nothing to change that view yesterday. Indeed, movements in the funds rate yesterday prompted some speculation that the Fed may have eased policy even further. 
 
No Open-Market Operations
The Fed chose not to conduct open-market operations yesterday when the funds rate was trading at 8.50 percent. The funds rate softened further later in the day, trading as low as 8 5/ 16 percent before rising to a late offered rate of 8 3/8 percent.
Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were unchanged to slightly higher in moderately active trading.
A number of analysts said technical factors associated with the end of a two-week reporting period for banks had much to do with the erratic movement in the funds rate yesterday. The Fed, which has been engaged in a policy of lowering the funds rate in increments of 25 basis points, or hundredths of a point, since late spring, has not changed its tactics, they said.
But others said they were not so sure. After looking at movements in the funds rate yesterday, Maria Fiorini Ramirez, a managing director at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., said, ''At this point, we are comfortable in saying that the new trading range for Fed funds is at least 8 3/8 percent to 8 1/2 percent, and it may be even lower.''
 
Debt Limit Raised Tuesday
Congress voted on Tuesday to raise the nation's debt limit to $3.12 trillion, through Sept. 30.
The Treasury's refinancing auctions will continue on Friday with the sale of $10 billion worth of 36-day cash management bills and will wind up early next week, when $10 billion of 10-year notes and $10 billion of 30-year bonds will be sold on Monday and Tuesday, respectively.
At the bill auction, the three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 7.67 percent, down from the average rate of 7.78 percent at the auction on Oct. 30.
The six-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 7.49 percent, down from last week's average rate of 7.62 percent.
In when-issued trading, the three-year notes to be sold today were offered at a price to yield 7.77 percent. The 10-year notes were offered on a when-issued basis late yesterday at a price to yield 7.82 percent. And the 30-year bonds to be sold on Tuesday were offered at a price to yield 7.88 percent.
The Treasury will sell the new bonds by reopening the current outstanding 8 1/8 percent issue of 2019.
Among secondary Treasury issues, the 8 1/8 percent bond was offered in late trading at a price of 102 29/32, mostly unchanged on the day, to yield 7.87 percent.
Much of the day's activity was in intermediate- to short-term notes, where prices inched higher. 5-Year Notes at 7.77% By late in the day, the 8 1/4 percent five-year notes were offered at 101 7/8, up 6/32, to yield 7.77 percent. And the 7 5/8 percent two-year notes rose by 3/ 32, to a late offered price of 99 3/4, to yield 7.76 percent.
Because of the shortened when-issued trading period, some traders said that to drum up demand in the Treasury auctions interest rates may have to move higher.
''Unless strong demand shows up, I would be shocked if there is not one significant up-tick in this whole series of auctions,'' said James R. Capra, a senior vice president at Shearson Lehman Government Securities. ''The most logical candidate looks like the 30-year bond. It is a reopened issue that is trading above par, or $100. But that auction is also the most difficult to predict because the make-or-break demand for it comes from outside the country.''
 
Heavy Municipal Calendar
In other developments, participants in the tax-exempt municipal bond market faced a heavy new-issue calendar yesterday as five deals were priced at competitive bid.
Among the issues offered was a $225 million sale of general obligation bonds from New York State. A bid from a syndicate led by Marine Midland Capital Markets won the issue, which consists of serial bonds with maturities from 1990 to 2019.
The bonds were reoffered with coupons ranging from 5.90 percent on the securities maturing in 1990 to 7.20 percent on the bonds maturing in 2019.
Investment bankers close to the deal said that demand for the securities was strong. The issue is rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service and AA- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
In the corporate bond market, the Pennzoil Company priced $400 million worth of notes and debentures in a two-part offering through an underwriting syndicate led by Shearson Lehman Hutton.
The $200 million worth of 9 5/8 percent 10-year notes were priced at 99.65 to yield 9.68 percent, 1.80 percentage points higher than the prevailing yield on the 8 percent 10-year Treasury notes at the time of pricing. The notes mature Nov. 15, 1999. The $200 million worth of 10 1/8 percent 20-year debentures were priced at 99.11, to yield 10.23 percent, 2.35 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 1/8 percent 30-year bond at the time of pricing. The debentures have a final maturity date of Nov. 15, 2009.
The issue is rated A-2 by Moody's and A- by S.&P.

HEADLINE: Talking Deals;
Japanese Move Into Stock Swaps

BYLINE: By Phillip H. Wiggins

 BODY:
STOCK swaps, a technique commonly used for financing acquisitions in the United States, may become more prevalent among Japanese companies as a result of the recent deal by the Kyoto-based Kyocera Corporation to acquire the AVX Corporation, the Great Neck, L.I., manufacturer of electronic capacitors, through an exchange of stock.
The acquisition was not easy. It took considerable legal agility to leap the hurdles presented by Japan's stringent commercial code that many had viewed as prohibiting such transactions.
But stock swaps are attractive to Americans because, unlike cash deals, they can be tax-free. Also, the deal allayed growing concerns about Japan's large purchases of American assets. Consequently, some Wall Street analysts speculate that this $561 million deal could start a new trend in American-Japanese mergers and acquisitions. 
Recently, Kyocera, a maker of ceramic packages for semiconductors, said AVX stockholders would receive a partial American depository share in exchange for each of their AVX shares. A.D.S.'s are virtually the same as American depository receipts, although actual shares, not receipts, are issued. AVX holders will receive a minimum of 39-hundredths of a Kyocera A.D.S. for each AVX share. The exact exchange ratio will be determined by a formula involving the average trading price of Kyocera's A.D.S.'s over a still to be specified three-week period.
The Kyocera-AVX transaction marks the first time a Japanese public company has merged with an American concern through a stock swap. Last week, the acquisition received American regulatory clearance on antitrust and national security grounds. If the agreement is approved in Japan, it could well provide a new model for similar deals in the future.
''As the outcry over the Sony deal for Columbia Pictures demonstrates, cash purchases of U.S. companies by the Japanese do not sit well with Americans,'' said Jack Barbanel, portfolio strategist with First Global Asset Management, a money-management firm based in Princeton, N.J. ''The Kyocera stock-swap arrangement might mitigate this problem.''
In the Kyocera case, Americans owning AVX stock will become shareholders of the Japanese company, creating what the managements of both companies refer to as a partnership.
''You have to look at the broader ramifications of this transaction for it potentially represents a major breakthrough in bilateral relations between the U.S. and Japan and could help diffuse the political obstacles confronting Japanese companies seeking to gain entree to the U.S. market,'' Mr. Barbanel said.
Some suggest that, if successful, the Kyocera-AVX deal might also pave the way for American companies to acquire Japanese concerns. ''At least theoretically, an American company could simply pattern a transaction after the Kyocera deal and use it to initiate a purchase,'' Mr. Barbanel said. ''As a practical matter, however, the higher multiples enjoyed by Japanese public companies would seem to cast doubt on the economics of such a transaction.'' In any event, the intricate structure of the Kyocera-AVX stock swap underscores the imposing legal and cultural obstacles that had to be overcome. The Japanese commercial code prohibits wholly owned subsidiaries from owning stock in the parent, thus seemingly preventing any acquisition involving an exchange of stock.
To bypass this legal roadblock, Kyocera effected a rarely used acquisition technique termed a ''forward triangle merger.'' In the Kyocera case, a company named the K C Subsidiary Corporation will be formed and incorporated in Delaware. The ownership of K C Subsidiary includes a 5 percent position by the Kyocera Finance Corporation, a Japanese computer-equipment leasing company that is 40 percent owned by Kyocera and 60 percent held by a consortium of 12 Japanese banks. The other 95 percent interest is held directly by the Kyocera Corporation.
''Since K C Subsidiary is not wholly owned by the Kyocera Corporation, we capitalized the partially owned entity, which will use the funds to buy the new American depository shares to be exchanged for AVX stock once the transaction receives shareholder and appropriate government approvals,'' said Rodney N. Lanthorne, president of Kyocera International Inc., the wholly owned American subsidiary of the Kyocera Corporation, and a director of the Japanese parent company.
Such a transaction is called a forward triangular merger, he said, because AVX will be absorbed by K C Subsidiary, which will then change its name to the AVX Corporation. ''From an operating standpoint, nothing has changed, but we believe the mechanism satisfies the Japanese restrictions on stock swaps and will enable AVX shareholders to realize a tax-free exchange,'' he said.
After the transaction is completed, AVX will become a subsidiary of Kyocera International, which is based in San Diego.
Despite its complexity, the Kyocera triangular merger is being done without the assistance of investment bankers. Kyocera retained the Los Angeles law firm of Spensley Horn Jubas & Lubitz and the Japanese firm of Tomotsune, Kumura & Mitumi to develop and carry out the strategy for structuring the transaction.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Asset Allocation's Effect on Volatility

BYLINE: By Anise C. Wallace

 BODY:
JOHN J. PHELAN Jr., chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, suggests that a form of computer-assisted program trading used by some large pension funds has the potential to become as destabilizing to the market as ''portfolio insurance,'' or using stock index futures to hedge a position in the stock market.
After the stock market crash in 1987, the Brady Commission cited portfolio insurance for its role in exacerbating the market's decline and volatility.
Money managers engaged in the version of program trading known as tactical asset allocation, which involves using computer models to signal when to shift assets among stocks, bonds and cash equivalents like Treasury bills, concede their trades may be disruptive. But they disagree with Mr. Phelan that the technique is as potentially destructive as portfolio insurance. 
In fact, they charge that Mr. Phelan's attempt to limit program trading in falling markets - last week the Big Board asked Wall Street brokers and institutional investors to refrain voluntarily from program trading - is a misguided violation of ''free markets'' and is an unrealistic effort to legislate away bear markets.
''I'd like to legislate away John Phelan,'' said Michael A. Petrino, president of Matrix Capital Management, a Greenwich, Conn., firm that invests almost $800 million for its clients and uses tactical asset allocation for some of them.
Mr. Phelan's concern about tactical asset allocation stems in part from the size of pension assets involved. Some of the two dozen or so firms that use this technique for an estimated $40 billion of assets buy or sell stock index futures as well as stocks when they move their clients' assets into and out of the markets.
The asset allocation models signal asset switches in anticipation of changes in corporate earnings, short-term interest rates and other economic factors. The managers using these models have different interpretations and forecasts, and so far this year, they have not moved in lockstep.
Money managers who used portfolio insurance, on the other hand, bought or sold stocks or stock index futures solely in reaction to stock price changes. Almost all of their models reacted to the same data in the same way, and thus when they began selling, a market decline could turn into a rout.
Nevertheless, the size of stock transactions unleashed by firms using tactical asset allocation has the potential to disrupt the market on a short-term basis. ''We have to allow for the possibility that there will be disruptive implementation of these strategies,'' Mr. Petrino said. Wall Street brokers have found trading big blocks for the asset allocation firms highly profitable. They can ''position'' large blocks of stocks, hedge their risks in the futures markets and charge more than the 5 cents a share ordinarily paid by large investors. On Oct, 17, for instance, a large buy program by Paine Webber Inc. executed for at least one firm using tactical asset allocation helped move the Dow Jones industrial average up more than 80 points, traders said.
Paine Webber has declined to comment on that transaction. But according to market sources, the firm agreed to execute the buy program as long as the money manager was willing to agree in advance that he would buy the stocks at the mean price for the day, instead of at the broker's actual purchase price or the closing price.
In such an arrangement, the broker takes as profit any difference between what the firm originally pays for the securities and the mean prices over the entire day. If prices fall, there might be less profit on the stock portion of the trade, but the broker would earn an additional return from his hedged position in the futures market.
Such arrangements have become common in recent years. Some brokers can accommodate these customers by hedging in futures, and managers using these computer-driven strategies are willing to pay slightly higher commissions to move large parts of their pension clients' portfolios.
But Mr. Phelan remains disturbed by the power of those using this strategy. In the past, he said, ''the good news is that they were buyers.'' But, he noted, their models could change. ''Then we have to ask, 'What happens if their signal is not buy but sell?' '' he said. ''That will create more problems than index arbitrage.''
Money managers at firms using this strategy concede that if the fundamental characteristics of the economy - interest rates and corporate earnings - begin to weaken, the managers would begin shifting their clients' assets out of stocks. And any simultaneous sell programs would send the stock and stock index futures markets into disarray.
''Any bear market is characterized by a consensus that fundamentals are deteriorating,'' Mr. Petrino said. ''And if the fundamentals are deteriorating, why shouldn't you sell?''

CORRECTION-DATE: November 10, 1989, Friday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
The Market Place column in Business Day yesterday misstated the day on which Paine Webber Inc. used computerized trading programs to buy a large amount of stock. It was Oct. 24.

HEADLINE: Stocks Up on Signs That Fed Eased Policy

BYLINE: By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

 BODY:
Stock prices rose broadly yesterday, on signs that the Federal Reserve had eased its monetary policy.
The Federal funds rate - the rate the central bank most closely controls - fell to 8 3/8 percent yesterday, a 12-month low.
The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 26.23 points, or exactly 1 percent, to 2,623.36.
Advances on the New York Stock Exchange exceeded declines by about 5 to 2, with 1,091 issues up in price and 418 lower. 
Federal funds are considered the basic cost of credit because that is the rate that banks charge each other for overnight loans. On Tuesday, the Federal Reserve Board added reserves to the banking system and thus lowered the Federal funds rate, which was widely interpreted as an indirect effort by the Fed to ease monetary policy.
The Southwestern Bank of St. Louis, yesterday lowered its prime lending rate to 10 percent from 10 1/2 percent.
 
Big Board Volume Expands
Volume on the Big Board expanded to 170.2 million shares, from 163 million on Tuesday.
In the broader market, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 3.34 points, to 338.15, while the New York Stock Exchange composite index added 1.74 points, to 187.48.
''Although market breadth was fairly good, the real strength was concentrated among interest-sensitive, defensive issues such as money center banks, insurers, soft drink and drug stocks,'' said Edward P. Nicoski, market strategist at Piper, Jaffray & Hopwood in Mineapolis.
J.P. Morgan, rose 1 7/8, to 43 1/2; American International Group 1 3/4, to 107 1/8; Schering-Plough 2 3/4, to 78 1/2, and Coca-Cola 2 1/4, to 74 1/2.
''Many economic-sensitive issues, however, failed to respond such as the steels, chemicals, papers and large capitalized technology stocks,'' he said.
Bethlehem Steel dropped 1/8, to 15 1/2; Dow Chemical 1/2, to 92 7/8; Weyerhaeuser 1/4, to 26 1/4, and Digital Equipment 1 1/2, to 87.
 
Yesterday's Movement in Dow
Yesterday's Dow gain, combined with the 14.96-point rise on Tuesday, recaptured almost all of the average's 47.34 loss on Monday. The Dow was up about 16 points after the first hour of trading, 24 points about 11 A.M.; nearly 29 points at noon; about 36 points at 12:30 P.M., where it hovered for the next two hours, before sliding to the close.
UAL jumped 5 1/4, to 185, after a report in The Wall Street Journal that the company's chairman, Stephen Wolf, has been cleared to explore possible transactions, like a buyout or recapitalization, for the carrier, traders said. Arbitragers said this indicated that the parent of United Airlines was headed for some kind of deal.
The jump in the price of UAL helped lift the Dow transportation index to a 10.85-point gain and a close of 1,199.15. Other airlines were narrowly mixed, with AMR, the parent of American Airlines rising 3/4, to 72; Delta Air Lines up 5/8, to 65; USAir unchanged at 35 1/4, and Pan Am off 1/8, to 3 1/8.
Wyse Technology was the most active Big Board issue, slipping 1/8, to 9 3/8, on a volume of more than 3.6 million shares. The company said it was in discussions with an undisclosed third party regarding the potential acquisition of the company at $10 a share.
Woolworth slipped 1 1/8, to 58 1/4. The company reported that its third-quarter operating profits rose 12 percent over the 1988 three months but that operating profits for general merchandise did not change from the $53 million a year earlier.
Warner Communications rose 1 point, to 63 1/8. The Tonka Corporation said it had agreed to acquire toy and game license rights for Batman products from Warner Brothers Inc., a subsidiary of Warner.

HEADLINE: St. Louis Bank Sets 10% Prime

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The Southwest Bank of St. Louis, often a bellwether on interest rate trends, said yesterday that it would lower its prime lending rate to 10 percent from 10 1/2 percent, effective Thursday. The move followed signs that the Federal Reserve is pushing down short-term interest rates. 
The prime rate, once a key corporate lending rate, is more commonly used now as a peg for consumer loan rates.
Southwest's cut was duplicated late in the day by the First Federal Savings Bank of Boston.
If the prime rate cut is followed by other major banks, it would be the first reduction in the rate since July, when banks lowered it to 10 1/2 percent from 11 percent previously. That move was led by the Chase Manhattan Corporation, which lowered its prime on July 10.
Other banks followed suit at the end of the month.
No leading banks immediately followed Southwest's lead yesterday. Spokesmen for Citibank, Chase Manhattan and Morgan Guaranty, all of New York, and the San Francisco-based BankAmerica said they had no immediate announcements on their prime rates.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Moves Up Modestly While Gold Also Advances

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose modestly against most currencies yesterday, showing resilience despite widespread expectations that interest rates will fall.
Gold prices also rose. In New York, the Republic National Bank quoted a bid for gold at 4 P.M. of $387.50 an ounce, up from $384.75 late Tuesday. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold contracts for current delivery closed at $388.80 an ounce, up from $386.20 on Tuesday. 
Currency traders said the dollar showed fundamental strength despite a perception in the market that the Federal Reserve is relaxing its credit policy, which is likely to encourage lower interest rates. Falling interest rates usually depress the dollar's value.
 
Fed Injection of Funds
That perception was fueled by the Fed's action in the bond market on Monday and Tuesday, when it unexpectedly injected several billion dollars of reserves.
''The dollar is basically absorbing the lower interest-rate scenario rather well,'' said Robert Hatcher, a vice president of corporate trading at the New York office of Barclays Bank P.L.C. ''It's hanging in there.''
He said traders were looking toward a report on wholesale price inflation in October, due out today, for further signs of an economic slowdown. Such indications could spur the Fed to ease credit further.
In Tokyo, where trading ends before the business day begins in Europe, the dollar fell to a close of 142.97 Japanese yen, from 143.63 yen at Tuesday's close. Later, in London, the dollar declined further, to 142.73 yen. But in trading in New York, the dollar recovered and finished at 143.18 yen, up from 142.95 yen late Tuesday.
 
British Pound Rises
The British pound rose in London to $1.5860, from $1.5810 late Tuesday. Later, in New York, the pound fetched $1.5885, up from $1.5865 the day before.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday, included: 1.8445 West German marks, up from 1.8430; 1.6168 Swiss francs, up from 1.6165; 6.2515 French francs, up from 6.2470; 1,347.25 Italian lire, down from 1,348.00, and 1.1698 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1712.
Gold bullion rose in London to a late bid of $384.75 an ounce, up from $384.50 late Tuesday. In Zurich, gold was unchanged from Tuesday, closing at a bid of $384.00.
Silver bullion slipped in London to a late bid price of $5.25 an ounce, from $5.26 on Tuesday. On the Comex, silver contracts for current delivery closed at $5.295 an ounce, up from $5.265.

HEADLINE: AQUINO SEEKS AID FROM U.S. BUSINESS

BYLINE: By RICHARD HALLORAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9

 BODY:
President Corazon C. Aquino of the Philippines met with President Bush, senior Administration officials and Congressional leaders today as she sought to encourage American investment in and American imports from her island nation.
During a welcoming ceremony at the White House, President Bush took note of Mrs. Aquino's objective. ''You deserve our help, and you will get it,'' Mr. Bush said. ''And I pledge our continuing assistance to your Government, and that means security assistance as well as aid to economic development.'' 
Mrs. Aquino focused on economic issues, ''particularly the means by which the Philippines and the United States can cooperate in more areas to our mutual economic benefit.'' She did not mention the future of American military bases in the Philippines, which has become an increasingly contentious issue.
 
No Public Stand on Bases
Filipino nationalists have demanded that the United States evacuate the bases or grant greater Philippine sovereignty over them. So far, Mrs. Aquino has declined to take a public stand on the issue.
Negotiations over the emotional issue are to begin next month. The Subic Bay Naval Station and Clark Air Base are the principal United States military installations in Southeast Asia and among the largest outside the United States. They are important links to American deployments to the Indian Ocean and Persian Gulf.
When Mrs. Aquino was last here three years ago, she received an enthusiatic welcome after taking over from Ferdinand E. Marcos. Since then, her Government is generally considered to have made progress in restoring democracy and some advances in fighting a leftist insurgency, but it has been less successful in developing the economy and in improving basic services to the poor, who constitute the majority of the population.
American officials and others asserted that the situation in the Philippines is still fragile.
 
Doubts About Her Leadership
''Questions have been raised about the President's leadership and vision, about the effectiveness and honesty of her government, and about the depth of its commitment to human rights and socio-economic reform,'' said David G. Timberman, a New York specialist on the Philippines, in a report this week.
In their talks at the White House, Mrs. Aquino pressed President Bush for greater Philippine access to the American market, help in debt relief and added investment, said Richard Solomon, Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian Affairs.
In addition to Mr. Bush, the Philippine President met with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Secretary of the Treasury Nicholas Brady.
Mrs. Aquino is scheduled to meet with Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney on Friday to discuss the bases. She is also scheduled to have breakfast with Vice President Dan Quayle.
While Mrs. Aquino was meeting with Mr. Bush, her Finance Minister, Vicente R. Jayme, signed three loan agreements at the World Bank that will provide the Philippines with $175 million for projects in health, water supply and industrial investment.
President Aquino plans to leave Washington on Friday afternoon for Dallas, where her hosts will be executives of the J. C. Penney company, which has been an importer of goods from the Philippines. On Sunday, she will be in Los Angeles before flying back to Manila.
 
Ahead, but Still Behind
Since Mrs. Aquino has been in office, foreign investment has risen to $936 million in 1988 from $127 million in 1986, according to the International Monetary Fund. Mr. Timberman calculated that American direct investment followed the same trend, rising to $157 million last year.
But he pointed out that foreign investment in Thailand and Indonesia, two of the Philippine's neighbors, ran to $6.2 billion and $4.4 billion last year, suggesting that there was vast room for growth in the Philippines.
Americans remain the largest investors in the Philippines, with about $1.3 billion invested there. But money being invested in the Philippines from Hong Kong, which is due to be taken over by China in 1997, and from Taiwan and Japan has risen faster than that from the United States in recent years.

LENGTH: 904 words

HEADLINE: Tokyo Journal;
From the U.S. Envoy, Salvos of 'Friendly Advice'

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 9

 BODY:
Japan and the United States may be engaged in economic warfare, but why do Japanese newspapers always use battlefield imagery to describe their relationship? At least that was what Ambassador Michael H. Armacost wanted to know recently at the Japan National Press Club.
''Choice of language is worth attention,'' Mr. Armacost told the Japanese reporters, mentioning the use of the words ''war,'' ''attack'' and ''counterattack'' in several recent economic articles. ''I urge you to search for some new metaphors.''
Six months after arriving in Tokyo, Mr. Armacost is giving out a lot of what he terms ''friendly advice'' these days, something almost unheard of for the diplomat holding one of America's most delicate and difficult ambassadorial posts. 
Indeed, for more than a decade, Mr. Armacost's predecessor, Mike Mansfield, was well known for making few pronouncements that aroused controversy, instead repeating that Japan and the United States had to nurture ''the most important bilateral relationship in the world, bar none.''
 
Highly Regarded by Japanese
Mr. Mansfield, a former Senate majority leader, is regarded as something of a saint here, and as a man of extraordinary stature and wisdom. The other evening, Japan's national broadcasting company ran a one-hour television special devoted to his life and reflections upon retirement.
At the same time, he and other officials at the American Embassy drew sharp criticism in recent years from those in Congress who assert that the United States has not pushed Japan hard enough to open up trade and investment barriers.
Mr. Armacost, a former Deputy Secretary of State for Political Affairs, initially disarmed many critics in Congress when he said that as Ambassador he would fight for access for American products to Japanese markets and view himself as the embassy's senior commercial officer.
Lately, he has said the $50 billion American trade deficit with Japan is ''untenable'' and he has gently but firmly suggested that Japan act to quell American anxieties about its investments in the United States.
''There should be no question, the welcome mat is still out,'' said Mr. Armacost, whose career has been in the Foreign Service. But he added that after the recent purchase of Columbia Pictures by Sony and other deals, American concerns ''are sufficiently widespread that they cannot be ignored.''
 
'People Are Pleased'
In the process, Mr. Armacost has won praise from many quarters previously critical of the American Embassy. By common agreement, he appears to symbolize the evolving notion that economic issues dividing Tokyo and Washington can no longer be subordinated to the need to maintain friendly political ties.
''The signals we're getting are that people are pleased with Armacost,'' said William T. Archey, vice president for international affairs at the United States Chamber of Commerce. ''The atmosphere is different, and he is not afraid to say some candid things that haven't been said before.''
The idea that economic issues are now more important than political or security issues is not widely accepted in Japan. But at the Japanese Foreign Ministry, officials say they are happy that Mr. Armacost is speaking forthrightly so that Japanese can understand American thinking.
In an interview, Mr. Armacost said he had no intention of establishing a different style from that of Mr. Mansfield, but he ackowledged that the mood in the United States on trade issues was different now. ''Our trade deficit with Japan has persisted, and American patience has worn a little thin,'' he said. ''I have simply tried to make that point and to inject a sense of urgency into the situation.''
Perhaps more intriguing, Mr. Armacost has not hesitated to wade into the serious philosophical debates raging among Japan specialists abroad, such as the contention of some critics that Japan is culturally unique and somehow incapable of welcoming imports or foreign investment.
In a recent speech, Mr. Armacost said he recognized that many Japanese found such a point of view offensive, but he then noted that Japan itself raises its own ''claims to uniqueness'' to buttress its demand for protection from imports of rice and other materials.
 
On the Local Scene
The Ambassador has also stirred some controversy by throwing himself into the Japanese political scene. He received a great deal of publicity when he met with the chairwoman of the Japan Socialist Party, Takako Doi, provoking complaints from businessmen that he seemed to be endorsing her leftist views.
Later, the businessmen said they were pleased when Mr. Armacost gave interviews to the Japanese press saying Miss Doi and the Socialists had failed to quell doubts about their longstanding positions, like those calling for renunciation of the security treaty with the United States.
On the subject of investment, he asserted that it was not ''racist'' for Americans to be concerned about Japanese foreign investment, as some Japanese charge. Mr. Armacost said that Japanese investment was large and growing more rapidly than anyone else's and that Americans are understandably worried.
He has told Japan to employ more Americans as managers in their American companies, take part more in local communities, employ more women and minorities and - most important - ''provide equal investment opportunities for U.S. firms wishing to invest in Japan.''

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: November 10, 1989

SECTION: Section A; Page 16, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1298 words

HEADLINE: Clamor in the East;
U.S. Worry Rises Over Europe's Stability

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9

 BODY:
President Bush hailed East Germany's opening of its borders today as a ''good development,'' but privately his Administration is growing concerned that the postwar European order is coming apart before any new stable structure has been established.
Speaking at an impromptu news conference at the White House after being briefed on the day's developments, Mr. Bush said, ''Of course I welcome the decision by the East German leadership to open the borders to those wishing to emigrate or travel.''
''If it's implemented fully,'' he said, ''it certainly conforms with the Helsinki Accords, which the G.D.R. signed. And if the G.D.R. goes forward now this wall, built in '61, will have very little relevance. It clearly is a good development in terms of human rights.'' 
 
Political System Is Key
The upbeat tone of the President's remarks was in contrast to the deeper concerns in the Administration over the uncertainty of what may happen next in East Germany, in relations between the two Germanys and in Europe as a whole. The entire structure of the postwar European order, which maintained stability for the last 40 years, has been based on a divided Germany.
The key questions now, Administration officials said, is what kind of political system develops in East Germany and whether the country will remain independent or somehow merge eventually with West Germany. East Germans who leave for the West will determine their own future, but those who stay may well determine the future of Europe by the type of state they and their leaders form.
In his public remarks the President seemed to mask any concerns about the rapidity of change in Europe, but those concerns nevertheless came through in his careful answers. When asked whether he saw a danger of events in Central Europe spinning out of control, Mr. Bush said:
''Well, I wouldn't want to say this kind of development makes things move too quickly at all. I'm not going to hypothecate that it may. But we are handling it in a way not to give anybody a hard time. We're saluting those who can move forward with democracy. We are encouraging the concept of a Europe whole and free. And so we just welcome it.''
 
'I'm Very Pleased'
When reporters observed that the President in his initial answers seemed less than elated by the day's events, he responded in a more enthusiastic manner.
''I'm elated,'' he said. ''I'm just not an emotional kind of guy. Oh, I'm very pleased, and I've been very pleased with a lot of other developments.
''I think the United States' part of this, which is not related to this development today particularly, is being handled in a proper fashion, and we'll have some that'll suggest more flamboyant courses of action for this country. We're handling this properly with the allies, staying in close touch trying to enhance reform, both political and economic. The fact that I'm not bubbling over, maybe it's - maybe it's getting along toward evening because I feel very good about it.''
On Capitol Hill, the Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell, Democrat of Maine, struck a more unequivocally enthusiastic note, saying, ''This is an historic event.''
''It can be made even more so,'' he added, ''if the East German Government now acts to tear the wall down. I urge them to do so. Only then will we know that their proposal of today has lasting substance and meaning.''
 
Remarks Are Recalled
The chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Claiborne Pell, Democrat of Rhode Island, also declared ''East Germany should now tear down the Berlin wall'' and ''emulate Poland and Hungary by announcing democratic elections so that the East German people can build a secure future without having to leave their homes.''
In his own way, the President also seemed to encourage East Germans to stay at home and work for reform in their own country instead of flooding to West Germany.
''You may remember that before I went to Poland I was asked by a Polish journalist, if I were a young Pole what would my advice be,'' the President recalled. ''And what I said is I think you ought to stay there and participate in this dramatic change in your country. You ought to feel the surge of freedom, feel the move toward democracy, and be a part of it.
''And these are Germans, and Germans love their country, and at some point I think a lot of Germans who have felt pent in and unable to move are going to say, 'Look, we can move but wouldn't it be better to participate in the reforms that are taking place in our own country?' So I think it's too early to predict that because of this opening that means everybody is going to take off.''
At the Pentagon, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said in a statement that the odds of using military forces from East Germany against the West appeared to be ''significantly lower now than at any time in the postwar period.''
 
'A Revolutionary Situation'
As events in East Germany take unexpected new turns each day, Bush Administration officials say they are discovering that while they have a great deal at stake in the final outcome they are virtually powerless to influence it.
As a result, American policy today consists largely of hoping for stable change, urging all sides to exercise restraint and quietly praying that if there is to be a reassociation of East and West Germany there will be enough time to work out arrangments satisfactory to all the parties in Europe.
''I admit that when all is said and done it is a policy largely of stated desires and rhetoric,'' said a senior Bush Administration policy maker. ''But what would you have us do? What we are dealing with in Eastern Europe, and to a lesser extent in the Soviet Union, is a revolutionary situation. Revolutionary situations have a dynamic of their own.''
Under such conditions, the official added, ''we can watch, applaud, hope and work together as closely as possible with the West Germans.''
''They know how best to deal with their own countrymen,'' he said. ''They can influence events inside East Germany, to the extent that anyone can, through their aid programs and their political parties, but even the West Germans have little influence.''
As events unfold in East Germany, Administration officials feel powerless not only to direct those events in any way but also to discuss any alternative security system for Europe if the postwar order based on a divided Germany becomes obsolete.
 
'Fulfillment of Our Dreams'
''The reason we seem to be so helpless is because what East Germans are demanding is the fulfillment of our dreams, the exercise of our values, and that is something that is inconceivable for us to oppose,'' said Michael Mandelbaum, an expert on East-West relations at the Council on Foreign Relations.
''Yet we are dealing with a country, Germany, which if it becomes united and independent transforms the entire strategic landscape in Europe. The Germanys we had fit into an order which despite its injustices and maybe even because of them gave us peace for 40 years. We don't know if a new arrangement for Germany can fit into a stable order.''
Summing up the Administration's quandary, Herbert S. Okun, a former United States Ambassador to East Berlin, remarked: ''We want the East Germans to be free and we want their freedom to come about smoothly and gradually. But as Lenin said, the path to revolution is not smooth or broad, and neither is the path to freedom. It is bumpy and full of turns.
''That simply underscores the fact that we urgently need to replace the present structure that has kept Europe stable with an alternative. We want the East Europeans to be free. The Russians are ready to let it happen slowly, provided their security is not damaged. But we need an understanding soon.''

LENGTH: 744 words

HEADLINE: Philadelphia Journal;
Hard Fight To Teach 7th Grade Is Over

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9

 BODY:
Thomas K. Gilhool holds degrees in philosophy, political science and law from Yale. He was a Fulbright Scholar in town planning at the London School of Economics and Political Science. For the last two years, he was the Pennsylvania Secretary of Education.
Mr. Gilhool thinks he is qualified to teach seventh-grade history. But the Superintendent of Schools here was not so sure, and it took a two-week investigation by the Board of Education to set aside the Superintendent's concerns. On Wednesday night the board hired Mr. Gilhool, ending a two-month bureaucratic imbroglio. 
The board's inquiry centered on School Superintendent Constance E. Clayton's concern that her aides may have given Mr. Gilhool's application favorable treatment - in particular, that they had him take a teacher certification test alone in a room away from other applicants.
Mr. Gilhool, who says he had to resign his post as State Education Secretary in June because of ''firestorms'' caused by his efforts to make school boards more accountable and teachers more autonomous, is no neophyte when it comes to the politics of education. But even he was surprised by the obstacles he encountered. ''I am amazed that I had to fight to teach,'' he said.
The 51-year-old Mr. Gilhool, who became a public interest lawyer in the 1960's to enlist in the cause of civil rights, switched to a career in education two years ago in the belief that the best way to achieve racial equality is to improve public education.
He says he decided to leave educational administration for teaching because ''teaching is the most exciting and urgently important profession of our time.'' He will take a drastic cut in pay: from the $55,000 a year he made as a lawyer to the $25,000 that starting teachers earn.
On Wednesday, the school board said there had been ''no breaches of integrity'' on the part of school district staff members who processed Mr. Gilhool's application and administered oral and written tests.
Mr. Gilhool became aware of the obstacles ahead of him on Sept. 27, when school officials pulled him out of a line of newly hired teachers who were selecting schools where they would teach.
''I was given a letter saying that my appointment was put on hold,'' Mr. Gilhool said. ''That was a month and 10 days after I had taken the test, three weeks after I had received an employment letter and 15 minutes before I was to pick a school where I was to start teaching the following Monday.''
The Superintendent was concerned that in August Mr. Gilhool had taken the teacher application test alone in a room apart from 56 other applicants. Mr. Gilhool said he had protested mildly at the time, but the officials insisted on it, saying the presence of a former Education Secretary might distract the other applicants.
He scored third among those taking the test that day. (''I wrote a magnificent essay on teaching; it must have been the orals that knocked me down to third place,'' he said.) No charges were brought against Mr. Gilhool, but the teachers' union filed a grievance on his behalf, saying his career was being delayed unfairly while school officials sorted out their administrative procedures.
The issue appeared to be nearing resolution late last month when the Superintendent's office made an unusual announcement that unspecified disciplinary actions would be brought against six of her aides, who were not identified, on the ground that they had committed ''improprieties'' in connection with Mr. Gilhool's application.
That announcement prompted the school board to begin its own inquiry on Oct. 23 and stop the disciplinary actions. Herman Mattleman, the board president, said the purpose of the inquiry was to ''make sure that the testing, hiring and placement of teachers is consistently applied.''
Two days later, The Philadelphia Inquirer published an editiorial characterizing the Gilhool affair as ''absurd and embarrassing.'' The editorial noted that the school system had no shortage of problems, including poor student achievement scores, deteriorating buildings and a looming deficit, and added, ''But the one that you wouldn't expect to find is the one that is currently preoccupying the School Superintendent and the Board of Education: undue favoritism shown to a V.I.P. who, bless his heart, wants to teach in an inner-city elementary school.''
Meanwhile, the eager teacher-to-be has been passing the time by writing a textbook on education law.

HEADLINE: House Backs $305 Billion Military Bill

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9

 BODY:
The House approved a $305 billion military programs bill today, but many members complained that Congress had failed to make tough decisions on cutting politically popular weapons programs.
They warned that the legislation would make it even harder to cut the budget next year.
The military programs bill, which calls for cutting money for the ''Star Wars'' missile defense program for the first time, was worked out last week by Congressional negotiators.
The House passed the bill by a vote of 236 to 172. The Senate has not yet taken up the conference legislation but is expected to approve it. 
 
Political Expediency Cited
The legislation sets spending limits for military programs for the fiscal year that began Oct. 1. Separate legislation is still required to appropriate the money the Pentagon can spend.
Representative Bill Dickinson of Alabama, the ranking Republican on the House Armed Services Committee, criticized the bill as an example of political expediency.
The House ''not only refuses to make tough decisions,'' he said, ''it refuses to pass the buck and let the executive branch make them.'' Despite his criticism, he voted for the bill as the best that could be achieved under the circumstances.
Mr. Dickinson was referring to the House refusal to quickly terminate weapons programs that Defense Secretary Dick Cheney had sought to end this year, like the Navy's F-14 fighter, built by the Grumman Corporation of Bethpage, L.I.
''If you do not know where you are going, any road will do,'' he said. ''This conference has no idea where it is taking defense policy.''
The military programs bill calls for money for 18 F-14 planes that the Pentagon did not want. They would cost $66 million each by Mr. Dickinson's estimate. After these planes are built, production of the fighter is to be terminated.
 
Money for Helicopters and V-22
The bill also calls for $195 million for 36 helicopters that the Pentagon did not want to buy and recommends $585 million for the V-22 Osprey plane that Mr. Cheney sought to terminate.
A repeated refrain in the debate in the House today was that the failure of the bill to cancel weapons programs now would only make it more difficult to trim military spending in future years without sacrificing programs to maintain military readiness.
If Congress does not have the political will to cancel weapons programs, some Congressmen contended, they would be forced to turn to other areas of the budget for savings, like operations, maintenance and personnel.
Confronting this criticism, the chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, Les Aspin, a Wisconsin Democrat, reminded House members that the bill failed to kill programs largely because the House wanted it that way.
The Bush Administration had sought to end 10 weapons programs over the next two years. The House voted to terminate only two of these while the Senate generally accepted the Administration's recommendations, according to a statement by the House Armed Services Committee.
 
Four Unwanted Programs Saved
The compromise worked out by House and Senate negotiators, which was approved by the House today, continues four of the 10 programs.
But while Mr. Cheney lost on these counts, the Pentagon largely got its way on spending for strategic nuclear programs. The bill, for example, provides $4.3 billion for the B-2 Stealth bomber, $420 million less than requested by the Defense Department. The budget calls for two B-2 planes, which cost more than $500 million each, to be purchased this year and five more next year.
The military programs bill represents the fifth consecutive year that the budget has gone down after inflation is taken into account. Mr. Aspin said in an interview that the budget will go down again next year, reflecting a perception in the United States of a receding Soviet threat.
''Next year will be the beginning of the Gorbachev driven defense budget,'' said Mr. Aspin, referring to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union.
The failure to kill programs this year, he said, ''will add to the problem next year. We are just postponing the problem.''

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
Remorseless Dozing Gets Presidential Nod

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9

 BODY:
Sometimes, even with all that adrenaline and power pulsating through the White House, you have to close your eyes and grab a few winks. Just for a minute. Just until you catch yourself crashing head-first into the bowl of flowers on the President's coffee table in the Oval Office.
Because the sad truth is, even the nerve center of the Western world can get a little tedious sometimes. So many charts and statistics. So many foreign visitors talking stiffly about good relations. So many bureaucrats droning on about the structural impediments initiative with Japan or the fine print in the Pentagon budget or Representative Dingell's latest reaction to Representative Waxman's latest counterproposal based on Senator Chafee's ideas about the clean air bill. Zzzzzzzzz. 
That's why President Bush has created the annual Brent Scowcroft Award, named for the courtly national security adviser who likes his catnaps.
Marlin Fitzwater, the President's press secretary, is the second winner, following Mr. Scowcroft himself. In their offices both display photographs of themselves, sprawled in sleep on Air Force One, with inscriptions from Mr. Bush congratulating them on their awards. ''The award,'' Mr. Fitzwater explained, ''is given to the person who can go to sleep in the most obvious and seemingly embarrassing of situations without any remorse whatsoever.''
Mr. Fitzwater prefers planes or the office couch. The 64-year-old Mr. Scowcroft, who works 14 hours a day and often jogs at midnight because it is the only time he has free, is a master of public naps.
He can fall asleep anywhere from the Oval Office to state dinners, cleverly masking the respite by striking the pose of ''The Thinker,'' with chin in hand and eyes downcast. But he always wakes up before he topples off the couch and in good time to answer a query from the President.
The only two officials who say they never conk out are the President and the Secretary of State.
Jim Baker glazes, a condition once described by a colleague as ''his eyes coming up peaches and oranges, like a slot machine.'' Mr. Bush does not. His metabolism is on such overdrive that he reminds old Washington hands of President Lyndon B. Johnson, who put on his pajamas every day at 4 P.M. for a nap, but ended up frantically working the phone in his bedroom for an hour.
Mr. Bush genially keeps track of everyone else who nods off. ''He passes out notes that say 'Throw a spitball at the general and wake him up,' '' said one senior adviser.
President Reagan was ribbed for dozing off during a 1982 Vatican meeting with the Pope. White House staff members recall clustering around the television back home, cheering him on to win one for the Napper: ''Hang in there, Dutch, you can do it! Just a few more minutes!''
Military briefers are considered the hardest on those prone to nod off. ''The repetition that is a strength when you are indoctrinating 19-year-olds is a weakness when you're trying to keep 50-year-olds awake,'' says one Administration official.
Once, after some military aides briefed Mr. Reagan and a group of aides with a slide show, the lights came up to find five out of the six, including the President, fast asleep.
The biggest group nap came at the 1987 economic summit meeting in Venice. As the Italian leader read the long final communique, all the other heads of state in the Group of Seven, except Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada, snoozed on stage.
Mr. Reagan was admired for his surreptitious nap style. When he awoke midmeeting, he would roll up his eyes, as though he might have had them down on purpose.
One Bush official makes it a habit to turn his desk chair away from the door and toward the window, thus giving the impression to anyone who interrupts that he is perusing papers.
But the most skilled in soporific secrecy was the late spymaster William J. Casey, who napped without letting his head fall forward onto his chest or backwards into that most risky of all positions, ''the whiplash.''
The only faux pas is snoring. ''It's like a Mafioso code of honor,'' explained one Bush adviser. ''We all wake each other up when the snore occurs. We never let things deteriorate to that stage.''

HEADLINE: About Real Estate;
Central Park West Gets Luxury Condominiums

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
Even though the construction of super-luxury condominums has been growing at a rapid clip in Manhattan over the last few years, Central Park West has been glaringly absent from this flurry of activity - despite its obviously appeal to affluent buyers -because virtually no sites have been available for redevelopment.
Now, however, two development partners, David Edelstein and Harry Simpson, are building on one of the few Central Park West sites suited to the purpose, the corner of West 88th Street, where the Progress Club had stood since 1904. Since 1932, the club building had been used by the Walden School. Like all sites on Central Park West, this one offers the opportunity to create apartments with broad views of the park and the city's skyline, an amenity for which many New Yorkers are willing to pay dearly. 
The building is proving to be a success. Though the apartment prices start at $900,000 and rise to $6 million, 21 of the 38 units have been sold since they went on the market in September. The building will not be ready for occupancy until September 1990.
The developers; the architect, Costas Kondylis, and the marketing firm of Gilbert Charles Beylen attribute the rapid sales to factors other than location. One is the concentration on larger, family-sized units with at least two bedrooms. Another is marketing strategy, which focused on the super-rich who, the developers say, cannot always find large, gracious apartments. Such people, they have found, are also far less affected by cyclical changes in the economy.
Thus, even after the stock market crash of 1987 and the subsequent slowing of apartment sales, the team retained the strategy of concentrating on larger units costing $1 million, Mr. Edelstein said.
Another factor contributing to the strong sales in the 24-story building, Mr. Kondylis said, was the decision to combine the advances of contemporary apartment house construction with the qualities buyers seek in elegant prewar cooperatives - nine-foot ceilings, crown moldings, parquet flooring, large marble-paved foyers, separate bedroom wings, servants' quarters and a service entrance, eat-in kitchens and formal dining and living rooms. All those features are offered along with central air-conditioning, large thermopane windows and up-to-the-minute kitchens and bathrooms.
''We also felt there would be a strong demand from people who loved the prewar co-op but did not want to deal with a co-op board,'' said Mr. Edelstein. Many would-be buyers, he noted, dislike disclosing details about their finances to boards and seeking board approvals for changes they want to make in their apartments.
The bulk of the initial buyers are from cooperatives nearby. One attraction has clearly been the chance to make custom interior changes -the sort not easily achieved in an older building. For example, one buyer, the Princess Yasmin Aga Khan, is combining a duplex and two two-bedroom units to produce a mansion-sized, 7,150-square-foot dwelling with seven bedrooms and eight and a half bathrooms at a cost of $7 million. Two others are creating four-bedroom apartments, one with a living room 40 feet by 24 feet, at a cost of $4 million each.
Plans for 279 Central Park West were started about two years ago when Mr. Edelstein and his partners were approached by the trustees of the Walden School to see if they would be interested in purchasing the Progess Club, a five-story Italian palazzo that the school had been using for more than 50 years.
The goals had been an infusion of cash to save the school from financial ruin and modern space within a new structure.
The partners struck a deal with the school that will give Walden a package worth about $10 million. That sum covers the sale of the 37,500-square-foot corner property and a share in the profits from the sale of the units. In addition it will give the school new accommodations encompassing 22,000 square feet in the condo structure. The new space is to be ready for occupancy in March.
It was a good deal for the developers, too, since as much as 24 stories could be built without any special zoning change. Even so, neighbors initially protested, believing that the original classical structure on that site - a turn-of-century German-Jewish men's club - should have landmark protection. But the Landmarks Preservation Commission decided the building was not sufficiently significant, in part because the cornice had been removed 15 years ago for the addition of another floor.
Nevertheless, the new building tries to create a sort of instant landmark by emulating the decorative limestone and tan brick facades that are traditional along Central Park West.
The units range in size from 1,800 to 4,000 square feet. Parking will be available for residents beneath the building.

SECTION: Section A; Page 36, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 394 words

HEADLINE: Setback for Yonkers

 BODY:
More than anything, the city of Yonkers, N.Y., needs to put a divisive housing desegregation controversy behind it and deal with pressing issues of economic development, crime and drugs. Yet on Tuesday, the city's voters elected a new Mayor and City Council that are likely to continue the housing distraction. That creates a new challenge for outside officials like Gov. Mario Cuomo and the Westchester County Executive, Andrew O'Rourke. 
In 1985, Federal District Judge Leonard Sand ruled that Yonkers had deliberately promoted segregation in housing and schools for nearly 40 years. That judgment was upheld by the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit and the U.S. Supreme Court. A voluntary desegregation plan has been instituted in the schools, but the city has nearly self-destructed over a housing remedy.
In January 1988, a majority of the City Council approved a consent judgment that promised 200 low-income housing units in mostly white areas. But by August, mounting public opposition caused the Council, by a 4-to-3 vote, to refuse any meaningful action. Judge Sand responded with crippling fines against the city. Two switched votes fended off bankruptcy, but continued foot-dragging has prevented any real progress. This week's election became a referendum on the housing issue, with Henry Spallone, one of the most defiant Council members, soundly defeating the Democratic incumbent, Nicholas Wasicsko, who was often a lonely proponent of compliance.
In addition to Mr. Spallone, three Council winners, all Republican, oppose the housing order. Three other apparent Council winners, a Democrat and two Republicans, would go along with it.
The potential split puts an added burden on higher-level officials. Mr. Cuomo has a task force working to promote a settlement. But he could be more assertive in trying to persuade Yonkers citizens to obey the law. Mr. O'Rourke, a Republican who began his political career in Yonkers, distanced himself from the controversy last year - a clear abdication of leadership.
Mr. Spallone owes his election only to his exploitation of voters' irrational fears. He has not shown any capacity for bringing statesmanship, or even common sense, to an issue that still creates the potential for enormous harm in his community. It's up to higher officials like Mr. Cuomo and Mr. O'Rourke to fill the void.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

ECONOMY
 
Producer prices rose 0.4 percent in October and there was no increase for goods at the intermediate and crude stages of production. The index rose a bit more than expected, but most analysts considered the overall report encouraging. [Page D1.] 
 
Donald T. Regan said he met with Charles H. Keating Jr., the savings executive, when Mr. Regan was White House chief of staff to talk about Mr. Keating's desire to get his friend Lee Henkel Jr. nominated to the Federal Home Loan Bank Board. [D1.]
 
COMPANIES
 
Telephone companies have begun to offer a service that takes the place of a telephone answering machine. The service allows a caller to leave messages if the number dialed is not answered, or if the line is busy. [D1.]
 
A law passed half a century ago to protect consumers and investors from utility company fraud is hurting consumers by barring big companies from the emerging business of competitive power generation, electric company officials said. [D1.]
 
NBC will pay the National Basketball Association $600 million for the right to broadcast professional basketball games in the U.S. for four years, starting in the 1990-91 season. [D17.]
 
Borden plans to spend $650 million during the next two years to expand and modernize plants around the world. [D4.]
 
Wang Laboratories will undergo a ''fundamental reordering'' and cut 2,000 more workers from its payroll. [D4.]
 
Philip Morris sold its 29 percent stake in Rothmans International for $860 million. [D4.]
 
Centrust Savings Bank has sold ''substantially all'' of a collection of Old Master paintings and sculptures that Florida bank regulators had called ''nonearning assets'' and ''speculative.'' [D17.]
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
British nuclear plants will not be included in the planned sale of the power industry, the Government decided. The move was another blow to the Thatcher privatization program. [D1.]
 
A new bilateral trade pact is being worked on by American and Soviet officials. Such an agreement could end a half century of trade discrimination but also set a framework for expanded investment and technology transfers. [D2.]
 
Moody's Investors Service downgraded China's long-term credit rating. [D2.]
 
MARKETS
 
Representative Markey has vowed to press legislation through Congress that mandates that regulators suspend index arbitrage in the stock and options markets at times of volatility. [D6.]
 
Stock prices declined and trading volume fell. The Dow dropped 19.67 points, to end the day at 2,603.69. [D6.]
 
Securities dealers placed bids on $10 billion worth of new three-year Treasury notes. [D12.]
 
Even though prices of ''junk bonds'' rose for the fourth day in a row, underwriters of high-yield bonds said the improvement was not great enough to reschedule postponed bond offerings. [D7.]
 
The dollar rose against most major currencies except the Japanese yen and Canadian dollar. [D13.] Copper prices surged on the New York Commodity Exchange amid investor concerns about labor conditions in Chile. [D13.]

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Post 0.4% Gain

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9

 BODY:
Further evidence of subdued inflation emerged today as the Government reported a moderate four-tenths of 1 percent rise in the Producer Price Index for Finished Goods in October and no increase at all for goods at the intermediate and crude stages of production.
Although the finished-goods index rose a bit more than expected, most analysts considered the overall report encouraging and likely to reassure the Federal Reserve that inflation risks are minimal. This week the Fed has acted to bring down interest rates.
''The Fed's recent credit-easing actions are consistent with the view that inflationary pressures in the economy are being successfully managed,'' said Dirk Van Dongen, president of the National Association of Wholesaler-Distributors, a trade group whose members pay the producer prices. The October figures confirm that analysis, he said, adding that the data indicate stability in inflation into early 1990. 
 
Core Rate of Inflation
Economists were impressed not only by the unchanged prices for intermediate and crude goods, but also by the sharp deceleration, to a rise of one-tenth of 1 percent, in the finished goods index when the erratic food and energy components are excluded. The October performance followed two months in which this so-called core rate of inflation averaged six-tenths of 1 percent.
Other economists, however, were somewhat less optimistic. John E. Barnds, first vice president and economist at the National Bank of Detroit, called today's report ''a mild positive'' but cautioned against assuming that inflation posed no immediate concern.
''You still have to look at the year-over-year numbers,'' he said, which now show finished goods have climbed 4.9 percent since October 1988 and at a 5.2 percent annual rate for the first 10 months of this year.
Indeed, added Lawrence A. Hunter, deputy chief economist for the United States Chamber of Commerce, ''producer price inflation is actually higher now'' than a year ago even as economic growth has slowed to an annual rate of perhaps 2.5 percent from more than 4 percent. ''The Fed's effort to slow economic growth has reduced employment opportunities but not inflation,'' Mr. Hunter said.
 
Big Jump in Food Prices
In broadest outline, the four-tenths of 1 percent rise in the finished-goods index last month reflected a 1.4 percent jump in food prices - the biggest in nearly two years - that was substantially offset by a 1.4 percent decline for passenger cars. Energy prices rose a scant two-tenths of 1 percent, after soaring 6.5 percent in September and helping push that month's overall finished-goods index up by nine-tenths of 1 percent.
Prices of fresh and dried vegetables jumped 18.9 percent in October, a bit more than they fell in September, and fresh fruits climbed 4.9 percent. Pork rose 9.5 percent and dairy product prices accelerated 2.8 percent, but beef and veal prices eased, as did those of chickens, coffee and shortening, the report showed.
Much of the rise in vegetable prices was because of poor weather in Florida and California, analysts said.
Passenger cars, reflecting the introduction into the sample of 1990 models, rose 8.3 percent before seasonal adjustment but fell 1.4 percent after adjustment. The seasonal adjustment factor for October included $180.74 for the value of quality improvements, 26 percent of the average $694.54 increase in auto prices.
 
Energy Costs Stabilize
The negligible two-tenths of 1 percent rise in finished energy goods reflected a downturn in prices for home heating oil and natural gas, and moderating increases in gasoline prices, which were up 2.3 percent after jumping 10.6 percent in September.
Among capital goods, which posted an overall three-tenths of 1 percent decline in price, increases slowed markedly for trucks, while prices turned down for printing equipment and agricultural machinery. Prices rose for metal-cutting machine tools and photographic, communications and electromedical equipment.
Among intermediate goods, where aggregate price stability followed a four-tenths of 1 percent rise in September, there were further declines for several manufacturing materials that balanced increases for some construction materials. The price of plywood soared 9 percent, the biggest monthly increase since April 1974, to bring the advance over the last 12 months to 22.1 percent.
A four-tenths of 1 percent decline for nondurable manufacturing materials was the fifth straight drop, and durable manufacturing goods, after an upturn in September, resumed the decline begun last spring. Prices fell for copper, brass and aluminum mill shapes, but rose modestly for primary copper, the Labor Department's report showed.
 
Electricity Price Falls
All major petroleum fuels rose somewhat, but the intermediate energy index edged down because of a 1.9 percent drop in the index for electric power.
Crude goods, which swing by large amounts from month to month, were unchanged in price after a 1.1 percent rise in September and a 1.9 percent decline in August. Energy rose more slowly. Crude materials excluding food and energy rose the same three-tenths of 1 percent as in September, and foods continued to fall.
Substantial price increases were posted for softwood logs and copper base scrap, while ferrous scrap and leaf tobacco fell sharply. Chicken prices dropped 18.2 percent and soybeans dropped 10 percent.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Budget Woe Goes Beyond Gimmicks

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
AS Washington's current battle of the budget demonstrates, more than a month into the new fiscal year, the effort to stay under the Gramm-Rudman deficit ceiling has worsened public confusion and increased the use of budget gimmicks. For instance, Government payments are shifted to a different fiscal year or goods are paid for not in cash but through certificates or by pushing outlays ''off budget.''
This has been a longstanding problem. Twenty-two years ago, the Presidential Commission on Budget Concepts, in recommending a unified Federal budget as a basis for the nation's financial planning, warned against overconcentration on a single number - the budget surplus or deficit. Such overconcentration, the commission said, ''has been a root cause of public confusion and has been responsible for accusations of gimmickry. 
But eliminating gimmickry is only the start of what needs to be done to clean up the Federal budget process. The General Accounting Office has proposed a plan for overhauling the budget to improve the Government's financial decision-making for both the short and long run. It would retain the unified budget to assure continued disclosure of the Government's total financial operations but would divide the budget into three main components -general, trust and enterprise funds (to cover business-type entities like the Postal Service and the Tennessee Valley Authority), with each of the three components subdivided into operating and capital accounts.
This approach would offer a way to resolve the controversy over whether the Social Security trust fund surpluses, intended to finance the enormous benefits for the postwar baby-boom generation when it retires, should continue to be used to offset the huge operating-budget deficits.
The unified budget deficit is important for planning fiscal and monetary policy, counting everything the Government takes in or borrows and spends. That was the basic reason the Budget Concepts Commission recommended the unified budget in the first place. But the G.A.O. report contends that merging the Social Security surpluses into the total ''leaves the erroneous impression that the structural imbalance in the Government's fiscal affairs is being corrected when, in fact, it is getting worse.''
The chronic United States budget deficit depresses the already low level of national savings. Japan's net public and private saving, which has been averaging 20 percent, has been five times as great as that of the United States, and that difference helps explain Japan's greater rate of investment in new plant and equipment and in research and development, and its much greater investment in foreign real and portfolio assets.
One way of reducing the disparity between United States and Japanese rates of capital formation would be for this country to bring its operating deficit into balance, while allowing the Social Security surpluses to accumulate and thereby make more private savings available for investments.
The G.A.O.'s proposal to divide the general, trust and enterprise budgets into operating and capital components is also meant to end bias against Government outlays that would improve long-term efficiency. But there are great difficulties in defining what should be counted as a capital outlay.
The chronic budget deficit, as Henry Aaron of the Brookings Institution observes, ''helped President Reagan achieve the reduction in nondefense activities of the Federal Government that he sought.'' But the times are changing, and a new consensus seems to have emerged - evident, according to many political analysts, in this week's elections -that the role of Government should increase in several areas: combating drugs, improving the environment, modernizing roads, bridges and other public facilities, improving schools and extending health coverage to the uninsured.
In the foreign policy area, with notable hazards and opportunities in Eastern Europe and Latin America, the United States is severely hobbled for lack of funds. ''How can you be a superpower,'' asks Goran Ohlin, a leading Swedish economist, ''when you are out of pocket?''
Further, the budget's almost exclusive focus on current cash transactions means that many costs are greatly understated or ignored. One huge case that has been grabbing headlines is the bill American taxpayers now must pay for resolving the savings and loan crisis - it seems certain to exceed $150 billion and could be more than $300 billion including interest costs.
President Bush says he wants a reconciliation budget bill ''without gimmicks.'' But the problem goes many billions and many years beyond gimmickry. Instead of the partisan maneuvering for position, there is need for a new budget commission - and White House and Congressional action - to deal with the Government's unfinanced obligations and concealed costs, and the nation's unmet needs.

HEADLINE: British Banks Lift Reserves

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: LONDON, Nov. 9

 BODY:
Two major British banks put aside money yesterday to protect them against bad third world loans, together adding more than $2 billion to their reserves following similar moves by United States and Canadian banks.
The banks, Lloyds Bank P.L.C. and National Westminster, said their profits would be hurt by the move. 
Lloyds said that it would add 1.2 billion, or $1.9 billion, while NatWest said it would add 575 million, or $908.5 million.
''Economic and political problems have intensified in those countries, and 15 out of 29 countries have stopped paying us interest,'' said Brian Pitman, Lloyds's chief executive.
''The debt situation has deteriorated further in recent months and this increase in provisions reflects our commercial assessment of the situation,'' said Lord Alexander, NatWest's chairman.
Lloyds said the latest move means it will report a ''substantial'' loss for 1989, after a profit last year of 952 million, or $1.5 billion.
