HEADLINE: Trade Officials to Meet On U.S.-Soviet Accord

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9

 BODY:
Top commercial officials of the United States and the Soviet Union will meet next week in Washington to begin work on a new trade pact, Administration officials said today. It is to be similar to an agreement nullified by Moscow in 1975, after Congress demanded freer Soviet emigration.
The meeting next Wednesday and Thursday of the U.S.-U.S.S.R. Joint Commercial Commission, a body set up in 1972 to foster trade links, comes just two weeks before the Dec. 2 and 3 Mediterranean summit meeting. At the meeting, Presidents Bush and Mikhail S. Gorbachev are expected to discuss closer trade ties. 
Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher and the Soviet Minister of Foreign Economic Relations, Konstantin F. Katushev, are heading the two delegations, which are likely to set up informal working groups on the trade agreement, American officials said.
 
Better Tariff Treatment
Such an agreement could bring about normal economic relations between the two superpowers, not only ending a half-century of trade discrimination but also setting a framework for expanded investment and technology transfers.
The Jackson-Vanik Amendment to the Trade Act of 1974, which Moscow cited in aborting the earlier trade agreement, bars most-favored-nation tariff treatment - generally low tariffs - to countries that deny freedom to emigrate.
Responding to Mr. Gorbachev's reforms, including more liberal emigration, President Bush announced last May that he would ask Congress for a waiver under Jackson-Vanik for the Soviet Union.
But he set two conditions: Moscow must put its more liberal policies into law, and there must be a period to monitor how well the law is carried out.
According to reports from Moscow, an emigration law is expected to clear the Supreme Soviet by the end of this month.
John P. Hardt, Soviet affairs specialist at the Library of Congress, said he expects formal negotiations on a trade agreement to get under way after the summit meeting, and that by the time of the leaders' next meeting, probably in mid-1990, the President could submit a trade agreement to Congress.
Under Jackson-Vanik, no tariffs can be cut until a trade agreement is approved by Congress. Tariffs on Soviet goods are generally five to 10 times higher than on imports from most other countries.
The approval process could pit the Administration against chiefly conservative critics, like the Center for Security Policy, a Washington research institute, who still see the Soviet Union as a military and strategic menace.
 
Priority Issue
Normal treatment is high in the list of Soviet demands mainly because it would end the country's status as an economic pariah. Mr. Gorbachev has often spoken of his desire to integrate the Soviet Union into the global economic community.
Current two-way trade between the two countries is about $3 billion a year, most of which represents American agricultural exports. Without agriculture, the flows are about equivalent to American trade with Haiti.
The agreement the United States and the Soviet Union concluded in the 1970's called for elimination of discriminatory trade restrictions and included provisions for settling the Soviet Union's World War II lend-lease debt of $674 million.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Why Japan Likes Lower U.S. Rates

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:

FOR most of 1989, the Japanese stock market has been a laggard, a sharp reversal from the leading role it played for much of the 1980's. But it was Japan that stemmed the tide of the mini-crash that rocked most world markets in mid-October, and this week it was Japan that reacted most enthusiastically when the Federal Reserve seemed to signal it wanted to ease credit.
As a result, yesterday's rise of 61.83 points, to 35,657.42, in the Nikkei 225, the most widely watched index of Japanese stocks, left the average just 32 points, or 0.09 percent, below the record it set on Sept. 28. The Dow Jones industrial average, by contrast, remains 6.7 percent below its record, set on Oct. 9. 
''People have been hoping the Fed will ease, and that that will weaken the dollar,'' said Lawrence S. Prager, an American who this summer was promoted to chief fundamental analyst and strategist at Nikko Securities Ltd. in Tokyo.
To the Japanese, such a course holds out the possibility of easing two problems that have faced the Japanese market. Interest rates have been pushed up, in Tokyo as well as in much of Europe, to fight the dollar's strength and to stem inflation rates that seem high by their standards. ''This could gradually develop room for the Bank of Japan to ease and let interest rates fall,'' Mr. Prager said.
The Fed's easing on Tuesday, signaling that it was willing to allow the Federal funds rate - the rate at which banks lend money to each other - to fall from 8 3/4 percent to 8 1/2 percent, got a hesitant response that day in the American stock market. The Dow rose almost 15 points, but both the over-the-counter market and the American Stock Exchange saw more stocks fall than rise in price.
But in Japan on Wednesday, share prices rose rapidly, with the Nikkei average surging 325 points, or almost 1 percent, and the American market joined in the party later the same day, as the Dow rose 26 points in a rally that was broader than any since the Oct. 19 slump. The advance slowed in Tokyo yesterday, and prices fell in New York.
Whether the Japanese market can keep climbing depends in part on whether the American easing of interest rates really does help bring down the dollar. The yen rallied a bit just after the Fed move but then gave up much of its gains. The worry over relatively high interest rates - 10-year Japanese bonds now yield 5.6 percent and savers can get 6.7 percent on three-month bank certificates of deposit - is widely viewed as being one reason that stock prices fell in early October, before the drop began in the United States.
Those rates are not high by American standards, but the spread between Japanese and United States Government bond yields - about 2.3 percentage points - is the lowest since 1986. If an even narrower spread is needed to bring down the dollar, the Japanese would much rather see that come from lower American rates than from higher Japanese ones.
Foreign investors have generally stayed away from the Japanese market this year, reflecting concerns about the poor performance of the market, as well as about the high price-earnings ratios in Japan - often two or three times what they are in Europe or the United States. And some of those earnings, as William L. Clauss, a market strategist with Banca della Svizzera Italiana, notes, include gains from stock speculation. ''If the market goes down,'' he said yesterday, ''corporate profits will follow.''
The Nikkei is up a respectable 18.2 percent this year, in yen terms, but after adjusting for the rise of the dollar, the index is up just 4.8 percent. By contrast, the Dow is up 20.1 percent.
After becoming net buyers of Japanese shares in late 1988, as the dollar was falling, the foreign institutions kept up their purchases only through February. They then began selling shares, according to Japanese Government figures, reaching a peak net sale of about $3.4 billion in June. Although foreigners were net buyers in August, they returned to selling in September.
Since the end of June, the Nikkei average has marginally outperformed the Dow, but that gain has been small consolation for many American portfolio managers who own Japanese stocks. The big export-oriented companies have generally not done that well this year as Japanese investors focused on smaller companies and on ones that could cash in on the consumer boom.
The Japanese savings rate remains high, but more and more consumers are borrowing as they seek to enjoy luxuries befitting their wealth. Outstanding Japanese consumer debt for purchases of goods and services was about 16 trillion yen ($115 billion) at the end of 1986. Less than three years later, it is more than 65 trillion yen ($450 billion).

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Sells $10 Billion of Notes

BYLINE: By KENNETH GILPIN

 BODY:
Securities dealers yesterday placed bids on $10 billion worth of new three-year Treasury notes as prices of most notes and bonds ended the day lower in fairly light trading.
Yesterday's auction of the three-year issue was highlighted by large bids from Japanese securities firms.
According to officials at those firms, the Japanese placed bids on a little more than 40 percent of the issue.
''If you are looking at major markets around the world, the United States is the only major country where there is some prospect of a central bank easing monetary policy,'' said William M. Brachfeld, an executive vice president at Daiwa Securities America Inc. ''On that basis, you should be buying short-term maturities.'' 
 
Concern Expressed
Some dealers expressed concern that the bidding from Japan at yesterday's auctions might bode ill for upcoming sales of 10-year notes and 30-year bonds. Mr. Brachfeld rejected that notion. ''There will be Japanese interest in all the auctions,'' he said. ''There always is.''
For the most part, traders said the slight dip in prices was a defensive reaction to a move by the Federal Reserve Board to drain reserves from the banking system when the overnight Federal funds rate was trading at 8 3/8 percent.
The funds rate fell to that level on Wednesday, prompting some analysts to speculate that the Fed, which on Tuesday clearly indicated it wanted the funds rate to drop a notch, may have sanctioned a decline in the rate to below 8.50 percent. The Fed's action yesterday more or less scotched that notion.
''The draining move was a pretty clear rate protest,'' from the Fed, one government bond trader said.
 
Fed Funds Trade at 8 3/8%
Nevertheless, after the Fed's move the funds rate continued to trade at 8 3/8 percent, and was quoted at that level late yesterday.
In addition to the Fed's move, market participants said yesterday's report on producer prices spurred some selling because it showed that measure of inflation rose by four-tenths of a percentage point last month, a bit higher than anticipated.
At the three-year note auction, the notes were sold at an average yield of 7.77 percent, the lowest level since the auction of Feb. 2, 1988, and well below the 7.93 percent average yield at the last three-year note auction on Aug. 8.
The refunding auctions continue today with the sale of $10 billion worth of 36-day cash management notes, and wind up early next week, when $10 billion of 10-year notes and $10 billion of 30-year bonds will be sold on Monday and Tuesday, respectively.
Late yesterday, the 10-year notes were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 7.86 percent, up from 7.82 percent late Wednesday. 30-Year Bond at 7.89% Meanwhile, the 30-year bond was offered at a price to yield 7.89 percent in when-issued trading, compared with 7.88 percent late Wednesday.
In the secondary Treasury market, the 8 1/8 percent bonds of 2019 were offered at a price of 102 5/8 late yesterday, down 5/32, to yield 7.89 percent.
Among note issues, the 8 1/4 percent five-year notes were offered at 101 22/32, down 3/32, to yield 7.82 percent. And the 7 5/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 99 23/32, down 1/32, to yield 7.78 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates moved higher in reaction to the Fed's draining move. By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.68 percent, up three basis points, or hundredths of a point. And six-month bill rates rose by nine basis points, to a late offered rate of 7.56 percent.
 
Texaco Offers Notes
Elsewhere, a number of corporate issuers priced more than $1 billion in new issues yesterday. Among the issuers was Texaco Inc., which made its first offering since the company went into bankruptcy in April 1987.
The company, which emerged from bankruptcy a year later, after its battle with the Pennzoil Company over Getty Oil was completed, offered $400 million worth of seven-year notes through an underwriting syndicate led by Morgan Stanley & Company.
The 9 percent notes were priced at par, or 1.15 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the 8 percent seven-year Treasury notes. The issue is rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Other issuers included New Jersey Bell, which sold $150 million worth of 40-year debentures through a syndciate led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets, and Citicorp, which sold $200 million worth of five-year notes through an underwriting group led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.
The New Jersey Bell issue, which carries a final maturity of Nov. 15, 2029, includes a ''put'' at par in the 10th year. The 7.85 percent debentures were priced at 99.75, to yield 7.887 percent, 7.5 basis points over the prevailing yield on the 8 percent 10-year Treasury notes at the time of pricing. The issue is rated AAA by both Moody's and S.&P.
The 8 5/8 percent Citicorp notes, which mature Nov. 15, 1994, were priced at 99.77 to yield 8.683 percent, 93 basis points over the prevailing yield on the 8 1/4 percent Treasury notes at the time of pricing.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday that the narrowest and broadest measures of the nation's money supply M-1 and M-3, fell during the week ended Oct. 30. The third measure, M-2, rose by $3.1 billion. The report had no impact on prices in the credit markets.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Generally Higher While Gold Prices Decline

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose yesterday against most major currencies, except the Japanese yen and Canadian dollar.
Gold prices fell. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold fell to $387.10, from $388.80 the day before. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted a bid for gold of $386.30 an ounce at 4 P.M., down from $387.50 late Wednesday. 
Dealers said the dollar had little reaction to a larger-than-expected four-tenths of 1 percent rise in United States wholesale prices in October. Analysts had expected an increase in the Producer Price Index of two-tenths of a percent.
''You saw most of the market reaction rather subdued to the Producer Price Index report,'' said David Ethridge, vice president of foreign exchange at Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. ''It wasn't a shock.''
Currency traders said the dollar remained strong despite the market's perception that the Federal Reserve is easing its credit policy, which will likely encourage lower interest rates. Falling interest rates usually depress the dollar's value.
 
Factor in Dollar-Yen Trading
The key factor pushing down the dollar against the yen was the selling between other currencies, said Keith Raphael, an assistant vice president at Bank Brussels Lambert in New York.
He said the yen rose against the West German mark and also gained ground against the dollar in the morning. The selloff ran out of steam when the dollar hit 142.25 yen and traders bought dollars in an afternoon rally, traders said.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 142.70 Japanese yen, down 0.27 yen from Wednesday's close. Later in London, the dollar rose to 142.85 yen. In New York, the dollar closed at 143.13, down from 143.18 late Wednesday.
Mr. Raphael said the dollar rose against the British pound because the Bank of England expressed concern that pressure to increase wages could lead to a recession.
In London, the British pound edged up to $1.5863, from $1.5860 late Wednesday. Later in New York, the pound fetched $1.5823, less than $1.5885 late Wednesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's rates, included: 1.8523 West German marks, up from 1.8445; 1.6250 Swiss francs, up from 1.6168; 6.2810 French francs, up from 6.2515; 1,354.25 Italian lire, up from 1,347.25, and 1.1670 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1698.
Other dollar rates in Europe, compared with rates late Wednesday, included: 1.8475 West German marks, up from 1.8450; 1.6212 Swiss francs, up from 1.6170; 6.2545 French francs, up from 6.2510; 2.0815 Dutch guilders, up from 2.0805; 1,351.50 Italian lire, up from 1,349.50, and 1.1675 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1695.
Gold bullion rose in London to a late bid of $386.25 an ounce, from $384.75 late Wednesday. In Zurich, gold rose to $387.30, from $384 late Wednesday.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Labor Conditions in Chile Keep Copper Prices Rising

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Copper prices continued to surge yesterday on the Commodity Exchange in New York amid investor concerns about labor conditions in Chile.
On other markets, grain was mostly lower and soybeans higher, energy and sugar futures were higher and gold was off while silver gained.
Copper settled 0.70 cent to 1.35 cents higher, with the contract for delivery in November at $1.1640 a pound. 
Miners at Chile's four largest mines have voted to strike if the Chilean Government adopts a law that would reorganize the state-owned Chile Copper Corporation. The proposal would give members of the military Government power over mine operations after the Government leaves office, and it would reduce the power of unions.
Helping to spur prices was the perception that the metal had been oversold in recent weeks because of settlement of labor disputes in Canada and Mexico, said Don Tierney, an analyst for Stanley Bell & Company in New York.
Expectations that a report scheduled to be released on Monday about stocks in warehouses approved by the London Metal Exchange would show a decline also helped prices, as did prospects that interest rates were going down, which would increase demand, Mr. Tierney said.
On the Chicago Board of Trade, grain futures were mostly lower and soybeans were higher in quiet trading. Corn and soybean trading was subdued, as investors waited for the Agriculture Department's latest crop report to be released.
The report, issued after trading closed, estimated the 1989 corn harvest at 7.59 billion bushels, up by 54 percent from last year's drought-shriveled crop. The estimate was up by 2 percent from prospects a month ago, when the department estimated this year's production at 7.45 billion bushels.
Wheat prices were forced lower because of less export business, although some support was received from the National Weather Service's forcast for the next 6 to 10 days, which called for dry weather in winter-wheat crop areas.

HEADLINE: CLAMOR IN THE EAST: UNITED STATES;
U.S. ENTHUSIASTIC, BUT HAS CONCERNS

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10

 BODY:
Like the rest of the world, Washington is scrambling to keep pace with the changes unfolding by the hour in Eastern Europe. But in contrast with the pivotal role the United States played 40 years ago in shaping the postwar European order that now seems to be coming apart, Washington finds itself more of a bystander - astonished, enthusiastic and concerned.
Twice in the last 24 hours, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d found himself being slipped notes from aides informing him of major changes in Eastern Europe that only a week earlier no one had imagined, let alone predicted. Officials said a policy review that Mr. Baker ordered three weeks ago on how the United States should relate to changes in East Germany will have to be tossed out and begun anew.
The political changes reverberating across Europe, and the diminished threat of military conflict, also promised to stir new debate in Washington about the need for maintaining a large, expensive American military presence in Western Europe. Moving quickly to deflate such speculation, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney cautioned against letting the euphoria of the moment dictate American defense policy. 
But Washington today was mostly a capital energized by a sense of witnessing - and participating in - an epochal moment.
''Someone asked me, 'Weren't you surprised?' '' said Mr. Baker, who ignored the Veterans Day holiday to monitor events from his seventh floor office in the State Department. ''I said, 'Your're darn right and so was everybody else.' So were the East Germans. So were all of our allies. So were the West Germans. If anybody tells you that they knew this was going to happen yesterday they are smoking something.''
''This is a remarkable event,'' added Mr. Baker, who is saving for posterity the typed note which was passed to him at a luncheon on Thursday, informing him of the opening of East Germany's borders.
 
Intervention Seen as Unlikely
Mr. Baker said: ''It is the most significant event in terms of the East-West relationship since the end of the war. There is no question about it. It is really something. You may see some backsliding, even on the part of the Soviet Union, although I remain convinced, I hope not naively, that they are not going to intervene with force. You are not going to see a 1956 again. That is what they tell us privately and now they are saying it publicly.''
Mr. Baker was referring to the Soviet military intervention that crushed the Hungarian revolution in 1956.
In light of the rapid developments in East Germany, American officials now anticipate that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union may try to use his meeting with President Bush next month to discuss the fate of Germany and to press for a dissolution of NATO and the Warsaw Pact. The two leaders are scheduled to meet Dec. 2 and 3 aboard American and Soviet naval vessels off the coast of Malta in the Mediterranean.
 
Studying Implications
Administration officials made clear today they have no intention of getting into a negotiation with Mr. Gorbachev about the future of Germany, let alone a dissolution of NATO. But following the stunning changes under way in Eastern Europe, American officials are increasingly interested to hear how far Mr. Gorbachev is prepared to let events in East Germany develop and the implications this will have for the East-West security balance in Europe.
One thing is clear, said an Administration European affairs expert: ''This summit will have to address things that no one imagined two weeks ago.''
Adopting a much more enthusiastic posture than he did yesterday about the opening of East Germany's borders, President Bush said: ''The changes in recent months make clear that the process of reform initiated by the Eastern Europeans and supported by Mr. Gorbachev and by America and by our allies is real, offers us all much hope and deserves our continued encouragement. We're living in fascinating times and we will seize every opportunity to contribute to lasting peace and to extend democracy.''
Mr. Bush spoke with Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany by telephone for about 20 minutes this afternoon, as the President was touring Texas. The White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater quoted Mr. Kohl as saying that ''this day would not have been possible'' without the United States.
For some of the men who were architects of the postwar order four decades ago, this week's developments were cause for reflection about how America's role in Europe has changed since the United States stepped in to help a devastated Continent recover from the war and resist the threat of Soviet expansion.
Paul H. Nitze, the 82-year-old former arms-control negotiator who was a member of the Truman Administration team that helped to establish NATO and the Marshall Plan at the start of the cold war, discussed the contrast in an interview.
 
'We Have Come Out on Top'
''If you go back 40 years what you see is that we suddenly had pulled ourselves together to follow a very different course in the world from the one we had been following - standing up to the Russians in Europe, establishing NATO and creating the cold war,'' said Mr. Nitze.
''Today, that kind of situation is not called for,'' he added. ''We have come out on top. The situation in Europe is evolving our way and our task is to simply be helpful to that evolution. Events are going on right now with results that cannot be forseen. We know things are going to be different but we are not certain how much better. So maybe we should keep our powder dry. We don't need to be operating every second, but we should be analyzing every second.''
Among the most critical analyses now being undertaken is how these events in East Germany and Bulgaria might affect the Bush-Gorbachev summit talks.
''The Soviets' rhetorical position has been that they would be prepared to see a reunited Germany provided it was neutral and came about in the context of a demilitarized Europe,'' said an Administration European expert. ''That, of course, is a nonstarter for us. The big question for now is whether Gorbachev might propose something that makes more sense, maybe some formal reassociation short of total merger, or political and economic union, but with American and Soviet troops maintaining a certain presence, or some other framework to deal with the security implications. Obviously nothing is going to be decided there. We can't cut any deals. But this summit is going to be enormously significant in determining what the Soviets really want in terms of the German question and overall European security.''
 
Baker Won't Forget the Moment
Secretary Baker said he will never forget the moment when he was informed of the opening of the German borders as he was giving a lunch on Thursday for President Corazon C. Aquino of the Philippines at the State Department's gilded dining hall yesterday.
''We were sitting there at the table and a note was given to me by our executive secretary,'' recalled Mr. Baker. ''I just told the table and everybody was really, really profoundly moved by it. It said: 'Mr. Secretary, the East German Government has just announced that it is fully opening its borders to the West. The implication from the announcement is full freedom of travel via current East German-West German links bettween borders.' ''
Reflecting on his feelings at the time, Mr. Baker said: ''I am almost 60 and I remember the war, I have a vivid memory of where I was on the day of Pearl Harbor, and I remember vividly where I was on V.E. day and V.J. day. I don't have a specific memory where I was when the wall went up, but I'll never forget this. What is so mind-boggling is the way it happened - an announcement by some deputy press person. You would think if something like this was going to happen it would be some carefully crafted move. This just sort of oozed out and boom! There we are. The most significant event in 40 years. It's a heck of a deal.''

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1, Column 3; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1115 words

HEADLINE: CLAMOR IN THE EAST: Redefining Europe;
As the Revelry Goes On, Politicians Ponder The Ramifications of Changes in Germany

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WEST BERLIN, Nov. 10

 BODY:
By the simple act of forcing their Communist rulers to open the Berlin wall and allow them to go wherever they wish, the people of East Germany have irrevocably changed the way Berlin, Germany and all of Europe have defined themselves for more than 40 years.
Thousands and thousands of East Berliners celebrated their triumph today by promenading up and down the elegant, tree-lined shopping boulevards of the western part of the city, which most of them had never before been allowed to see. They made the Kurfurstendamm into a street festival this evening as church bells pealed joyously into the night.
 
'A Different Relationship'
Willy Brandt, who was Mayor of West Berlin when the wall was built in 1961, said at a rally this evening, ''The moving together of the German states is taking shape in reality in a different way than many of us expected.'' 
No one should act as if he knows in which concrete form the people in these two states will find a new relationship. But that they will find a relationship, that they will come together in freedom, that is the important point.''
But the entire postwar European order has been based on the assumption that Germany, and Europe, would remain divided, and the countries of Eastern and Western Europe firmly anchored in their respective alliances.
In that assumption the United States, in the NATO alliance, guaranteed the security of Western Europe. And in that same assumption France, West Germany and the other major industrial countries of Western Europe began the economic and political unification of the European Community.
West German politicians, including Mr. Brandt and Chancellor Helmut Kohl, who interrupted an official visit to Poland today to fly to Berlin, all insist that West Germany's commitment to West European integration and the alliance remains.
 
Europe as a 'Haven of Order'
But politicians, diplomats and business leaders all over Europe are considering new implications for both institutions now that the end of German partition is at last imaginable.
''Europe, though Europeans did not always appreciate it, has been a haven of order these past 44 years,'' The Economist wrote today. ''For East Europeans the price of that stability has been high: a lifetime wasted under a government you loathed. For West Europeans the stability has been marvelous. They could get rich, and start to build a new unity, within a clearly defined zone which ended at the river Elbe and the Bohemian forest.''
Now, a NATO diplomat in Brussels said, ''The end of the wall raises questions of what's going to happen in Europe. The whole concept of the European Community now may have to change.''
So would the concept of the NATO alliance, this diplomat conceded: ''Our role will be to design a new role for the alliance - maintaining a balance of stability with the East while all this change is going on.
''There's a reassessment of the Warsaw Pact going on too,'' he said. ''This organization we rejected over the years is beginning to be seen as a possible element of stability in the future, to prevent the Balkanization of Eastern Europe.''
Rudolf Witt, a 32-year-old mechanic from East Berlin who crossed over this afternoon with his wife, Barbara Rieck, and their 4-month-old baby, Susanne, said on his way back home at the Invalidenstrasse crossing point, ''We're the balancing scales of Europe, and we don't want to tip them with something like German reunification.''
An American diplomatic expert on Germany said, ''I think the orderliness of everything that has happened so far, and the great restraint shown by the West Germans, shows that there will be an orderly transition to something else.''
 
Western European Unity
''I think Kohl will make a great big pledge and West German industrialists will start rebuilding'' East Germany, he said. ''But the price will be more political reform than the East German leadership originally intended. If they follow the Polish model, East Germans would have 8 or 10 years to determine whether they wanted to remain a separate country,'' he said.
Such uncertainties have been far from the minds of the European Community politicians who have spent the last three years trying to agree on ways to closer economic and political unity among the 12 existing members.
Chancellor Kohl has been trying to persuade his fellow European leaders to agree to make the Community into a confederation, rather than the loose collection of cooperating sovereign states that is preferred by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain.
 
Thatcher Seen as Obstacle
Mrs. Thatcher is already regarded by the other leaders in the Community as an obstacle to greater unity among the 12. At full steam only a year ago, momentum toward closer union could falter if much of West Germany's attention in the next few years is diverted to the East. On Wednesday, Mr. Kohl promised a ''completely new dimension'' of economic aid for East Germany if it went ahead with promised political changes.
But even if European integration is sidetracked for the time being, it may acquire a new direction if the peoples of Eastern Europe can go on forcing democratic change in their countries. Nations like Hungary, Poland and perhaps even East Germany could become associate members of an expanded European Community, if not full ones.
The challenge would be to allow them to flourish economically in association with Western Europe without upsetting the security interests of either the United States or the Soviet Union in the process.
Both superpowers, at the moment, look more or less like passive, though benevolent, bystanders as events in Eastern Europe unfold. Moscow no longer seems to see itself as threatened by radical political or economic change in Eastern Europe, and both the United States and the Soviet Union have an interest in achieving substantial cuts in their conventional armed forces on both sides of the German divide.
 
Strategic Bottom Line
What is not so clear is where Moscow's strategic bottom line lies, and what the attitude of the United States - not just the Bush Administration, but Congress as well - will be if many Americans decide the cold war is over and their troops should all come home. There are about 300,000 Army and Air Force troops in Western Europe.
The American attitude is the key to insuring that Germany does not lose its Western orientation and that Europe manages an orderly transition to whatever new future awaits it, many Germans and Western diplomats agree.
''We are at present at the creation of a new postwar era,'' one American official said, ''and I hope the people at home will see it that way.''

SECTION: Section 1; Page 7, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 939 words

HEADLINE: CLAMOR IN THE EAST: NATO and the Warsaw Pact;
As Threat of War Recedes, U.S. and Soviets Face Pressure for Troop Cuts

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10

 BODY:
The political unheaval in Eastern Europe is raising the prospect of change in the military balance in the region, putting pressure on Moscow and Washington to substantially reduce their forces there.
A senior Bush Administration official said this week that he had been informed by a Hungarian official that Hungary's goal was the elimination of Soviet forces there.
And Polish officials reportedly have objected to a Western plan to store substantial quantities of Soviet and American military equipment in their nation as part of a conventional arms accord, believing that such a move could perpetuate the Soviet presence there.
Showing increased political independence from Moscow, some Eastern European officials have privately told American aides that they want to see deep reductions, if not the complete withdrawal, of Soviet forces. 
 
Soviet Troop Cuts Are Reality
With an eye toward events in Eastern Europe and reducing the burden of military spending on its economy, the Soviet Union is already withdrawing a sizable complement of its forces from Eastern Europe. It has indicated a willingness to go much further as part of an emerging agreement on cutting conventional forces in Europe.
The Soviet Union has said publicly that it is willing to disband the Warsaw Pact if the North Atlantic Treaty Organization is similarly dissolved, although the proposal has been flatly rejected by Bush Administration officials.
As a result of the Eastern European developments, Pentagon officials assert that the risk of military aggression is at its lowest point since World War II.
''The likelihood is certainly significantly lower now than at any time in the postwar period that military forces from East Germany would be used to move offensively into Western Europe,'' Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said in a statement. The text was issued after the East German Government announced that it was opening its border to the West.
 
U.S. Fears Pressure on Spending
But while the Pentagon cautiously welcomes the changes in Eastern Europe, it fears that political developments will increase public pressure in the West for reductions in defense spending and in the American military presence in Europe.
''We must not be euphoric,'' Mr. Cheney said. ''We must maintain our own capabilities until we see the kind of fundamental changes that cannot be altered overnight. Any reductions in our military commitment to Europe should be made in our negotiations on conventional and strategic forces. Only after agreements are pursued and signed should any reductions be made.''
The Pentagon's concern about eroding domestic support for military spending appears to be well founded. The bill for 1990 military programs, approved Thursday by the House of Representatives, marks the fifth consecutive year that the defense budget has decreased after inflation is taken into account.
Legislative leaders predict that the political developments in Eastern Europe will encourage Congress to cut defense spending again next year.
''Next year will be the beginning of the Gorbachev-driven defense budget,'' said Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, who is chairman of the House Armed Services Committee.
 
No Deep U.S. Troop Cuts Yet
So far, Congress has not sought to make deep cuts in troops in Europe. The 1990 defense bill would cut 15,000 Army and Air Force troops, the number that Congress says were used to handle the intermediate-range missiles that are being eliminated under the 1987 American-Soviet missile accord.
But if West Europeans respond to events in Eastern Europe by cutting troop strength, pressure will build in Congress to take comparable steps, American lawmakers warn.
By any measure, Moscow has maintained a domineering military presence in Eastern Europe since World War II. About 600,000 Soviet troops are stationed in Eastern European nations. The heaviest concentration of Soviet forces is in East Germany, where Moscow has roughly 380,000 soldiers.
The United States has 305,000 Army and Air Force troops in Western Europe, to which are added the smaller forces of Britain, France and other NATO nations.
 
Surprise Attack More Remote
The unilateral withdrawal of 50,000 men and 5,000 tanks from Eastern Europe - announced in December by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in an address at the United Nations - will limit Moscow's capability for surprise attack. It also has given Eastern Europeans an impression that Moscow has begun to consider a more far-reaching withdrawal.
A new East-West conventional arms agreement that is being negotiated in Vienna would require much more of Moscow, erasing the Soviet Union's longstanding advantages in ground forces. The upheaval in Eastern Europe now threatens to outpace the negotiations despite President Bush's goal of achieving an early accord.
To some, the recent developments are nothing but good news. Others are more cautious.
East Germany's Ambassador to Washington, Gerhard Herder, warned today in an appearance at the National Press Club that the situation in his country must be carefully handled by all parties. He said a miscalculation could lead to armed conflict between East German and nearby American, British or French troops.
A senior Pentagon official, while welcoming the change, also sounded a note of caution.
The rapid pace of change in Eastern Europe carries the risk of dangerous instability, he said. And he emphasized that Moscow's concurrent talk of dissolving the Warsaw Pact and NATO alliances was most unwelcome.
''I think they are very much playing the game of trying to drive us out of Europe,'' he said.

HEADLINE: In Hartford, Drug Wars May Broaden Concern

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Nov. 10

 BODY:
Little more than a mile from the glass skyscrapers of downtown and the gold-leaf dome of the state Capitol, teen-age gangs are locked in what the police say is the city's worst blood feud since the cocaine business took root here.
In the last month, three youths - 15, 16 and 18 years old - have been slain and four others have been shot in drive-by or ambush attacks.
On an island of urban poverty surrounded by well-tended New England industry and affluence, the gang war has highlighted the worlds of rich and poor that coexist at the center of this state's society.
With 138,000 people crammed onto 17.8 square miles - neighboring Bloomfield has 19,500 in 26.4 square miles - Hartford is the core of a metropolis of about 740,000 people who live in dozens of towns and cities. 
 
Waking the Sleeping Giant
In a state with the nation's highest per capita income, Hartford is the nation's fourth poorest city among those with populations over 100,000, the 1980 census says. City officials say the ranking has not changed significantly since the census listing.
Hartford's public schools are about 90 percent black and Puerto Rican; outside the city, the schools are overwhelmingly white. In the city's poorest section, the North End, unemployment is at least 30 percent, according to city officials; in neighboring towns, the rate is under 4 percent, and in several, under 2 percent.
City officials say that making the suburbs - and their 100,000 residents who commute to jobs in Hartford every day - realize their relationship with Hartford's poverty has long been the city's main hope for the future.
The surge of killings, they say, may shock some people into that realization. While the traditions of small town home rule may persist, suburban residents are going to have to accept that the inner city of Hartford is the inner city of the region.
''The bunching up of the killings has been horrible - on the other hand, because of the bunching up, it has awakened the sleeping giant,'' said Hartford's Mayor, Carrie Saxon Perry. ''I see them more willing to listen and say 'maybe there is something more we should be doing.' ''
In a city that depends heavily on big banks and insurance companies for its tax base, questions are also being asked about how much more the city can do by itself.
In the last year, a soft real-estate market has stalled several big office-tower projects in which developers had pledged millions of dollars for subsidized housing and other projects to help the poor.
Since early 1988, the amount of vacant office space - an important measure of downtown vitality - has about doubled, to 13.4 percent in the central business district, according to Cushman & Wakefield, a commercial real-estate company.
 
Less Attractive to Business
A spokesman for the state's insurance industry trade association said that changes in technology, higher local and state taxes and transportation problems are making the city less attractive as a place for business to expand.
H. Craig Leroy, president of the Insurance Association of Connecticut, said, ''It's becoming more difficult to justify locating in the city of Hartford.''
In the last decade, the city's largest employer, the Aetna Life and Casualty Company, has expanded and moved operations employing 7,000 workers to the nearby communities of Middletown and Windsor. Meanwhile, the company's employment in Hartford has fallen by 2,606, from 11,514 in 1980 to 8,908 this year.
A spokesman for Aetna, Jason Wright, said the company remains committed to Hartford. But he added, ''Hartford is not the city, it's the region.''
 
Bitterness and Resignation
Mayor Perry, who was elected to a second term on Tuesday, said that pressure for a regional identity is coming from the state, which wants to coordinate plans for affordable housing, and from a school integration lawsuit that could result in school districts being merged or coordinated across city lines for the first time. Connecticut has no county governments, which in many states deal with shared regional problems.
For now, Hartford's problems are largely its own. A spokesman for the Hartford police, Sgt. Charles S. Morris, said the wave of violence that began with the shotgun slaying of two gang members in the city's North End on Oct. 13 will almost certainly continue.
Retaliation, including the drive-by shootings of two brothers who were wounded on consecutive days last week, has raised tension, he said.
Sergeant Morris said that the police have identified about 300 gang members and six gangs or posses in the city. But most of the violence has been traced to a core of 25 to 28 ''constantly feuding'' members, he said.
The Albany Avenue Posse, which takes its name from the thoroughfare through Hartford's North End, and the Park Street Posse, centered only a few blocks from the Capitol, have been particularly prone to violence against competitors, he said.
On Adams Street in the North End, where one of the shootings occurred last month, three teen-agers spoke of the shootings with bitterness, but resignation. Greed, vengeance and ready access to firearms have made violence an accepted part of the drug business, they said.
''As long as brothers are selling drugs, they're going to be shooting because people are jealous that they don't have the money and gold and stuff like that,'' said Joe Lindsey, a tall, slim 19-year-old with a heavy gold chain around his neck.
''It ain't going to cool down,'' he said. ''It ain't going to cool down.''

HEADLINE: Koch Resists Ideas Backed By Dinkins

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
Mayor Edward I. Koch issued a 10-point warning yesterday about the future of New York City, one that seemed to be directed largely at positions and ideas endorsed by David N. Dinkins, the Mayor-elect.
Having vowed on Wednesday not to criticize his successor for six months, Mayor Koch already seemed to be proposing an agenda against which Mr. Dinkins's performance might be judged - although he preferred to liken his speech to Washington's farewell address to his officers.
''The city's new leaders will be called upon to implement new programs that have tremendous symbolic appeal,'' Mr. Koch told members of the City Club of New York, in his 12th and final talk as mayor to that good-government group, with which he has been at odds more than once.
''They should be careful not to send the wrong signal to the employers and taxpayers who foot the bills,'' the Mayor said. ''They should also be careful not to implement changes that divide the city against itself.'' 
 
Rent Control and Health Benefits
Specifically, Mr. Koch warned against commercial rent control, an all-civilian police complaint review board, legislation to prevent apartment ''warehousing,'' racial set-asides in city hiring and judicial appointments through patronage rather than merit selection.
He urged that the city not reject a home port for Navy ships on Staten Island. He pleaded for caution in adopting more measures to deny city business to companies with ties to South Africa.
Mr. Koch also said the city should not pay health benefits to unmarried partners of municipal employees, unless that arrangement were reached through collective bargaining. He criticized the concept of comparable worth, in which jobs with equal skill, effort and responsibility are paid equally.
And, in what might have been a pointed aside to Mr. Dinkins, who enjoyed considerable union support, Mr. Koch said: ''A mayor cannot sit on both sides of the bargaining table. If he does, it will come back to haunt him and it will make it more difficult to balance the city's budget. The mayor is management.''
In almost every case - with some exceptions like merit selection - Mr. Koch described positions opposite to those taken by Mr. Dinkins. But when he was asked whether he was directing his points to the Mayor-elect, Mr. Koch said, ''Why don't you look at this as the kind of speech that could be delivered at Fraunces Tavern?''
 
'Have Agreed to Disagree'
The Dinkins camp greeted the speech with equanimity. ''Ed Koch never said, nor did David ever presume, that his support in the general election would mean that he would now agree with every position of David Dinkins,'' said David M. Fishlow, a spokesman for Mr. Dinkins.
''David and the Mayor have agreed to disagree on issues and work together on the general-election campaign and the transition,'' Mr. Fishlow said.
Mr. Dinkins favors a form of commercial rent control involving arbitration. Yesterday, Mr. Koch said commercial rent control ''would have a chilling effect on an already cool economy.''
Mr. Koch warned against creating an all-civilian board to investigate complaints against the police, which Mr. Dinkins favors. As it is now, half of the board members are employees of the Police Department. The Mayor said any effort to advance the all-civilian board might result in an ''ugly, divisive referendum.''
In the matter of legislation meant to prevent apartments from being ''warehoused'' - that is, kept off the market - Mr. Koch said the idea was a ''fraud'' in that would make no difference in the city's housing market but would ''send another negative signal to the business community.'' Mr. Dinkins favors anti-warehousing legislation.
Mayor Koch warned about further limiting the business done by the city with companies that have corporate links to South Africa. Mr. Dinkins favors strengthening anti-apartheid measures but Mr. Koch said if too many companies were excluded from city contracts, ''the city might be forced to accept bids that cost millions of dollars more.''
 
'I've Changed My Mind'
The Mayor urged the city not to scrap its agreement to provide a home port for a naval surface action group. Mr. Dinkins is opposed to the home port. ''No one likes the idea of war,'' Mr. Koch said, ''especially a war fought with nuclear weapons. But it's foolish to think we can avoid war by engaging in unilateral disarmament.''
As to the extent to which he and Mr. Dinkins differed, Mr. Koch said, ''I hope he changes his mind as a result of having the responsibility of running the city.''
''When you come in,'' he said, ''and you recognize what the problems are and that the solutions you proposed make no sense, there's nothing wrong with changing your mind. I've changed my mind.''
The audience greeted Mayor Koch warmly, listened attentively and lined up to ask questions afterward, most of which were gentle and respectful.
There was a lot of laughter when Mr. Koch described his dismay at discovering the fallacy of presuming that his wishes would be carried out by the bureaucracy. Civil servants could be unhelpful, he said, and ''they know they're going to be there long after you're dead.''
At the outset of the gathering, at Sardi's restaurant on West 44th Street, Peter Samton, the president of the City Club, made an oblique reference to past battles between club members and the Koch administration when he introduced Sally Goodgold, the chairwoman, as ''someone who can go one-on-one with our special guest.''
Mayor Koch, who was seated next to the lectern, looked up. ''And has, quite successfully,'' he said.
''But not today,'' Ms. Goodgold said.

HEADLINE: Nassau County Proposes to Cut Property Taxes

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 10

 BODY:
Nassau County, under fierce pressure from homeowners to lower property taxes, proposed today a $1.62 billion budget for next year that would reduce county property taxes by almost 3 percent.
The proposed budget would be 4.3 percent higher than the current one, a sign of the austere times facing county and state governments throughout New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
Anger over rising tax bills on Long Island helped oust two incumbent Suffolk County legislators in primary races and two more in the general election on Tuesday, and the furor contributed to showings that were poorer than expected by Republican candidates, who dominate Nassau politics. 
With that message in mind, Nassau officials proposed a fiscal plan that would eliminate 200 vacant positions, from secretaries to groundskeepers, but would maintain health and social services, would call for hiring 61 additional correction officers and would allow a small tax cut. $25 Average Saving The proposed budget ''contains no new initiatives, no fee increases and cuts positions,'' said County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta, a Republican, who was re-elected on Tuesday. He announced the proposed budget at a news conference at his office here.
Under Mr. Gulotta's plan, most homeowners would pay an average of $25 less in county property taxes than last year, lowering the total average bill to $881. The rate would be $12.95 per $100 of assessed valuation.
Another factor could be that the sluggish economy may be picking up. Sales-tax revenues increased 7 percent in the third quarter over the same quarter a year ago, Mr. Gulotta said, leading officials to project a 2.3 percent increase in sales taxes next year.
County taxes account for 22 percent of a homeowner's tax bill, which includes school and town taxes, as well as assessments for services like garbage and water districts.
 
Elimination of 200 Jobs
Mr. Gulotta said his budget offered the small tax cut despite an 11 percent increase from a year ago in costs mandated by the Federal and state governments in areas like as Medicaid and education for handicapped children.
Offsetting the rising costs would be savings, which are to be outlined on Monday, including eliminating the 200 jobs, largely through automation and the merging of responsibilities.
Last year, the county raised property taxes 12 percent, mainly to make up for a loss of $95 million in sales taxes.
Mr. Gulotta's proposed budget would include additional Health Department and social workers, whose salaries the state would partly reimburse. In some cases, Mr. Gulotta said, hiring employees saved money. Adding the correction officers, he said, would cost the county less than the $14 million in overtime it is paying officers this year.
The budget goes to the six-member Board of Supervisors, who have until Dec. 18 to adopt or amend it.

Companies
 The chairman of Ford will retire on March 1, about a year and a half earlier than expected. Donald E. Petersen, 63, will be succeeded by Harold A. Poling, 64, now the vice chairman and chief operating officer. Ford said Mr. Poling would retire in three years. Under Mr. Petersen, Ford fought back from a grim performance in the recession of the early 1980's to become the most profitable of the Big Three auto companies. Mr. Petersen said his decision was based on a need ''to make a change in my life.'' [Page 35.] Mattel lost a 12-year legal battle it had been waging with an inventor who filed a patent-infringement suit over the toy company's Hot Wheels miniature cars. A Federal jury in Chicago ordered Mattel to pay $24.8 million in damages. Mattel said it would appeal. [35.] Colorizing movies has proved a disappointing business. The costs of putting color in black-and-white movies are much greater than expected, and the practice has been resisted by people who consider it tampering with works of art. HEADLINE: Little Gold in Coloring Old Films

BYLINE: By MICHAEL LEV, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 10

 BODY:
When color versions of such vintage black-and-white films as ''Yankee Doodle Dandy'' and ''Topper'' began appearing on television in 1986, executives in the color-converting business thought they saw a bright new industry emerging.
They calculated that if just 10 percent of the thousands of old movies and TV episodes were converted to color, the converters could rack up more than $1 billion in revenues.
But a combination of high costs and some resistance to tampering with the originals has kept those high expectations from materializing. While the public seems to have accepted the alterations, many Hollywood executives, directors and actors quickly rejected what the industry calls ''colorizing'' as a travesty, and some studios declined to participate.
 
Costs Are High
More fundamentally, the computer technology required, for example, to make the Christmas tree green in ''It's a Wonderful Life,'' took longer to perfect and cost more than expected. 
''If the cost of coloring was $1,000 a minute I'd be a very rich man, but it's not,'' said Patrick C. Byrne, president of Tintoretto Inc., a Toronto-based colorizer. Mr. Byrne said colorizers must often charge the owner of the film, frequently a studio or distributor, $2,500 to $3,000 a minute for a film that runs 100 minutes or more.
One reason for the high cost is that the conversion process is labor-intensive, requiring many highly specialized operators using costly computer equipment.
Color Systems Technology Inc., the first American company in the business, converted many films at a huge loss. Color Systems miscalculated the price it should charge because it ran into unforeseen problems in mastering the new technology. As a result, it has never turned a profit and has amassed $19 million in debt.
 
Stock Down Sharply
If Color Systems, based in suburban Los Angeles with 165 employees, fails to renegotiate with creditors, the company may collapse, analysts say. Color Systems' stock, once at $29.50, closed today at $1.75, down 12 1/2 cents, on the American Stock Exchange.
''They've spun into oblivion,'' said David Garcia, an analyst with the Howard, Weil Financial Corporation. ''Color Systems won't be economically viable.''
Colorization Inc., another Toronto-based company, also finds itself in a financial bind. The company is half-owned by Qintex Entertainment Inc., which filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code in October. Qintex Entertainment, of Los Angeles, is owned in part by the Qintex Group of Australia, which failed in a recent bid to acquire the MGM/UA Communications Company.
Colorization Inc.'s principal client is Qintex Entertainment, which is paying the company to convert episodes of the ''McHale's Navy'' television series to color. With the future of Qintex Entertainment now in question, Colorization Inc.'s prospects are also suddenly clouded.
 
'Mismanagement' Reported
Tintoretto has been in business more than two years but has completed only two films while losing $3 million because of ''mismanagement'' by former executives, said Mr. Byrne, the company's president.
''We suffered from poor art direction,'' said Mr. Byrne, who added that Tintoretto was recovering and negotiating with new customers.
The strongest player in the color-conversion industry, American Film Technologies Inc. of Wayne, Pa., seems to be losing interest in that part of its operations. The company earned $622,000 in the fiscal year 1989 on sales of $11.6 million. It expects to earn $4.5 million to $5 million this year on sales of $20 million.
As a byproduct of its colorizing business, American Film developed a computerized, or ''paperless,'' animation technique that company officials say will ultimately be far more profitable than color conversion. In two to three years, the company said, it hopes to derive 70 percent of its revenues from animation.
''We'll be very satisfied converting eight to ten pictures a month, because we see an upside in paperless animation that quite frankly outweighs coloring motion pictures by a ratio of 50 to 1,'' said Robert L. Glaser, American Film's president.
 
Public Acceptance Seen
The troubles these companies face do not result from a rejection of colorized films by the public. And no one in the industry is saying that color conversion will die out.
Even troubled Color Systems has three shifts a day at computer consoles to give a new look to sometimes-forgotten films like ''Manhattan Melodrama,'' starring Clark Gable.
Turner Broadcasting System Inc., which holds 2,500 black-and-white films in its library, already owns 100 colorized films and has contracts to convert 24 more with American Film and 12 more at Color Systems.
Roger L. Mayer, president of the Turner Entertainment Company, a subsidiary of Turner Broadcasting, said that when his company spends $250,000 to $270,000 to colorize a film it can recoup two to three times that amount in two years through domestic and international syndication to television stations and Turner's own cable outlets, the TBS Superstation and Turner Network Television.
''We find as distributors, to say nothing of our position as an exhibitor, that people, particularly young people, prefer color to black and white,'' Mr. Mayer said.
 
Industry Heartened
The commitment made by Turner, which shows as many as three newly converted color films every month on TBS and TNT, is heartening to industry executives like Norman Glick, chairman of Colorization Inc.
''I believe there is life in the hereafter in the colorization business, but it's going to take some courage,'' said Mr. Glick, who is also president of Colorization's half-owner, Glenex Industries. ''People thought the industry would blossom a lot sooner.''
One reason Turner is by far the largest customer of the colorizing business is that it owns a film library and cable outlets in addition to a distribution network.
''The individual studios don't have the cable network,'' Mr. Byrne of Tintoretto said. ''Many are reluctant to spend the money before they know they can get air time.''
Mr. Glaser of American Film said the industry still suffered from the debate over the merits of colorizing. ''Some of the major studios feel they don't want to step on the toes of the Directors Guild,'' he said. Many film directors oppose film coloring.
Color Systems faced major problems in its early years with cost overruns and bad color quality. Its executives now say they have improved quality and pared costs to the point where operations are profitable, even though the large debt remains.
Buddy Young, Color Systems' president, said the company hopes to woo new investors, perhaps through a limited partnership that would acquire the rights to old television series. Color Systems would keep part of the profits generated through syndication.
 
A Digital System
A similar plan worked at American Film Technologies, which acquired the rights to several Sherlock Holmes mysteries and then distributed the colorized versions on video at a profit, Mr. Glaser said.
Industry executives say American Film has had more success because it uses a more efficient system - a digital process.
When a black-and-white film is converted to color, it gains a new copyright. Many films now or soon to be in the public domain could make money for new owners, Mr. Young said.
And with film libraries changing hands in deals like the acquisition of Columbia Pictures by the Sony Corporation, he said, more companies may be willing to invest $250,000 in a film, in hopes of raising its potential value to $750,000 or more.
Mr. Young said he was particularly optimistic about the European market, where deregulation has spawned scores of new television stations.
''Europeans were not weaned on black-and-white television,'' Mr. Young said. ''Now that all these stations are proliferating, they need product, and black and white isn't going to fly.''
Even in the United States, the colorizers now say old television series like ''I Love Lucy'' are better candidates for profitable colorization than movies because they are less subject to criticism as altered icons and also cost less to colorize than films.
''If you produce a half-hour TV show, it can cost you $700,000,'' said Mr. Glick of Colorization. ''To color an episode is $60,000. Really, you're creating a brand-new product for $60,000, which could find a market worldwide.''

HEADLINE: Ford Motor Chairman To Retire

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DEARBORN, Mich., Nov. 10

 BODY:
Donald E. Petersen, the executive who helped bring the Ford Motor Company from the edge of financial disaster to a ranking as the most profitable of the Big Three auto makers, said he would retire on March 1 as chairman and chief executive, about a year and a half earlier than expected.
Ford simultaneously announced that Mr. Petersen's successor will be Harold A. Poling, 64 years old, vice chairman and chief operating officer. After three years in that post, Mr. Petersen is to retire.
Mr. Petersen, 63, was a product planner who early in his career worked on the development of the Ford LTD, Mustang, Maverick and Continental Mark III. Mr. Poling is a financial expert. 
 
New Lineup
Philip E. Benton Jr., 60, head of the company's automotive group, was named president of the corporation and chief operating officer, succeeding Mr. Poling. Allan D. Gilmour, 55, an executive vice president who had been considered a top candidate to succeed Mr. Petersen, was named president in charge of all of Ford's automotive businesses. Ford had disclaimed such speculation, and the company said it had no succession plan for the time Mr. Poling retires.
Messrs. Poling, Benton and Gilmour, along with Stanley Seneker, the chief financial officer, will make up Ford's office of the chief executive, Mr. Petersen said.
Under Mr. Petersen, Ford fought back from a grim performance in the recession of the early 1980's to become a profitable and much admired corporate model. Market Share Gained Ford has steadily gained market share in the United States in recent years. Until last summer, Ford reported higher profits in each quarter for the last three years, and the company's earnings surpassed those of General Motors in each of the last two fiscal years.
Mr. Petersen was known for his style of influencing subordinates to seek a consensus, in contrast to the more autocratic style of Ford's past leaders. His policy of giving designers more latitude led to the development of the highly successful 1983 Thunderbird. He is also credited with helping to improve quality and with fostering the creative environment that produced the popular Taurus and Sable models.
Mr. Poling, who said he had reconciled himself to never being chief executive, said the automobile industry was heading into a cyclical decline, which means he may be taking the reins as car sales and profits slip.
Mr. Petersen's decision surprised many high company officials; it was kept secret until today from all but a very few friends, family members and associates. Mr. Gilmour said he learned of the developments only on Thursday.
At a news conference, Mr. Petersen fought back tears as he said that 10 years as chief operating officer and chief executive, capping a 40-year career at Ford, was enough. He cited a need ''to make a change in my life.''
Appearing fit and saying his health was excellent, Mr. Petersen emphasized that no conflicts or disappointments had prompted his sudden move.
He got the idea of retiring early last March, he said, when William Clay Ford retired as vice chairman after 40 years, at age 63. On reflection, he said, he realized he had had little time to himself and with his family during his career. During the last few years, he said, his job has frequently required seven days a week of intercontinental travel, speaking engagements, ceremonial functions and meetings. ''While the demands of the job have increased, my energy level is progressively declining,'' he said, smiling. Aside from weariness, he said there was the matter of individual growth , and he cited the thoughts of an educator at his alma mater.
''I have been struck with the philosophy of Ernie Arbuckle, who at one time was the dean of Stanford's graduate business school,'' he said. ''He followed a plan to change occupations every 10 years. He called it repotting himself. Well, 10 years are up, and it's time to repot myself.''
He said another important factor in his decision was that Mr. Poling might have to retire without having had a chance to be chief executive. ''It bothered me,'' Mr. Petersen said. ''It seemed Red wasn't going to have his chance, and that was wrong.''
Two weeks ago Mr. Petersen asked Mr. Poling whether he would be willing to stay on past retirement. ''It was quite a surprise,'' Mr. Poling said. ''I had to talk to my wife about it.'' Ford's board approved the plan on Thursday.
Mr. Poling will stay at Ford about two years past his expected retirement at age 65. Ford does not have a mandatory retirement policy, but 65 is the customary age of retirement for most executives and managers.
Mr. Petersen said he hopes to play more tennis, to spend more time with his family and to slow down during the next year before deciding on his future plans.
Mr. Poling, a native of Detroit who started as a college trainee in the company's steel division, worked his way through financial management jobs, becoming executive vice president in charge of North American automotive operations in 1980 and chief operating officer in 1985.
Just two weeks ago Mr. Poling was looking for office space as part of a retirement plan to work for Ford on a consulting basis. ''I just told the kids this morning,'' he said. ''They are pretty excited.'' He has three children and two grandchildren.
Mr. Gilmour, who joined Ford in 1960, has been in mostly financial jobs until recent years, when he was given responsibility for overseas operations. Among his past jobs are president of Ford Motor Credit, controller of the corporation, head of government affairs and labor relations and chief financial officer.
Mr. Benton has been in charge of nonautomotive operations and has broad experience in sales and marketing for the North American automotive operations.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
East German Events Seen Lifting Dollar

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The dollar rose yesterday against the West German mark and other European currencies in gains traders attributed to the opening of East Germany's borders.
The rapid changes in East Germany, traders said, are creating short-run uncertainty, though traders said the situation could have positive long-term effects for Europe and the Western alliance. Initially, however, this kind of political uncertainty usually causes traders and investors to seek safety in the dollar.
''There is uncertainty about the Soviet response and the Warsaw Pact response to the pace of change,'' said Paul Kimball, a managing director at Morgan Stanley & Company. ''And when you are uncertain, you get closer to home.'' 
 
Smaller Gain Against Yen
In late trading in New York, the dollar was at 1.8675 marks, up from 1.8520 on Thursday, but down from its 1.8690 high for the day. But the dollar gained less against the yen; it was at 143.45 yen, up from 143.05 on Thursday.
Gold prices eased. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted a 4 P.M. bid of $386.25 a troy ounce, down from $386.30 late Thursday. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold lost 30 cents an ounce, closing at $386.80.
The dollar also rose against the Swiss franc, jumping to 1.6435, up from 1.6250 Thursday. But some traders said this had more to do with the underlying weakness of the currency than the situation in East Germany. In addition, the dollar gained against the pound, closing in New York at $1.5773, compared with $1.5823 Thursday.
The dollar's climb was not that sharp when compared with some other days this year, when the dollar has been fairly volatile. And traders were divided over whether this rally would continue and possibly force another round of dollar selling by central banks to keep the currency in line. At 143.45 yen, the dollar is already above the 140 ceiling believed set for it by the United States and its economic allies. And at 1.8675 marks, the dollar is again beginning to move toward the 1.90 ceiling.
The United States and its allies in the Group of Seven have fought to keep the dollar in line. They have issued communiques saying the dollar is too high, changed interest rates, and sold billions in the foreign exchange market to push the dollar lower. And since the stock market plunge of Oct. 13, the dollar has been back in line, at least against the mark.
Hubert Pedroli, vice president at Credit Suisse in New York, said he thought the dollar was now moving higher. But he also said that the September trade deficit number, scheduled for release Thursday, could have a big impact on the outlook, especially if it indicates that the deficit is growing again. The August trade deficit was $10.8 billion, up from $8.2 billion in July.
 
Looking for Signals
Mr. Pedroli suggested that the uncertainty in the market could continue until next month's United States-Soviet Union summit meeting between Presidents Bush and Mikhail S. Gorbachev. He said the changes in Eastern Europe ''go beyond the understanding of the average foreign exchange trader,'' and they will be looking for any strong signals of what to expect.
Liliana Nealon, vice president for foreign exchange at Union Bank of Switzerland, said that the slowing American economy, lower corporate profits and further declines in the stock market could again push the dollar lower.
One reason for yesterday's rise is that many traders had aggressively sold dollars for West German marks after the Dow Jones industrial average fell 190 points on Oct. 13. But after markets became calmer, they found themselves overloaded with marks, especially in light of the uncertainity in East Germany.
The mark also fell against the Japanese yen, partly because of rumors early in the day that the Japanese would raise interest rates next week. Because West Germany has moved much more aggressively than Japan to raise interest rates this year, the yen has remained much stronger against the dollar in recent weeks.

HEADLINE: Your Money

BYLINE: By Jan M. Rosen;
Paying the Maid Requires Care

 BODY:
People who pay for child care or who pay household workers like maids and gardeners face special tax reporting and withholding requirements. And they should be sure they have complied with the requirements within 1989 - not wait until next spring when filing their tax returns.
This year for the first time, for example, people claiming a child and dependent-care credit on their tax returns are required to list the name, address and Social Security number of the worker, or if the service is provided by an agency, the Federal employer identification number, on Form 2441.
The Government can then use its computers to match this information with the recipient's tax return to be sure the income is reported and, if the recipient is legally an employee, can check to be sure the payer has withheld Social Security tax and paid the employer's share. Both the employee and employer owe 7.51 percent of wages beginning at $50 per quarter and going up to $48,000 a year. The employer may also be liable for quarterly state unemployment insurance contributions. 
Social Security payments are due quarterly with Form 942, said Richard J. Stricof, a tax partner with BDO Seidman in New York. Individuals, unlike businesses, are not required to withhold income tax from domestic employees unless they request it, he added.
Nor do Social Security taxes have to be withheld for independent contractors like painters or plumbers. Unlike those engaged in a trade or business, individuals are not required to file information returns, Form 1099, for payments made to independent contractors, but it is important to be sure that legally the person really is an independent contractor and not the payer's employee.
''This is an area of widespread noncompliance,'' said Julian Block, a tax lawyer in Larchmont, N.Y. ''Often employees say, 'I'm not going to work for you if you report it,' '' he said, and many employers also want to avoid the cost and the paperwork.
But, he warned, ''The costs of not complying far outweigh the costs of complying.'' A woman in Mississippi failed to pay Social Security taxes for her maid for years, he recalled. ''Her words were, 'Let's just let sleeping dogs lie.' '' But the maid - a human being, not a sleeping dog - eventually retired and filed for Social Security. She had records of what she had been paid, and her former employer had to pay both the tax and thousands of dollars of interest and penalties.
If an employer has failed to withhold income and Social Security taxes, the employee is still liable for the taxes. If he or she does not pay the taxes, the I.R.S. will try to collect them. But if it cannot, the employer may be held liable for a portion of the employee's taxes, Mr. Stricof noted.
People may be unsure if a person they pay for services - a private-duty nurse or a governess or gardener provided by an agency, for example - is an employee or an independent contractor.
Wilson Fadely, a spokesman for the Internal Revenue Service, said the first step was to ask the agency or hospital that refers the person. ''You can have lots of different scenarios,'' he said. The person might be an employee of the hospital or agency, rather than of the person receiving the service or he or she might be an independent contractor.
''Section 3506 of the I.R.S. code is very specific in regard to sitters for children or the elderly or disabled,'' he said. If the parent or relative gets the sitter through an organization and pays the sitter who, in turn, must pay the organization a fee, the sitter is an independent contractor, he said, so there are no withholding requirements.
But the law is less specific about drivers, gardeners and others who may work in private homes. Gardeners or maids might work a half day a week in 10 different homes, for example, but may still be employees, not independent contractors. In the case of employees, the homeowners have the right to exercise control over their work. So all 10 employers would have to file Forms 942 and W-2.
Payers who are uncertain may request a ruling by filing Form SS-8. Any tax forms or publications needed are available at I.R.S. offices or can be requested by calling 1-800-424-FORM toll-free, he said. I.R.S. publication 926 explains employment taxes for household employers in detail.
One way to avoid tax difficulties is to hire domestic help through agencies that send out employees.
''We get the SWAT team,'' said a partner at a national accounting firm. He and his wife work, so on Saturday morning, an agency sends a half-dozen workers to clean house. ''It's done in an hour, and there are no reporting requirements,'' he said.
Another advantage of such an arrangement, Mr. Block said, is that an agency is insured and bonds its employees. Still, many people would rather have someone they know personally, he added, so they are willing to pay both the employee's and employer's share of the Social Security tax. For a part-time maid who is paid $50 a week, or $2,600 a year, that comes to just under $400.
