SECTION: Section 2; Page 29, Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1066 words

HEADLINE: RECORDINGS;
Tempos That Tell More Than Time

BYLINE: By PETER WATROUS

 BODY:
Three recent albums of almost nonstop brilliance by the pianist Andrew Hill, 52 years old, the alto saxophonist Frank Morgan, 55, and the flugelhornist Art Farmer, 61, are good examples of how, for jazz musicians, age amplifies control. The critic Hugh Kenner once wrote that art is the accumulation of detail; in jazz, detail derives from constant playing and the experience that comes with age.
On all three albums the nuances come through in the tempos. Each performer uses carefully shaded speeds to reach emotions often overlooked by younger musicians. The tunes creep ominously, or they stumble or slink; the unusual tempos can extract longing, fear and alienation from a composition, or warmth and love. Avoiding cliche, they make all three albums, in varying degrees, advertisements for the pleasures of classical jazz orthodoxies. 
Age in jazz also bestows, if not a loss of nerve, a retreat from the aggression and hardheadedness of youth into the embracing arms of tradition. The challenge for older musicians is no longer to destroy the rules of jazz, but to use them as freely as possible. All three albums show how jazz orthodoxies can be subtly distorted to yield the pleasures that long ago vanished under cliches.
Andrew Hill's ''Eternal Spirit'' (Blue Note 7 92051; all three formats) features a quintet with Greg Osby on alto saxophone, Bobby Hutcherson on vibes, Rufus Reid on bass and Ben Riley on drums. It is the first album Mr. Hill has released in nearly 20 years that captures the rigorous logic and experimentalism of his string of Blue Note albums in the 1960's. An eccentric pianist whose best work exhibited the possibilities of combining new (for jazz) meters with impressionistic harmonies, he was eclipsed by McCoy Tyner and Herbie Hancock, the two dominant jazz pianists of the 1960's.
Mr. Hill is more abrupt, more iconoclastic than either of them. His pieces scuttle sideways, crablike, or settle into brooding, stormy emotionality. On ''Eternal Spirit,'' which he prepared in a five-day stint at the Knitting Factory in Manhattan, his pungent yet elliptical compositions, laden with a feeling of cold anomie, are underscored by tempos that grind against conventional speed and feel dislocated and slightly uncomfortable. On ''Pinnacle,'' a classically angular tune, the tempo inches forward, uncertainly and with bluster; an alternate take found on the CD offers a slightly brighter version, which changes the mood radically.
It also changes the solos. Mr. Osby is an extraordinary young musician, whose improvisations pair hurtling lines with jangling, abstract melodies and are among the album's high points. On the original take of ''Pinnacle,'' he measures out a tender solo that jars the harmony into releasing unexpected colors. On the second take, he sounds as if he were in a burning house, with all the doors slowly shutting; nervous and skittish, he races through the tune.
Age allows for other nuances as well. In ''Mood Indigo'' (Antilles 7 91320; all three formats), Frank Morgan has made his best album ever. Some credit goes to the wise production work of John Snyder, which intersperses duets between Mr. Morgan and the pianist George Cables with quartet sections, two tunes featuring the trumpeter Wynton Marsalis and a snippet of an unaccompanied bass solo by Buster Williams. There is also a short talk at the end by Mr. Morgan. The effect is like chapters in a book, keeping a plot unfolding and breaking the tedium.
Mr. Morgan is one of jazz's most personal and passionate soloists, and the album rarely breaks into more than a trot; its mood is autumnal and intimate, full of lovers' whispers. The tempos, withholding easy gratification, help the mood, but Mr. Morgan's playing, constantly varied in rhythm and tone, does most of the work. Nowhere is this more evident - and it's helped by a recording that captures every breath - than in his duets with Mr. Marsalis.
Mr. Marsalis's opinions may be subject to debate, but his technical prowess isn't; he's an adept soloist. Mr. Morgan, however, makes him sound merely talented. On ''Bessie's Blues,'' set at the sort of relaxed tempo that allows musicians to take their time and reach a profound level of improvisation, Mr. Marsalis solos first, carefully. Harmonically sophisticated and well plotted, his solo sounds preconceived. Mr. Morgan comes in, playing with the rhythms of Mr. Marsalis's last phrase, bending notes, tagging flourishes to bold statements of melodies. Phrases wheel off, ending in flutters; Mr. Morgan varies his tone from line to line, reaching a climax with clear yelps, then descending into woolly and round honks. At times evasive and oblique, he'll suddenly confront a listener with a tough melody. Like a good boxer, he's continuously resourceful, jabbing from all angles.
A subdued, intimate mood also prevails on Art Farmer's ''Ph. D.'' (Contemporary 14055; all three formats), which features the guitarist Kenny Burrell and the saxophonist Clifford Jordan in the front line as well.
Mr. Farmer, who lives in Vienna but came onto the California scene in the late 1940's as one of the most gifted of the second generation be-boppers, is often described as a lyrical musician. He's more than that. Having trimmed all the fat from his playing, he's become a minimalist. The smallest rhythmic intensification is picked up and magnified; lines and melodies are likely to be separated by long inhalations of breath. On a tune like James Williams's ''Ph. D.,'' set at an anxious, creeping tempo, Mr. Farmer's dreamlike flugelhorn floats gently, occasionally flickering. The perfectly shaped albums Mr. Farmer has been releasing for the last three years have all had Mr. Jordan on them, and he is simply extraordinary here, with clearly defined ideas that march up melodic steps, then bounce into the basement, riding a low honk.
Like the other two albums, ''Ph. D.'' is well conceived and arranged. There is a sense in all the recordings that decisions have been made, that the economics of jazz, usually horrible, have for once allowed the composers the time and capital to realize their visions. The shades and nuances of the music argue for the merits of age. It's not an argument likely to be heard - jazz, like the rest of American culture is enthralled by youth - but the subtle manipulations of standard material offer a way out of stagnation.

GRAPHIC: Andrew Hill (Outline/John Livzey)

LENGTH: 2189 words

HEADLINE: From Cash Cow To Cash Machine

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
Romeo J. Ventres knows exactly what he wants Borden Inc. to be when he retires in December 1991. He wants it to be the lowest-cost producer of all its products, from milk to pasta to plastics to glue. He wants it to have a decent mix of national and regional brands. He certainly wants it to be independent - a year ago, he and Borden's top 25 managers agreed to quit simultaneously in the event of a hostile takeover. But most important, he wants Borden to be a ''perpetual cash machine.''
Sounds almost like science fiction, but the 65-year-old Mr. Ventres, who has been Borden's chief executive since 1986, sees it as a practical goal - so much so that on Thursday, he told analysts that, over the next two years, Borden would spend $650 million to expand its plants, and would increase its advertising budget by between $75 million and $100 million.
Mr. Ventres's idea of a perpetual cash machine is a company that spends heavily to persuade consumers that its branded products, including even garden-variety items like milk, are better than generic versions. That means those brands can command premium prices, which, when combined with more efficient plants, means high margins - and more money for yet more advertising. 
It is all logical - but until now, it was also eminently undoable for the New York-based Borden. An effective advertising blitz requires two things: money, and products distributed widely enough to justify spending that money. Borden, thanks to the hefty cash flow that its dairy business provides even in bad times, has always had access to the money. The products, though, were a different story.
Borden used to be a crazy quilt of a company with a sizable stable of regional brands as unrelated as waffles and car-care products, but with most of its capital tied up in cyclical businesses like commodity chemicals and milk.
But since he took over, Mr. Ventres has been tinkering with the product mix and the organization chart to provide what he calls a ''critical mass'' of high-growth products. He has spun off commodity chemicals and 20 other businesses, accounting for about $932 million in annual sales, because they did not fit in to what he has designated as Borden's six ''strategic growth areas'': dairy, pasta, snacks, niche groceries like canned seafood or cheese substitutes, non-food consumer products like Elmer's Glue, and industrial films and adhesives.
And he bought even more quickly than he sold. Since 1986, Borden has spent $1.7 billion to buy 77 small companies. The purchases more than doubled the number of Borden's plants and pushed the company's annual sales to $7.2 billion last year - up 11.2 percent from 1987 - and its net income to $411.9 million, 16.8 percent higher than in 1987. More importantly, they gave Borden a nationwide distribution system and a stable of brands to take national through that system: Creamette pasta, Krunchers! kettle-cooked potato chips, Classico pasta sauces and a handful of others.
Now Borden's simultaneous slash-and-build strategy has peaked. On Sept. 28, Mr. Ventres announced that he would sell 20 of Borden's lowest-margin dairy plants, effectively shrinking Borden's mainstay dairy business by a third. He also said he would close 45 sundry grocery and snack plants, and transfer the products being made in them to existing, more modern plants, or to so-called hyperplants - huge, multiproduct facilities - that would be built with part of that $650 million Mr. Ventres committed last week.
''What all the acquiring has done is given us distribution, an ability to consolidate manufacturing and a shot at national brands,'' Mr. Ventres said in a recent interview in his Park Avenue office. ''We now have the mass to go for economies of scale.''
The short-term cost of the move is high: Borden set up a pretax reserve of $571 million to cover the plant-closing costs and severance payments to the approximately 7,000 of Borden's 46,000 workers who will lose their jobs. The company is likely to end this year between $47 million and $58 million in the red. Next year does not promise stellar returns either.
 
Mixed Reviews
 The restructuring is playing to mixed reviews on Wall Street. Borden's stock jumped $2.25, to $36.75 right after Mr. Ventres laid out his plans, yet fell a few days later, as investors realized how sparse the short-term payoffs would be. Mr. Ventres's spending announcements Thursday did not help, either.
Now some analysts wonder whether Mr. Ventres has cut too far into product lines, while others say he has not cut far enough. ''He's selling those dairy plants at the bottom of the dairy cycle,'' said John M. McMillin, an analyst with Prudential Bache who has a ''hold'' recommendation on Borden stock. With the 1988 drought long over, Mr. McMillin notes, pasture land and corn for feeding dairy herds is in greater supply, which means that milk will be cheaper to produce. ''He overreacted to a couple of bad quarters,'' Mr. McMillin said. ''Long-term returns would have been best served by sticking it out.'' William Leach, a food analyst with Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette, has only a ''weak'' buy recommendation on Borden stock, in good part because he feels Mr. Ventres is holding onto too much. ''It is ludicrous for one company to be in wall coverings and in pasta, and a strategic growth category like non-food consumer products can include half the G.N.P.,'' he said. ''I'd like to see them divide into two companies, with food in one and non-food in the other.''
Not surprisingly, Borden executives shrug off such comments. ''It's simple - we got rid of plants in areas that were oversupplied with dairy products,'' said Richard W. Fowlkes, president of the dairy division.
Anthony S. D'Amato, president of Borden's packaging and industrial products division, also gives his critics short shrift. ''A lot of packaging goes into food wrap, and the processes for making plastic film aren't that different from making pasta,'' he said. ''And we are the No. 1 company in the world in wall coverings. Why would we want to get rid of that?''
 
Confusion on the Street
 Still, Borden's diverse product mix has always given Wall Street a bad time. In 1986 Mr. Ventres set targets of 15 percent annual growth in earnings per share, 18 percent return on equity and assorted other goals. He has either met or exceeded each. Yet Borden's price/earnings multiple remains low. At the start of October, Borden stock was selling at about 84 percent of its earnings growth rate, compared with 120 percent for other food companies.
One reason is that investors have a hard time understanding Borden. Food analysts are not comfortable judging performance of, say, adhesives, while chemical analysts dismiss Borden as a food company.
Moreover, Borden has a somewhat chaotic structure. Although its official headquarters are in New York, nearly all of its executives are in Columbus, Ohio. Analysts grumble that they never get to see them. ''These are nameless, faceless people to us, and we need a chance to ask them questions,'' said William F. Maguire, an analyst with Merrill Lynch who nonetheless recommends that investors buy Borden stock.
Making matters worse, Borden's six strategic growth areas are crammed into four divisions that seem to have been put together by aimlessly throwing darts against an organizational chart.
Snacks, for example, are lumped together with international consumer products. Creamette pasta, a product that Borden is working hard to turn into a $120 million national brand, sits in the same group with niche groceries and specialty products, items whose very strengths are their regional nature. ''Their segment reporting really confuses analysts,'' said Mr. Leach.
Mr. Ventres, a strong-willed but even-tempered man, does not get riled by such criticism. Why keep the line people in expensive space in New York, he asks, when it is only he and the 20 or so legal, public relations and financial people on the corporate staff who need to be near the analysts and bankers? And as for the haphazard segments, ''Sure, some day we may set up separate divisions for high-growth areas like pasta or snacks,'' Mr. Ventres said. ''But for now, more divisions just means higher head count and more overhead. And that's the last thing I want.''
Indeed, cost-cutting seems as high a priority as advertising at Borden. In that sense, Mr. Ventres is returning to his roots.
In 1957, after receiving a degree in chemical engineering from Worcester Polytechnic Institute, he joined Borden's polyvinyl chloride operation in Leominster, Mass. In 1974 he left Borden to join a specialty chemicals company. When that company was sold five years later, Mr. Ventres returned to Borden as group vice president of the company's chemical division. He rose swiftly through the commodity chemical ranks, and was named Borden's president in 1985.
 
Learning the Business
 That same year, Gene Sullivan, then the chief executive, designated Mr. Ventres as his heir. So Mr. Ventres set about learning the food side of the business. He discovered that two cultures were living side by side at Borden: a commodity business, which invariably competes on price and thus revolves around keeping costs low, and branded foods, which stresses marketing and brand awareness rather than costs.
Mr. Ventres set out to meld the two cultures. He formed 12 teams, each a mixture of people from food and chemicals, and sent them to all the company's plants to see how they would improve on operations.
One team figured out how to make vegetable oil go further in snack processing. Another suggested closing aging ReaLemon and Cracker Jack plants in the Chicago area, and moving their production to a far newer Wyler's plant - the first of what has become a whole cadre of multiproduct plants at Borden. All told, the team approach yielded nearly $12 million in savings, and spawned an awards program for suggestions to improve safety and productivity that is still continuing.
Mr. Ventres insists that Borden will now concentrate on consolidation and cost-cutting. And when asked, his four divisional presidents - one of whom will probably succeed Mr. Ventres in two years - dutifully tick off the ways to wring out savings.
But they get most animated when they talk of growth. George J. Waydo, president of Borden's snacks and international consumer division, notes that his division has already grown from $800 million in sales and no national brands in 1986 to probably $2 billion in sales and three national brands - Krunchers!, Cheez Doodles and Wise Premium Choice Popcorn - this year. ''Five years down the road I'd like to think we'll see at least $2.5 billion in sales, and five or six national brands each doing at least $100 million or more,'' he said.
Jon G. Hettinger, president of the grocery and special products division, has put his emphasis on ''getting our cost structure right.'' But pasta, which has already tripled in sales in four years, and the company's fast-growing food-service business have his heart. Already, he is talking about a new hyperplant for pasta, and is ready to go national with a new microwavable pasta.
In food service, which sells to restaurants, schools and other institutions, he has been pushing high-volume, low-margin items like vats of mayonnaise and vegetable oils, and low-volume, high-margin items like single-serve packets of condiments and sugar substitutes. Now, he wants to produce many of those items in one plant. Even the dairy business - where soaring raw milk prices and intense competition have forced margins as low as 2 percent in some areas - is looking for growth. ''There are all kinds of new products - new yogurt flavors, say, or low-sodium cottage cheese, or lower-fat items - that we can create, and new markets that we can develop with advertising,'' said Mr. Fowlkes, the dairy chief.
And, despite Mr. Ventres's insistence that Borden is now in a ''consolidation phase,'' there is always a chance for more acquisitions. As Mr. Waydo put it, ''There is never a shortage of small businesses to buy.''

HEADLINE: WEEK IN BUSINESS;
Hopes Are Rising For Lower Rates By STEVE DODSON

 BODY:
The credit market took hope from signs of an easing in Fed monetary policy. On Tuesday the Fed added money to the banking system when the Federal funds rate was at 8 11/16, bringing the rate down to 8 1/2 percent. But when the rate went below that, to 8 3/8, the Fed acted to drain money from the system, leading analysts to conclude that the easing would be limited. Southwest Bank of St. Louis, a small institution that often is the first to move on rates, cut its prime rate to 10 percent, from 10.5 percent, but no big banks immediately matched the cut. The Fed's actions came in a confusing week, with the Treasury forced to delay its auctions while awaiting Congressional action on the national debt. But once the debt ceiling was raised to $3.12 trillion, the auctions began, and they confirmed a lowering of rates. The three-year notes sold at an average yield of 7.77 percent, the lowest since February 1988.
 
*
 Venezuela is buying the 50 percent of Citgo it does not already own. The $675 million deal will make Venezuela the first OPEC member nation to own a large American oil refiner and marketer. Three years ago Venezuela bought half of Citgo for $400 million from the Southland Corporation, which operates the 7-Eleven stores and is trying to reduce the debt taken on in a $4.9 billion buyout in 1987. 
 
*
 American and Japanese industries agreed to cooperate in developing high-definition television. The accord reached between American semiconductor makers and Japanese electronics companies offered no guarantees on the amount of American parts that would be used in Japanese-made HDTV sets but it could help insure that the two nations use the same standard for the new technology.
 
*
 A change at the top of Ford is scheduled for March 1. The company's chairman, Donald Petersen, said last week he would retire and be replaced by the vice chairman, Harold Poling, pictured at right. Mr. Petersen, who is 63 years old, has led Ford since 1985. Mr. Poling, 64, has been vice chairman for two years and has also been serving as chief operating officer. Ford said he would be chairman for three years and then retire . . . Lewis T. Preston, 63, will retire at year-end as chairman of J. P. Morgan & Company. He will be succeeded by Dennis Weatherstone, 58, the banking company's president since 1987 . . . Alberto Vitale, president and chief executive of Bantam Doubleday Dell, will succeed Robert L. Bernstein as chairman of Random House.

 The stock market spent the week trying to bounce back from a 47-point plunge on Monday. The effort did not quite succeed, and the Dow Jones industrial average finished the week at 2,625.62, down 3.90. Computerized program trading got much of the blame for the Monday selloff, but disappointing corporate earnings were also cited. The ''junk bond'' market, in a severe downturn most of this autumn, showed some signs of recovery, although the price gains were confined to the higher quality issues. Gold prices reached three-month highs near $390 an ounce but were backing off at week's end.

 Braniff ceased its airline operations and put itself up for sale. The decision halted the 46 daily flights Braniff has been operating since filing for Federal bankruptcy protection in late September. Braniff had about 30 percent of the market in its hub at Kansas City, Mo., with flights to 11 cities. Most of its 1,800 employees faced layoffs.
Plans for 2,000 layoffs were announced by Wang Laboratories. The computer company, based in Lowell, Mass., has already cut 5,000 jobs in recent months. The new reductions will bring its work force down to about 22,000 . . . Shearson Lehman Hutton warned its employees to expect more layoffs, and officials said privately that 700 to 800 jobs would be eliminated . . . The Jacksonville Shipyards in Florida said it would close in January, dismissing 1,500 workers, unless a buyer is found by year-end.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1, Column 2; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 2796 words

HEADLINE: The Great Real Estate Rush of '89

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

DATELINE: DALLAS

 BODY:
They are the dogs of real estate.
Take the Ramada Inn in east Dallas. Burned out and encased by barbed wire, it is hardly a place where tourists would want to stay. Or the Alta Mesa shopping center in Fort Worth, a strip of vacant buildings. And then there are miles and miles of raw land in places no one wants to go. All these are for sale, thanks to the savings and loan crisis, and will soon be marketed by the Government in what promises to be the biggest real estate sale in the nation's history.
Nearly $300 billion in assets from busted savings institutions - mortgages, commercial loans and real estate - is about to fall into the Government's hands as part of the savings industry bailout. Most of this will be quickly packaged and sold, largely by selling whole savings institutions outright. But some $100 billion, most of it in Southwestern real estate, will remain with the Government to sell piecemeal. And getting these properties to market is expected to be a painstaking process that could extend well into the next century. 
These are not the shimmering office buildings that gild the Dallas skyline, but rather the thousands of ill-conceived and ill-financed projects that now litter the Texas landscape. ''We're in the real estate business,'' said L. William Seidman, chairman of the Resolution Trust Corporation, the new Government agency created to handle these sales. ''We're neck deep and sinking.''
What the Government is being asked to do is indeed overwhelming: Sell hundreds of millions of dollars of distressed properties, with a minimal staff, in a depressed region and under intense Congressional scrutiny. ''This is so much bigger than anything anyone has had to deal with,'' said Gene C. McQuown, a vice president at the asset management firm of J. C. Robert Company of Texas. ''It's going to be traumatic.''
Yet just how the Government fares in selling these properties will determine the final tab of the savings unit debacle. The cost to taxpayers, now estimated at $50 billion, could easily rise into the hundreds of billions of dollars if these properties remain unsold for long. Every day, the Government incurs enormous carrying charges on these properties - taxes, upkeep and financing costs. And if the assets are sold for too little or too late, the taxpayer will have to make up the shortfall.
 
Thorny Issues
 Right now, the Government is trying to resolve a series of thorny issues that have a direct bearing on how much more risk the taxpayers may have to bear: will the Government provide seller financing? Can the Government sell so much property without driving real estate prices down further? Will the Government be able to keep fraud and abuse from seeping into the program?
Many of the better properties will likely be scooped up by Wall Street investors with an eye for a bargain. Such firms as Goldman Sachs & Company and Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. are said to be amassing funds of hundreds of millions of dollars to speculate on these parcels. But with few lenders providing money for Texas real estate, the Government may be forced to provide financing to attract buyers to the less attractive properties, putting additional taxpayer dollars at risk.
''The willingness of the R.T.C. to provide liquidity may be critical,'' said Richard Peiser, director of the Lusk Center for Real Estate Development at the University of Southern California. ''But if there are massive defaults on notes backed by the Government, the Government could be required to come into this crisis again.''
While some people in the Southwest fear that the sudden sale of so many properties in such a distressed region will only further depress real estate values there, others believe that the real danger is that the Government will move too slowly. The Government will not actually sell the properties itself, but will oversee an army of private contractors - appraisers, attorneys, asset managers and brokers - who will do the work. The process could easily get mired in bureaucratic inefficiency, which some say would only cause the costs of the bailout to rise and could also keep the Southwestern economy on hold.
The Government, fearful that some of the high-flying operators that helped cause the savings unit crisis could land on its doorstep once again, is drafting a tight new ethics policy. But, some say, it is so strict that it eliminates virtually anyone who has done business in Texas real estate in the last decade - conceivably even such experts as the Trammell Crow Company and and the Gerald D. Hines Interests.
Many in the Dallas real estate community say the proposed guidelines eliminate those who the Government needs the most, while admitting those who are small or inexperienced and are therefore more likely to bungle the job.
As the Government sorts through these issues, Dallas is getting ready. ''There's anxiety in the Dallas real estate community,'' said David W. Gleeson, president of the Lincoln Asset Management Company, one of Dallas's largest real estate firms. ''It's anxiety that they won't get a piece of the action.''
The city has been hit hard by the savings and loan collapse. As the industry here boomed in the mid 1980's, so did real estate - in part because of the increased liquidity available for property development, and in part from the wild speculation in real estate by the savings unit operators, using depositors' funds.
As the real estate market collapsed from overbuilding and the oil crisis, savings and loan institutions began to experience losses. And as they sank, the real estate market fell even further - reducing employment, too. But the bailout will probably bring jobs to the region, said Joe Foster, vice chairman of BEI Real Estate Services, a real estate consulting company. ''It's going to keep a lot of people warm and dry.''
Right now, the trust corporation is setting up shop in Dallas, one of four regional offices. The regional director, Carmen J. Sullivan, is currently hiring about 2,000 employees to oversee the contractors who will handle the sales. There are also about 1,000 employees at the trust corporation's office in Washington, which sets overall policy and handles the sales of whole savings units.
Since arriving in Dallas last August, Ms. Sullivan has been meeting with the Dallas real estate community and compiling an inventory of the properties that are coming her way. With a portfolio whose value is estimated at more than $50 billion, Ms. Sullivan ''is the most popular gal in Texas right now,'' said Mr. Gleeson, of Lincoln asset management. ''Her name is a household word.''
 
Missing a Chance
 ''Anybody who is a player in Texas real estate is going to have to work with the R.T.C.,'' said G. Ronald Witten, president of M/PF Research Inc., a Dallas real estate research firm. ''If you don't, you will miss out on a substantial share of the market.''
That is why the ethics guidelines are of such concern among Dallas's real estate community. As proposed, they would prevent the Government from contracting with anyone who - or whose partners or employees - has ''demonstrated a pattern or practice'' of theft or misuse of depositors' funds, or has caused ''substantial'' loss to the Federal insurance funds for savings associations.
But Dallas developers say the Government has cast too wide a net. For instance, they say, legitimate developers may be barred from Government contracts because their real estate ventures were foreclosed when the market collapsed or because they borrowed money from a bank that failed.
''Virtually anyone doing anything in the 1980's in the Southwest would not pass a single conflict-of-interest test,'' said Mr. Gleeson of Lincoln asset management. ''These guidelines virtually eliminate a high percentage of the real estate market who are qualified to do the work.'' Jim Leslie, chief financial officer of the Staubach Company, said: ''This affects every major player in Dallas.''
There is no disagreement that those real estate speculators who contributed to the problem should be precluded from benefiting from the cleanup. A steady stream of real estate executives has been traveling to Washington, where trust corporation officials are trying to decide such matters as what exactly constitutes a ''substantial'' loss. David C. Cooke, executive director of the trust corporation, admits that no matter how carefully the rules are written, the program is so big that fraud is inevitable.
''With $30 billion to $40 billion in assets up for management, that's a lot of money changing hands and a lot of potential,'' Mr. Cooke said. ''We hope to monitor our contractors, but with so much money the temptation may be too great.''
Yet the real risk to the taxpayer, in terms of dollars, is not the losses that could be caused by fraud, but the costs that could be incurred if these properties are not disposed of in quickly. Selling distressed properties is difficult, and it could take years to bring many of them to market.
Often, they are in disarray - vandalized, half-finished or in need of some improvements to stop further deterioration. For others, records are often sketchy if not nonexistent, making it difficult to provide potential buyers with economic data. In many cases, the Government does not have clear title to the assets and may have to wage costly court battles with a variety of parties, including borrowers or their partners.
''Each one of these assets has its own complexity,'' said Jim Pendley, national marketing director of the Federal Asset Disposition Association, a quasi-governmental organization that has sold about $760 million in real estate properties from savings units under contract with the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation. (Assets from all savings units that failed before 1989 are being liquidated by the F.S.L.I.C. and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. The R.T.C. will manage the rest.) ''There's seldom clear title,'' added Mr. Pendley. ''In some states, like Florida, where judicial foreclosure is difficult, we've had properties that have taken three years to get title to.''
In addition, many properties are of questionable market value. Many were not built because they made economic sense, but merely as devices to generate fee income for high-flying savings units. And some 40 percent of the real estate the Government will inherit is raw land, often large parcels located so far from developed areas that they have little economic value.
''A lot of these properties were poorly designed and poorly built,'' said Mr. Leslie of the Staubach Company. ''We went through the free and easy money days from the savings and loan industry, and they got into a lot of developments that have no business being there.''
 
Skunks in the Pile
 The trust corporation is not deterred. ''We do have a lot of skunks as far as our assets go,'' said Lamar C. Kelly Jr. director of the asset and real estate management division at the trust corporation. '''And we're going to put a prom dress on them and make them queens of the prom. But, it won't be an easy effort.''
As a result, the Government is unlikely to get top dollar for these properties. ''People are buying a future when they are buying that property,'' said Philip Montgomery, president of Montgomery & Company, a Dallas real estate firm. ''There's a market for these assets - but it's at a price.''
Further depressing prices, the trust corporation's properties have to compete with other distressed real estate that will be coming on the market as the savings unit crisis deepens. The trust corporation is taking over any savings unit that has failed since January and any that fail in the future.. So far, the R.T.C. has $95.6 billion in assets from some 256 failed savings units. The corporation's figures another 250 shaky units will eventually come its way.
There already are about $16 billion in real estate assets in the hands of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation from banks and savings units that failed prior to 1989.
There are also distressed real estate assets being marketed by regional banks like NCNB Texas, which recently bought two failed Texas banks and a failed savings unit. NCNB Texas is working through an $11 billion troubled loan portfolio from those deals. And other banks and financial groups that buy Texas savings units from the Government are expected to put parts of their real estate loan portfolios on the market. Timothy P. Hartman, vice chairman of NCNB Texas, expressed an attitude shared by many. ''We don't intend to invest in troubled real estate loans. We're primarily interested in building a deposit franchise.''
 
Low Prices
 Many in Dallas are already citing a host of additional reasons why the Government may get low prices.
One is appraisals. Appraisals in such a distressed market are extremely difficult to make and are quite often meaningless. Traditional valuation measures like replacement costs or comparable sales are worthless when properties are selling for less than their replacement costs and when recent sales are few and far between.
At the same time, many Dallas appraisers, heavily criticized and even sued for overly optimistic appraisals during the boom years, have since become extremely conservative. And that may push down the selling prices for the Government's properties.
''Appraisals are where the rubber meets the road in real estate,'' said Mr. Montgomery of Montgomery & Company. ''But to understand appraisals, you have to understand their fear of being sued. And that's helping drive down prices in many areas.''
 
Drawn Out Process
 What is more, the appraisal process may be drawn out. The ranks of Dallas appraisers, who know the market best, thinned after the market collapsed, causing backlogs. The wait is now 90 to 120 days.
Yet under current regulations, the Government requires that all properties have two appraisals and that no property be sold for less than 95 percent of its appraised value. In practical terms, this slows down the selling process as a buyer waits for the two appraisals. It also forces the Government to sell properties at 95 percent of an appraised price that is highly subjective and may or may not reflect market values.
Not only is the trust corporation having to steer through a thicket of issues, but it is being watched closely every step of the way. There are currently no less than six Government bodies overseeing and auditing the trust corporation's operations, including two Congressional committees. In addition to carrying out its assigned tasks, the trust corporation will have to tread carefully to keep political controversy at bay.
''With every decision we make and every letter we write, we have to adopt the attitude that, in conducting our business, someone may take exception,'' said Ms. Sullivan of the Dallas office.
Ms. Sullivan only has to look across town to the Federal Asset Disposition Association for a cautionary tale. The association was formed several years ago to sell real estate from troubled savings institutions taken over by the F.S.L.I.C. - almost the identical job that the resolution trust corporation is being asked to do.
But the association ran was widely criticized in Washington forspending too much and selling too little. Much of the association's trouble, many say, stemmed from the fact that it never mastered the political ways of Washington and failed to explain to legislators that the asset disposition is a long and tedious process.
Today, the association, which nevertheless gets high marks from real estate experts for its professionalism, is being sold by the Government to a private buyer. Bids for the association have been accepted, although no deal has yet been announced.
 
Open to Criticism
 ''A lot has got to happen before the R.T.C. can start marketing properties,'' Mr. McQuown said. ''And the public sector doesn't understand that. That's where F.A.D.A. failed. It didn't educate others as to how the process worked.''
No matter what the trust corporation does, it is open to criticism: if it sells a property for too little, if it holds a property too long, if it pays a contractor too much or hires the wrong one, if a property is mismanaged. Any perceptible mistakewill be grist for the various oversight bodies, once the process gets into full gear.
''They've got to come up with bulletproof processes to protect themselves from flak,'' Mr. McQuown added. He knows this all too well. In his previous job, he was the Dallas regional manager for the disposition association. In that capacity, he said, ''I always lived in fear that I would sell something for the F.S.L.I.C., someone would flip it and it would be in the paper.''

HEADLINE: WHAT'S NEW IN BLACK ENTERPRISE;
Promising Prospects Despite Recent Setbacks

BYLINE: CHRISTOPHER C. WILLIAMS; Christopher C. Williams is a writer based in New York.

 BODY:
Black Americans in recent years have made powerful political strides. Their business successes have been less brilliant, but many civil rights activists hope that blacks can push into the economic mainstream in the 1990's. And recent changes in Federal assistance programs for minority-owned businesses and President Bush's campaign pledge to help these companies could fuel their cause. 
''Minority business development will be the hot topic of the 90's,'' said Harriet R. Michel, president of the National Minority Supplier Development Council Inc. in New York, which matches corporate clients with minority suppliers.
Blacks have come a long way since the civil rights movement of the 1960's. Having gained experience in the public sector in such areas as finance and real estate, many blacks have moved into the private arena. In the last few years, a few forceful role models have emerged, like Reginald Lewis, who in 1987 led the $985 million leveraged buyout of Beatrice International Foods. Another sign of their entrepreneurial success: Annual revenues of the nation's top 100 black businesses increased by 368 percent since 1979, to $5.7 billion last year, according to Black Enterprise magazine.
Yet blacks still face formidable obstacles. Black businesses have historically struggled to get financing, making their failure rate high and stifling their ability to expand. In fact, minority-run companies today account for less than 1 percent of the sales of American businesses, according to the Department of Commerce.
The tone set by the Reagan Administration has also been crippling. Not only did the Administration oppose affirmative action, but it also repeatedly tried, without success, to dismantle the Small Business Administration, which helps finance many minority-owned companies.
And in January, the Supreme Court ruled in Croson v. Richmond that the city's minority set-aside program for public contracts was unconstitutional. Minority contractors, who had previously been guaranteed 30 percent of Richmond's public contracts, now win only about 2.5 percent of them.
The decision has had a ripple effect. It has prompted cities across the country to suspend or review their programs and has brought other Government incentive programs designed to help minorities under legal attack.
''We are seeing the legacy of the Reagan era,'' said Anthony Robinson, president of the Minority Business Enterprise Legal Defense and Educational Fund Inc., a legal advocacy group.

LENGTH: 1606 words

HEADLINE: Brazil's Economic Crossroads

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE

DATELINE: SAO PAULO

 BODY:
On the eve of its first direct presidential election in nearly 30 years, Brazil, the giant of Latin America, stands frozen at an economic crossroads. Frustrated by a decade of economic stagnation, Brazil's 82 million voters will now decide the path the Western world's eighth-largest economy will take in the 1990's.
One school of candidates is offering the classic Western prescription for economic growth in the third world, a path now being followed by Mexico, among others: trade liberalization, more foreign investment and far less state ownership of industry. The other group of candidates in a very crowded field is offering the classic blueprint of Latin American development usually associated with the left: higher wages, land for the landless and at least a temporary moratorium on payments of foreign debt. Brazil has $110 billion in debt, the most in the developing world.
The outcome of the election is impossible to predict. But business leaders say that if the voters choose the pro-Western, free-market course, Brazil will emerge in the next decade with glittering, Pacific Basin-style growth rates. They say that a leftist victory, however, would seriously wound the country, already hobbled by social tension, four-digit inflation and capital flight. 
Fueling social combustion, Brazil has one of Latin America's widest gaps between rich and poor. In a nation where three-quarters of the voters earn less than $125 a week, Brazil's conservative military maneuvered for decades to avoid a direct vote for the presidency, fearing a victory for the left. The voting this Wednesday will be the first such election since 1960; since 1964, presidents have been chosen by the military or by a civilian electoral college.
''All long-term plans are on hold,'' Timothy A. Durkin, a Citibank vice president, said of the nervous business mood in this city, often known as the ''locomotive'' of Brazil. ''I know of several $100 million-plus projects that are tabled until the situation is defined.''
With no clear frontrunner in the 22-candidate race, Wednesday's voting is expected merely to clear the field, leaving the two highest vote getters to face each other in a runoff Dec. 17. The winner of the runoff will succeed President Jose Sarney in March.
At stake is the future of Latin America's largest market, with 144 million people. A favorite of American bankers and investors during the high-growth years of the 1960's and 1970's, Brazil lost its allure during the 1980's, when economic growth fell to an average of less than 2.9 percent a year, barely pacing population growth.
Business executives attribute the stagnation to several causes: oil price shocks, a net outflow of capital to service the foreign debt, economic mismanagement that led to gyrating inflation rates and a highly controlled domestic economy that proved increasingly unattractive to investors.
 
Big Trade Surplus
 Despite all that, Brazil last year racked up a $19 billion trade surplus, the third-largest in the world after Japan and West Germany. Once largely an exporter of agricultural goods - coffee and the sugar to sweeten it - Brazilian factories now send overseas a panoply of manufactured goods: airplanes, steel, tanks and shoes.
The surge of manufactured exports and Brazil's barriers against imports have led to conflicts between Brazil and the United States. United States officials last May gave Brazil 18 months to lower its barriers or face retaliatory tariffs. Although some import tariffs have edged down, Brazil remains, in the words of a recent Bank of Boston report, ''very much a closed economy.''
Last year, for example, Brazil bought only $4.2 billion worth of American goods, less than what was purchased by Venezuela, which has one-eighth of Brazil's population.
In response, Brazilians say they have to keep import barriers high in order to record a trade surplus that can be used to service the foreign debt. American bankers lead the list of creditors of the $65 billion commercial portion of the debt.
In September, Brazil quietly stopped servicing the foreign debt, in what was seen as a temporary, improvised move. But the debt remains a burning issue in the presidential campaign. Indeed, two strong left-wing contenders have made the debt public enemy No. 1.
Leonel Brizola, a Socialist former governor of Rio de Janeiro state, and Luis Inacio da Silva, a trade unionist known as Lula who has strong Marxist backing, have blamed it for a wide range of ills - from stifling the economy to spurring inflation, now at an annual rate of 1,300 percent.
The two candidates are calling for a formal moratorium on payments while auditors review the debt and far more favorable terms can be negotiated - a process that could easily take a year.
A victory of the left would probably cause further strains with the United States. Dismissing as insufficient Washington's country-by-country debt-relief plan, the leftists say that Brazil should lead a coalition of debtor nations. In the 1980's, such coalitions never got beyond the talking stage. But this could change with an energetic leftist at the head of Brazil.
A milder stance on the debt has come from the frontrunner of the center-right, Fernando Collor de Mello, a former governor of Alagoas state.
But the campaign rhetoric, which is expected to sharpen during the second round of the election, may well force the new president to adopt an unrealistic position on debt negotiations after being inaugurated for a five-year term next March 15.
Many American banks are now in a stronger position to resist Brazil's pressure and to cut off new lending. This year, many banks raised their loan-loss reserves, effectively taking early losses on Brazilian loans.
''We can now be tougher at the negotiating table, because we have very little to lose,'' said one American banker in Rio.
In the third world, the secondary debt market serves as an informal barometer of international assessment of a nation's debt management, political stability and general economic policies.
In Latin America, Chile and Colombia, two careful money managers, score high - their debt securities trade for about 65 percent of face value. Mexico and Venezuela, two countries that this year adopted decisive economic programs featuring free-market reforms, score in the medium range - about 40 percent.
 
Hitting Rock Bottom
 Last week, Brazilian debt securities hit their lowest point ever - 21 cents on the dollar. Among the major debtors, only Argentina (at 18 cents) and Peru (6 cents) scored lower.
Meanwhile, confidence in domestic debt securities issued by Brazil has dropped so low that the Government is paying real interest rates of 6 percent a month to attract lenders. Analysts calculate that Brazil's internal debt has increased 50 percent this year, to about $120 billion, roughly a third of the country's gross domestic product. By comparison, Mexico's internal debt has declined as a percentage of G.D.P., to 28.6 percent at the end of 1988, from 33.3 percent the year before.
The lack of confidence reflects the Brazilian Government's increasingly precarious hold on the economy. In the last 15 years, tax collection has dropped from 17 percent of G.D.P. to 9 percent. And with an estimated 90 percent of this year's budget going to pay salaries for the state's 8 million employees, the Government has resorted to printing or borrowing money to pay for nearly everything else, fueling inflation.
It is even unclear whether Brazil's economy can make it to March 15 without disintegrating into the kind of hyperinflation that sparked widespread street rioting in Argentina after presidential elections there last May. With the emergency, Argentina's new President, Carlos Saul Menem, was able to galvanize bipartisan support for a tough anti-inflation program - raising taxes and public utility rates, cutting Government subsidies and selling money-losing state companies.
 
Waiting for a Disaster
 ''Unlike Argentina, we have not yet had a disaster - only a half-disaster,'' said Roberto Campos, a senator and economist who advocates a similar set of tough measures for Brazil. Under a new Constitution, Brazil's Congress wields strong powers over economic policy. But there is no consensus in Congress for an emergency program, Senator Campos said.
Looking ahead, a diplomat in Brasilia concurred: ''A key issue is whether the next president will be able to mobilize huge sectors of the population and Congress for an economic salvation program.''
In Sao Paulo business circles, there is growing support for cutting the state sector and for opening Brazil to foreign investment and imports.
''The closing of our borders keeps us inefficient,'' said Jose E. Mindlin, president of Metal Leve, a Brazilian-based multinational auto-parts manufacturer.
Antoninho Marmo Trevisan, the president of an economic consulting group here, predicted that the budget shortfall will force the Government to start dismantling the state empire of 230 companies.
''Whoever wins, whether it is Lula or Collor, he will have to privatize if he wants to build schools, roads and health clinics,'' Mr. Trevisan said, advocating selling the money-losing state companies to a mix of foreign and local investors.
But it is unclear whether the voters will follow the recent prescription of a Sao Paulo newspaper: ''Less government, less misery.''
''We may go with the half-measures of Brizola, or with the wrong-headed radicalism of Lula,'' Senator Campos said of the 1990's. ''Then we will have to wait another five years for Brazil to grow again.''

HEADLINE: BUSINESS FORUM: PERESTROIKA GOES SOUTH;
Auctioning Off the National Patrimony

BYLINE: By NATHAN P. GARDELS; Nathan P. Gardels is editor of New Perspectives Quarterly, the journal of the Center for Study of Democratic Institutions.

 BODY:
Although world attention is focused on the drama of Communist reform, the statist systems of Latin America are undergoing an ideological restructuring that is no less radical than perestroika. New leaders like Argentina's Carlos Saul Menem and Mexico's Carlos Salinas de Gortari are bent on privatizing their economies and opening them to the international market. The fierce nationalism that once led the Latin American states to close their borders is giving way to the hope, not unlike Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's, of fully joining the world economy in order to develop.
So far, the new reforms have gone farthest in Mexico. In an unusually candid conversation about Mexico's reforms, Foreign Minister Fernando Solana recently outlined a program that, in the eyes of still powerful nationalistic forces at home, amounts to selling off the previously untouchable pillars of the national patrimony. 
While Mr. Solana acknowledges the central role of the state in building Mexico's foundation as an industrializing nation, he believes that central role is now over. He looks primarily to the private sector to competitively integrate Mexico into the world economy. ''State investment and broad participation in the economy was very important during the stage of 'import substitution.' But the strategy was overused. It outlived its time,'' said Mr. Solana. ''Now Mexico has matured. It is time to join the great transformation to a global economy that is taking place today.''
In a radical departure from economic practice since the time of Mexico's revolution in 1914, the borders have been cast open to foreign investment. Under Mexico's newly promulgated 1989 foreign investment regulations, foreigners may own 100 percent of businesses in a surprising range of sectors from agriculture to livestock, building and contruction, magazines and newspapers, air navigation to legal and financial services. And in many areas, Mexico is less protectionist than the United States.
In August, the Chase Manhattan Bank announced it had put together a consortium to purchase 25 percent of Mexicana Airlines, once the Government's flagship enterprise. In the same month, the Government announced that the largest state-owned mine in Mexico would be allowed to go bankrupt.
According to Mr. Solana, the state's share of the economy has rapidly been shorn to only 6 percent of gross domestic product. In the last two years alone, state-owned enterprises have been reduced by 75 percent, to 300 companies from 1,200. In the petrochemical area, which was nationalized in 1938, the number of products subject to nationalization has been reduced to 30 from 200. Remarkably, Mr. Solana defined only the railroads, electric power plants and the extraction and trade of oil and uranium as the remaining core of nationalization. ''Everything else,'' he said, ''is open to privatization.'' But, will the strategic opening of the protected Latin American or Eastern Bloc economies work? There is as yet no evidence - anywhere in the developing world - that opening previously closed economies to the unkind winds of international competition has resulted in improved living standards. Quite the contrary, it is inevitable that living standards will fall in the near term. Given the very low productivity rates from Mexico City to Moscow free competition with Japan, the United States and Europe threatens to decimate whatever national economic foundation domestic protection was able to build. And with the removal of subsidies on everything from Mexican tortillas to Polish bread, the consumer will be hit as hard as the worker.
Yet there is no going back. And, in reality, there is not much choice for farsighted leaders like Carlos Salinas or Mr. Gorbachev. As uncertain as a future of market reforms may be, it necessarily proceeds from the certainty that the past strategy of import substitution in the case of Latin America inevitably ends in stagnation. Both are incapable of surpassing uncompetitive industrialism and partaking of the high wages and dynamism of a global economy driven by information technology.
The great danger in Latin America as well as in the Eastern Bloc, is that the pain of restructuring will kill a renewed faith in the future born from shedding old ways. Yet the success of these reforms is crucial to a promising future for the post-industrial West. It would thus seem a more responsible course for the United States to search for ways to cushion the transition than gloat over capitalism's triumph.

GRAPHIC: Nathan P. Gardels (NYT/Bart Bartholomew)

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2, Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 788 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS FORUM: PERESTROIKA GOES SOUTH;
Privatizing Will Make Life Worse

BYLINE: By MICHAEL HUDSON; Michael Hudson is an economist and international financial consultant in New York.

 BODY:
I attended the annual meetings of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank in Washington last month. When the meetings ended, I was left with the impression that no further writedowns would be forthcoming for Latin America's debtor countries unless they followed the lead of Mexico. To do this, countries like Brazil and Argentina would have to sell off their public utilities, some potentially profitable industrial corporations and some service industries like airlines.
In the past, one met mostly bankers at these big international meetings. Now there are a lot of lawyers. 
For Latin America the foreclosure process has begun, but for the time being it is called privatization or debt-for-equity swaps. Countries hoping to borrow more money from creditor-nation governments, the I.M.F. and the World Bank, are being told to help themselves by relinquishing ownership of their basic economic infrastructure.
In advocating this brave new world of privatizing hitherto public monopolies, these local investors and their partners, the international banking and investment community, cite a number of truisms.
Private-sector managers will run enterprises more efficiently, the proponents of privatization say.
This argument has merit, as far as it goes. But it should be remembered that the troubled savings and loan institutions in Texas were all privately run businesses.
But more important, in the United States and Europe there exists a balance between private profitability and the public's need for popularly priced power, transport and other services. This balance is insured by public regulatory agencies and is backed by antitrust legislation.
But few Latin American or other third world economies have ever had to develop these regulatory traditions because their governments have owned the major public utilities and other monopolies. The fact that private ownership of these enterprises will be a new experience for these countries means that it may not have the same salutary consequences as in the United States.
Proponents of privatization say that a sell-off of utilities will reduce government budget deficits. They argue that privatization will turn government-owned businesses, which are often fiscal drains on a country, into private tax-paying entities. As a result, lower federal deficits may help slow the endemic inflations that plague most debtor economies.
But for the population at large, shifting the economic burden away from government (and hence the taxpayers) may turn out to be largely illusory. For what the government saves in subsidies may be paid by users of these utilities in the form of higher power, phone and transport rates charged by the new proprietors.
Fortunately, there are alternatives to the above scenarios. The most obvious one is to keep these monopolies public but restructure them as truly independent corporations by bringing in the best management possible. The alternative to badly run public enterprise is not necessarily privatization, but better administration with effective checks and balances against incompetence and malfeasance.
A second option is to put public regulatory and antitrust legislation in place before it is too late. The objective is to hold privatizers to their promises by making them absorb the penalty for their own possible inefficiency, by enjoying lower profits rather than extorting higher rates from consumers. After all, why should third world populations deserve less than the United States in this respect?
Whatever option is chosen, the possible outcomes are relatively clear. If the new purchasers of public utilities are foreign, it will constitute a retrogression from neocolonialism back to direct colonialism. If domestic investors buy a nation's economic infrastructure, they will achieve a higher degree of power than has been attained by investors in the United States and Europe. The upshot of this may be an unprecedented economic polarization in countries where wealthy citizens already have a strong influence on government.
But the most likely outcome is an alliance between wealthy local families and foreign banks and other international investors. That would give the takeover process a cosmopolitan patina.
One way or another, the debt-into-equity conversion represents a foreclosure on the mismanaged economies of the third world. But behind the rhetoric of today's privatization, one must always ask, Qui bono? Who will benefit from the prospective economic changes? In my opinion, it will be the rich and the creditor banks who benefit from these schemes. For the people in general, and for public-employee labor unions, privatization means that life may well be more expensive in the future.

GRAPHIC: Michael Hudson (NYT/Bill Sweeny)

HEADLINE: THE EXECUTIVE COMPUTER;
At the Front in the Battle Over Unix

BYLINE: By Peter H. Lewis

 BODY:
Even though the Unix operating system is 20 years old, it seems as if the battle over the one ''true'' Unix has been going on since the Crusades. The war is far from over, but in recent weeks the field has narrowed to two major versions of the operating system. One is controlled by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and supported by an advisory group called Unix International; the other, scheduled for delivery next year, is being developed by a group called the Open Software Foundation, whose goal is to come up with something not controlled by A.T.&T.
If Unix came in only one flavor, life would be easier for everyone. But two versions are certainly better than the more than 200 that existed at one time, and it appears that the rival camps are prepared to co-exist for a while. ''My interpretation is that Unix International seems to have a slight edge in momentum,'' said Kevin O'Neill, vice president of research and consulting at the Business Research Group, a subsidiary of Connors Publishing Inc. of Newton, Mass. 
The latest move toward a unified standard was the development of A.T.& T.'s Unix System V version 4.0, announced earlier this month at Unix Expo in New York. Version 4.0, flying the banner of Unix International, unites several of the more popular variations, including Berkeley, Xenix and SunOS. SunOS was developed by Sun Microsystems Inc., which has been one of the fastest-growing makers of work stations.
When A.T.& T. bought a stake in Sun last year, the alliance led the International Business Machines Corporation, the Digital Equipment Corporation and more than 100 other equipment makers to form the Open Software Foundation in an attempt to keep A.T.& T. from giving Sun an unfair advantage in the work-station market.
The foundation has reportedly switched recently from a core technology developed by the International Business Machines Corporation to one hatched at Carnegie-Mellon University. That ''in some minds calls into question their timetable,'' Mr. O'Neill said. ''Both camps have a significant list of companies that are committed to them, but with version 4.0 on the table now, there might be some defections from O.S.F.''
The fact that analysts are even discussing Unix, let alone dissecting its turf wars, is significant. From its ivory-tower beginnings in science and academe, Unix has emerged as a significant operating system for businesses, especially those that use big computers as a hub for a network of terminals, in contrast to those that use groups of powerful personal computers linked in local area networks, or LAN's. The latter are expected to be based on the OS/2 operating system developed by the Microsoft Corporation and I.B.M.
The recent rise in popularity of Unix has been the result of several related factors: the growth of networked computer systems, the increasing sophistication of corporate computer users who want multi-user and multi-tasking ability, and the availability of powerful work stations capable of using Unix in retail computer stores at relatively low prices. The idea that Unix systems would be sold in mainstream computer stores would have been unimaginable several years ago. In recent months, however, Apple Computer Inc., the Compaq Computer Corporation, the Dell Computer Corporation and other personal computer makers have been touting the Unix capabilities of their systems.
''Unix is no longer a sleepy little pocket-protector operating system deep in the bowels of Harvard, M.I.T. and the data processing department at the Pentagon,'' said John McCarthy, director of professional systems research at Forrester Research Inc. of Cambridge, Mass.
''On the other hand, Unix isn't the be-all and end-all yet,'' Mr. McCarthy hastened to add. ''You aren't going to put Unix in the office and have every computing problem you've had disappear. But A.T.& T. and Sun Microsystems are moving to eliminate a lot of the traditional headaches of Unix, the most damning of which was that there were so many versions.''
Although Unix offers such important features as allowing several users to share the same sets of data, and for several applications to be active on screen at once, Unix is unlikely to become a dominant operating system. DOS, OS/2 and the Apple Macintosh OS are more popular. However, many analysts say Unix is capitalizing on the relatively slow acceptance of OS/2, which was introduced two years ago and which is expected to be the most widely used operating system in the 1990's. A version of OS/2 that is promised for next year will match many of the features found in Unix today.
Unix can run on computers built around the industry-standard 80386 and 80486 microprocessors made by the Intel Corporation as well as on reduced instruction set computer, or RISC, chips from Motorola Inc., I.B.M., Intel and others. The ability to run on a variety of systems, including personal computers, work stations, minicomputers, mainframes and even supercomputers, is a major advantage over other operating systems.
The profusion of Unix versions came as computer makers added their own proprietary features in an attempt to make their systems competitive with others. That resulted in a hodge-podge of incompatible Unix versions.
Then the computing environment changed. A decade ago, most corporations bought all their computers from a single vendor, like I.B.M. or the Digital Equipment Corporation. There was no need to choose the flavor of Unix, since each vendor sold its own.
Today, according to figures supplied by Compaq, 80 percent of large corporations buy their computer equipment from multiple sources. Having a common operating system that can operate on a wide number of machines has become a critical issue.
''Given the accelerated rate of change in business and the world economy, customers can't be tied to artificially constrained operating systems and tied down to one vendor,'' Mr. McCarthy explained.
Still, even supporters of Unix dispute how successful the operating system will be in the business environment. Doug Michels, vice president of the Santa Cruz Operation Inc., a Unix system software developer in California that is partly owned by Microsoft, said he expected Unix to equal the market share of OS/2. But Steve Balmer, a senior vice president at Microsoft, said last week that Unix will always be a small niche player in businesses.

HEADLINE: BEYOND THE WALL;
Not Just One German Question But Many

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN

DATELINE: EAST BERLIN

 BODY:
OF all the startling images on the night of Nov. 9, perhaps the most gripping was the sight of Germans streaming from both sides through the brightly illuminated Brandenburg Gate.
For 40 years it had stood as a symbol of Berlin's fate, a battle-scarred relic of a grand history gone wrong, a gate stranded in no man's land in the middle of the wall through which passage was banned in either direction. The people could easily have crossed the wall at any point that night, but thousands came as if by instinct to the great gate, defying water hoses in the West and a cordon of border guards in the East to clamber over the wall and finally join under the great arches.
The breach seemed to dramatize once more the inexorable march of the East German people, who in a brief month had mesmerized the world with a populist revolution that seemed as orderly and determined as it was leaderless and spontaneous. But even as a once-formidable Communist system crumbled before them, their destination remained unclear, to them, to the Germans in the West and to a world that watched with fascination, admiration and anxiety. 
''The German question will remain open just as long as the Brandenburg Gate is closed,'' the West German state President, Richard von Weizsacker, said a few months ago. But now that the gate was opened, the questions seemed to gape ever broader. What was really in the hearts of the Germans perched atop the wall and chipping at its concrete? Would they bring a forced coupling of the Germanys, destabilizing Europe, threatening the strategic interests of the superpowers, undermining the process of European economic integration?
Was reunification in fact imminent? Or did the end of enforced division paradoxically clear the way to an amicable separation? Once they were granted a genuine option, would the majority of Germans in the East choose to maintain and build their socialist homeland?
Willy Brandt, who was Mayor of West Berlin when the wall went up and who won a Nobel Peace Prize for shaping the complex compromise with the East that came to be known as Ostpolitik, summed up the excitement and the uncertainty when he declared from the steps of the city hall: ''This is a beautiful day after a long voyage, but we are only at a way station. We are not at the end of our way.''
Over four decades, ''reunification'' has assumed various connotations. In West Germany it has been a guiding myth, enshrined in the Constitution but never officially plotted or discussed in front of strangers. In East Germany the notion has been considered treason, implying the dissolution of a nation whose only reason for existing was its ideology. In Moscow, Washington, Paris and London, the concept has been laced with sinister connotations of a Bismarckian monolith in the heart of Europe. In public the Germans were pitied for their division, in private everybody wanted to keep it that way.
Even now that the German question was on top of the world's agenda, answers remained elusive. None of the placards or slogans in five weeks of virtually daily mass demonstrations across East Germany ever raised reunification. If anything, the chants of ''We're staying here!'' spoke of a pride in a separate identity.
In West Germany, too, politicians rejoiced at reunion even as they warned that it was still a long way away. Again and again, Chancellor Helmut Kohl urged the East Germans to stay in their own homeland, promising them large-scale aid if they would work to rebuild their state. The national mood was ambiguous. Many of those who stood teary-eyed at the West Berlin city hall declined to join in the singing of the West German national anthem, which to many Germans remains a symbol of a nationalism they still consider somehow shameful. This was a family reunion, not the reaffirmation of a tribe.
From Moscow came the rumble of caution. It is your right to walk through the wall, the Kremlin seemed to say, but it is our decision when the division will end. It may well be that President Bush, President Francois Mitterrand and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher whispered a silent amen.
Nobody at this stage seemed ready to predict how things would develop. If there was one thing the October Revolution of 1989 had shown, it was that nobody really controlled the march of the East German people -not Egon Krenz, the new Communist leader, who threw out concession after concession in a headlong retreat before the people; not Mr. Kohl, who could do no more than make room for newcomers and beg remaining East Germans not to come; not Moscow or Washington, which watched their former wards march to a very German tune.
But the very discipline and reasonableness with which the East Germans had largely avoided violence and excess seemed to feed confidence that the process would stop well short of a riotous breaching of the European order. It was, wrote a Marxist historian in Neues Deutschland, the Communist Party newspaper, a ''conservative revolution,'' in which the goal was not to turn the world upside down but to restore it to order, to bring the people back into the ''leading role'' hijacked by a clique of old men, to restore a right as basic as visiting compatriots in a neighboring state.
There was the risk that having tasted the might of people power the Germans could be tempted to drive on into the unknown, pushing for a premature political linkage. The possible ramifications were scary: the military and economic groupings of Europe would collapse in disarray, the new state would command awesome economic and military power, the formidable task of bringing the East German economy to Western levels would tie up all West German resources and effectively disrupt not only West European economic integration, but the revival of other East European states as well.
Little at the moment gave flesh to such a scenario. ''No people on this earth, no people in Europe have to fear if the gates are opened now between East and West,'' declared Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher. ''No people have to fear that liberty and democracy have returned to the German Democratic Republic.''
But there was also the sense that politicians on both sides and in both alliances had to confront the real possibility of reunification, even if still far off. The West German Constitution, endorsed by the Western allies, calls for German unity in free self-determination. With the promise of free elections in East Germany, the referendum of the German question was no longer a theoretical goal.
''There will come a day when the Germans in the G.D.R. decide whether they want to form one state with the Germans in the Federal Republic,'' wrote the Frankfurter Allgemeine. ''Then the Federal Republic will have to face up to its provisional character, which will be hard for a lot of people.''
But others argued that the breach of the wall had effectively pushed back the German question by taking away its pain. With free elections and free travel now virtually guaranteed in the East, the wall was reduced to a benign fence between neighboring cousins. Then President von Weizsacker would be proved right in a way he might not have intended: the opening of the Brandenburg Gate would not only make it unnecessary to have a wall, it might also make it unnecessary to take the wall down.
