HEADLINE: THE NATION;
A Savings Failure That Illustrates Everything Wrong With the Industry

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE collapse of the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association in California has come to represent a microcosm - in the extreme, to be sure - of the failure of hundreds of other thrift institutions at a cost to taxpayers of more than $100 billion.
In Lincoln's story are all the elements of the industry's woes: lax state-level regulation, Federal regulation that was hampered by the use of political influence, a highly aggressive, risk-taking entrepreneur, speculative investments, accounting gimmickry, political connections, possible criminal fraud and a huge price tag for failure.
The Government has filed a $1.1 billion civil suit against the thrift's former chairman, Charles H. Keating Jr., and his associates, and criminal investigations are under way. The Lincoln failure has proved particularly embarrassing for five Senators who had received large contributions from Mr. Keating and met with regulators on his behalf. 
''Lincoln follows the pattern of all the catastrophic S. & L. failures over the last few years,'' said William Black, district counsel in the San Francisco branch of the Office of Thrift Supervisions, formerly the Federal Home Loan Bank Board. ''It epitomizes the entire debacle.''
Bert Ely, a financial consultant based in Alexandria, Va., said there were signals from the start that Lincoln would someday collapse. He noted that Mr. Keating was among many businessmen who entered the thrift business in the early 1980's with little or no experience in the highly regulated industry.
Moreover, Mr. Ely said, the struggling thrift in Irvine, Calif., was probably close to insolvent even when Mr. Keating bought it in 1984, and reflected a pattern in which regulators hoped unrealistically that a new owner could turn things around. Experts said that Lincoln's excessive growth should have been the first indication that there would be problems. In the five years between his purchase of Lincoln and its takeover by Federal authorities last April, Mr. Keating had turned a $1 billion institution into one with assets of almost $6 billion.
During the mid-1980's, it was relatively easy to collect vast deposits by offering above-market interest rates, but investing those funds prudently was much more difficult. As it turned out, instead of making relatively safe investments such as home mortgages, Mr. Keating poured money into raw land - a highly speculative investment that only earns a return if it is developed - a huge hotel and other development projects that soon floundered.
 
An Auditor's Help
Moreover, Mr. Black said, with the aid of an outside auditor, Lincoln and scores of other institutions were able to show record profits while hiding the fact that investments were collapsing. In some cases, owners and directors and members of their familiies appeared to reap large rewards from financially anemic institutions. Investigators said Mr. Keating and his family received a total of $34 million in salaries, bonuses and proceeds from stock sales.
One scheme would go something like this: An institution would make a $10 million loan to a developer. But while $10 million in cash would be dispensed, the developer would sign a note promising to pay back $12 million, the $10 million principal, plus $2 million in interest over two years. The $2 million would then be ''booked'' in an interest reserve account, and a certain amount would be credited to earnings from that account every month, even though the builder had not paid back a penny.
And if after two years the builder still could not pay interest on the loan, it would simply be refinanced in the same way with no loss showing.
''You are showing great earnings with all the money going out and no money coming in,'' Mr. Black said. ''That is why some S. & L.'s reported record profits in one year and collapsed the next.''
 
Relaxed Regulation
Lincoln and other institutions enjoyed a lax regulatory environment, particularly from state regulatory agencies, that permitted these practices. In early 1983, California, for example, permitted its state-chartered savings institutions to invest 100 percent of their assets in high-risk real estate projects. It was eventually overruled by a Federal Home Loan Bank Board imposition of a 10 percent limit on such investments.
During 1983 and 1984, California granted more than 200 new thrift charters and in general encouraged aggressive investments, in keeping with local officials' view that tying the industry strictly to home loans was an outmoded rule. Into that environment stepped Mr. Keating, who quickly eliminated almost all of Lincoln's home mortgage lending in favor of junk bonds, raw land and real estate development.
But many of Lincoln's activities began setting off warning bells at the bank board, prompting San Francisco examiners to warn Washington officials as early as August 1986 that Lincoln was insolvent. To keep the regulators at bay, Mr. Keating turned to the political system, and developed extraordinary political clout by generous contributions, on local, state and national levels.
Experts say the money that Mr. Keating distributed to many members of Congress, and his success in getting five Senators to take up his cause with regulators, was matched only by attempts by owners of troubled savings institutions in Texas to get the former House Speaker and Texan Jim Wright to urge regulators to go easy.
''The way Congress's chain was jerked by a few can only be described as extraordinary,'' said Representative Jim Leach, Republican of Iowa. Mr. Keating, he said, perfected ''the technique of giving a little money up front that would come out of the taxpayer later.''
As a result, Mr. Leach said, Lincoln ''came to symbolize the ideological bent of an Administration that did not realize there had to be some curtailment of deregulation.''

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
Global Warming Means New Global Politics

BYLINE: By ALLAN R. GOLD

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
UNTIL recently, politicians who wanted to avoid the issue of global warming could duck behind the scientific uncertainties. Now, with soaring public concern for the environment and wide scientific agreement about the nature if not the timing of the problem, the debate has shifted. The question is no longer whether the threat is real, but rather how fast it needs to be countered and at what expense.
As discussion moves from the scientific to the political, the world has split into several factions. Some nations like the United States and Japan are also fighting internal political battles. 
Last week environmental ministers from 68 countries met in the Netherlands and agreed in principle to stabilize emissions of carbon dioxide, the main contributor to the so-called greenhouse effect. But bowing to pressure from the United States, the conference avoided any specific timetable.
Much of the carbon dioxide buildup is caused by the burning of coal and oil in power plants and gasoline in automobiles. Other sources include the burning of tropical rain forests. Cutting back carbon dioxide emissions could require big advances in energy conservation, large investment in renewable fuel sources like solar energy and greatly increased automobile fuel economy.
Deciding to pay the price of prevention is doubly painful because no one can prove just when pollution-induced warming and weather disruptions will begin, if they have not already. Experts warn that if the world waits for incontrovertible evidence of major climate change, it will be far too late to do much about it.
The debate has split the world into three camps. Several industrialized European nations support strong measures to stabilize or reduce the emissions. Third world countries like China and India argue that since they are not responsible for much of the problem they should get financial aid in return for cooperating in measures that could hamper desperately needed economic growth. Three major industrial powers, the United States, Japan and the Soviet Union, advocate more cautious approaches.
In October, the United States led a United Nations-sponsored working group in Geneva to discuss an agreement on global warming. American representatives said they came away from the sessions surprised by the extent of support for faster action to stabilize carbon dioxide emissions.
The tone of the Geneva meeting anticipated what would occur in the Netherlands. In the conference declaration, the participants agreed that stabilization of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases should be achieved ''as soon as possible.'' Several European nations, led by the Netherlands, had pressed for a commitment to stabilize the emissions by the year 2000 at 1988 levels, and for a 20 percent reduction by 2005.
The Administration favors more study of the impact of carbon dioxide emissions on the climate and wants to pursue the issue more slowly through the United Nations. That approach received support this week from Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain, who called on the United Nations to complete a global warming treaty by 1992.
Not everyone in the Administration supports the deliberate approach. William K. Reilly, the head of the Environmental Protection Agency, is known to have favored a more aggressive posture at the Netherlands conference, but was rebuffed by other Administration officials. A similar internal struggle is apparently under way in Japan, said Richard Mott, a representative of the Environmental Law Institute, a Washington group that closely monitors climate change issues. As in the United States, the forces in Japan that backed a slower approach won the day at the Netherlands conference.
The White House would prefer a general accord at first, followed later by specific commitments. But William Nitze, the State Department official responsible for coordinating Government policy on global warming, suggested at a conference last month that the United States may be unable to resist a commitment to stabilize carbon dioxide emissions if a world agreement is negotiated in the next few years.
In recent weeks, the President has been sharply criticized by environmental groups and members of Congress from both parties for resisting more aggressive action. The critics warned of dire environmental consequences if the United States, which contributes a fifth of the world's emissions of carbon dioxide, failed to take the lead in dealing with the greenhouse effect.
''It may be logical to say that we need more information about the consequences of accepting a plan to freeze emissions of carbon dioxide at current levels,'' said Senator John Heinz, Republican of Pennsylvania. But on the other hand, he said, ''It is illogical not to weigh the consequences of indecision and inaction on the global environment and our own well-being here in the United States.''

LENGTH: 938 words

HEADLINE: THE REGION;
Dinkins and the Unions That Supported Him Face Fiscal Bad News

BYLINE: By RICHARD LEVINE

 BODY:
STARTING six months after David N. Dinkins's Jan. 1 inauguration as New York City's 106th Mayor and continuing for most of the next six months, contracts with dozens of unions representing the city's 330,000 workers expire, group by group.
Coming at a time of sluggish city tax revenues and rising demand for new spending, especially to meet the needs of the poor and the infirm and to deal with the addicted and the incarcerated, this round of bargaining would do much to define the limits of any new administration. It may be an especially telling period for a new Mayor nominated and elected with strong labor support, especially from the municipal unions.
During the campaign that culminated in his victory last week Mr. Dinkins joined private hospital workers pressing for higher wages and briefly considered supporting a lessening of the penalties under the Taylor law, which bars strikes by public employees. 
But he also indicated his preparation for collective bargaining would include consultation with the Financial Control Board, which was created in the bad old days of profligate spending and would step in if the budget appeared to be slipping out of balance. He has also appointed a panel of economic advisers.
Some union leaders, too, seem mindful of the city's fiscal uncertainties, although given Mr. Dinkins's ascension they may have to cope with heightened expectations among their rank and file. ''We want to make sure David succeeds,'' said Stanley Hill, executive director of District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees. But he also said, ''I always tell my members, 'David Dinkins is a boss. We supported him, but he's a boss.' '' Former Mayor Abraham D. Beame was also a friend of labor, but as the fiscal crisis of the mid-70's deepened the unions made concessions. During the Koch years, which the unions have now helped end, wages increased at just under the rate of inflation, said Robert W. Linn, the Director of Personnel and Labor Relations. He notes, though, that wages alone are not a true measure of a contract's cost.
 
A Growing Payroll
In any event, what has grown far more dramatically than wages is the size of the city workforce. As New York recovered from its fiscal crisis and then unexpectedly found itself flush with revenue, the payroll swelled by 50,000 new positions in six years. In bad times, that payroll could be ripe for pruning.
''The real issue is what are things going to be looking like next year, when the time comes for the administration to begin its talks with labor,'' said Felix G. Rohatyn, the investment banker and chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation. ''Clearly you can't have it all, you can't have a significant increase and a large labor force. Maybe you can have neither.''
If the stakes of municipal bargaining have grown, the tactics have also changed. Mr. Linn characterized the 1960's and early 1970's as a time when labor costs ''exploded,'' not only because of wage increases but also through less obvious contract provisions, such as shortening the time it took new employees to reach higher pay levels.
Typically, he said, the cost to the city of such provisions was not fully appreciated. It was also a time, Mr. Linn said, when each union would demand what the previous union received and a little more, forcing the city into ''an endless cycle of catchup.''
During the fiscal crisis the municipal unions bargained in coalitions that began to break up in the mid 1980's. But Mr. Linn said the administration has been able to maintain equal treatment among the labor organizations though ''pattern bargaining,'' in which the city reaches an agreement with one union and uses the cost of that contract - including, he said, the expense to the city of provisions other than wage increases - as a model for settlements with the rest of the workforce. The various unions can then determine how they want to spend the money, deciding how to divvy up the pot between salary and fringe benefits. This type of bargaining has enabled unions to deal with specific needs. For example, Mr. Hill created a fund that was used to improve salaries for hard-to-fill positions like Emergency Medical Service technicians and Human Resources Administration caseworkers without affecting the contracts with all the other unions.
Does pattern bargaining allow enough flexibility for every group? ''I don't think it does,'' said Sandra Feldman, president of the United Federation of Teachers, who said her union's goal is to make salaries of city teachers competitive with those of teachers in surrounding districts, even if it breaks the pattern. ''That's the way collective bargaining is traditionally carried on,'' she said.
But Mr. Linn sees in such a strategy the danger for the new administration of a return to the time when each union looked out for itself and the city was subjected to what he called ''me, too'' bargaining.
There are other labor issues facing Mr. Dinkins as well. During the Koch years many employees were hired at the discretion of the administration, in some cases bypassing Civil Service. That left the city's personnel system vulnerable to political pressures and patronage, the New York State Commission on Government Integrity found last summer.
And a group of business executives asked by Mayor Edward I. Koch to critique municipal government found among other things that many municipal work places ''are substandard by almost any definition of acceptable employee working conditions.'' In a city strapped for cash, however, that is just one more competing need.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 22, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 749 words

HEADLINE: Two Tyrannies

 BODY:
Historic. Now there's a word journalists love. But what other word is there for democracy's advances last week on German streets, and in the American elections? The dominating demons of our lifetimes are Communism and racism; what is it but historic when the first tyranny shudders and the second continues, visibly, to soften?
Four years ago, four days ago, it was barely imaginable that the East Germans would open the hated wall. Now they can't punch holes in it fast enough. The turmoil is wondrous - and worrisome. 
Before long, Berlin's exultation will wear off. The Germanys will have to find ways to manage the flow of East Germans. The free world must grope for a new equilibrium. Otherwise, the West, having won the cold war, risks losing the hot peace.
In the same week, democracy made less dramatic but more deliberate gains in the United States. The elections did not unsettle the world order. They did produce milestones in the struggle against the interior tyranny of racism, one in which there is no Mikhail Gorbachev to loosen the roots.
A Virginia editor says his state is so conservative that it takes four Virginians to change a light bulb, one to change it and three to say how fine the old one was. It sends a message when an electorate like that, only 15 percent black, gives L. Douglas Wilder enough votes to claim election as the first black governor of any state. Seattle voters, 10 percent black, sent the same message by choosing Norman Rice, a black City Councilman, for mayor.
And racially tormented New York City, where only one voter in four is black, has broadcast the same message even more clearly by electing David Dinkins as its first black mayor. Many black candidates have won mayors' races but usually in cities where black voters predominated. Tuesday's victories demonstrate trans-racial triumphs, once as unimaginable as the end of the wall.
Consider Dallas County, Ala. In 1961, it was half white, half black. But there were 9,000 white voters - and 156 black. Then the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. led the protests that produced the monumental Voting Rights Act of 1965.
In 1965, there were four black members of Congress. Now there are 23. In 1965, there were 280 black elected officials around the country. Now there are 7,200. But democracy, even with the vote, requires vigilance, as Dallas County shows. Not until 11 months ago, under continuous pressure, did it hold commissioner elections in fairly drawn districts. Three blacks, the first ever, were elected.
What law has changed in the South is yielding to cultural change in the North. David Dinkins attracted many more younger than older voters, a portent of progress. But even so, there's a danger of confusing political and economic progress.
Yes, the proportion of blacks who live in suburbs has jumped, since 1960, from 15 percent to 26; but for whites it's still half. Yes, black husband-and-wife families earn $30,000-plus. That's 82 percent of the white figure, a big gain in 20 years. But nearly half of black families are headed by women, and their income typically is only $11,000.
America knows how to help, with Head Start, for instance. Yet society sputters and stalls. How many eligible poor children are enrolled? One in six. There's much to do, and no mystery about how to do it. The need for early childhood programs is obvious to men like Douglas Wilder, David Dinkins and Norman Rice, and they speak not only for black constituencies. They speak for a country that is moving, messily, unevenly, toward a standard of racial equality probably unknown in history.
There is very far to go, but it's also worth pondering race relations elsewhere. Periodically, Japanese politicians apologize profusely for pronouncing recklessly on the low state of literacy among American blacks. Black visitors to the Soviet Union regularly recoil in disgust at blatant racism. In China last year, students rioted over ''the black devils'' from Africa. Insult, discrimination and deep poverty endure in this country. And yet, as the elections attest, America keeps enlarging democracy.
At the start of the cold war, a magazine ad showed a girl looking up from a history book to ask, ''Mommy, who was Hitler?'' Perhaps one day, a child of this generation will ask, ''What was the Berlin wall? What were Civil Rights?'' The answer depends on Americans' prudence in Europe, and determination at home. ''Victories,'' we may earn the right to say; ''victories for democracy.''

PUB-DATE: November 12, 1989

SECTION: Section 4; Page 23, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 716 words

HEADLINE: ABROAD AT HOME;
The New Europe

BYLINE: By Anthony Lewis

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
In the disorder of our stunned reactions to the drama playing out in East Germany, we can scarcely begin to see the consequences. But one is clear. Political stability in Europe is going to depend more than ever on the European Community.
Only the Community can provide an alternative political focus for all the European states as, inevitably, the Soviet Union and the United States withdraw military forces from the region and their influence wanes. Only the Community can offer a reassuring framework that will be Europe's economic powerhouse. 
Economics and political ideas drove events in East Germany. The longings for freedom and a better life that first burst out in the 1953 uprising brought East Germans to the streets and across the borders. This time the Soviet leader refused to use force. Mikhail Gorbachev told Egon Krenz: You're on your own.
The moment when Mr. Gorbachev made that decision marked the symbolic end of the postwar order in central Europe: an order maintained by Soviet military force. To have allowed the formation of a non-Communist government in Poland was an enormous change. To doom Communist domination of East Germany was more.
Mr. Krenz is hardly a liberating figure by nature; last summer he applauded China for crushing the students in Tiananmen Square. But he understood what Mr. Gorbachev's decision meant. Without Soviet support for a military response, protest could no longer be contained.
The state was bleeding, its best-trained and most highly motivated people leaving by the thousands. If things went on that way, East Germany would be a country of pensioners. Mr. Krenz's only recourse was to convince citizens - by reason, not by force - that they should stay.
Mr. Krenz opened the gates and promised they would stay open, so people need not seize this opportunity to leave. He spoke of free elections. He allowed an opposition to form without harassment.
But all that is still not enough. East Germans will be persuaded not to vote with their feet only if they have hope of economic improvement. They see West German television, and they know the difference between that standard of living and their own gray existence.
Where can Mr. Krenz look for the investment and aid needed to lift the standards of life in East Berlin and Leipzig and Dresden? Only to West Germany. And that fact has political implications.
Governmental aid from Bonn, large as it already has been, cannot be enough. Private investment is needed. And West German companies will not invest in the East unless they can use the methods that have made them so successful. They will want market conditions. And it looks as though Mr. Krenz is ready to let that happen.
The result of such change in the East German economic system, and of heavy investment from West Germany, must be to bring the two Germanys much closer together. Formal reunification still seems a distant prospect, but there are many ways of association short of that.
In economic terms, the division of Germany is almost certainly going to fade away. A few years from now there will be a German economy with twice the gross domestic product of any other country in Europe. That would surely raise the old fears of German domination - unless the European Community is functioning as it hopes in economic unity and political purpose.
The Community's program to end all trade barriers among members by 1992 is given greater importance by the events in Eastern Europe. Even more vital is the proposal to create a European central bank and a common European currency. For the alternative is domination by West Germany's financial policy and its central bank.
The new realities have a particular meaning for Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. She has been fighting the Community's plan for financial union, splitting her own Cabinet and Conservative Party in doing so. Now her insistence that Britain must defend its sovereignty by staying aloof from the Community plan looks even more shortsighted.
But there will be consequences for many politicians. Will Vice President Quayle finally understand that Mikhail Gorbachev is really making changes in the Soviet world? Will the Stalinist leaders of Czechoslovakia be able to go on resisting the tide of freedom? Autumn 1989 is only the beginning.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-ed

COUNTRY: EUROPE (97%); GERMANY (96%); UNITED STATES (94%); EUROPEAN UNION MEMBER STATES (93%); CHINA (79%); POLAND (79%); CENTRAL EUROPE (73%); 

CITY: BERLIN, GERMANY (79%); 

COMPANY: EUROPEAN COMMUNITY (84%); EUROPEAN COMMUNITY (84%);

PUB-DATE: November 12, 1989

SECTION: Section 6; Page 42, Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 3904 words

HEADLINE: LAUGHTER, TEARS AND THE PERFECT MARTINI

BYLINE: By Alex Witchel; Alex Witchel is a senior features editor at Mirabella magazine and writes the Inside Theater column for 7 Days.

 BODY:
AR. GURNEY JR. IS AT HIS FAVORITE kind of party - the kind where they don't read the reviews. The occasion is that after 370 performances of the Off Broadway hit ''The Cocktail Hour,'' Keene Curtis, the actor who has been playing the father, is leaving the show.
The party is being held in the empty lobby of the Promenade Theater after a Sunday matinee; the cast is there, a few of their friends. Curtis toasts the other actors with his plastic cup of champagne. He tells them that a friend who saw the play overheard someone announce, ''They should sell T-shirts that say, 'A. R. Gurney knows my family,' '' The cast laughs. They feel good about this, having come under fire - as many Gurney characters do - for playing WASP's who avoid emotional accountability and shun confrontation. The only handicap they acknowledge is on the golf course.
The actors encourage two of the ushers, Hispanic teen-agers, to re-enact a scene between the play's father and son, which they deliver in Spanish. Everyone howls. Everyone except the man who wasn't bred to howl, the man who, instead, stands at the edge of the crowd and broadcasts a smile they could see back in his native Buffalo. 
Gurney is in his element. Wearing crumpled khakis and a blue, button-down shirt (real WASP's don't wear Polo), he looks like a well-meaning guy from somewhere out of town who's having a perfectly marvelous time. Which is exactly what he is. Because after spending 26 years on the Massachusetts Institute of Technology faculty while he struggled to establish himself as a playwright, Gurney, 59, is finished with what his teaching colleague, Richard Douglas, calls ''leading a hyphenated life.'' Having written his first full-length play at the age of 40, Gurney finally got the nerve to give up his day job - and (Continued on Page 102) his parents' scorn of the theater as an exhibitionist forum - and moved to New York seven years ago.
Gurney's intimate, small-cast plays are ideal for the theater of the Nineties, where Broadway's blockbuster economics continue to prohibit any writer - with the possible exception of Neil Simon - from maintaining a consistent presence. Instead, like the work of Sam Shepard and Terrence McNally, Gurney's plays have a loyal following Off Broadway and in regional theater, where they are always revived.
''The Cocktail Hour'' opens at Chicago's Royal George Theater this month; a touring company begins in January, playing small theaters that seat roughly 1,000. Gurney's two-character star vehicle, ''Love Letters,'' which is written in letter form and read aloud, opened in August to positive reviews. It will continue to rotate its casts weekly at Broadway's Edison Theater, to which it recently transferred after a limited run at the Promenade - counting among its number William Hurt, Julie Harris, Jason Robards and Kate Nelligan. Another production of the play opens this week at San Francisco's Theater on the Square, and companies are planned for Los Angeles and Chicago.
Television, too, has discovered Gurney. His play ''The Middle Ages'' has been adapted by friend and fellow playwright Percy Granger for an ABC special this season called ''His Brother's Wife,'' starring John Ritter, Polly Bergen and Mel Harris.
Gurney has also just started work on a musical. It is an adaptation of his novel, ''The Snow Ball,'' the story of a rich WASP girl and a poor Irish boy who are perfectly suited to each other once they're on the dance floor.
Talk about prolific. Many theater insiders do, and snidely, the implication being that if Gurney can write so much - without the playwright's requisite suffering and extended dry periods - how good can any of it be? The playwright Wendy Wasserstein, whom Gurney relies on as one of his ''torpedoes,'' the group of four or five theater professionals he turns to when his play goes ''into the tunnel'' - the inevitable crisis point in its rehearsal period - dismisses this idea. ''All I can think of is Gene Kelly,'' she says. ''You know. 'Gotta dance.' ''
Gurney remains impervious to the theater world's sniping. His confidence comes from having won his success in gradual doses, through his unrelenting Protestant work ethic. ''Slow and steady wins the race is perhaps the most WASP-y thing of all,'' says Andre Bishop, fellow WASP and artistic director of Playwrights Horizons, who has produced three of Gurney's plays and was responsible for launching his breakthrough hit, ''The Dining Room,'' in 1982.
''Most WASP's identify with tortoises, not hares, and Pete's one of them.''
Gilbert Parker, Gurney's agent for the last 16 years, who represents some of the theater's biggest names, including John Tillinger, a frequent Gurney director, offers what is possibly the ultimate rave for any agent: ''I never cringe when I hear that Pete is on the phone.'' And the Broadway press agent David Powers, a veteran of many Gurney plays, says: ''He's a real gentleman. I once told him I had the perfect title for his autobiography: 'I Can Get It For You Retail.' ''
ALBERT RAMSDELL GUR-ney Jr. - known as Pete (don't look for a connection; his mother just liked the name) -is the only playwright to have had nine of his plays produced in New York over the last eight years. What he continually writes about is Buffalo's WASP aristocracy. And if it's impossible to peg Gurney as the prototypical WASP, he comes close enough. Unlike Philip Barry of ''The Philadelphia Story'' and ''Holiday'' fame, to whom he is often compared, Gurney refuses to glamorize his WASP's a la Hollywood - cotillion balls and fox hunts are not for them. Barry's Tracy Lord would be bored to distraction in a Gurney play.
Still, Gurney's characters live in a world of maids, country clubs and cocktails. No matter how adverse their circumstances, they make monumental efforts not to raise their voices. They are prime ulcer candidates, but they never let the strain spoil their backhand. And they all know how to mix the perfect martini - which helps make everything more bearable.
But these people are far from dull. Gurney's elegant, light touch with dialogue is as reassuring as it is entertaining; his banter is just a more refined version of what you tell your shrink:
BRADLEY: (Looking warily at manuscript) What's it called, this play?
JOHN: It's called ''The Cocktail Hour,'' actually.
BRADLEY: It's called the what?
JOHN: ''The Cocktail Hour.''
BRADLEY: That's a terrible title.
ANN: Oh now, sweetheart. . . . BRADLEY: Terrible. JOHN: Why is it terrible?
BRADLEY: To begin with, it's been used.
JOHN: That's ''The Cocktail PARTY,'' Pop. That's T. S. Eliot. BRADLEY: Even worse. We walked out on that one. ANN: This is ''The Cocktail Hour,'' darling.
BRADLEY: Doesn't make any difference.
ANN: No, it does. A cocktail party is a public thing. You invite people to a cocktail party. A cocktail hour is family. It's private. It's personal. It's very different.
BRADLEY: Nobody will know that. It will confuse everyone. They'll come expecting T. S. Eliot, and they'll get John. Either way, they'll want their money back.* Nancy Marchand, who played the mother in ''The Cocktail Hour,'' and who also grew up in Buffalo, says: ''I do wish that every actor who plays the son in this play would study Pete more. Physically, the way he uses himself is very WASP-y. He doesn't walk as much as shuffle, he looks at you sidewise, smiles a lot, and keeps his hands in his pockets.'' Arthur Miller, Gurney's longtime friend, neighbor and tennis partner, has a favorite story. A few years back, he was standing in the subway, waiting for a train, when he was approached by a Hasidic Jew. ''Excuse me,'' the man whispered. ''Are you Jewish?'' ''Yes, I am,'' Miller answered. The man brightened considerably. ''Then, can you tell me, does this train go to Canal Street?''
This is, of course, the same assumption that many make about Gurney's world - that if you didn't prep at Hotchkiss, you just won't get it. But the reason why there are just as many Schulmans as Simpsons lining up at the box-office window for Gurney's plays is the work's universality. Once you get past the idea that his characters are people who actually like dressing for dinner, you can recognize their loneliness, bitterness and overwhelming sense of isolation. One of Gurney's favorite reviews of ''The Cocktail Hour'' came from Michael Elkin, syndicated columnist of Philadelphia's Jewish Exponent: ''Sure, we know Gurney is reportedly wired into the WASP experience with his own WATTS line, but . . . 'The Cocktail Hour' . . . is intoxicating proof that families drink from the same glass of tsoris no matter the spelling of their last name.''
Yet, last year, before Gurney's ''Another Antigone'' opened at Playwrights Horizons, there was some talk of anti-Semitism. The lead character, Henry Harper, a classics professor, clashes over graduation requirements with Judy Miller, a headstrong Jewish student, who joins an attempt to have him ousted from the faculty. But the allegation was inaccurate. Frank Rich wrote in The New York Times, '' . . . it's patently obvious that Harper is no anti-Semite, and Judy's enrollment in the smear campaign only destroys her integrity as a character.''
Besides drawing a Jewish audience - a necessity for survival in the New York theater - Gurney's WASP's travel well. Productions of most of his 13 full-length plays have been produced worldwide -everywhere from Argentina to Australia to Italy.
The one real gripe critics have with Gurney's work is that he has never written a major character on a par with a James Tyrone, Blanche DuBois or Willy Loman. Nor has he ever written the blood-and-guts battle after which a character - or the audience - can find a pure catharsis. But because the operative element in Gurney's dramatic world is ensemble - checks and balances take on a new meaning here - these kinds of moments are not consistent with his characters. Any word or action too extreme would threaten their very existence, and Gurney simply won't have it.
''I was lucky to grow up in a civilized world,'' he says, ''because Buffalo, which doesn't sound very civilized, was really the city time forgot. It had all the cultural advantage of a big city, with a small-town coherence. The dancing school that I went to, and my wife, Molly, went to, was the same one my parents attended. My grandmother was taught by the same guy who taught me. We're talking about continuity that went back three or four generations. So, at an early age, I sensed the comforts of civilization - but also its discontents, what you give up. The emotions are carefully trained, ultimately honed, tamped down.
''I'm not terribly comfortable with conflict,'' he continues. ''All my life, I was accused of being the troublemaker in my family. My mother used to say that whenever things were settled down and quiet, she and my father would hear these yelps coming from upstairs and they knew it was me teasing, going into someone's room and starting a fight. But whether those fights ever ended in an authentic confrontation that a play should have, I don't know. How many ultimate confrontations are there in Chekhov? Very few.''
Gurney's stance has drawn fire from critics like New York Magazine's John Simon, who called ''The Cocktail Hour'' ''one of 1988's better insipidities.'' Frank Rich wrote that Gurney ''is not the sort to turn an evening of martini-fueled drawing-room banter into a truly drunken 'Long Day's Journey Into Night.' ''
But rebuttals are rampant. Arthur Miller says, ''Most playwrights never write a character like Willy Loman and they're still perfectly good playwrights.'' Gurney's daughter, Evelyn, one of his four grown children, also defends him. ''A repressed emotion doesn't mean it's not a valid emotion. It's unfair to ask him to write about something outside his experience.'' Andre Bishop notes: ''I love and understand a world where things are unspoken and yet very clear. Where it isn't all out there, and doesn't have to be. You'll never make Pete Gurney into Christopher Durang - he's not a go-for-broke satirist. What he is, is a true and graceful chronicler.''
What he is also, is rabid about his critics. Everyone who attended ''The Cocktail Hour'' opening night party at Ernie's - a cavernous yuppie eatery near the Promenade Theater where no self-respecting Gurney character would ever be caught dead - recalls Gurney's fury at the reviews. Holland Taylor, who played the daughter, remembers: ''Someone read The Times review'' - which was mixed - ''and Pete just stood there with his hands in his pockets, looking left to right, sort of bobbing his head. He was quite flushed. He felt dismissed. It was one of those moments where everyone was talking at once and there was no focus on him particularly. It was an indistinct moment, the kind Pete can capture easily in a play - hurt feelings, instantly concealed. A stunned, wounded kind of anger.''
Tom Viertel, one of the producers of ''The Cocktail Hour,'' says that, despite Gurney's distress, the play recouped its $385,000 capitalization at the 399-seat theater in 16 weeks. According to Viertel, this was faster than any play he and his partners had ever produced.
IT IS LUNCHTIME AT BICE, A crowded midtown restaurant. Gurney, uncomfortable in a one on one about himself, smokes contraband Merits, which Molly, his wife of 32 years and a nutritionist, forbids at home. He's wearing a nondescript tweed jacket (with peppermint Lifesavers in the pocket) over his usual cotton uniform, and his quiet, almost-warm tone betrays three decades of wine and cheese with wide-eyed literature students. At his core, he's the best kind of teacher, the generous kind, rooting for everyone to get it right. It's an attitude that endears him to most, especially to actors.
Lunch is salad and a squid-ink risotto, with both courses delivered to the table almost simultaneously. When the waiter brings coffee, he asks if everything has been all right. When we tell him that one course at a time would have been appreciated, he launches into a million excuses. After he leaves, I say, ''Don't you love when a waiter asks how things are and you tell him and he really doesn't want to know?'' Gurney laughs. ''That's true of everyone, isn't it?'' he says.
It certainly is of Gurney. But no matter how many times he's criticized, he never stops writing. It's almost as if, having been born into the most accepted, most white, most powerful group in the society, he can't fathom one existing that he can't eventually break into and belong. And not just belong, but excel. Molly Gurney says: ''I dread opening nights. With 'The David Show' (Gurney's first produced play in New York, 1968), Pete got physically sick over the reviews.''
Gurney's eldest son, George, remembers, ''After 'The David Show,' my father came back from New York and we were all excited, expecting presents. But Clive Barnes had nailed him, so he just went upstairs and went to sleep.'' But, Molly says, he was up and writing again the next day.
PETE GURNEY WAS born in Buffalo on Nov. 1, 1930. His father, A.R. Gurney Sr., was president of Gurney, Becker and Bourne, an insurance and real estate business (and, as Gurney says, ''the wonderful autocrat of the dinner table''). Pete was the middle child of three; his sister, Evelyn, still lives in Buffalo and his younger brother, Stephen, is on the faculty of a private school in New Haven.
Gurney graduated from Williams College, was commissioned as an officer in the Navy - where he had the love affair with a Japanese woman that makes its way into two of his plays,'' The Middle Ages'' and ''Love Letters.'' Not quite rebellious enough to bring her back home (''There were certain frantic signals from Buffalo, New York, on that, I can tell you''), he returned alone and enrolled in the Yale School of Drama's playwrighting program. Midway through, he spent a summer in New York working as a script reader for the Kraft Television Theater. His mother had him look up Molly Goodyear, a Buffalo girl who had left Bryn Mawr and was spending the summer working at New York Hospital. The two married the following year. (A side note on WASP inbreeding: Two years after Gurney's father died in 1977, his mother married Molly's father.) After graduating from Yale, Gurney taught English for two years at the Belmont Hill School, a private school in Belmont, Mass. In 1960, a friend offered him a position at M.I.T. (''my salary jumped from $4,800 a year to $5,200''), where he stayed until 1987, teaching literature, and doggedly writing his plays. ''After 'The David Show' got thoroughly pasted by The Times, I had to slink back to school and teach a course on the American drama the next day,'' he remembers.
Gurney wrote on summer vacations and sabbaticals. And, he says, he wrote about what he didn't have: ''I wrote 'The Dining Room' after we had given up our own dining room - we lived in a big house in Newton, Mass., and during the energy crisis we had closed off the living room, sold our dining-room furniture and turned it into a family room. We all huddled together and ate in the kitchen. I realized what we'd lost, so I tried to write my way back into that world.''
He took a similar approach with ''Love Letters.'' ''I'd been fooling around with the letter form for some time. In the world I grew up in, they were always sending you away someplace, so in order to maintain contact with your family or your girl, you'd have to write,'' he says. ''My father-in-law had given me an I.B.M. PC and I started playing with it. I wasn't very good at the margins, so I wrote great chunks of dialogue, just practicing, and suddenly the letter form came together. The computer made me think about the differences in computer writing and letter writing - the scratch of the pen, the special quality of a personal letter. I found myself writing about the lost process of letter writing.''
Perhaps the most important thing that Gurney has always been without is his father's approval. It is what drives him repeatedly to write plays with fathers and sons in adversarial relationships; and it may be that the irrational hope of getting that approval is what has prevented him from writing a character capable of an all-out tantrum, rejecting the father and the father's world, as surely as he feels it has rejected him.
''Just as it's mentioned in 'The Cocktail Hour,' my great-grandfather hung up his clothes one day and walked into the Niagara River and no one understood why,'' Gurney says. ''He was a distinguished man in Buffalo. My father could never mention it, and it affected the family well into the fourth generation as a dark and unexplainable gesture. It made my father and his father desperate to be accepted, to be conventional, and comfortable. It made them commit themselves to an -ostensibly - easy bourgeois world. They saw it so precariously, but the reason was never mentioned. I first learned about it after my father died'' - an event Gurney won't discuss - ''from my father-in-law, who is a genealogist and had dug out the old newspaper articles. I was 48 at the time.''
Molly Gurney remembers: ''Peter's father was a very charming guy, and I used to think he was just wonderful - until I married Peter. He never really accepted me. You could say I wasn't good enough for his son, but his son wasn't good enough, either. He didn't accept any of his children's spouses. The charm just went off. In some ways I'm angrier at his father than Peter is. He's very forgiving. He never would have dared to talk to his father the way the son does in 'The Cocktail Hour.' But that's a form of confrontation and reconciliation he wishes he had had with his own father.''
If Gurney has found his revenge in that most public of places, the theater, then he's also found it in the way he's raised his own family - sans martinis and dinner jackets. On a Sunday afternoon last July, two of his children -Evelyn, 28, and George, 31, his oldest - are visiting their parents' Connecticut farm with their spouses; George's wife, Connie, expects the family's first grandchild this month. From the road, the house seems ordinary -white clapboard with black shutters - but its size is deceiving. It spreads itself out away from the road. There's a swimming pool, a barn, two active wells, orchards of peach and apple trees, a vegetable garden and 20 acres of hills, lawn and trees.
Inside, Molly is making borscht with beets from the garden. The house is full of books and Gurney has his dining room back now - with a vengeance. The antique table looks long enough to seat George Washington's troops. Upstairs, Gurney writes on a computer in one of the bedrooms - predictably bare -on an old desk burned down one side by coffee-cup rings.
Molly brings the hot borscht out to a picnic table on the terrace (the house has no air-conditioning, but she doesn't sweat - none of them do) and serves it with bread and cheese. Gurney presides at the head of the table. Everything feels easy - no rules past ''please'' and ''thank you''.
Evelyn recalls when she and her siblings were growing up, and Gurney was deep into writing a play, he'd pay no attention to the dinner conversation, although he'd pretend to. ''He'd be totally out of it and we'd say, 'Dad, can we have some candy?' and he'd stare out the window and say, 'uuuuh-huuuuuuh.' ''
When lunch is over, Gurney stays at the table outside and, safe from Molly's view, lights up a Merit. Time is short; we will be leaving soon for New York, to see Julie Harris and Richard Kiley perform in ''Love Letters.'' Forced again to talk about himself and his work, about his detractors, about the Stanley Kowalski he's never written, Gurney finally says: ''I think that what I have done, is to create a body of work, somewhat interconnected, about the first Eastern city to suffer as American power moved west, and I've dealt with its people in a changing time.''
Does he speculate on how his successors at M.I.T. would teach his work, if they taught him at all? He answers like a true professor: ''My point of view is primarily comic in that I see a reconciliation possible at the play's end between the individual and the world. And that's not terribly American. If you look at the European tradition - Moliere, Coward, Congreve - the world is always put back together by the end. In American comedies, there's anarchism at the end - Huck Finn says goodbye and shoves off for the territories, Holden Caulfield ends up in the madhouse. So, I see what I do as going against the grain of the American embracing of private freedom.''
He talks about his plans for the musical, about a new play that will focus on his generation as the parents instead of the children. ''I think I have pretty much mined this vein,'' he says of the WASP culture. ''I've pretty much said what I've wanted to say. In musical comedy, certainly, emotions have to be more direct. I'm trying to move away from the tight form of the drawing-room comedy.''
Molly comes outside and, pretending not to see the Merits in the ashtray, signals that it's time to leave. We go to the car, and the kids all come out as if on cue to see us off. It is a familiar ritual for them, one they've grown up with. When, at just the time of day that some people are having a cocktail hour, their father says goodbye, and goes to the theater.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 53, Column 1; Magazine Desk

HEADLINE: JUST ANOTHER NIGHT ON CRACK STREET

BYLINE: By Philippe Bourgois; Philippe Bourgois, an anthropologist on fieldwork leave from San Francisco State University, is writing a book about street culture in East Harlem, to be published by Little, Brown.

 BODY:
THE HEAVYSET UNDERCOVER POLICEMAN pushed me across the ice-cream counter, spreading my legs and poking me around the groin. As he came dangerously close to the bulge in my right pocket I hissed in his ear, ''It's a tape recorder.'' He snapped backward, releasing his grip on my neck, whispering a barely audible, ''Sorry.'' Apparently he thought I was an undercover cop from another department. Before I could get a close look at him, he had left the bodega, a grocery store-cum-numbers joint.
After almost five years of living in a tenement apartment in East Harlem with my family, I have learned how to deal with the police officers who regularly stop me in the course of my work. I am an ethnographer conducting long-term, participant-observation research on street culture in the underground economy. I spend long hours, night and day, in crack houses and on drug-copping corners, observing, befriending and interviewing street dealers, addicts and anyone else who will pause to talk with me. It is unusual work, to say the least, difficult for outsiders to appreciate, perhaps most particularly the police, who cannot fathom why anyone would immerse himself in the heart of the drug culture if not for the drugs. 
Once I made the mistake of trying to explain my work to two patrolmen, both white, who stopped me late at night and angrily said, ''Go buy your drugs in a white neighborhood, and get the hell off these streets, white boy.'' I had barely uttered, ''No, you don't understand, I don't use drugs. I am a professor . . .'' when I was called ''dirty white scum,'' and threatened with a booking in the precinct if I didn't ''shut up and get out of here right this minute.''
The night in the bodega I did what I had learned to do when being frisked - stare at the ground, avoid eye contact and mumble obsequiously, ''Yes, sir,'' whenever appropriate. This encounter was an easy one. I hadn't even had (Continued on Page 60) to say, ''Thank you, sir,'' and I was not publicly cursed. As soon as the officer was out of earshot, I was able to focus back on my work.
In an effort to display trust and establish a better rapport, I told Jesus - the street dealer and crack addict I happened to be interviewing that night - to grab the change from my $10 bill from the cashier as I hurried to leave. At the doorway, however, I was blocked by a thin teen-ager named Bennie, who pushed me aside and lunged at the loose dollar bills in Jesus' hand.
''That's my money now, Jesus; give it to me,'' Bennie shouted. I started to shout back: ''Hey! What are you talking about? That's my money!'' But one look at Bennie's contorted face and narrowed eyes stopped me. Jesus muttered ''Be careful - my man is dusted,'' but it was unnecessary. I was ready to give up the eight bills - and more if I had to -to avoid any out-of-control violence from an angry mugger high on angel dust.
Jesus went through the motions of confronting Bennie, to whom he really did owe money. First he was gentle. Staring into Bennie's face, which was two inches from his own, he pulled at the fistful of bills and said: ''Yo, Bennie, chill out. I know how much I owe you. I'll take care of you tomorrow. This ain't my money. Please don't take this money.'' Then he tried a harsher tack: ''I told you this ain't my money; Get off of it! It ain't my money!'' Bennie just got tougher. He knew Jesus was a coward. He yanked at the bills, hissing about the $60 still owed him. They had been selling marijuana together for several weeks on the corner next to the bodega, and during a bust a week earlier, the police had confiscated their supply. Bennie wanted Jesus to make good on his share. He knew that Jesus would not fight back. As the bills began to rip, Jesus finally let go, looking back at me sheepishly.
As we stepped out the door of the bodega, Bennie kept yelling at Jesus about the $60. Then he let out a whistle, and a dented Vega came roaring down the block. It careered to the curb and cut us off. A young man in the passenger seat tried to open his door and jump onto the sidewalk before the car stopped, but he fell on his face in the gutter. He jumped back to his feet, and stood, unsteadily. His nose was bleeding. He was waving a baseball bat in his right hand.
The driver, who was steadier - apparently not as high as his companion - had also rushed out of the car and was running at us. Bennie called out that all was ''cool,'' that he already had the money; and they slowed down, walking toward us with puffed backs, the one with the baseball bat resting it on his shoulder.
Frightened, I jumped back to the bodega door, trying to figure out where to run and what to do, but Jesus had to stand firm. This was the corner he worked; those were his former partners. They surrounded him, shouting about the money, and began kicking him and hitting him with the bat. Jesus still did not turn and run; instead he jumped up and down, prancing sideways along the sidewalk toward the corner on the main avenue. He was hoping his new colleagues at the bogus botanica, a shop that ostensibly sold herbal potions and spiritual items, around the corner, to whom he was steering crack customers, might catch sight of what was happening. He was knocked down twice before reaching the corner. Then the two men backed away, walking back to the Vega with deliberate slowness, pretending not to notice me. They had not seen the policeman search me, and they evidently did not think it wise to pick a fight with an unknown ''white boy'' who was just the right age to be an undercover. Obviously nervous, they pulled at Bennie's elbow to hustle him into the car. Then they drove off, leaving rubber at the curb.
By the time I caught up with Jesus, half a block down the avenue, he was telling the story to his cousin. A woman in her late 20's, dressed ''butch'' in a long-sleeved jean jacket, she was on her way to the botanica crack house. Her emaciated face and long sleeves made it likely she was a coke mainliner. She was waving her skinny arms and stamping on the ground, whining hoarsely at Jesus, telling him he couldn't just run off like that; that he had to ''go down swinging like a man''; that he couldn't just let people chase him around; that he had to show them who's who. Now what did he expect to do? Where was he going to work? Finally, she said she needed the money she had lent him the day before to buy a new supply of marijuana - he had spent it on crack instead - and that she was disgusted with him.
At the crack/botanica house, we told our story to Julio and Papito, who were on duty selling that night. Julio jumped up excitedly, calling out: ''What street was that on? Come on, we can still catch them. How many were they?'' I said we should just forget about it; revenge wasn't worth it. And Papito looked at me disgustedly, sitting back down on the milk crate in front of the botanica's door. Julio, whom I knew better, jumped up in front of me, raising his voice to berate me. ''Man, you still think like a blanquito,'' he said. A half-dozen spectators - some of them empty-pocketed, ''thirsty'' crack addicts, but most of them sharp-dressed teen-age girls competing for Papito's and Julio's attentions - snickered at me.
To regain some minimal respect, I turned on Jesus, telling him he owed me the $8 Bennie had stolen, and ordering him to empty his pockets. Grinning, he pulled out a dollar and promised he would come by tomorrow with seven more. He told me not to worry; he would pay me back first. Of course, I knew he would not. He knew that I was one of the few individuals on the street even softer than he.
At this point, seeing my feeble attempt, Julio, making sure I saw what he was doing, dropped a vial of crack in Jesus's shirt pocket in payment for the half dozen customers he had steered to the crack house that evening. I was supposed to grab the vial - worth $5 - from Jesus's pocket as partial compensation for the seven he still owed me. But I could not bring myself to rip Jesus's shirt pocket open, knowing that Jesus was ''thirsty'' to smoke and might get violent with me.
A few minutes later, Papito and Julio told everyone it was time to close shop. It was 12:30, and they had to turn in the evening's receipts to their boss. They pulled down the metal gates over the botanica's entrance, eager to leave work and get on with an evening of partying.
UNLIKE THE CRACK DEAL-ers and addicts that I hang out with and interview, the vast majority of the residents of East Harlem are honest and hard-working. It is a struggle to live there, and they struggle honorably. Nevertheless, to many, especially the young, the underground economy beckons seductively as the ultimate ''equal opportunity employer.'' The rate of unemployment for Harlem youth is at least twice the citywide rate of 8.1 percent, and the economic incentive to participate in the burgeoning crack economy is overwhelming.
The individuals ''successfully'' pursuing careers in the ''crack economy'' or any other facet of the underground economy are no longer ''exploitable'' by legal society. They speak with anger at their former low wages and bad treatment. They make fun of friends and acquaintances - many of whom come to buy drugs from them - who are still employed in factories or in service jobs.
Most of the people I have met are proud that they are not being exploited by ''the White Man.'' All of them have, at one time or another, held the jobs - delivery boys, supermarket baggers, hospital orderlies -that are objectively recognized as among the least desirable in American society. They see the illegal, underground economy as not only offering superior wages, but also a more dignified workplace.
For example, Julio's last legal job before selling crack was as a messenger for a magazine. He had become addicted to crack and began selling off his possessions to pay for his habit. Finally he was thrown out by his wife, who had just given birth to his son. He quit his 10-hour-a-day messenger job in favor of stealing car radios for a couple of hours at night in the same neighborhoods where he had been delivering messages. After a close encounter with the police, Julio, who is 26 years old, begged his cousin for a job in his crack house. The sense of responsibility, success and prestige that selling crack gave him enabled him to kick his crack habit and substitute for it a considerably less expensive powder cocaine and alcohol habit.
JULIO'S GIRLFRIEND JACKIE also sells crack. Her husband used to own the botanica crack site, but he is now ''upstate,'' serving two to five years for his second conviction for selling cocaine and possessing firearms. Two nights before he was scheduled to go to jail, as he was closing down the botanica, Jackie, who was eight months' pregnant at the time, shot him in the stomach in front of all his workers. She was furious because instead of leaving money for her before beginning his jail sentence, he had been running around spending thousands of dollars on young women and bragging about it.
Ten months later, Jackie, at 32, was doing much better, especially following the problem-free delivery of her fifth daughter. Her husband's cousin, who had taken over the crack franchise at the botanica while her husband was in jail, had witnessed the shoot-out, and had been impressed by Jackie's aggressiveness; shortly after the birth of her daughter, he hired her to sell ''twenties of rock'' -$20 foils of cocaine - at his other sales point in the neighborhood, a candy store.
Not everyone shared his feelings, however. Shortly after her husband's hospitalization and jailing, Jackie took up with Julio, and she told Rose, a 15-year-old former girlfriend of his, to stop hanging around the crack house - or else. I was there one evening when Rose was discussing this threat with a crowd hanging out around the crack house. Someone was warning Rose that Jackie meant business, when Aida, the seller on shift at the crack house that evening looked up from the pink blanket she was knitting for the baby she was pregnant with and called out: ''Big deal! Anybody can buy a gun. You just stay here, Rose. You can come visit me any time you want. That woman's just nasty. She can't tell me or you or anyone else what to do here. She don't own the place.''
Rose did, indeed, keep coming back, even after another of her ex-boyfriends, who claimed he still loved her, threatened to kill Julio and then commit suicide if she kept hanging out at the crack house at night. He showed up a few days later with two big friends, but by then Julio had gathered a group of his own for protection, and the would-be assailants just kept walking. Julio was exasperated with the whole issue; he had lost interest in Rose after he had gotten her pregnant, and they had argued heatedly when he refused to pay for her abortion.
REGULAR DISPLAYS OF violence are necessary for success in the underground economy - especially the street-level drug-dealing world. Violence is essential for maintaining credibility and for preventing rip-offs by colleagues, customers and intruders. Thus behavior that appears irrationally violent and self-destructive to the middle- or working-class outsider can be interpreted, according to the logic of the underground economy, as judicious public relations.
This can be clearly seen in the events described at the outset of this article. Jesus and I were mugged because he had a reputation for being a coward and because I had been publicly unmasked as not being an undercover cop - hence, safe to attack. Jesus had tried to minimize the damage to his ability to sell on that corner by not turning and running. Nevertheless, the admonishments of his cousin just minutes later could not have been clearer: Jesus was not going to be upwardly mobile in the underground economy. Where was he going to work after such a public humiliation?
Employers or new entrepreneurs in the underground economy are looking for people with experience that proves their capacity for effective violence - Jackie's being hired to sell cocaine by the man who witnessed her shooting her husband is an example. Papito had a ''bionic leg.'' He had been shot through the thigh in a previous crack confrontation, and his leg had been successfully rebuilt, leaving him with a pronounced limp. He frequently referred to his rebuilt limb in conversation; it was a source of pride and credibility for him. He was considered an effective crack dealer.
For the owner of the crack house, the ability of his employees to face up to the possibility of violence is crucial; stickups of dealing dens are common. During my time there, the botanica was held up twice. Julio was on duty both times. He admitted that he had been very nervous when robbers held a gun to his temple and asked for money and crack. Nevertheless, not only did he withhold some of the money and crack, kept hidden inside a hollowed-out statue of a saint, but he also later exaggerated to his boss the amount that had been stolen; he pocketed the difference himself.
The possibility of being held up was constantly on Julio's mind. When more than two people walked into the botanica at once, he would stiffen, as if expecting them to pull out weapons. Once he told me he was nervous about a cousin of his who had started hanging out at the crack house, feigning friendship. Julio suspected him of being in the process of casing the place for a future stickup.
Several times I asked crack dealers or robbers to explain how they were able to trust their partners in crime. In each case, I was told: ''What do you mean how do I trust him? You should ask how does he trust me!''
They were claiming, I believe, that they are not dependent upon trust because they are tough enough to command respect and enforce all contracts they enter into. Ruthlessness is their security.
My failure to display a propensity for violence cost me, in several instances, the respect of the crack sellers. This was evident when I turned down Julio and Papito's offer to search out the three men who mugged Jesus and me. Julio was genuinely disappointed that I was not someone with common sense and self-respect.
His reaction was a setback for my research. In the few weeks prior to getting mugged, I had established a routine for tape recording life-history interviews. After Julio closed the botanica, we would go back to Jackie's apartment to babysit her children and her husband's grandfather, a 65-year-old alcoholic. Babysitting involved sending one of the children out for beer, keeping the grandfather from drinking any hard liquor, shouting at the young children if they quarreled, playing with the 9-month-old. Eventually I would follow Julio and whoever else had come with us from the crack house into the bedroom, to keep talking to them as they ground up and snorted cocaine. At this point I could comfortably take out my tape recorder, and they would dictate chapters for my book, competing for my attention and for space on the tape. By daybreak, Jackie had usually returned from work with fresh coke for Julio to snort. He would then sleep from mid-morning until mid-afternoon, careful to arrive on time for the evening shift - 3 P.M. to 12:30 A.M. - at the botanica crack house.
INNER-CITY STREET violence is not limited solely to drug sellers or to street criminals; to a certain extent, anyone living in the neighborhood who wants to maintain a sense of autonomy - i.e., who does not go outdoors during daylight hours only - finds it useful to participate, at least passively, in some corner of the culture of terror. I overheard the story of a boy whose mother had told him never to fight. Not long into the school year a classmate mugged him, stealing his midafternoon snack and pocket money. The child quickly developed a reputation as a weakling. During the ensuing weeks, he lost his snack and money daily until finally he complained to his mother. Her response was to berate him: ''What's the matter with you? Can't you fight back?''
Anyone who is frequently out on the street will be exposed to the violence of the underground economy, even if he does not participate in it. In the first 13 months I spent in Spanish Harlem I witnessed:
A deadly shooting, outside my window, of the mother of a 3-year-old child, by an assailant wielding a sawed-off shotgun.
A bombing and a machine-gunning of a numbers joint, once again within view of my apartment window.
A shoot-out and police-car chase in front of a pizza parlor where I happened to be eating a snack.
The aftermath of the firebombing of a heroin house.
A dozen screaming, clothes-ripping fights.
Almost daily exposure to broken-down human beings, some of them in fits of crack-induced paranoia, some suffering from delirium tremens, and others in unidentifiable pathological fits screaming and shouting insults to all around them.
Perhaps the most poignant expression of the pervasiveness of the culture of terror was the comment made to me by a 13-year-old boy in the course of an otherwise innocuous conversation about how his mother's pregnancy was going. He told me he hoped his mother would give birth to a boy ''because girls are too easy to rape.''
BASED ON MY EX-perience, I believe the assertion of the culture-of-poverty theorists that the poor have been badly socialized and do not share mainstream values is wrong. On the contrary, ambitious, energetic, inner-city youths are attracted to the underground economy precisely because they believe in the rags-to-riches American dream. Like many in the mainstream, they are frantically trying to get their piece of the pie as fast as possible. In fact, they follow the traditional model for upward mobility: aggressively setting themselves up as private entrepreneurs. Without stretching the point too much, they can be seen in conventional terms as rugged individualists on an unpredictable frontier where fortune, fame and destruction are all just around the corner.
Consider the example of Indio, an ambitious young crack dealer who, while he was high on angel dust, shot his brother in the spine and paralyzed him for life in a battle over sales rights. His brother now works for him, selling on crutches. Meanwhile, the shooting has cemented Indio's reputation, and his workers are awesomely disciplined. Indio reaffirms this symbolically by periodically walking his turf with a $3,000 gold chain and nameplate hanging around his neck.
Many of the street dealers claim to be strictly utilitarian in their involvement with the drugs they sell, and disdain their clients despite the fact that usually, like Indio, they have alcohol and powder-cocaine habits themselves. They refer to their merchandise as ''this garbage'' and openly deride addicts as they arrive with fistfuls of money. Papito used to chant at his regular customers: ''Keep on killing yourself. Bring me that money. Smoke yourself to death. Make me rich.'' Though the average street seller is employed by the owner of a sales point for whom he has to maintain regular hours, meet sales quotas and be subject to being fired, the street seller has a great deal of autonomy and power in his schedule. His boss comes once or twice a shift to drop off drugs and pick up money, or else sends a young messenger. Because of the money and drugs passing through their hands, sellers are often surrounded by a bevy of ''thirsty'' friends and hangers-on - frequently teen-age girls - willing to run errands, pay attention to conversations, lend support in arguments and fights and provide sexual favors upon demand. In fact, even youths who do not use drugs will hang out and try to befriend the dealer, just to be privy to the excitement of people coming and going, copping and hanging.
The ultimate expression of success is opulence without visible means of support. There is plenty of proof of this on the street as teen-age crack dealers drive by in white Suzuki jeeps and middle-aged cocaine tycoons speed around in well-waxed Lincoln Continentals or Mercedes-Benzes. Anyone can aspire to be one of the ubiquitous sellers, perched on mountain bikes with beepers on their belts. In fact, many youths not particularly active in the drug trade wear beepers, just pretending to be big time.
The feeling of self-worth that the street-level dealer's life style offers cannot be underestimated. A former manager of a coke-shooting gallery who had employed a network of a half-dozen sellers, lookouts and security guards before he was jailed, explained to me that the best memories of his drug-dealing days were of the respect he received from people on the street. After his release, he became a clerk in a Wall Street brokerage concern, determined, he said, not to return to street life. But he recalled that, as a dealer, when he drove up in one of his cars to pick up the day's receipts, a bevy of attentive men and women would run to open the door for him and engage him in polite small talk. Others would offer to clean his car. He would invite a half-dozen friends and acquaintances out to dinner in expensive restaurants almost every night. Jokingly, he also noted that his shooting gallery had enabled his wife and two children to get off welfare.
A CASUAL STROLL through Spanish Harlem exposes one to legions of emaciated coke and crack addicts. Many will be begging for their next vial; others will be ''petro'' or ''bugging out'' - i.e., high, intensely paranoid, shying from everyone around them - shivering, mumbling agitatedly to themselves, with their eyes wide open and jaws tense. If the stroller should happen upon a ''copping corner'' it will look like a street fair, especially late at night - cars driving by, people coming and going, doors of buildings opening and closing, people hanging out all over. Most likely a hail of whistles and shouts will accompany the stroller's arrival as the lookouts warn those ''pitching'' the drugs that a potential undercover is on the scene.
Anthropologists have developed a concept known as ''conjugated oppression'' -whereby ethnic discrimination interacts with class exploitation to produce a perception in its victims of inescapable oppression. I have come to believe that this begins to explain why hordes of crack heads continue to fry their brains and burn up their bodies.
Substance abuse in general, and crack in particular, offers the equivalent of a born-again metamorphosis. Instantaneously, the user is transformed from an unemployed, depressed high school dropout, despised by the world - and secretly convinced that his failure is due to his own inherent stupidity and disorganization. There is a rush of heart-palpitating pleasure, followed by a jaw-gnashing crash and wide-eyed alertness that provides his life with concrete purpose: Get more crack - fast!
After almost five years living in and out of that world, it is impossible not to get depressed, especially when some of the emaciated figures I see are women in advanced states of pregnancy, mothers dragging screeching toddlers behind them - or a former friend broken down on a binge.
Often, the day after an especially brutal night of fieldwork, I seek out the bright-eyed, cheery-faced schoolchildren who fill the streets of Harlem after 3:30 each afternoon. I've come to know a half dozen of them and have their mothers' permission to take them on outings. We'll play ball, take a walk to the East River, visit a fancy toy store or a museum downtown. The energy, love and dreams of these children stand in stark contrast to the desperate substance-abuse and violence that goes on around them. I am suddenly filled with the hope that they might survive these mean streets - and, for a while at least, I feel better.

GRAPHIC: Gun-toting drug dealers mingle with children on the streets of East Harlem.(pg. 52)(Susan Meiselas)
