The New York Times

PUB-DATE: November 12, 1989

SECTION: Section 6; Part 2, Page 21, Column 1; World of New York Magazine

LENGTH: 2726 words

HEADLINE: THE ULTIMATE MARKETPLACE;
Tales of Success

BYLINE: By SUSAN CHIRA; Susan Chira is a reporter for The New York Times.

 BODY:
A SALESWOMAN hovers in the doorway of Volity Narayan Prakash's office in his jewelry store in Jackson Heights, Queens. She has a problem. A customer is buying a $2,400 gold chain for cash, but he is $100 short. Mr. Prakash strides out to the counter and speaks to his customer in the south Indian dialect he learned as a child in Bangalore. They shake hands and the customer leaves with his purchase.
''I told him, please take it and send the money later,'' said Mr. Prakash, who is 38 years old. ''They feel proud because someone trusts them.''
''Gold is a trust business,'' he said. ''Someone will say, let's go to Prakash because we know him and we've never had a problem. We jewelers are like barbers. You don't change your barber.'' 
This is how Mr. Prakash has prospered in a very specialized business - selling diamonds and handmade Indian gold jewelry to Indians in the United States.
In New York there is hardly a need that is not supplied by an entrepreneur whose livelihood depends on an accurate grasp of this vast marketplace. The city is full of dreamers and risk-takers, each seeking the niche that will allow him or her to prosper.
They crowd into neighborhoods like Jackson Heights, where Mr. Prakash's Jewels of India shop is but one in a row of Indian enterprises. Store windows are plastered with advertisements for visiting Indian singers, stocked with Indian and Pakistani delicacies and draped with saris in stunning shades of cobalt and saffron, fuschia and lime.
They venture farther out in Queens to Kew Gardens, where Mitaecha Kim has spent 10 years establishing her nail salon and now faces Korean-run competitors across the street and down the block.
They are tucked away in anonymous Manhattan skyscrapers like the one where Alma Nugent runs her interior design business. And they thrive in the sprawling warehouses of the Brooklyn Navy Yard, where Bill Howell bases his petroleum products company.
These four entrepreneurs are part of New York City's tapestry of ingenuity and dedication. Each embodies the promise of this city - that here it is possible to start, to begin again and maybe, someday, to get rich.
Each year, according to Dun & Bradstreet, the business information services company, some 5,000 new businesses are started in New York City, out of a national total of about 250,000. Dun & Bradstreet defines a new business as one that begins to participate actively in the marketplace, purchasing goods and services from other businesses. A new business is almost by definition a small business, with an average of five employees. The riskiness of such ventures is illustrated by their failure rate. ''In 1988,'' said Reid Gearhart, a Dun & Bradstreet analyst, ''700 New York City businesses failed, meaning that their creditors were left with losses. There is no way of knowing how many businesses simply pay their debts and discontinue operations. Our statistical rule of thumb is that about half of the businesses that fail every year are five years old or younger.''
Particularly daunting is the lack of start-up capital, according to Gary Kesner, Commissioner of New York's Office of Business Development. Many people underestimate how much money they will really need. Once established, the aspiring entrepreneur must grapple with the legal requirements of incorporation, partnership and licensing, along with bookkeeping, obtaining insurance, maintaining security and managing employees. Dreams of wealth notwithstanding, at the beginning most entrepreneurs have little to look forward to but hours of grinding work.
Mr. Prakash, for example, keeps his store open seven days a week. He also devotes time and energy to the Indian community. He heads the local jewelers' assocation and hosts receptions for Indians visiting the United States. When a competing jeweler was robbed, he sent him some stock from his own store as a goodwill gesture. And he donates money to the local Hindu temple.
Although he will not disclose his sales or profits, Mr. Prakash appears to be thriving. He recently bought a house in New Hyde Park, L.I., for his wife and two children, and workmen are building counters and fixing mirrors for a new diamond showroom.
It took him a decade to get this far. The Prakash family has sold silk and gold in the South Indian city of Bangalore for generations. But Mr. Prakash sensed a market for an American branch. .
''I am always a person who takes risks and adventures,'' he said. ''I spoke to a lot of Indians here. A lot of people gave me negative opinions. They said gold and guns go together, and you don't want to be a part of that. Gold in this country is sold at a cheaper price than Indian gold. But I studied this market for a year and decided no matter what happened, I had to open a jewelry store.''
While most entrepreneurs have trouble raising enough capital, Mr. Prakash could draw on family money. And most of his employees are relatives. The most crucial decision he had to make was where to locate his store. Deciding against Manhattan's 47th Street, the diamond district, he settled on Jackson Heights because it was the center of a vibrant Indian immigrant community.
Mr. Prakash's shop thrived there, and has spawned nearly a dozen imitators. Now his biggest headaches are security and the cost of insuring his merchandise.
''This country is so helpful to business,'' he said. ''In India, we have a lot of red tape. That's what makes this country so great - they help you.''
EVEN SO, THERE ARE DAYS WHEN Mitaecha Kim thinks about giving up the business she opened ten years ago in her one-bedroom apartment in Kew Gardens. Women and people who work out of their homes are major forces among entrepreneurs today - an estimated 8 million to 10 million businesses are operated from homes with some 400,000 new ones being started each year, according to the Commerce Department.
Mrs. Kim appears to have prospered, judging by the sleek gray and black decor of her present shop, the brisk efficiency of her nine employees and the chairs full of customers. Still, she said, speaking in a mixture of English and Korean translated by her sister-in-law, ''Sometimes I think maybe working for someone else is better.''
While New Yorkers marvel at the seemingly well-organized and cooperative networks of Korean immigrants who have become the city's greengrocers, dry cleaners and manicurists, Mrs. Kim and her husband, Jae Hoon, see both the drawbacks and the benefits of such a network.When they left South Korea 17 years ago with their young son, Robert, both found work in New York with other Koreans - Mr. Kim with a construction company, Mrs. Kim as a manicurist in a nail salon in Manhattan. Patiently, Mrs. Kim absorbed the economics and the techniques of the business. After seven years she and her husband had saved enough to enable her to quit working for someone else and, with an investment of a few thousand dollars, set up a manicure table in their apartment. Steadily adding more tables and customers, she outgrew the apartment and rented a storefront on Queens Boulevard. She called it Kim's Golden Nails.
The problem, according to the Kims, is that so many other Korean immigrants have latched onto the same dream. There are six nail salons within a few blocks of hers, and at least 10 along Continental Avenue. They charge prices so low she has not raised hers in years - it is still $4.50 for a manicure, $5.50 on weekends.
''It's just too much competition,'' said Mr. Kim, who is 44.
The Kims were reluctant to divulge their revenues or profits because the business varies so much. They had two good years ending in 1987, but business has lagged last year and this. They pay $2,250 a month for their office space, and commercial and real estate taxes bring the total to $3,000. They live in the same one-bedroom apartment they moved into 15 years ago.
Mrs. Kim keeps the shop open from 9:30 A.M. to 7 P.M., six days a week. When it closes, she goes home to cook dinner. Sundays are for sleeping and washing clothes. It is these long hours, she believes, that have helped her succeed where some others have not. ''I came to this country 17 years ago, and only two times I have gone to the movies,'' Mrs. Kim said. ''The media say all Koreans make money. American people work 40 hours and take off vacations. We work 70 hours and have no vacation.''
THE WILLINGNESS OF MANY newcomers to work such long hours can provide stiff competition for other Americans. In fact, when many New Yorkers think of small-scale entrepreneurs, they think of immigrants. According to Harper's Index for December 1988, the chances that a white American man is self-employed are 1 in 7; the chances that a foreign-born Korean-American men is self-employed are 1 in 4. In fact, a 1982 census count, the latest available, showed that 17,350 blacks, 10,338 Hispanics and 13,577 Asians and other minorities own their businesses in New York City.
Bill Howell, president of Howell Petroleum Products, a wholesale distributor of fuel and motor oil, grease, lubricants and antifreeze, is determined to prove that opportunities exist for all. A black American who grew up in North Carolina, he works in his spare time as a counselor in the city's job-training programs for inner-city youth, expounding the message that they, too, can succeed.
Mr. Howell suggested several reasons fewer blacks than immigrants go into business for themselves: many immigrants are well educated and were professionals or businessmen in their own countries; many can draw on extensive networks of support and credit from fellow immigrants. And many immigrants, desperate to make it, are willing to put in longer hours than many Americans, black or white.
''We haven't been willing to work for nothing,'' said Mr. Howell, ''What I'm all about is trying to import the work ethic. It's a fact: to achieve anything in America you've got to be willing to work real hard for it, just like the Koreans, Indians or Jamaicans.''
Mr. Howell, who is 41, said he had always dreamed of going into business for himself. He pursued that dream through a succession of jobs, including bank credit officer, life insurance salesman, special assistant to former Senator James L. Buckley, executive director of the Association of Minority Enterprises of New York and senior marketing officer at two petroleum products firms.
Finally, he felt ready. After heart-to-heart talks with his wife, Jessica, who works as a civilian employee of the Coast Guard, Mr. Howell took his savings of $15,000, enlisted his wife and a friend as partners and founded his company in 1985. He made his first sale to a buyer he knew in Co-op City, lugging a five-gallon drum of grease in his own car for a $5 profit.
To build his business, he drew on his marketing experience, his personal contacts and his volunteer work. It was at a youth leadership seminar that he met a Texaco official who offered to supply him, cash on delivery. Now Texaco provides 80 percent of his products, as well as substantial credit.
Aggressively seeking out opportunities provided by affirmative action programs, he competed for contracts set aside for small businesses owned by women and minorities,, winning them at the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and from New York City agencies.
Living at first on his wife's Coast Guard salary, Mr. Howell expanded slowly. He stored his products in a friend's garage. The first year, he lost $10,000 on sales of $50,000, but his sales doubled every year thereafter and in 1988 he cleared $30,000 on sales of $750,000. He ran his business out of trailers, and the trailers kept proliferating. City officials told him about inexpensive office space at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, and last February he moved his barrels, drums, fax machine and seven-person staff there.
Now his customers include Brooklyn Union Gas, Nynex and The New York Times, and his biggest dilemma is how to expand. He is sorting through offers from banks and from city agencies to lend him money, and hoping for sales of $1.5 million this year.
Mr. Howell praises New York City officials for their outreach to minority-owned business, but he fears that the opportunities that helped to build his business will shrink in the wake of recent Supreme Court decisions that significantly weakened affirmative action precedents.
''Up until the Supreme Court decisions, I was called on a daily basis by people trying to find minority-owned businesses to fulfill whatever contracts they had,'' he said. ''Since the decisions, there are no calls. If this had happened two years ago, it probably would have put me out of business.''
IT WAS RACIAL DISCRIMINATION, in part, that gave Alma Nugent the incentive to go into business for herself. Born in Costa Rica and brought up in Nicaragua, Ms. Nugent, now 50 years old, arrived in the United States at the age of 22. She became a nurse, but later realized that she really wanted to be an interior designer. So she went back to school, working part-time as a nurse. But when she graduated from the New York School of Interior Design and the New York Institute of Technology in the mid-1970's, a recession was in full swing and she found no openings.
Being black, a woman and older than most other design-school graduates did not help. ''When I showed up, they told me the job had just been given to someone else,'' Ms. Nugent said. So 13 years ago she decided to start her own company from her apartment in Manhattan. Using $20,000 in savings to live on, she planted herself at home, printed some stationary and looked for clients. Her first break came when a doctor she knew asked her to design his office, and she began the slow process of garnering referrals.
''This is a word-of-mouth business,'' she said. ''I have a lot of friends. I join a lot of organizations. That's what happens - friends tell friends.''
In four years, her expanding business allowed her to share an office with an architect on 114th Street, near Columbia University, and then move in 1983 to her own offices on West 57th Street. She now employs two full-time designers and one part-time office worker and her biggest costs are rent, payroll and insurance.
''One of the things I have to credit myself for is perseverence,'' said Ms. Nugent, smiling at her own understatement. ''It's taken a long time - much longer than I would have wanted - to have people know me and want me.''
It is still difficult to head a young company in a business where many of the best-known designers are men and a less-established company often loses clients to big-name firms. But the frustrations have not stopped her, and Nugent Designs is still around and winning commissions. One of the largest was a 15-month series of projects for Prudential Insurance's Newark office. One of the most challenging: designing the interior of a corporate jet, from the built-in consoles down to the table linens.
Ms. Nugent spends part of her free time interesting young people in going into business for themselves. Working with business organizations such as the New York City Partnership, she helps students at Grand Academy, a public school on the Lower East Side, learn to set up a school store, get a bank loan for it and mark up goods.
Like most entrepreneurs, Ms. Nugent vacillates between euphoria at success and fear of failure, juggling her determination to keep doing what she loves with the inevitable stresses that risk entails. Last year was her worst time. With sales (total gross earnings, including design fees) of $250,000 - which she says is very little for the interior design business - she feared her company could not survive. Like most designers, Ms. Nugent charges her client a fee for her designs as well as a commission on the furnishings she orders for them at her professional discount. But after paying rent, salaries and overhead, she estimates her profits after all taxes and expenses are between 5 and 7 percent of her sales.
This year, business picked up, and she is awaiting word on a contract that could allow her to reach sales of more than $1 million.
''It's a wonderful field, and it really means a lot to me,'' Ms. Nugent said. ''It's much easier now. I've proven myself. But sometimes business is good and sometimes it slows down tremendously and I think, why am I in this?''

He now rents office space at the Brooklyn Navy Yard and is hoping for sales of $1.5 million this year; Mitaecha Kim in her salon, Kim's Golden Nails. PUB-DATE: November 12, 1989

SECTION: Section 6; Part 2, Page 49, Column 1; World of New York Magazine

LENGTH: 1722 words

HEADLINE: THE ULTIMATE MARKETPLACE;
Potrait of a Wall Street Lady

BYLINE: By DAVID MARGOLICK; David Margolick covers legal affairs for The New York Times.

 BODY:
''GENTLE DRAGON Lady.'' That's the phrase Alice Young chose to describe herself for a profile commissioned by the Dewar's Scotch people. Ms. Young, 39, was recently selected by the liquor manufacturer as one of 50 youngish, accomplished New Yorkers, a ''Do-er.'' She accepted the honor, although she never touches the stuff.
Ms. Young, a partner in the Wall Street law firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy, was the only corporate attorney on Dewar's list. Her latest accomplishment, she told Dewar's, was ''negotiating five different joint ventures and acquisitions involving Japan, Italy, France and the United States simultaneously; getting my son and daughter to willingly eat fried calamari.''
When it comes to her accomplishments, Alice Young is not modest. ''I wanted to have a successful career, and I have that,'' Ms. Young, who is head of her firm's Asian group, said in a recent interview. ''I wanted to have a happy marriage. I have that. I wanted to have children, and I have two, who are really neat, happy, bright. I don't know what happens in a couple of years, but so far, so good.'' 
How does she explain her success? A bit uncertainly. For fear of offending other, more battle-scarred women, she'll reiterate just how difficult it is to be mother, wife and law partner simultaneously, and how she could never do it all without a phalanx of the faithful - husband, nanny, secretary, paralegal, cleaning woman -behind her. On the other hand, she seems to resent the notion that to prosper in a large law firm, a woman must be angst-ridden, masculine or maladjusted. ''Just because you're driven doesn't mean you have to be neurotic,'' she said.
By all measures, Alice Young has had a charmed career. She has been the right person in the right place at the right time. She entered the law when firms at least said they wanted women. She began her career as the world's economic center of gravity shifted eastward, when terms like ''Pacific Rim'' entered the lexicon. And, at a time when law firms were attempting to build bridges to the Far East but had little sense of how to proceed, she was an Asian-American who'd grown up speaking Chinese at home, had picked up Japanese in college and also knew a smattering of Korean. She became a partner as competition on Wall Street intensified and firms, jettisoning the genteel behavior of a gentlemanly profession, aggressively courted superstars, then let them be themselves.
And, in a world where appearance and personality matter, Alice Young is charming and individual. In a world of unisex gray flannel, she dresses brightly - on one day recently, in indigos and magentas. (Though she claims to dress in 15 minutes and says she puts on her makeup in taxis, she looks impeccable.) Her clothes match the bouquet of lilies and heather on her desk; flowers, delivered each week, lend an unusual panache to her utilitarian surroundings in Milbank's offices at One Chase Manhattan Plaza.
Still, Ms. Young is not just another pretty face, as her docket for September attests. In that time she helped Nippon Shinpan, Japan's largest consumer credit company, set up an American operation; represented a major American museum - which she declined to name - on various matters in Europe and Asia; handled real estate financing deals for the Development Bank of Singapore and securities lending issues for the Yasuda Bank and Trust Company (of which she is a director); advised the New York Life Insurance Company on ventures in Japan and Hong Kong, and counseled a Japanese construction company in negotiations with several American cities over a proposed linkage of mass transit systems. She also negotiated space for a Japanese gallery seeking to open in New York, advised three Japanese artists on attempting to bring a musical to Broadway, and signed Don Johnson, star of ''Miami Vice,'' to shoot two television commercials for another client, Japan's Minami Sports Company.
''It's a pretty long list,'' she said. ''It's been a long month.'' Still, there is enough time left over for extracurricular activities. Ms. Young is on the board of the Aspen Institute, serves on the business associate committee of the Metropolitan Museum, belongs to the Council on Foreign Relations and is secretary of the Japan Society.
Yet, for all of her accomplishments, Ms. Young has her detractors, who, given the close-knit world of the Asia bar, tend to keep their feelings to themselves. Quietly, they'll tell you she is more image than substance, with a streak of self-promotion. There's that Dewar's award, for instance.
ALICE YOUNG WAS born into a family of achievers. Her brother, Peter, is an investment banker at Salomon Brothers; her younger sister, Nancy, is a partner at the New York law firm of Richards & O'Neil. Their parents were born in China. Dr. Young entered the diplomatic corps, and was stranded in the United States during the Communist takeover in China in 1949.
Ms. Young was born in Washington, D.C. When she turned 12, her family spent two years in Tokyo, where her father administered a language program for the University of Maryland. They then moved to Honolulu, where Ms. Young entered the University of Hawaii in an accelerated study program. She transferred to Yale, becoming part of the first group of women to matriculate there. Her major was in East Asian studies, and she won a fellowship to study Japanese literature in Tokyo under Yasunari Kawabata, the novelist and Nobel laureate, in the summer of her junior year. She graduated in 1971 and entered Harvard Law School, from which she graduated three years later. She entered private practice, first in the Hong Kong office of Coudert Brothers, a firm long known for its international work, then with the San Francisco firm of Graham & James, for whom she set up a New York branch.
Ms. Young's first marriage ended in divorce - the result, she said, of a youthful mistake and not her workaholism. In 1984, she married Thomas Shortall, an institutional bond salesman at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. (Mr. Shortall's late father, Leonard, was an author and illustrator of children's books; in response to the Dewar's profile question ''last book read,'' Ms. Young cited ''Washington Goes to War,'' by David Brinkley, and ''Little Toad to the Rescue,'' by Leonard Shortall.) A daughter, Amanda, was born in 1985, and a son, Stephen, followed in 1987.
Starting a family did not set back Alice Young's career. Indeed, despite a difficult pregnancy that included four and a half months confined to bed, Ms. Young billed more hours in 1985 than any other lawyer in her office. (When Amanda was born, a wise client gave her mother a fax machine.) In 1987, when most of her law school classmates were still relatively junior partners - and many of her female classmates had dropped out of law altogether - she began talking with Milbank, Tweed, an old-line, somewhat stagnant firm anxiously seeking to shed its stuffy image. Impressed by the advantages of working for a large, multiservice enterprise and eager to get rid of some of her administrative chores, she made her move. She's rarely stopped moving since.
Every morning, Ms. Young leaves her home in Montclair, N.J., around 8, two hours after her husband. Amanda gets dropped off at the school bus; Stephen stays with a babysitter. Ms. Young is in her office by 9, where her day's activities are listed on her computer. There are meetings and other tasks, like glancing at the Asian Wall Street Journal, the Far Eastern Economic Review, and, for some Japanese fashion clients, Women's Wear Daily. But much of her work, like that of any international lawyer, is done by phone; the average day brings 50 calls. Mornings, they come first from Europe, then New York. By midafternoon, they may be from the West Coast. One requires her to switch instantaneously to Japanese. A visitor can make out only a few words - ''debt-equity ratio,'' ''America,'' ''speakerphone'' - plus the gist of the conversation: yet another Japanese company is acquiring yet another piece of America. At least one more thing can be detected from the caller's laughter: here is a client at ease with his counsel. Ms. Young hangs up, saying, ''People expect me to be a different, much more hard-boiled . . .'' - here she stops, searching for the right euphemism - '' . . . a tougher style of person.''
Around 7, the domestic calls stop, and the calls from Asia start. The beads of lights along the Brooklyn Bridge, visible outside Ms. Young's window, go on at different hours, depending on the time of year; but even when the days are longest, she is invariably around to see them shine. When, then, does she quit? ''When there is no major crisis, when I'm too tired, when I have some sort of family or social obligation that forces me out,'' she said. Nevertheless, from time to time, her husband goes ahead and eats dinner without her.
Ms. Young says it is her Asian-American background, with its stress on personal interdependence, that has helped keep her sane. The emphasis on family and friends, something she found suffocating as a teenager, is reassuring now. By way of explanation, she notes a phrase from a book by another Asian-American, Maxine Hong Kingston's ''Tripmaster Monkey'': ''Anybody American who really imagines Asia feels the loneliness of the U.S.A. and suffers from the distances human beings are apart.''
Alice Young admits to paying a price for her success. Nowadays, the books sit on her nightstand longer than they once did. Other interests are either neglected or abandoned; she has less time than she'd like with her family. Still, it is a sacrifice she seems willing to make. ''I've seen kids who were messed up even though their parents were around all the time making cookies,'' she said.
EN ROUTE TO COLLECT her Dewar's prize, Ms. Young calls her family on the car phone.
''Hi, Pumpkin, how are you doing?'' she asks Amanda. ''Did you have a good time in school today?'' Then another voice comes over the wire, one which, at first, she does not recognize. In fact, it is her son. ''That's right,'' she says to him, as she's about to leave the limousine. ''Mommy's working.''
''Attorney, wife, mother, daughter, Asian and dreamer, not necessarily in that order.'' That's how she summed herself up for Dewar's.

GRAPHIC: Alice Young, a partner in the Wall Street law firm of Millbank Tweed, in the lounge of the Council on Foreign Affairs. As head of Millbank's Asian group, she has negotiated contracts for some of asia's largest companies (Michael O'Brien)

Copyright 1989 The New York Times Company 
The New York Times

PUB-DATE: November 12, 1989

SECTION: Section 6; Part 2, Page 50, Column 1; World of New York Magazine

LENGTH: 2844 words

HEADLINE: THE ULTIMATE MARKETPLACE;
It's Not Just Window Dressing

BYLINE: By LOUISE LAGUE: Louise Lague is an independent writer and window shopper.

 BODY:
SIMON DOONAN, THE vice president and creative director of Barneys New York, stands before one of his Seventh Avenue windows and purses his lips slightly. He points at the sleeve of a jet-black Ronaldus Shamask jacket, where a stray white thread has been carelessly abandoned. ''That,'' he says, all firm and British, ''is not supposed to be there.''
One has the feeling heads will roll for this. In the small, fickle world of window dressing, Doonan is renowned, an enfant terrible. In one window last year, he shwoman being sawed in half; another was the target of a knife-thrower. ''There was a terrible uproar,'' says Doonan. ''I just told everybody that it was unfortunate if the scenes reflected a violent attitude toward women, but these things do happen in the circus, and these windows were about the circus.
''Most people think display people are all nut cases anyway,'' he adds. 
No one will be decapitated for the errant thread. Doonan's not really that kind of guy. If his windows have ''a pretty sharp edge,'' as he puts it, he's only trying to get attention. That's what windows are for. New York City has always been the display capital of this country. It is one of the few places left in America where people walk to stores and pass other stores on the way and are caught by the beauty, cleverness or absurdity of the scene within a frame. Elsewhere, people drive to enclosed malls, within which stores have glass walls facing an indoor corridor - the entire store becomes the exhibit. But visual merchandising that happens within the perimeters of a window, perhaps with a backdrop, is by comparison a haiku, a nearly obsolete art, says Robert H. Hoskins of the Fashion Institute of Technology. As assistant professor of display and exhibit design, Hoskins observes: ''We take windows very seriously in New York. Only here could we have designers as celebrities.''
At the moment, the celebrities are few but colorful - Doonan at Barneys, Gene Moore at Tiffany, Danuta Ryder at Henri Bendel, Fernando Lara at Citarella Fish. As well as they know each other's work, they do not know each other personally. ''Of course, I've sent him many fan letters,'' says Simon Doonan of Gene Moore. ''There's an association,'' says Thomas Beebe, the display director at Paul Stuart, ''but we're all too busy to go.'' Hoskins says: ''The competition is fierce. They build their own kingdoms. Put them all in a room and the walls would crack.''
Creativity in window display has flourished in cycles. Salvador Dali made history at Bonwit Teller in 1938, when he filled a Persian-lamb-lined bathtub with water and juxtaposed it with a bloody-faced mannequin wearing coq feathers. Other famous artists worked incidentally on windows on the way up: Maurice Sendak, Robert Rauschenberg, Jasper Johns and Andy Warhol all either designed windows or built props. L. Frank Baum, the author of the first Oz books, was the founder and first president of the National Association of Window Trimmers and in 1897 started Show Window, the trade's first journal.
In the 1950's, designers began to attain superstar status. While doing the windows for Bonwit's, Gene Moore would go to the runway shows with the buyer and ''just pick out dresses that would look good in the window and make her buy them,'' he recalls. He once ripped a pink satin rose off the sash of a white Norell ballgown while doing a window, later explaining to the furious designer that ''it ruined an otherwise brilliLnt design.''
At 79, Moore is the acknowledged dean of New York window design; he has been doing Tiffany's celebrated boxlike windows since 1955. ''It's easy for me,'' he says, ''but isn't it crazy that it's still fun?'' He has the most fun when he can unstring some pearls or smash a Waterford goblet. ''Then,'' he says, ''I actually get phone calls telling me there's a broken glass in the window.''
His style is wildly diverse: a heart locket in front of a chest X-ray, a toy truck dumping a pile of real sand in which a real diamond glistens. He takes cues from current events. Once, during a drought, he showed a fountain spewing gin. When a fire inspector called it flammable, Moore lighted a match to prove it wasn't.
While the art and scenery at Tiffany are planned eight months ahead for the biweekly changes of his five windows, the jewels that will be exhibited are almost an afterthought. Moore sweeps through the store the day before his Thursday dawn installations and snaps up five pieces of jewelry that will function with whatever artwork he has created. ''I never change my mind, either,'' he says.
THE LATEST GOLDEN age of windows was the 70's, when Candy Pratts Price was turning the Bloomingdale's windows into a kind of street theater. ''We had surrealistic windows, situation comedies,'' she recalls. ''Bob Currie was doing the same thing at Bendel's. The press covered the windows, people came to see them, small stores all over town got into the act.'' Little gangs of New Yorkers, members of the creative community, would tour the town on Wednesday and Thursday nights when the windows changed, oohing and aahing over the new installations. (''Aaaah'' is a big word among window designers; they go for the ''aaaah'' the way Jane Fonda used to go for the burn.) Price, now a fashion director at Vogue, remembers serving Thursday night popcorn to window groupies outside her store.
That excitement has died down for various reasons. For one, the number of experienced designers has been diminished. ''AIDS has completely decimated the profession,'' said one store owner. He refused to divulge the name of the freelancer he hires. ''Good people are too hard to find.'' Currently, more and more women are entering the field. At Parsons School of Design, where Linda Cahan has taught visual merchandising for seven years, 90 percent of the display students are now women. ''There never was anything about the job that women couldn't do,'' says Cahan, ''but it was just very hard for women to break in, more so in New York than anywhere else.'' In response to the popularity of display classes, Parsons is introducing a 10-course certificate program in visual merchandising this fall, and next year the School of Visual Arts will inaugurate a four-year degree program in display.
CAHAN ESTIM ATES that half of New York's display designers have had formal training. She tells her students to expect an average of $10 an hour to start as an assistant. A freelancer can get $1,000 or more for a single window on Madison Avenue, and a very good creative planner who becomes a store vice president can earn upward of $100,000 a year. ''They all want to go into apparel,'' she says, ''but the chains with their mass design ideas - Benetton, Banana Republic, The Limited - have made apparel less creative. I tell them that the future is in travel agencies, accessory stores, liquor stores and service storefronts in general.''
If the world of windows is less outrageous than it has been, Robert Hoskins of F.I.T. lays the blame on the corporate tenor of the marketplace in the 80's. ''The recession hit retailing, and all decision-making went to upper management,'' he says. ''Budgets were cut, the business became bottom-line oriented rather than creative. And that was before all the major department store takeovers.'' In the eternal battle between the creative types and ''the suits,'' the suits have been winning.
Over at Barneys (no apostrophe, please, it's part of the style thing), Simon Doonan has conquered this problem by being a creative type who wears a suit. ''Display and merchandising are a marriage,'' he says. ''That's why I dress for this job.'' Before he came to Barneys four years ago, Doonan, 37, had built a reputation as a freelance designer for Maxfield's in Los Angeles, where he'd done windows featuring women in coffins, coyotes stealing babies and a couple of urinals and a sink to set off some Yamamoto menswear.
Barneys, which opened 66 years ago at Seventh Avenue and 17th Street as a men's discount clothing store, has since become a purveyor of men's and women's full-price fashions and accessories, gifts and antiques. Windows elsewhere exist to pull pedestrians in off the street. Barneys, in a pedestrian-poor area, is, for the fashion-conscious, a destination in itself - ''Which is all the more reason to do special windows for the people who come here,'' says Doonan.
Barneys, which devotes half its display budget to windows, is very successful at the primary purpose of window display, which is not to sell merchandise but rather to give the store an identity and image. ''This is what display should be about,'' says Robert Hoskins. ''Most shoppers today see the same merchandise everywhere and don't even know what store they're in.''
Danuta Ryder, the director of visual planning at Henri Bendel, meets four times a year with the store president, Mark Schulman, and the store manager to draw up a schedule for the next 13 weeks. ''We name a fashion designer for each week in the main window,'' says Ryder. ''Being selected is a coup, especially for a young designer.'' But sometimes plans go awry. ''One designer went out of business just before his week,'' she remembers. ''Another sent clothes so boring we couldn't put them in the window.''
Ryder installs on Wednesday night from 6 until 2 in the morning, working with two assistants and seven freelancers. ''I use one assistant for hair, one for makeup,'' she says. Real makeup is used and later removed with a spray of Fantastik. She usually pulls the clothes from the designer's boutique on Monday, renting her props on Tuesday.
''Basically you can sell anything from a window,'' says Ryder, but she likes her nonmerchandise windows best: a great pile of fake dollar bills for a storewide sale, a couple of fantasy lame ballgowns of her own design for a Christmas window. Usually the inspiration comes from the fashion. ''You see these Karl Lagerfeld coats with velvet collars? I took off on the velvet theme and spent the night making black velvet bows to stick on the walls. Everybody thinks this is glamorous. It's a lot of hard work.''
Up at Citarella Fish on Broadway at 75th Street, a Mexican immigrant who does not speak English (or even eat fish) spends at least three hours every morning laying out a new mosaic of salmon, squid, sole, scallops, shrimp, swordfish and shark. Fernando Lara made a British flag of fish for Princess Diana's visit, portrayed Mickey Mouse fishing for the cartoon character's 60th birthday and has put a Walkman on a 40-pound salmon.
One of the town's most famous window designers, Lara, 33, has almost as many press clippings as Simon Doonan. ''I get my ideas from my head, on the subway,'' he says. Topical notions are often suggested by his boss, Joseph R. Gurrera. Untrained in display, Lara was a busboy at the restaurant across the street from Citarella until Gurrera nipped him to work his icebox. Lara got his chance to try the window display when the regular man was sick. Since then, he has refused several offers to arrange fish elsewhere.
To keep his display fresh, Lara stretches it on packed crushed ice, and sprays it regularly with ice water during the day. At 6 P.M., in seconds flat, he takes the whole thing apart for the night, knowing he'll have to think up something else tomorrow.
LAST SUMMER, PAUL Stuart, at 45th and Madison, began ''hitting a comical vein,'' says the creative services director, Patricia Grodd. Thomas Beebe, the 36-year-old display director, and his three assistants are doing some of the most entertaining work in town at one of the most unexpected places. ''There's a lot of competition now in classic apparel,'' says Beebe, ''and we've got to try harder to get attention.'' Most of Paul Stuart's customers work around Madison Avenue, but they hurtle past the store at top speed, on their way to catching a train or a meeting. ''He's tense, his mind is going a mile a minute,'' says Grodd of the Paul Stuart shopper. ''There is a trend to try to sell people a life style, but we think that's patronizing. He's already got a life style. He needs a little bit of delight, a little surprise.''
Paul Stuart's 14 windows are full of innuendoes that puncture the stuffiness of being very well dressed. A masculine figure in a pristine pink suit sits on a park bench sharing a hot dog with a pigeon. The other end of the bench bears a ''Wet Paint'' sign. A man in a flawless charcoal suit strides purposefully, carrying a briefcase and, under his elbow, an enormous striped bass. ''He'd rather be fishing,'' says Beebe. ''The joke is always to juxtapose the formality of the clothes with people's private fantasies.
''Our windows are meant to make the store less forbidding, to give people a lift,'' he adds. ''We get our feedback from the hot dog vendor on the corner, and from the finger marks on the glass.''
AS CO-OWNER OF Pure Madderlake, a SoHo flower store that does a brisk telehone-and-delivery service with East Side hostesses, Billy Jarecki has the ultimate freedom to do wild windows, the kind he had for years when Madderlake was uptown in the East 70's. He once used a mannequin's head wearing a blond coif that was perfect in the front but teased, matted and stuffed with cigarette butts and a soda can sprouting a narcissus in the back. ''Okay,'' he says sheepishly. ''You're not supposed to make fun of the customer. I did that. I got yelled at.''
Pure Madderlake now deals in home furnishings and outdoor furniture as well as flowers. The next dimensions for display there will be smell and taste. ''I'm putting a big kitchen in the middle. You know how all stores smell like potpourri? This will smell like frying onions, simmering soup, whatever I'm making that day. I'd like to put a bowl of soup in the window.''
Robert Hoskins finds Jarecki's ideas not at all off the wall. ''What shoppers want now is a sense of place. That's what Ralph Lauren does so well. You look at the windows, you go in the stores, you feel that you're in a place that you instinctively know and like. The big complaint now is that all the stores look alike. That ought to end.''
But Jarecki isn't thinking about marketing. He's thinking about life. ''I feel so lucky to be able to walk around and breathe. I say, hey, I'm alive, let's have fun. In case people aren't sure they're alive, I like to have a little something in the window that makes two little brain cells rub together. That does it for me.''
 
ON THE OUTSIDE LOOKING IN
If you have ever wanted to watch a window dresser at work, this season offers some of the best opportunities -shops and department stores all over the city will be decorating holiday windows during the next couple of weeks. Scheduled installation dates for stores mentioned in the accompanying story are given below.
 
BARNEYS NEW YORK, Seventh Avenue, at 17th Street (929-9000). The window dressers began to install holiday windows - ''Signs of the Zodiac'' - last Thursday and will continue on Monday and Tuesday, beginning at 9 A.M. each day. After Jan. 1, 1990, all 17 windows will be changed on alternate Thursdays.
 
HENRI BENDEL, 10 West 57th Street, off Fifth Avenue (247-1100). During most of the year, the four windows are changed every Wednesday evening. The window dressers begin at 6 and work until they're through. Holiday windows will be installed this weekend and will remain until after New Year's.
 
BERGDORF GOODMAN, 754 Fifth Avenue, between 57th and 58th Streets(753-7300). Holiday windows, however, will be installed during the day on Nov. 18 and 19 and wont' be changed until after Christmas.
 
BLOOMINGDALE'S, 1000 Third Avenue, at 59th Street (705-2000). Displays change about every 10 days, but the dressers drape the windows so that spectators cannot watch.
 
CITARELLA FISH, 2135 Broadway at 75th Street (874-0383). Fernando Lara lays out the fish in the window every morning between 8 and 11, although store doesn't open until 8:30 from Monday to Saturday and 10 on Sunday.

PAUL STUART, Madison Avenue at 45th Street (682-0320). The women's fashion windows (one on Madison, one on 45th) are usually changed during store hours on Wednesday. PUB-DATE: November 12, 1989

SECTION: Section 6; Part 2, Page 22, Column 1; World of New York Magazine

LENGTH: 5112 words

HEADLINE: THE ULTIMATE MARKETPLACE;
Working to Feed the City - the Butcher, the Baker ... the Marketplace Maker

BYLINE: By MOLLY O'NEILL; Molly O'Neill is reporter for the living section of The New York Times.

 BODY:
THE FOOD DAY BEGINS shortly before midnight at the Hunts Point Terminal Market in the Bronx. It is a militaristic-looking complex in a wasteland of auto wreckers and junkyards. Convoys of semi-trailers pass through a toll-booth opening in the barbed-wire and corregated-tin wall that surrounds the grocery compound. They unload, they load. Last year, five million pounds of fresh fruits and vegetables were sold from the gargantuan warehouses here, primarily to grocery chains and huge wholesale buyers. Meat, packaged fish, dairy goods, canned and frozen food are also sold, about $7 billion worth a year. Almost everything comes in packages; almost nothing is sold retail.
On the far West Side of Manhattan, angling from 14th Street to Ninth and 10th Avenues, the day also begins before dawn in the city's meat district. Refrigerated trucks purr outside the low-lying buildings. Meat cutters in splattered white coats and hard hats push racks of swinging lamb and goat carcasses and sides of beef across the uneven sidewalks. The aromas of game and diesel fuel hang over the blocks. 
At 3:30 A.M., as trucks begin to pull away from the Hunts Point Market, a different fleet idles around the Fulton Fish Market, the 158-year-old fish exchange under the East River Drive, near the tip of Manhattan. In shin-high rubber boots, workers push handcarts loaded with mussels and clams, baskets of small flatfish and loose dinosaurean halibut across the wet cobblestones. The steady squish of the the veneer of ocean underfoot gives the early morning a rhythm. The air smells of low tide and diesel, coffee and doughnuts.
Commerce has etched New York City's topography as irrevocably as any natural force. And commerce began with the buying and selling of food. Today, New York can be seen as a long food chain. From the wholesale markets, on the city's fringes, it spirals through the shops in the boroughs' ethnic neighborhoods where food is prepared and sold and on into the large grocery stores and boutiques that dot Manhattan.
You can still buy and sell almost any kind of food in New York City. But the nature of that buying and selling is changing. Centralization and bulk buying are nibbling away at the old-time wholesalers. And the effect can be felt in the sense of erosion that now pervades the outer ends of the food chain.
When it opened in 1967, the Hunts Point Market, with its modern, efficient, bulk-buying mentality, eclipsed the nearby Bronx Terminal Market. Today, the older market is a quieter shopping area, still running under the Major Deegan Expressway, still hearkening back to a time when produce was chosen by touch and aroma. The three-block stretch smells of cilantro and garlic. Hunts Point has pallets of canned tuna; its predecessor still has dollies loaded with fresh sugar cane, bins of watermelons, mounds of mangoes. Although no longer a major source for large supermarkets, the Bronx Terminal Market is still a mecca for Hispanic grocery stores.
Before dawn, the owners of New York's small bodegas and corner shops pull their battered vans and station wagons into the market. They walk the stained cobblestones and make deals. There is something fragile in the crumpled greenbacks they exchange. There is something endangered about the peculiar odor that comes when parsley stems and fruit peels and cigarettes are paced into the diesle-fuel-drenched pavement. But the market perseveres.
So does La Marqueta, the string of shedlike buildings that stretches beneath the Metro North tracks along Park Avenue from East 111th Street to East 116th Street. Needed renovations been at a standstill for the past two years, and more than half of the market's 150 food stalls have been abandoned. But La Marqueta remains the place for chayote squash and fresh tamarind pods, for smoked turkey necks, fresh farm eggs, sorrel syrup and hairy purple potatoes - still sold retail or wholesale at some of the best prices in town.
The downtown meat district pushes anyone who walks here back to the time before meat was portioned, positioned on absorbent Styrofoam and wrapped in a transparent shield. Tons of meat are shipped from here each week. And yet that number diminishes every year, according to Edward Seh Jr., of Pacific Seh Wholesaling, who has been selling meat from the area for 40 years. ''The big chains buy boxed meat direct from the slaughterhouses,'' he explains, which cuts out the some of the middlemen of Manhattan.
And so, the Bronx Terminal Market and La Marqueta grow quieter. In the meat district, established wholesalers worry about their sales. Will they crumble like the piers that stretch their ghostly tentacles into New York Harbor?
Not long ago, small parcels of food were landed on those narrow piers, everything from local fish to bananas from Panama. Then small parcels gave way to semi-trailer-size containers, and they could only be landed and stored in sprawling ports like Red Hook, in Brooklyn, Newark and Elizabeth in New Jersey.
Yet New York is still the most active port in the country. And despite some decay, its wholesale markets continue to feed some fundamental need in New York. Maybe it's just that the sense of adventure it takes to embrace the city's wildly varied foodstuffs is predicated on the assurance that somewhere two people shook hands over the ingredients.
No market portrays the abiding importance of this exchange better than the Fulton Fish Market. More than 450 varieties of fish - 90 million pounds annually - are sold from the sagging tables that line the stalls of this the largest fish market in North America. But in an era of computerized accounting and bulk buying, every deal at the Fulton Market is person-to-person, handshake-by-handshake, cash-to-pocket. ''It's the last piece of civilization in this town,'' says Robert Neuman, co-owner of the Rosedale Fish and Oyster Market on the Upper East Side, as he makes his daily 4 A.M. purchase.
By 6 A.M., the local bakeries are beginning to issue yeasty smells. The city's ethnic enclaves are rousing. The second link of the New York food chain is waking up.
Not far from the East River, in the former German and Hungarian enclave on the Upper East Side, the aromas of baking rye and raisins and pumpernickle bread have nearly been eclipsed by the trendy scent of chocolate chip cookies. But by 4:30, an Old World essence still wafts from Orwasher Bakery on East 78th Street. At the same time, the smell of sourdour creeps up to the sidewalk from the subterranean bakery at nearby E.A.T. where Eli Zabar uses electric French ovens to fire his signature baguettes.
''This wasn't always a white bread town,'' says Mr. Zabar, pointing out that it is getting hard to find Jewish cornbread (Moishe's Bakery, on East Houston, still makes it) or an oven-warm bialy (except at Kossar's Bialystoker Kuchen Bakery, on Grand Street). A fine variety of traditional breads can be found on at Gertels Bake Shop, on Hester Street, and the Streit Matzoth Company, on Rivington Street, makes matzohs.
Bread has a different flavor in SoHo where, at D & G Bakery Mary Jackson turns out loaves of prosciutto bread, and Vesuvio Bakery is well-known for its Italian pepper biscuits. Until nine years ago, Trio Bakery, which produces sesame sticks, sandwich rolls and Italian and French bread, was on Bleecker Street. But SoHo, says Paul DiGiovanni, a baker at Trio, had gone from a fringe location, easily plied by delivery trucks, to a chic and congested area.
Now, by 7 A.M., there is bread-truck gridlock outside Trio on Ninth Avenue. Bread for hotels, restaurants and food stores is loaded, push-cart vendors stock up on sandwich rolls, and neighbors wander in to buy still-warm rolls. Ninth Avenue, one of the oldest ethnic enclaves in the city, has begun to stir.
IN THE BACK OF DI LUCA Dairy and Deli, a closet-size storefront, a man whose hands are used to the feel of boiling milk begins making some of the best fresh mozzarella in town. Behind the double windows of Manganaro Grosseria Italiano, where jars of imported pasta, biscotti, olive oil, vinegar and cheese are displayed against a backdrop of gilt Venuses, Sal dell 'Orto slips into his blue grocer's jacket and sips the morning's first espresso.
Back in 1890, when his mother's family opened the grocery, recalls Mr. dell 'Orto, the neighborhood was called ''Paddy's Market,'' and pushcarts lined Ninth Avenue from 31st Street to the low 50's. Today, much of the best shopping is compressed between 40th and 36th streets. ''Its a tough time,'' says Mr. dell 'Orto, noting the scheduled razing of a nearby block of tenements and the high-rise (and high-rent) apartment complex that has been proposed for the site.
But until that development and its attendant real estate repercussions are unleashed, these four blocks of Ninth Avenue offer food of an astounding ethnic diversity.
Manganaro sells a wide range of Italian staples, and Giovanni Espositio and Sons Pork Shop has delicious Italian parsley sausage. Bulaklak Philippine Food Center stocks groceries from the Philippines. At the Ninth Avenue Cheese Market, Karen and Pando Andonopulo sell more than 300 kinds of cheese, in addition to dried fruits, olives, Rumanian sausage, Iranian caviar and Turkish groceries. Central Fish, a wholesale and retail store, stocks species to ease the worst case of homesickness, whether the longing is for Greece or Italy or Southeast Asia. With its bins of dried spices and beans and tubs of fresh feta, International Groceries and Meat Market remains an important Greek grocery. And the West African Food Corporation, in the shadow of the Port Authority Bus Terminal, offers white corn, pigeon beans, ground yams, palm wine and Nigerian beer.
BY 7 A.M., THE ETHNIC ENCLAVES on the fringes of Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens are also awakening. In tiny shops on Canal Street, bundles of long green beans, fresh lemon grass, hairy melons, bok choy, rice stalks and duck eggs covered in ash are arranged for display. Swimming in cloudy aquariums, carp and black bass turn a lazy eye to the tourists and the Chinese housewives who drag their wire carts along the crowded sidewalk.
The stretch between Mott, Pell and Doyers is like an alley in Hong Kong, offering such treasures as fresh water chestnuts, taro root or snow pea shoots. Kam Man Food Products is an excellent overall market, as is Kam Kuo, where English-speaking clerks offer a huge selection of Chinese produce, dried goods and groceries as well as the pots to cook them in. Other interesting shops include Tai Pei Wine and Liquor, for Chinese alcohol, and the Han May Meat Company. Hoi Lee has fresh tofu, and the Chinese American Trading Company stocks an array of dried mushrooms, soy sauces and Chinese canned goods.
Along Mulberry Street, the smell of ginger gives way to that of garlic as Chinatown ends and Little Italy begins. For the most part, food stores have been eclipsed by tourist restaurants here, but a few fine shops remain. Alleva Dairy continues to sell fresh and smoked ricotta, along with a huge selection of other fresh and aged cheeses. Milan Lab Wine and Beer offers spices and home-brewing equipment. The Italian Food Center stocks pasta, canned goods, sausages and oils. Farther north, Faicco Pork specializes in pork braciola. And although glitzy pasta shops have covered New York City like locusts, not one of them turns out a more tender fresh ravioli than Raffetto's on West Houston Street.
The East Village (a real estate term that promises clean and well-lighted supermarkets filled with tightly wrapped, mass-produced groceries) is encroaching on the Lower East Side. But family-run specialty stores that are crowded with bins of unpackaged foods still open early in the morning. Fine smoked fish is laid out at Russ and Daughters. Ben's Cheese Shop has perfect cream cheese, while Miller's Cheese specializes in baked farmer's cheese, and Yonah Schimmel sells potato, kasha and fruit knishes.
DESPITE THIS FINE VARIETY, today some of the most authentic ethnic strongholds are outside of Manhattan. In Brooklyn, waves of Russian emigres have been revitalizing the food-shopping center under the El on Brighton Beach Avenue. On Sundays, every Russian within a hundred-mile radius seems to be packed into M & I International, known as the Zabar's of Brighton Beach. And there are plenty of other interesting shops: Stolichny Deli and Fish Town Deli both sell whitefish and caviar; Melrose Take Out Foods has sweet-potato kugel and homemade gefilte fish; Mo's Deli Market offers spicy Georgian relish.; Israel's Take Home Foods has deliciouis peirogi, and outside the Continental Grocery, a young woman sells cabbage-filled pirozhok.
On Brooklyn's Atlantic Avenue, Middle Eastern groceries abound. The gentrification in Cobble Hill and Brooklyn Heights may have spurred renovations at Sahadi's Importing Company, but it didn't change the quality of the store's olives, fresh dates, cracked wheat or spices. The Oriental Pastry and Grocery Company offers lamb sausage as well as zata (pita with spices and olive oil), along with a dozen types of olives and six different kinds of perserved lemons. Damascus Bakery specializes in pita bread; Shammas & Company is the place for feta cheese.
In the West Indian and Carribean neighborhood neighborhood of Crown Heights, the narrow sidewalks are crowded with women wrapped in vivid African dresses, and the early-morning air is dense with Rastafarian incense and the aroma of frying meat patties. Ultrafine Meats, on Nostrand Avenue, may be the most exotic butcher in New York, offering fresh goat, oxtail, hog's head and smoked turkey. El Caribe Food Center stocks a wide selection of island vegetables.
Brooklyn is not without its Italian stronghold. Along the trim streets of Carrol Gardens, you can still find deep-fried chickpea balls and rice balls, fresh biscotti (at Caputo's) and potato pizza (at Monteleone's). Most importantly, the neighborhood is home to the premier branch of G. Esposito Jersey Pork Store, which offers cuts of meat from Manhattan's meat district as well as sausage, prosciutto balls and fresh pasta.
WHEN THE EARLY MORNING light dances across the Agean-blue facades of the shops along 30th Avenue in Astoria, Queens, bakalva and spinach pie are already cooling on bakery counters. Astoria is the third-largest Greek city (after Athens and Salonika) in the world. It is a place where bouzouki music plays against the rumble of trains on the El, where dill and oregano, mint and sage grow in window boxes. At Titan Foods, the A. & P. of Astoria, lines of people debate the qualities of the store's six different kinds of feta, and they buy goat's-milk yogurt, olive oil, canned and preserved Greek groceries. Mediterranean Grocery Foods also stocks an extensive array of Greek groceries. And the Ocean Number 11 Fish Market stocks the fresh octopus and thumb-size squid that Greeks dote on.
Flushing is New York's second Chinatown, where prices are lower than in Manhattan, and Korean, Japanese and Southeast Asian groceries are often offered along with groceries from mainland China. Flushing Food, for instance, offers Chinese and Thai products, while the shelves of Daido/Main Street Foods are stocked with Japanese and Korean groceries. Flushing Seafood has a high evnough standard to please them all.
Like Manhattan's Ninth Avenue, Jackson Heights has a great variety of storefront groceries. The aroma of Indian spices surrounds Patel Brothers and the Shamiana Sweet Center, while the clean perfume of fresh lemon grass emanates from Tahi Grocery and the sweet molasses smell of Latin American pastries envelops La Constancia Argentinian and Las Americas.
By 8 A.M., Manhattan has begiun to stir. Gray suits and briefcases are scurrying along the sidewalks toward midtown offices, the farmers in the green market at Union Square are setting up their stalls, and the third layer link in the New York food chain - the city's specialaty stores and carriage-trade grocers - are unfurling their tidy awnings. Unlike the wholesalers the small, ethnic providers, and, indeed, the farmers, these suppliers count on presentation and service as much as they do on quality.
The elaborate and imaginative arrangements in the window at Citarella Fish, on the Upper West Side, for instance, are famous throughout the city. The display windows are more subdued at the Rosedale Fish and Oyster Market and Pisacane Midtown Corporation. But, along with the seafood departments at the Jefferson Market, Balducci's and Dean & Deluca, the premier fishmongers of Manhattan all artfully showcase the fish they bought hours before at the Fulton Fish Market.
When it arrives from 14th Street, the some of the best of New York's meat is carefully primed for display at such distinguished general butcher shops as M. Lobel and Sons, the Nevada Meat Market and H. Oppenheimer Prime Meats. There are also many specialty meat stores in Manhattan: Ottomanelli's Meat Market is noted for its game; Raoul's Butcher Shop is the best French butcher in town, and Bremen House has good German meats. Butchers at each of these stores cut and groom their products with an eye toward the profits it takes to finance ceramic tile floors in pricey neighbhorhoods.
SPECIALTY EMPORIUMS like Zabar's (for smoked fish, cheese, condiments and coffee), Fairway (for cheese and produce), Murray's Sturgeon (for smoked fish) and Todaro Brothers (for Italian groceries), even the Jefferson Market (for exquisite personal service and general groceries), haven't moved very far from their sawdust-on-the-floor days - each store is a loud circus where assertive shopping is the key to top service and quality.
But the rising generation of carriage-trade stores sometimes seems to be moving away from the idea of groceries as comestibles and toward the notion of food as art. At the ever-enlarging Balducci's, for instance, the huge and arcane selection of produce is often wilted - but it is always impeccably polished. Dean & Deluca suffers no such quality problems. Every sprig of mountain-grown wild thyme, every scallop with its bright orange roe intact, every green bottle of olive oil has been selected for its perfection. And, even if buying a basket of these groceries can run the price of a small piece of art, it's impossible not to be grateful for this elegant SoHo resource.
Stores such as Balducci's and Dean & Deluca have been designed to soothe the ever-escalating concerns of food shoppers. The gleaming glass cases promise precious ingredients that have been protected from dirty hands and tainted environments. The marble counters don't give up splinters or salmonella. Every ingredient carries a pedigree of its origin, picking time, packing time, shipping time and possible use in the kitchen.
The flavors - of wild strawberries at Dean & Deluca, caviar at Caviarteria, cheese at Cheese of All Nations, herring at Old Denmark, chocolate at Kron, Le Chocolatier Manon or Teuscher - are often astounding. And along with these well-groomed groceries, the food products that were bought before dawn on the fringes of New York reach another apogee in dishes prepared to be sold like groceries. In the heart of the city, where the sidewalks are clean and wide, Good and Plenty sells a remarkable roasted vegetable-stuffed focaccio, Country Host sets out kidney pie, Lorenzo & Maria's Kitchen makes vegetable-stuffed eggplant, Mangia sells current-stuffed English scones, and Word of Mouth offers a fine glazed ham.
THOUGH THESE STORES ARE generally located far from the rough edges of the city, their pristine, white tile floors are not bedrock. They are stages supported by an economy that began hundreds of years ago.
''Where's the gourmets going to be without me,'' asked a rubber-booted lumper at the Fulton Fish Market one recent dawn. Like the previous generations of men who pushed dollies loaded with seafood, he had stopped to warm his hands over a fire built in a metal trash drum. He was scowling. Residents of a nearby co-op, it seems, had called the fire department to complain.

HEADLINE: THE ULTIMATE MARKETPLACE;
HOW WE MAKE IT

 BODY:
COMMERCE. BUYING AND SELLING. MONEY - IF you can make it here, you'll make it anywhere. That's one of the most powerful images of New York City: this is the big time. Seven of the 10 largest banks in the United States are headquartered here, along with 6 of the top 10 financial institutions and 4 of the 6 largest insurance companies. New York Harbor is the most active in the country, moving 2 million tons a year. Over 1.5 million workers belong to 550 union locals in New York.
There are 700 major galleries, museums and nonprofit exhibition spaces in the city; the Metropolitan Museum alone receives 4.5 million visitors each year. About 350 American films were released here in 1988, and 115 of them were shot here as well, at least in part, generating $600 million. 
New York is a complete fashion marketplace. More than 5,000 firms are engaged in the design, manufacture and production of clothing (100,000 lines are on display at any time), and 76 trade publications originate here. Apparel worth $14 billion is shipped annually.
Sometimes New York's predominance is simply a matter of scale. Every town has some kind of food industry, but in New York City last year there were 10,500 eating and drinking establishments employing 132,440 people and generating well over $6 billion; 7,000 food retail businesses made another $8.3 billion. Even the individual businesses can seem over-scale: Zabar's is visited by 35,000 paying customers and 10,000 browsers every week, during which period the store sells 35,000 pounds of coffee, 4,850 pounds of smoked salmon and 2,500 pounds of scallion cream cheese.
But the city isn't all big business. Some 360,000 New Yorkers are self-employed, and small enterprises start up every day. In Queens alone, 6,541 new sole proprietorships and general partnerships were registered last year. All around the block, in every borough, storefront businesses - pharmacies, photocopying centers, video rental parlors -are integrated into our communities. Some are so specialized they probably couldn't support themselves anywhere else (there's a beauty parlor in Murray Hill where owners and pets can get groomed simultaneously). Some will fail, to be replaced by others like them.
It all comes back to buying and selling. More than 405,000 people in the metropolitan area work fulltime in legitimate retail operations. And last year, according to the latest Survey of Buying Power, more than $42.2 billion was spent in this city in retail transactions.
There may be more opportunities to make it in New York, but there also seem to be limitless ways to spend it. Read on.
 
* Nearly 75 percent of all employees in the securities industry work for companies centered in New York.
 
* New York is home base for 6 pro teams, 5 leagues, 2 players' associations and a referees' union.
 
* Production of feature films, TV programs and commercials generates $2.3 billion a year in New York.
 
* In 1988, 3.38 billion feet of mail were delivered in the city. Federal Express made 900,000 pickups and deliveries.
 
* Between Thanksgiving and Christmas, 306,000 buyers and browsers saw Santa at Macy's Herald Square.
 
* Broadway sold about 8 million tickets for $262 million last season (1,097 playing weeks). Average price: $33.90.
 
* 1988 diamond imports to the U.S.: 1,644,298 carats ($589 million), most to be cut and polished near 47th Street.
 
* Last year, 19.8 million visitors stayed overnight in city hotels and spent $9.76 billion in New York businesses.
