HEADLINE: BEYOND DAMNATION OR DEFENSE: THE EARLY YEARS

BYLINE: By KEVIN STARR; Kevin Starr teaches urban history at the University of Southern California.

 BODY:

RICHARD MILHOUS NIXON
The Rise of an American Politician.
By Roger Morris.
Illustrated. 1,005 pp. New York:
Henry Holt & Company. $29.95.
In April 1945, a slightly rumpled 32-year-old United States naval officer, just returned from the Pacific, looked out of the 20th-floor window of a building on Church Street in Manhattan and watched Dwight David Eisenhower, Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, ride triumphantly through the ticker tape. The distance between the five-star general and the small-town lawyer from Whittier, Calif., temporarily in uniform, was by any stretch of the imagination unbridgeable, and no one felt this more wistfully than Lieut. Comdr. Richard Milhous Nixon. 
One year later, Mr. Nixon was in the House of Representatives. Four years later, he took his oath as the junior Senator from California. Six years later, before turning 40, he was elected Vice President of the United States on the ticket that took Eisenhower into the White House.
Where had this Nixon come from? To his enemies, many of them from the Eastern Seaboard, the southern California politician seemed to arise from the void, a creature of his own opportunistic self-invention. Even his friends and supporters, as well as some members of his family, found him mysterious.
He is among the most enigmatic figures in American history. Of all our Presidents, Mr. Nixon has been the most Shakespearean in his capacity to self-destruct (Richard III and Coriolanus come to mind) and, even when surviving, to elicit tortuous psychic drama from political action. The only President ever to be forced to resign from office, he occupied center stage in a unique instance of political theater. As if he were pushing the Shakespearean metaphor still further, the loss of the Presidency almost cost him his life.
This life - so internally opaque, so resistant to interpretation, so provocative of deep anger among the legions of Nixon opponents - is now the subject of a projected three-volume biography by Roger Morris, a Harvard-trained political scientist who served Mr. Nixon on the National Security Council before resigning over the invasion of Cambodia. This first volume takes the story up to the Vice Presidential inauguration in 1953.
''Richard Milhous Nixon'' is a massive, powerful biography, absorbing in its research and in its skillful use of anecdote and illustrative detail. When the project is completed, America will have a narrative useful to critics and defenders alike. In fact, it will no longer be possible to damn or defend Mr. Nixon without reference to this great locomotive of a work.
Certain biographers fasten onto their subjects at just the right time: not too early, when meaning is impossible to fix, nor too late, when all that remains possible is merely one more adjustment of the academic record. Like John Morley on Gladstone or Arthur Schlesinger Jr. on Franklin D. Roosevelt, Mr. Morris is writing at a moment when his subject is at once part of history and part of the central political consciousness of our era. The roles Mr. Nixon played, the lines he spoke - in the Alger Hiss case, in the McCarthy controversy, in the Vietnam, Cambodia and Watergate crises - are pivotal points in our contemporary history. By turns admirable, despicable and even tragic, he has played dark or, in the case of China, inspired parts in momentous events that to this day affect our political values and behavior.
All of the protagonist's adult roles in ''The Tragical History of Richard Nixon, Part One'' are a long way from the young Nixon who pulled down the kitchen shades of the family home in Yorba Linda, Calif., so that no one could see him washing the dishes after supper; or who wrote to The Los Angeles Times at the age of 11 asking for a job as an office boy and saying that he would work at any wage offered; or who took a merciless pounding as a junior-varsity tackle at Fullerton High School, pushing himself again and again into the game despite his essential ineptitude; or who became a small-town lawyer after failing to land a job in a fancy New York law firm despite his good grades at Duke University Law School; or who, as a persistent suitor, had his future wife, the astonishingly beautiful Thelma Patricia Ryan, bolt the door in response to his persistent knocking.
Mr. Morris's biography is filled with hundreds of moments in which the reader is tempted to say: ''Now I understand Richard Nixon.'' I am not talking here of psychoanalytic understanding or of a political or ideological response. I mean an intuitive leap - even if empathy wars with distaste - into the inner landscape of another's existence. Outside of his devoted family and a very small circle of close friends, Mr. Nixon has remained curiously resistant to such empathy.
Snobbery has accounted for some of this failure to empathize. Middle-class people like Mr. Nixon do not have the easy appeal to the intelligentsia possessed by patricians or campesinos. Even Arthur Miller finds it hard to like Willy Loman. But Mr. Morris has exhaustively established the human story of Mr. Nixon's early years in all their day-to-day detail, illuminating, for better or worse, defenders or critics, the public man.
The setting of this first installment is southern California, where Mr. Nixon grew up, was educated and got his political start in two ruthless campaigns. For many educated Americans, the area is terra incognita, as unsusceptible to interpretation and as tempting to scornful invective as Mr. Nixon himself. But it has been richly harvested by Mr. Morris.
Outside of those employed in the movie business, few southern Californians have entered the national arena, a surprising fact given the region's wealth, population and politically important entertainment industry. Those who have achieved national reputation - for instance, Gen. George S. Patton Jr. and Ronald Reagan - have by and large had their California associations held against them. Besides, Patton was an aristocrat, impeccable in his Virginia ancestry, and Mr. Reagan was a Midwest import turned film star. In southern California terms, Richard M. Nixon was the real thing.
Thus, when he went on television during the 1952 campaign to make his famous Checkers speech, he defended himself as the common man in politics, the sort of fellow who could afford only a cloth coat, not a mink, for his wife, Pat. This desperate ploy worked, in part because Mr. Nixon, so clumsy, so eager in his white starched shirts, perfectly embodied the lower-middle-class aspirations at the core of the southern California experience in the early 20th century. As a boy in the 1920's, Mr. Nixon was often taken, along with his brothers, to the Angeles Temple in Los Angeles to hear Aimee Semple McPherson preach. Brilliantly, ''Sister Aimee'' knew just what the Nixons and the others in her congregation wanted to hear: a message of redemption, economic as well as religious, amidst the bungalows and citrus groves.
Frank Nixon, the future President's father, was a sometime streetcar conductor who worked just such a citrus grove. But when the bills came due before the lemon trees matured, he turned to running a gasoline station and a grocery store. He had married above his station, into a clan of Whittier Quakers named Milhous, which could never accept Hannah Milhous's choice of a poorly educated, intermittently surly motorman as her husband. In later years, Hannah - a radiant figure by all reports, emanating a fundamental goodness born of an intrinsic spirituality - experienced both the positive and negative results of her choice. On the one hand, her husband adored her. And yet he could be difficult, sitting truculently in a parked car while she was visiting her relatives and honking the horn if she stayed too long. She worked by his side in the gasoline station-grocery store. Indeed, he seemed to panic when she was not by his side.
The major portion of the book concerns Mr. Nixon's political races against Jerry Voorhis and Helen Gahagan Douglas, his involvement in the Hiss case and the 1952 Presidential campaign. Each of these sections derives its power from the fact that a superbly told story is grafted onto the earlier narrative of Mr. Nixon's private life, extending through World War II. These youthful years are not employed as reference points to justify psychologically any of Mr. Nixon's more egregious offenses - the redbaiting of Douglas, for example, whom he defeated for a Senate seat in 1950. But described in detail, they do present, for the first time, a portrait of the 37th President as a full, if flawed, human being and not merely a symbol to be accepted or rejected on partisan grounds.
We see Mr. Nixon at age 12, losing his beloved younger brother Arthur to influenza and, later, his older brother, Harold, to tuberculosis. We see the teen-age Nixon rising at 4 A.M. to buy vegetables at the farmers' market for his father's grocery store, yet refusing to wear a grocer's apron and still delivering orders for his dad after he passed the bar and became a lawyer. We see him in high school, avoiding the dirty corduroy pants that were the fashion, angling for election as student body president. We see his inhibited college courtship of Ola Welch, who left him for a man who was more fun. And we see the dean's-office break-in he undertook with two fellow students at Duke to get an early look at their grades. That incident, which could have cost him his career had he been discovered, showed his massive insecurity even as a second-year law student (and, of course, is chillingly prophetic of a future break-in that would cost him the Presidency).
Mr. Nixon's courtship of Thelma Patricia Ryan has all the power of a realist novel set in southern California. Raised on a hardscrabble ranch in Artesia, Calif., she initially craved the bright lights and the big city. She attended junior college in Fullerton, Calif., and worked in a New York City hospital before returning to graduate from the University of Southern California. Resourceful enough to earn one speaking line in the 1935 film ''Becky Sharp'' (the line was cut), she opted instead for the respectability of becoming Miss Ryan, teacher of commercial subjects at Whittier High School.
Mr. Morris allows none of these early details to obscure his narrative's honesty or to sentimentalize it. Those who loathe Mr. Nixon because of his role in the Hiss case or the smears he leveled against Helen Gahagan Douglas in his Senate campaign will find much to corroborate their judgments.
In terms of the major events of the early career, Mr. Morris recounts a great deal that is new. During the Hiss case, for example, Mr. Nixon was in secret and risky contact with the F.B.I. He was also being fed information by the Rev. John Cronin, a priest who had his own extensive network of informants. Mr. Morris discloses Mr. Nixon's support in the anti-Communist Roman Catholic community, including that of then-Monsignor Fulton J. Sheen, and the equally important support of elite WASP's in Pasadena and San Marino, Calif. It was these gentlemen who created the fund that allowed Mr. Nixon to avoid out-of-pocket expenses for campaigning, and consequently almost cost him his place on the 1952 ticket. The account of this crisis reveals Mr. Nixon at his most complex, by turns brooding, despairing and courageous. Turning public opinion around with his Checkers speech, a televised tour de force, he buried his face in the studio curtains after the broadcast, convinced that he had blown it. He was soon capable, however, of forcing a previously vacillating Ike to eat humble pie in Wheeling, W.Va., then collapsing in tears again after the ordeal was over.
Such accounts give this biography its authority, and it will continue to be read as long as there are those who understand that to fathom Richard Milhous Nixon and his career is to come close, very close, to the inner landscape of middle-class America in all its aspirations, strengths and deficiencies. The composer John Adams understood this in his opera ''Nixon in China.'' So does Roger Morris.

LENGTH: 1196 words

HEADLINE: CHILDREN'S BOOKS;
IT'S SO MUCH EASIER TO WRITE ABOUT THE RICH

BYLINE: By MARK JONATHAN HARRIS; Mark Jonathan Harris's most recent novel for children is ''Come the Morning.''

 BODY:
During the discussion after a recent talk I gave at a school, a sixth grader asked me, ''Why are people poor?''
Surprised by his question, I stalled and asked the class. Hesitantly at first, then with increasing liveliness, they offered their views: ''stupidity,'' ''hard luck,'' ''not enough jobs,'' ''laziness,'' ''drugs,'' ''prejudice,'' ''God's will,'' ''the stinginess of rich people.'' Although many of their responses reflected the attitudes of their parents or the news media, what struck me most was the children's passion. This was a middle-class school, in a racially mixed neighborhood in Los Angeles, yet many of the children had firsthand experience of poverty. They had encountered the homeless in the streets as well as on television; they knew families who had suffered financial hardships; and from the fervor of some of their replies, or their embarrassed silences, I suspected that several of them were poor themselves. Almost all of them had had some personal glimpse of economic deprivation, and they wanted to understand it. 
Of all industrial countries, the United States has the highest proportion of children living in poverty. Approximately 13 million children - one out of every five - in this country are poor. Yet recent children's books have largely ignored the subject.
The 1960's and 70's saw the introduction of a new candor and realism into children's novels. Writers could tackle death, disease, divorce, addiction. Generally, however, these problems were all viewed from the perspective of the white middle class. Yet in the second half of the 19th century Horatio Alger wrote more than 100 books proving that even the poorest dead-end kid could make it to the board room - if only he were willing to work hard and use his initiative. Margaret Sidney also celebrated the triumph of pluck over poverty with her best-selling ''Five Little Peppers and How They Grew'' in 1881. The most enduringly popular of the cheerful school of poverty books are Laura Ingalls Wilder's ''Little House'' series, eight autobiographical novels, written from 1932 to 1943. For Wilder, like Sidney, poverty is only a temporary obstacle to be overcome by resourcefulness, courage and the love and kindness of the family.
In the 20th century the Depression took the romantic edge off poverty, and two world wars, urbanization and divorce began to erode the nuclear family. When children's fiction began to deal more frankly with contemporary life, idealized families like the Peppers and the Ingallses disappeared. Two decades ago, a pair of books by Vera and Bill Cleaver showed that parents can't always be counted on to protect their children from the ravages of adversity. In ''The Mimosa Tree'' (1970) and the Newbery Award-winning ''Where the Lilies Bloom'' (1969) the Cleavers present two impoverished families in which the children have only themselves to rely on. The second book portrays the rural poverty of Appalachia, the first the slums of Chicago, but in many respects the novels are virtually identical. The ailing father in ''Where the Lilies Bloom'' dies; the father in ''The Mimosa Tree'' is blind and never leaves the apartment. In both books it falls upon the gritty 14-year-old heroines - Marvella Proffitt and Mary Call Luther, respectively - to make the hard decisions for the family's survival. Although the poverty the Cleavers portray is much grimmer than that of Sidney or Wilder, their fictional children are larger than life, with a strength and resilience that, at times, borders on the mythological.
When Americans were more optimistic about the chances of working one's way out of penury, it was easier to write about the subject for children. Today most of us are skeptical of the rags-to-riches myth, and few would be willing to preach the character-building virtues of impoverishment. Because there are no easy solutions to the problem, most writers simply avoid dealing with it.
Two exceptions are Alice Childress and Walter Dean Meyers. Although written in 1973, Ms. Childress's novel ''A Hero Ain't Nothing but a Sandwich'' (which is not about poverty per se, but a 13-year-old boy on his way to being hooked on heroin) speaks to our bleaker view of poverty. Told from a variety of perspectives, it remains one of the most powerful and complex portraits of people trapped in the urban ghetto. ''We think of poverty as a condition simply meaning a lack of funds, no money,'' the school principal says in the novel, ''but when one sees fifth, sixth, and seventh generation poor, it is clear that poverty is as complicated as high finance.''
Walter Dean Meyers has written a number of books about black children and teen-agers growing up in our toxic inner cities. One of his latest, ''Scorpions,'' depicts the tragic consequences when Jamal, a 12-year-old, comes to possess a gun. The book is notable for the way Mr. Meyers conveys his protagonist's sense of powerlessness. Jamal wonders if there will ever be a time when he won't have to worry about somebody beating him up. Even when he gives the gun up at the end of the book, a part of him, ''a part that [is] small and afraid,'' still wants to keep it.
The families in both ''Hero'' and ''Scorpions'' are working poor, not second or third generations living on welfare; yet as the few examples of poor people in contemporary children's books, they may not be able to counter the commonly held belief that poverty is a problem of the underclass. The absolute increase in poverty, moreover, is among whites rather than blacks, among two-income rather than single-parent families. To think about poverty as mainly an underclass or minority issue is not only to misconceive it, but also to wall it off and make it alien.
With rare exceptions like ''Scorpions,'' in the last decade the social-problem novel has fallen into disfavor, swept off the shelves by the Reagan-era nostalgia for traditional values and a preference for simplistic, ''just say no'' solutions. Book-buying adults - who, by and large, purchase the books that children read - seem to be opting for works that extol community, continuity, security. Publishers, eager to cater to their middle-class buyers, produce more and more upbeat entertainments.
Like all of us, children want to make sense of the world around them. Poor children want to understand how others in similar circumstances cope with their feelings of anger, frustration and deprivation. Middle-class children may wonder if they should fear the poor, or pity them, or what might happen if their own family's fortunes were to founder; and they wonder how to help.
Books are still one of the most important ways that children extend the range of their experience. In the privacy of their reading, children can test their beliefs and perceptions without having to defend them against disapproving peers or parents. The writer's art and the reader's imagination free children to rethink, reassess and refeel their own attitudes about themselves, about others and about the world in which they live. In our increasingly divided society, it is critical that we not disdain or ignore the experience of one-fifth of our children.

SECTION: Section 8; Page 1, Column 2; Sports Desk

LENGTH: 1749 words

HEADLINE: Like His Team, Tarkanian Is Always on the Run

BYLINE: By WILLIAM C. RHODEN

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS, Nev.

 BODY:
''Athletically we are not a bandit school, we are not an outlaw school. We're good academically, that's been documented. We've made mistakes, like other people. But we're not outlaw, we're not crooked.'' - Dr. Robert Maxson, president, University of Nevada-Las Vegas.
 
When Jerry Tarkanian became the head basketball coach of Nevada-Las Vegas in 1973, the school was still being referred to in certain circles as Tumbleweed Tech, a derisive reference to the fact that the university opened in 1957 with 300 students and one building set on a 60-acre plot of desert.
There was no identity, no tradition, just an educational oasis in the midst of sand and casinos. 
''In the early 70's, if I said that I was from U.N.L.V. at various meetings, people would always ask 'Where?' '' said Dr. Richard Baepler, who was president of the university in 1973 and actively lobbied for the school to hire Tarkanian. ''We realized that we could use the athletic team to get the kind of attention that helps the academic side. We don't get that response anymore.''
Runnin' Rebel basketball under Tarkanian has put the school so solidly on the map that one can hardly think of Nevada-Las Vegas without thinking of a fast-break game and the sad-eyed coach known affectionately - by some - as the Shark.
Under Tarkanian, U.N.L.V. has reached the Final Four twice. His 1976-77 team went 29-3 before losing in the semifinals; his 1986-87 team, which some say was his best team until this season, was 37-2.
The 59-year-old coach begins the 1989-90 season with the highest winning percentage of any active coach (.823) and a team that many think is his best ever.
The Rebels have been ranked No. 1 in most preseason polls, marking the first time in Tarkanian's 28-year college coaching career that one of his teams has begun the season ranked at the top.
''When I came here 17 years ago, this was not a good job, there weren't many people who wanted this job,'' said Tarkanian, who came to U.N.L.V. from Long Beach State where he had turned that program around. ''I'm really pleased with the way the program has grown.''
''I'd like to coach a few more years and then retire,'' the coach added when asked about his future. ''I don't know how many more years I have. If things work out I'd like to stay here, but you never know.''
That final thought seems to come out of nowhere. Indeed, it seems odd that a coach of Tarkanian's stature would be uncertain about his future, particularly at a school that he has virtually helped create.
But the doubts about a solid future are more than the musings of a coach contemplating retirement. At a time when most men at his age, in his profession and with his accomplishments are enjoying the fruits of their labor, Tarkanian still finds himself being pursued by secret agents.
For the last week investigators from the National Collegiate Athletic Association enforcement staff have been in Las Vegas interviewing a wide range of athletic and non-athletic personnel about charges of improprieties within the men's basketball program. It is the fourth time in five months that the N.C.A.A. has been on campus. Tarkanian, despite a good front, admits that he is worried.
''They're not going to find a major violation,'' Tarkanian said. ''We haven't done anything. Absolutely haven't done anything. But there's not a program in the country that they can't go into and spend as much time as they've spent in our program and they might not find something minor. But they aren't going to find a major violation.
''I'd walk away from the program if they did.''
As if it weren't enough to have N.C.A.A. investigators on campus, a local newspaper in the last two weeks has raised questions about late-model cars that some Rebel players have been driving around Las Vegas. As it turned out, Mark Warketein, the assistant to the athletic director, was able to document the origin of the cars in question and in one instance pointed out an investigative error by the newspaper.
Nonetheless, the reports only served to intensify a conflict between Tarkanian and the N.C.A.A. that has been going on since 1974 when the organization placed Long Beach on probation, a year after Tarkanian left for U.N.L.V.
In 1977, the N.C.A.A., apparently continuing its pursuit of Tarkanian, put the U.N.L.V. basketball program on a two-year probation. The organization ordered Nevada-Las Vegas to suspend Tarkanian but was prevented from doing so by an injunction. The case went all the way to the Supreme Court, which last year ruled favorably for the N.C.A.A. and left the organization free to renew its effort to discipline Tarkanian.
Now a new investigation threatens to turn the university into a battle ground at a time when it is attempting to forge a reputation as a solid academic institution.
The reality is that the fervor that swept Tarkanian onto campus in 1973 and allowed unchecked expansion of the basketball program has been replaced by fervor to erase the bandit image of a basketball school. University and coach have clearly arrived at a crossroads and a stalemate.
As one member of the Board of Regents said: ''There was a time when we really needed it, the exposure that the basketball team could bring. Now it seems that we've outgrown the need.''
The university may have outgrown basketball in a figurative sense. As a practical matter, however, the Runnin' Rebels have become an integral part of the university's economic infrastructure.
The athletic department operates on an $8 million budget. It receives $1 million from the state and $1 million from student fees. The basketball program generates $5 million and single-handedly supports the university's sports program. Dr. Brad Rothermel, the school's athletic director, estimates that if the Rebels win a national championship, the program could bring in $6 million this season.
If the school is placed on probation it could cost the university $3.5 million a year in lost television and post-season revenue.
But the focus on finance, and even on Tarkanian's personality begs the larger questions: Has Tarkanian's basketball empire operated in accordance with N.C.A.A. regulations? More important, has that empire been built on the backs of players, the majority of whom were black and often poor, who put far more into the university than they were equipped to receive?
There is no clear-cut answer and Tarkanian has his own view: ''The way I look at it, if you bring a kid in that can't read and write, somebody nobody will touch, and you keep him here four or five years, teach him to follow the rules, make him responsible for what he does, at the end if he can read and write a little, you've done him a favor. Even if he doesn't have a piece of paper you've given him a chance to straighten out. I don't see anything wrong with that.''
From the time he began his college coaching career at Riverside City College in 1961, Tarkanian has specialized in finding and getting the most out of players who were overlooked, avoided or cast off by other programs. The pattern continued at Pasadena City College and began to attract attention at Long Beach State where Tarkanian, relying on a team of primarily junior-college players, had his team ranked seventh nationally in 1971-72.
''All I looked for was the kids who were committed to basketball,'' Tarkanian said. ''Often those were the black kids. I don't take another coach's word about a kid being a problem.''
Tarkanian has stretched the margins of his philosophy. In 1986 he authorized the recruitment of Lloyd Daniels, a player who attended four different high schools, never graduated from one, and was so controversial that no major program touched him. Except U.N.L.V. The result was one misadventure after another. Warketein became Daniels's guardian and the nature of that guardianship is the foundation of the N.C.A.A.'s current investigation. Daniels was admitted as a regular student in 1986. In 1987 he was arrested in a sting operation for attempting to buy cocaine.
Should the university have been involved with Daniels?
''If you're asking me if Mr. Daniels should have been recruited in the first place, I'd say you have to ask the coaches that question,'' Maxson said. ''I think you hold the coach responsible for who is recruited. I think that's the coaches' responsibility, they ultimately have to be responsible for the people they recruit. Once that person enrolls, then it becomes the business of the institution. I don't know of any president in the country that knows who's being recruited at any given time.''
Tarkanian admits that the experiment backfired, but stands behind the philosphy that allowed Daniels into his program.
''Lloyd Daniels was a real project, he had two and a half strikes against him when we took him,'' Tarkanian said. ''If it worked out, that would have been a great story. But it didn't work out and in all probability it wasn't going to work out. The odds of him working out were probably one in five. But we took that chance and it didn't work out.''
Critics point out that only 4 of the 13 players on U.N.L.V.'s 1977 Final Four team have received degrees. Only one of the four was a starter and another received his degree from another institution. Two of the 13 were unemployed as of last year, two worked as valets in Las Vegas, three are playing basketball, one is a security guard, one is a teacher, another a realtor, one a college coach, and another works in a paper mill.
Over the last five years, as the push for academic reform in athletics has become more rigorous, the basketball program has spent more than $60,000 a year for academic support programs. Since 1983, 10 of the 23 players who were eligible to play in their senior year graduated. Five of six seniors on the 1987 team also graduated. Seven players are back in school pursuing their degrees with fifth-year scholarships provided by the U.N.L.V. basketball Alunmni Association.
Maxson appears comfortable with the school's powerful basketball program.
''I do not believe there is an inherent conflict between good academics and good athletics,'' Maxson said, ''but you have to do them both with integrity, you have to be honest, you have to do what's right.''
Have the Runnin' Rebels done the right thing?
''Coach Tarkanian tells me that we have no problems, no major problems, in our program and I accept that,'' Maxson said. ''Until someone shows me differently, I accept what he tells me.''

HEADLINE: PERSPECTIVES: Town-House Rentals;
East Side Project Back in Construction

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
''IT'S the biggest bargain in New York!'' said Monica Dalton, casting an admiring glance upwards toward the dazzling skylight in the one-family town house she is trying to rent out for the owner. The skylight covers the entire room. It swoops down from a height of 45 feet, halting 17 feet above the living room floor.
Bargains are relative. The owner is asking $21,000 a month in rent for this 5,000-square-foot house at 222 East 67th Street, between Third and Second Avenues. That is about the annual income of the average New York City household. But in the town-house market on the Upper East Side, where prices in the $5 million range are no longer unusual, Ms. Dalton has a case. The wealthy user may work it out that the cost of renting will compare favorably to the net cost of owning. 
On East 67th Street, the interesting point is that the one-family house and the 10 houses that stretch down the block from it - which were started in 1983 and only now are being completed - are for rent at all. The first house was completed as a model, and the builder offered to finish the others and sell them to buyers for $4 million.
But buyers demurred and the marketing effort ceased. The buildings sat untouched, hollow shells of floors and walls behind a pink-granite facade, until this year. Now all 10 are back in construction, with a triplex and a duplex in each building. They are on the market for rent at $12,500 or $13,000 a month for the triplexes, with 3,050 or 3,100 square feet of space, and $8,500 or $8,750 for the duplexes, with 2,100 or 2,150 square feet. Leasing began in September. Occupancy starts in December.
The builder is Sheldon H. Solow, one of the Manhattan's few remaining producers of market-rate rental housing and one of the more innovative. The houses share a building lot with a 46-story apartment house, 265 East 66th Street, which Mr. Solow finished in 1979. The distinctive 301-unit, gray-glass apartment building has an underground parking garage that occupies ground beneath the town houses.
In the 70's, as the owner of a 40,000-square-foot site shaped like a backwards L - half along the west side of Second Avenue from 66th Street to 67th Street and the other half along 67th Street - Mr. Solow could have developed his site quite differently. He might have built a 35-story avenue tower and a 12- to 15-story midblock building, or a 51-story tower on Second Avenue, leaving the midblock area open as a private park.
Instead, he decided to use 50,000 square feet of floor area available under the zoning law for 11 five-story town houses. Their 60-foot height is in scale with the midblock buildings behind them on East 66th Street, which Metropolitan Life Insurance Company owns as a protective buffer for its full-block Manhattan House rental development across the street. The low scale also would assure better views for residents of lower floors in the tower.
The town houses have 18-foot frontages, 30-foot rear gardens behind 70 feet of structure and facades that are alternately flat or curved. Inside, there are 17-foot-high living rooms for the triplex occupants, broad skylights over the duplexes, which are reached by private elevator, and a level of luxury in the fixtures and interior construction that comports with the rents. The architect is Eli Attia.
''What we wanted was the feeling you get when you drive down Madison Avenue or Fifth Avenue - it feels like a fabric,'' Mr. Solow said. ''It had to be simple but luxurious.''
NEW town houses are a rarity in Manhattan, whether for rent or for sale. Gut rehabilitations of older shells are the more common form of constuction on the Upper East Side. ''You need 45 feet at a minimum for new development, and most of the sites are landmarked anyway,'' said Hope Parodi, a town-house broker with Brown Harris Stevens.
Beyond that, the Solow site was farther east than builders might normally be expected to venture with houses selling for $4 million.
In Greenwich Village, Ambassador Construction Company has completed eight speculatively built colonial-style brick town houses with garages on an 8,000-square foot site between Christopher Street and West 10th Street, and began offering them five months ago at $1.2 million to $1.4 million. The project is called Greenwich Mews. Two have been sold and one has been rented. The builder is willing to rent out the others at about $5,000 a month.
Rentals are gaining in the resale market as well. Brokers report resistance to the prices being asked for resale properties, whose formerly elevated price structure partially reflected the availability of steep income-tax deductions on mortgage interest. The 1986 tax reform act sharply cut the marginal tax rate for high-income taxpayers, so that the deduction is less significant than before.
TWO years ago there were about half as many town-house rental listings on the East Side as there are now, according to Nancy Packes, president of Feathered Nest, which handles town-house rental listings. The firm has about 30 such listings, she said. Douglas Elliman-Gibbons & Ives, which is handling the Solow town-house rentals, says it has listings of 125 private homes for sale on the East Side. Asking prices have a huge range - from $2.75 million to $11 million - suggesting the sensitivity of the market to the precise location as well as the wide variation in the condition of the properties.
The Solow town houses have links to the apartment house. They are tied in with its security system and are maintained and serviced by its staff. As for prices on a square-footage basis, they are renting for about $49 a square foot a year, topping even the average $42 that the builder is getting at East River Place, a 50-story, 415-unit building he has been renting out at 525 East 72d Street, on the East River, since January 1988. A total of 270 apartments have been leased.
The user's decision on renting or buying at this extreme high end of the market probably will be based on matters other than economic. Nevertheless, on financial grounds alone specialists say that the case for renting has improved in recent years.
Taking the example of the $156,000 annual rent for a triplex in a Solow town house, they make a comparison to the cost of a owning a one-family East Side house with a comparable 3,000 square feet of space. That much cash would suffice to pay the annual after-tax cost of owning a town-house unit of a similar size bought for about $2 million. This assumes that the buyer pays 20 percent in cash and gets a fixed-rate 10 percent, 30-year mortgage.
The buyer's net cost for the town house at the end of the first year would be about the same as the renter's, except that the buyer would also lose the interest he might have earned on the $400,000 down payment.
Eventually, buyers would recover their investment at resale, and possibly benefit from appreciation in value as well. But people expecting a shorter-term occupancy give that factor less weight.

HEADLINE: TALKING: Windows;
To Repair, Restore or Replace?

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
FROM almost every source - television, radio, direct mail and print ads - homeowners are being bombarded with promotions for thermal-pane replacement windows. A homeowner with an aging house and no restrictions on exterior modifications can find all this quite tempting.
The old windows may have unslightly rotted frames, which can let moisture and insects in. They may have deteriorated sashes, which make them hard to open and close. They may leak air, which results in heat loss. And the wooden muntins - the vertical and horizontal dividing bars - can be an annoying visual barrier and make cleaning difficult, although they also may add style and authenticity to a facade. 
But before deciding to plunge ahead there are less expensive alternatives to weigh, for even the most economical job is likely to cost an average of $300 a window, plus installation. In addition, there are so many types of replacement windows on the market that it is important to know the questions that need to be asked. (It is also possible, by shopping around for dealers and installers, to replace the glass alone.) First, some claims need to be discounted. Heat conservation experts insist that, assuming the house already has a full set of storm windows, even old ones, there is no evidence to confirm manufacturers' statements that there will be a major saving on fuel costs. ''There will be virtually no difference unless your windows leak and you don't already have storms,'' said Peter Judd, an assistant commissioner in the New York City Department of Housing Preservation and Development. Thus having the job done just to lower heating bills may be misguided. Further, brokers say, replacement windows will probably not add to resale value. ''It doesn't make much difference,'' said Ruth Brewster, president of Brewster Realty of Elizabeth, N.J., unless the existing windows are so decayed, rusted or warped that the house looks shabby and the fuel bills are far above average.
Typically, therefore, Jared Edwards, a partner in Smith Edwards Architects of Hartford, Conn., recommends replacing existing windows only when the owner wants more light or wants to escape the burden of maintenance.
For replacement windows truly are easier to maintain. Most have panes that can be tilted for easy cleaning from the inside, lessening the need for professional window services. If the new windows are double-glazed, which they should be, this eliminates the need for storm windows. And the frames are now being ''clad'' - permanently coated with vinyl or enamel-covered aluminium - to eliminate the need for periodic repainting.
In addition, the muntins will be slimmer and may be ''optional,'' meaning they can be clipped in or out at will. Or they can be embedded between the layers of glass for greater cleanliness and ease of maintenance.
Elimination of muntins, for example, was the goal of Norma and Alva Anderson, who replaced six rotted windows in their 50-year-old Cape Cod in Fairfield, Conn., earlier this fall. ''I love the open look,'' said Mrs. Anderson. Like many couples the Andersons did not change all their windows at once, dividing the job into two parts, which spread the cost over a longer period. An equity loan is another financing alternative.
Homeowners who opt for replacement windows need to decide if they wish to replace only the sashes - the movable frames holding the glass - or the sashes and the entire stationary frame within which the sashes move. Most prices quoted cover only sash replacement, and this may not suffice. Mark Russo, housing specialist with Cornell University Cooperative Extension Services in New York City, noted that often it is the frame that is rotted, since it often is unprotected by storm windows and therefore is most exposed to weather.
And the difference in price is steep. George Nemeth, vice president at Clearview Inc. of Bridgeport, Conn., a company that supplies and installs replacement windows, charges homeowners around $300 for a double-hung thermal replacement sash fully installed and $500 for the entire window with framing.
REPLACEMENT windows can be bought in either vinyl or aluminum for about the same price, said Mr. Nemeth. Vinyl has become more popular, he noted, possibly because ''it has more of a wood look.'' Homeowners, he said, should visit a dealer-installer's showroom to see the actual windows before deciding on a brand or model. They should also visit one or two homes where a job was recently done. He cautioned that a carpenter will probably also have to be hired if a change of window size or shape is being contemplated.
Installers and homeowners who have bought replacement windows say it should take no longer than one or two days for a crew to make the complete changeover if only sashes are being replaced, and about a week if new frames are included.
It is also a good idea to have the manufacturer send his own representative to measure each new window being ordered. Consider, for instance, what happened to Paul and Jane Mattingly of Elizabeth, N.J. A year ago they spent $9,000 replacing 30 windows at the four-bedroom, Tudor-style home they had just bought because the original iron casement windows, dating to 1926, were severely rusted and no longer closed properly. Storm windows were not feasible.
What they had feared - and what indeed did occur - was that three windows were incorrectly measured and had to be returned and rebuilt. Had a carpenter or other intermediary measured those windows, said Mr. Mattingly, there could have been a prolonged dispute over who was responsible for paying for the error. This way the manufacturer was clearly responsible.
If esthetic change or convenience is not the issue, then fixing the old windows might be wiser and more thrifty, and will enhance the integrity of the original facade in a manner that replacement windows rarely match. The rise of the restoration movement, noted Mr. Edwards, the architect, has helped develop many techniques for fixing even the most severly rotted sash or frame. Now available are replacement pieces and epoxies that restore a rotted area like a filling in a tooth cavity. Local preservation organizations are an excellent source of technical help for this kind of work.
Anyone opting for repairs should, at the same time, consider replacing old storm windows that may have warped and become unsightly. The newer storm windows are less obtrusive and more energy-efficient. ''Some of them are almost invisible,'' said Mr. Edwards. New storms cost about $80 to $100 each, installed.

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:

Rights of a Co-op Renter
Question: I own a vacant apartment in a co-op that has no subletting restrictions. A potential tenant, who now lives in a rent-stabilized apartment in a nonevict co-op, expressed an interest in renting it but is worried because the apartment is not stabilized. He said he would not have the statutory protections he now enjoys, nor would the Division of Housing and Community Renewal come to his aid if I were to harass, overcharge or try to evict him. Is he right? Can I register the apartment under rent stabilization? . . G. T., Manhattan
Answer: According to Thomas R. Viola, a spokesman for the division which has jurisdiction over rent-regulated housing, there is no mechanism for adding units like yours to the rent-regulation system. Your prospective tenant is right; the agency would not be involved in any dispute that might arise between the two of you. 
However, a tenant does not have to be in rent-regulated housing to be protected against such things as harassment or illegal eviction. For example, to evict a tenant a landlord would need a warrant of eviction from Housing Court. Moreover, any tenant can bring a claim against a landlord in Housing Court and would not need a lawyer to do it. As for rent, while you are free to ask what you want, you could offer a lease-based rent and increases set by the Rent Guidelines Board.
 
Property Rights
Question: The property of my home is separated from my neighbor's by a fence eight or so inches inside his property put up many years ago by the previous owner. A tall hedge on my side of the fence has been cared for by my gardener for 30 years and my neighbor took for granted that we would trim and fertilize it.
The neighboring property was recently sold and the new owner has let it be known he is claiming the strip of property on my side of the fence, basing his claim on a survey, which is probably correct, that shows it belongs to him. The amount of land is minimal and of no practical use to him. Do we, by reason of ''historical'' considerations, have any rights to the strip on which the hedge is located? . . . S. P., Whitestone, Queens
Answer: Probably not. There is a legal doctrine known as ''adverse possession'' under which a person who openly and exclusively occupies real property continuously for 10 years under hostile circumstances, might be able to gain title from the owner of record.
''But it would depend on the relationship with the previous owner,'' said David L. Smith, an attorney who specializes in real estate matters. ''If he had an agreement to use this strip, it is likely that this would be considered an easement. Therefore, a claim to title under adverse possession would probably fail.''
Also, as a practical matter, the cost of making such a claim in court would probably far outweigh any benefits.
 
Prepayment Penalty
Question: I am a homeowner with a 30-year fixed- rate mortgage. According to the terms of my mortgage, there is a penalty for prepayment. I recently read that prepayment penalty clauses are no longer enforceable. Is this true? . . . M. E., Woodmere, L.I.
Answer: Yes, in most cases. According to Section 5 - 501, 3B of the New York State General Obligations Law, no lender can impose a prepayment penalty after the first year of a mortgage as long as the mortgage is on a residential property of between one and six units and is occupied by the owner. If you wish to file a complaint, write to the mortgage division of the New York State Department of Banking. The New York City office is at 2 Rector Street, New York, N.Y. 10006.

HEADLINE: Parking Spaces

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Imagine someone landing from Mars or Oshkosh and seeing your ''Talking'' column on Oct. 15 on protecting rent-stabilized parking spaces in a cooperative conversion.
Tenant attorneys, the New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, and the State Attorney General all offer opinions on why a tenant should keep his place on a waiting list for a space after a building goes co-op. 
None of the experts seems concerned that the Rent Stabilization Law, designed to protect New Yorkers from rent gouging in a housing emergency, has become a windfall for car owners who happened to rent a space in a garage a few years before their neighbors.
Originally, the Rent Stabilization Law directed the state housing agency to establish guidelines for garage rents to prevent landlords from requiring exorbitant parking fees in connection with leasing a low-rent, regulated apartment - in other words, so that you couldn't be required to rent a $1,000 parking space to keep your $300 apartment.
The law would have been satisfied by rules limiting parking fees to tenants to those prevailing for all other garage customers. Instead, state regulators decided to treat parking spaces exactly like apartments, with their own stabilized leases, renewal notices and annual percentage increases way below market - all monitored at taxpayers expense.
By the same logic, New York should now buy every homeless person a car to live in.
P.S. I park on the street.
 
DAN MARGULIES
 Manhattan
 
The writer is executive director of the Community Housing Improvement Program, an organization of rental apartment building owners.

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Carriage Houses;
New Home For Ballet

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. LYONS

 BODY:
Ten years ago the Ballet Hispanico of New York, a minority-oriented dance group that was gaining a foothold in the entertainment world, formally asked New York City officials if it could convert two former carriage houses in the West Side Urban Renewal Area into a permanent headquarters for the company and its school with studios, dressing rooms and office space.
Last Wednesday, after a decade of program reviews and the rehabilitation of the buildings, the new headquarters of the ballet group at 167-169 West 89th Street near Amsterdam Avenue was formally dedicated at a reception attended by 300 supporters. 
A total of $1.8 million had been raised from government, corporate and private donors to buy and renovate the two buildings. The structures were built in 1892 from a Romanesque revival design by the architect Frank Rooke as carriage houses, with the first floors as stables and living quarters on the second floors.
In 1984, the Ballet Hispanico bought the two buildings from the city for $110,000 as part of the West Side urban renewal effort.
The architect for the renovation of the buildings, which were gutted, joined and given a new roof, was the Manhattan firm of Buck & Cane.

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Reverse Mortgages and Repairs;
New Help for Older Homeowners

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. LYONS

 BODY:
Two government programs announced this month offer loans and grants to older homeowners having low incomes or housing problems or both. In Washington, the Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, made available for the first time about $200 million in guaranteed funds for 2,500 so-called reverse mortgages to be insured by the Federal Housing Administration. In Albany, the New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal made available $750,000 for emergency home repairs. 
Fannie Mae will guarantee loans by 50 lending institutions, which will issue mortgages for people at least 62 years of age who want to tap into the equity in their homes for living expenses. The terms of the reverse mortgage guarantee the homeowner that he may live in his dwelling for the rest of his life. The mortgage's concept involves gradually increasing the loan, rather than decreasing it as is customary. Upon the homeowner's death, his estate repays the outstanding debt through the sale of the property.
The pilot program, enacted by Congress to be run by the Department of Housing and Urban Development, lets homeowners choose either a monthly income check or a line of credit. Payments are based on age, interest rates, the type of plan chosen and the value of the property. Details are available at local offices of the Department of Housing and Urban Development, reachable in Manhattan at 264-8053.
The state program, called Restore, for Residential Emergency Service to Offer Repairs for the Elderly, makes grants to local community action groups that provide up to $5,000 to low-income homeowners for repairs. To be eligible in New York City, a homeowner must be at least 60 years old with a yearly income not exceeding $18,950 for a single person, or $21,650 for a couple. Amounts differ in other parts of the state. For information, call the state housing agency in New York City at 519-5856 or in Albany at (518) 473-2104.

LENGTH: 1282 words

HEADLINE: Mayoral Victors Break New Ground But Face Old Woes

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

 BODY:
WHEN State Senator John C. Daniels was elected Mayor of New Haven last week, the retiring Mayor, Biagio DiLieto, felt a tinge of pity for his celebrated successor, the first black to occupy the city's top executive post.
Standing alone in a corner at Mr. Daniels's victory party Tuesday night, cupping an ever-present cigarette, Mr. DiLieto, also a Democrat, said he could think of no worse time for anyone to be taking over the reins of the city.
''I don't envy John Daniels,'' said Mr. DiLieto, a former police chief in his fifth term as Mayor. ''I could go on ad nauseam about all the problems he'll be facing.''
Much the same could be said for Bridgeport and its Republican Mayor-elect, Mary C. Moran, a real estate manager who brought about the biggest political upset of the year in Connecticut by defeating the incumbent, Thomas W. Bucci, a Democrat. Indeed, Ms. Moran, who will be the first woman to be a mayor in Bridgeport, may face the greater challenge of the two new Mayors. 
 
Problems of Cities
Ms. Moran, who has described herself as a housewife, has no experience in public office and will govern a city widely regarded as the state's most ungovernable, a long-dead industrial hub burdened with serious fiscal problems, a soaring crime rate and a seemingly indelible image as the shantytown of Fairfield County. ''The next two years are going to be difficult,'' Mr. Bucci said. The problems facing both cities are those facing many cities in Connecticut and elsewhere: a decline in Federal aid and a shrinking local tax base, rampant poverty, racial divisiveness, AIDS, homelessness and a weakening of public school systems.
Then there are the myriad social ills that stem from those problems: drug abuse, teen-age pregnancy and infant mortality.
 
'On the Edge'
''Our city is on the edge in many ways,'' said Mr. Daniels, who easily defeated white challengers from the Republican and Green parties in a campaign virtually free of racial conflict. ''We can only pull back from the edge if we all pull together.''
Mr. Daniels, a part-time college football referee in addition to his work as a legislator and the owner of a plumbing business, will govern a city with 127,000 people.
His chief goals are to focus on poverty in the city, which ranks as the seventh poorest city in the nation among cities its size. The Mayor-elect also plans to push for more police manpower in poor communities and for more inner-city development projects ''This administration has staked itself on economic development, downtown development,'' said Khalid Lum, Mr. Daniels's press secretary.
Ms. Moran, who defeated a former mayor, Leonard S. Paoletta, by 32 votes in a seven-way primary in September, will head the state's largest city with 140,000 residents.
She should be helped more than previous administrations by amendments to the city charter that were approved by the voters on Tuesday. The amendments will create a Department of Finance and an Office of Policy and Management.
''We're going to market this city and turn it around,'' said Ms. Moran, a Bridgeport native who has held several jobs in residential real estate and labor relations and ran unsuccessfully for city clerk in 1977.
 
'We're Novices'
Ms. Moran's victory turned out to be the shocker of Tuesday's municipal elections in 158 towns and cities. Perhaps the next biggest surprise was her arrival at her victory party in a white Rolls-Royce.
''We're novices, but we didn't make one backroom deal,'' said Ms. Moran. ''When anybody said, 'What are you going to give me? I said, 'A better Bridgeport.' '' Her campaign manager, David DeFelice, said: ''Everything is timing. This was Mary's time to run. She always said she wanted to be the first woman mayor of Bridgeport.''
 
Financial Crisis
Mr. DeFelice credited her victory to widespread dissatisfaction with Mr. Bucci and his handling of the city's long-running financial crisis. He said Ms. Moran's backers were the ''taxpayer constituency.'' He said Mr. Bucci raised taxes by 31 percent over four years and helped create a $60 million deficit that forced the city to ask the state for a bail-out plan.
''He went and put the city in state receivership,'' Mr. DeFelice said.
Mr. Bucci, who during the campaign cast his opponent as being a pro-developer candidate who would allow condominiums to be built throughout the city, credited his loss simply to a desire for change. ''For two years, we were the bearers of bad news, especially on the financial side,'' he said. ''I think the voters wanted a new messenger. They wanted someone fresh, someone new, someone with no experience.''
Ms. Moran, who is 56 years old, had 15,624 votes, or 53 percent, to Mr. Bucci's 12,368 votes, or 42 percent. Four other candidates had petitioned themselves onto the ballot. Combined, they received 5 percent of the votes.
In New Haven, Mr. Daniels, 53, had 68 percent of the vote, as against 29 percent for the Republican candidate, Robie Pooley, an Alderman, and 3 percent for Matthew Borenstein, the Green Party candidate.
In both cities, the voter turnout, which was moderate, was not a significant factor in determining the outcome of the elections. Neither were campaign contributions nor fund raising.
In Bridgeport, Mr. Bucci outspent Ms. Moran by $280,000 to $78,000. In New Haven, Mr. Daniels raised more than $400,000, a record for a mayoral race; Ms. Pooley raised about $20,000.
Mr. Daniels's victory, however, was never in doubt, as Democrats outnumber Republicans in the city by a 10-to-1 margin. The city has not had a Republican mayor since 1953, when William C. Celantano was elected.
 
Other Races
Elsewhere in Connecticut, the Democratic challenger in Danbury, Gene Eriquez, upset the incumbent Republican Mayor, Joseph H. Sauer Jr. Mr. Eriquez had 57 percent of the vote, Mr. Sauer 42 percent.
Mr. Sauer was a political novice who won election two years ago chiefly because of a political scandal that led to the indictment last year of Mayor Thomas E. Dyer, a Democrat. Mr. Dyer's trial starts tomorrow in United States District Court in New Haven.
In Stamford, Mayor Thom Serrani, a Democrat, won a fourth term, easily defeating the Republican in the race, Leonard Vignola Jr., a business consultant, for the second time. Mr. Serrani collected 58 percent of the vote to 42 percent for Mr. Vignola. The margin was greater than expected.
And in Middletown, State Representative Paul Gionfriddo, a Democrat, defeated the Republican incumbent, Mayor Sebastian J. Garafalo, by 362 votes out of the 12,564 cast.
In other races around the state, Joseph J. Santopietro, the Republican Mayor of Waterbury, won a third term, defeating his Democratic challenger, Elizabeth C. Brown, a State Representative and a former nun. Mr. Santopietro had 65 percent of the vote to 35 percent for Ms. Brown.
In Hartford, where the power of the mayor's office is diluted by a strong city council-city manager form of government, Mayor Carrie Saxon Perry easily defeated her Republican challenger, Rosemary Z. Cardwell. Ms. Perry had 71 percent of the vote to 29 percent for Ms. Cardwell.
In New Britain, Donald J. DeFronzo, a Democrat, defeated the Republican in the race, Marilyn C. Krazckowsky. Mr. DeFronzo, who defeated the six-term Mayor, William J. McNamara, in the September primary, had 59 percent of the vote, as against 41 percent for Ms. Krazckowsky.
And in an unusual nonmayoral issue that attracted widespread attention, New Haven voters overwhelmingly approved a nonbinding resolution supporting a cut in Federal defense spending to make more money available for social programs. The vote was 7,357 to 1,459.

HEADLINE: LONG ISLAND OPINION;
Women Win Quiet Victories In Equitable Pay

BYLINE: By Charlotte Shapiro; Charlotte Shapiro is associate director of Women on the Job, a nonprofit advocacy group in Port Washington.

 BODY:
PAY equity victories have been and will continue to be won at the negotiating table rather than in the courts.
Recently, a court in California ruled that lower wages paid to women employed by the State of California are not a consequence of sex discrimination but only a condition of the market. Courts rule on the basis of narrowly defined law, but women refuse to be confined by narrow legal standards. On Long Island, women are uniting their energies through political and economic action to challenge historic, market-driven, systemic wage discrimination. These are the women making front page news. 
Equal pay for work of equal value! That is the goal of several well-organized, grassroots coalitions of women. They are office workers, aides, nurses, librarians, women employed in ''pink collar'' occupations. They work for school districts, counties, towns, libraries and universities. Their employers pay them as women - that means 20 to 30 percent less than male co-workers in ''blue collar'' occupations such as maintenance and groundskeeping.
Networks of women in sex-segregated occupations have joined forces with women activists in a coalition of traditional civic, business and professional organizations. Together, these coalitions advocate, negotiate, hold rallies, publicize injustice and gain support from co-workers and the community for wage equity. The victories thus far? In 1985, the Supervisor of the Town of North Hempstead was asked to examine equity for women on the town payroll. He soon recognized that fairness required that the town raise the grades and salaries of clerks. Thirty-one employees in four titles were upgraded by three grades to make them comparable to jobs held by men with equivalent responsibilities. This pay equity adjustment was accomplished through a budget resolution, not litigation.
Three years ago, public health nurses employed by Suffolk County won equal pay for work considered comparable to the public health sanitarians. Sanitarians, a male-dominated job classification, ranked two civil service grades higher than nurses. Advocacy by the women's coalitions with county legislators and the County Executive succeeded in closing the wage gap.
Five women employed in a water district in the Town of North Hempstead, last year, also achieved pay equity success. They quietly organized a women's caucus within their union after several meetings with Women on the Job, the founder of the grass-roots coalitions. Armed with information and strategies to advance their cause, they also won access to the job of meter reader (a traditional male occupation) and the inclusion of a comparable worth clause in their contract.
In 1987, Glen Cove School District clericals and aides won $270,000 in retroactive pay increases to bring them up to the wages of maintenance staff after a four-year long pressure campaign of rallies, speaking out at school board meetings, press reports, media appearances and 103 individual complaints filed with the New York State Division of Human Rights. The women also won new respect, professional advancement benefits and recognition for a union that committed itself to negotiating for women's issues as well as labor issues.
School secretaries in Central Islip also filed a sex discrimination complaint with the Division of Human Rights. When the division found probable cause for wage discrimination, the women won a settlement of $2,000 across the board and a 12 percent wage gap increase. As in Glen Cove, their victory depended upon the active support and assistance of the 53 organizations in a coalition called the Women on the Job Task Force.
The ripple effect can be seen in school jurisdictions across Long Island. Since 1985, about 20 school district clerical associations have won compensatory wage increases. Most employers recognize but will not publicize these increases as pay equity actions. However, employers who stonewall the issue are increasingly brought to the New York State Division of Human Rights. Two examples: women employed in the Wantagh and Sachem School Districts.
This year, Adelphi University clerical workers voted to strike when wage gap demands were totally ignored. Their settlement brought recognition of the pay equity issue and a first step toward fair wages. Their success hinges on their ability to organize themselves and take leadership positions within their union.
Most recently, Hofstra University women ended a six-week strike for pay equity. There, a senior executive secretary, after eight years on the job, earned $15,000 a year compared to $20,000 to $23,000 for custodians, guards and tradesmen.
These women are partners in working families where two paychecks are a necessity, or are sole supporters of their families. They can no longer afford to accept a two-tier wage system that assigns them to second-class status and poverty. The experience of the strike, the negative publicity for Hofstra's wage policies for administrative support staff and the women's new-found cohesion spell significant change for the future.
All eyes are now on Nassau County. It is the defendant in the only major lawsuit on sex and race-based wage discrimination remaining. Despite the protracted delays of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees lawsuit filed five years ago, employees anticipate that wage adjustments will soon become a reality.
The county recently responded to long, unrelenting pay equity advocacy from women's groups. It agreed to undertake the first important step in achieving wage equity: a job evaluation and classification study to be completed next February. But, whatever the outcome, the Long Island pay equity bandwagon rolls on.

PUB-DATE: November 12, 1989

SECTION: Section 12LI; Page 27, Column 2; Long Island Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 669 words

HEADLINE: School Economies Are Essential

 BODY:
Reading the three letters flailing Mr. Gerber for daring to suggest that economies can be made in school budgets [''Trim the Fat From High Cost of Education,'' Sept. 24] without impacting adversely on the education of children makes me despair of finding a basis for dialogue between the education establishments and the people of their communities. I define the establishment as school board, administration, and PTA.
The letter from the teacher in New York City has no validity for us. We chose to live on Long Island specifically to avoid the conditions she faces every day. And, I might add, compared to her environment, teachers on the Island work in paradise. 
The arguments by the other two writers add nothing to what I am accustomed to hearing from the establishment in Hewlett-Woodmere, which has been, until recently, a sea of affluent tranquillity. I won't go into the details of why the climate changed, but early in the year the first cloud in this blue sky on the South Shore made its appearance when a $28 million bond issue to refurbish our five remaining schools was resoundingly defeated.
The shock waves from that defeat should have taught the establishment that its demands on the pocketbooks of even a comfortable enclave such as ours had exceeded reasonable limits. Should have, but didn't.
In May of this year they proposed a school budget in excess of $36 million, a budget they assured us was ''bare-boned.'' It was defeated. The identical budget was resubmitted in June, with the warning that defeat meant austerity and enumerating the dire consequences therefrom.
An even larger number of my townspeople voted no the second time, and we went on austerity. Miraculously, this bare-boned budget turned out to be not so bare-boned because they managed to cut over $700,000 of fat without doing harm either to themselves or the children. It passed on the third submission in August.
I cannot speak for any district but my own; however, there is a sameness to each. The population is getting older, and the taxes have become a burden to many of our senior citizens, single parent families and working parents. It isn't that we view excellence in education as less desirable, but we have become more aware with the passage of years that school bureaucracies, if not controlled and monitored, will do what all bureaucracies do: grow beyond the point of toleration.
I am well aware of state-mandated costs, of special education classes for the learning disabled, the physically handicapped, emotionally disturbed and mentally retarded. I am equally aware that most districts, mine included, pay 100 percent of the cost of medical and dental insurance for our teachers. I am aware that many districts have negotiated contracts with their teachers for the next three years totaling in excess of 25 percent. I am aware that many P.T.A.'s have been successful in lowering the requirements for bus transportation to district schools from the mandated two to three miles to as little as half to three-quarters of a mile.
I remember driving my and other children to school a scant seven years ago and thinking nothing of it. Were they the same age today, they would be bused. I am also aware that increasing class size from 17 to 20 or 22 will not matter one whit so far as education is concerned, but would eliminate some teaching positions. I know, too, that many schools have hired ''consultants,'' many of whom are retired teachers, whose duties and responsibilities are somewhat ambiguous.
The point is that unless we effect economies together, in our respective communities, as surely as night follows day, we will be at each other's throats year after budget year until one day many of our districts will take a giant step backward and find themselves operating under austerity for the foreseeable future. Should that come to pass, we need not look to the stars to fix the blame; the fault, fellow Islanders, will lie at our collective doorsteps.
 
CORINNE BONI
 Woodmere

PUB-DATE: November 12, 1989

LENGTH: 1233 words

HEADLINE: For Florio, Fiscal Issues Top Agenda

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
GOVERNOR-ELECT James J. Florio will not have much time to savor his victory on Tuesday. Just ahead is the transition period when he said he hoped to begin his promised audit of state spending.
New Jersey's fiscal health holds the key to the success of the Florio administration, especially in its early months when campaign promises are fresh in voters' minds and expectations are at their highest.
Mr. Florio's victory was so strong, nearly 2 to 1 over Representative Jim Courter, the Republican, that it helped some Democrats who were locked in close Assembly contests to win, and returned control of the Assembly to the Democrats, who had held it for 16 years before Gov. Thomas H. Kean's landslide re-election victory four years ago.
 
Bright Spot for G.O.P.
The one bright spot in Tuesday's balloting for Republicans was the election of Assemblyman Joseph A. Palaia to the State Senate in the 11th District in Monmouth County. The seat had been held by Frank Pallone Jr., a Democrat, until he was elected to Congress to fill a vacancy caused by the death of Representative James J. Howard. 
John D'Amico, a Democrat, was appointed to fill Mr. Pallone's seat pending Tuesday's special election. The Republican victory reduces the Democratic majority in the Senate to 23 to 17 but does not change control.
On election night, Mr. D'Amico was being mentioned as a possible candidate for appointment as state transportation commissioner.
Democrats now hold the governorship and control both the Senate and Assembly and will be under pressure to solve some lingering problems, notably high automobile insurance costs, in the next two years before the 1991 legislative races, when both houses will be up for election.
 
No Quick Fixes Likely
Promises to deal with insurance costs are usually couched in broad terms - roll back rates, eliminate the state's deficit-ridden Joint Underwriting Association or limit a motorist's right to sue - but the problem is complicated and not susceptible to quick fixes.
And the Republican minorities in both houses are not expected to jump at helping the majority party look good before the next election.
Mr. Florio also faces some problems that did not arise in the campaign, although one could be a blessing in disguise.
''There are a lot of expectations in the inner cities,'' said Richard Roper, director of the Council on New Jersey Affairs at Princeton University. ''Urban redevelopment is on the minds of mayors like Sharpe James of Newark and Randy Primus in Camden, and while it wasn't talked about in the campaign, the mayors expect Florio to focus attention on the problem.
''Growth management is another real challenge facing the state and Florio supported the steps already taken, with modifications, while Governor Kean's support has been timid and he came at it with a suburban prospective.''
''A real challenge is urban education,'' Mr. Roper said. ''Experts say the state and the nation are not doing enough to tap the potential of children in the inner cities, and without some real effort the situation will continue to deteriorate.''
Alan Rosenthal, director of the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University, said he did not expect Mr. Florio's promised audit to yield any major economies.
''Kean has taken everything there is to take, and all Florio may find is a few bucks to make it look like something,'' he said.
Unless the economy turns around dramatically and the state's major taxes begin to produce the kinds of revenue needed to support new initiatives, Mr. Florio may have to seriously consider raising taxes early in his administration, Mr. Rosenthal said.
The state's looming budget problems began coming to light late last year when collections of some major taxes - principally the state sales tax and corporate taxes - failed to keep pace with projections. The gap between expectations and projected collections grew from slightly more than $150 million to more than $250 million on an annual basis.
But with the state originally expecting to end the fiscal year last June 30 with more than $500 million in unexpended funds, the drop posed no immediate problems. It merely reduced the amount of money on hand with which to begin the current fiscal year.
 
Quarterly Monitoring
The trend may really begin to hurt if it continues next spring. Mr. Kean has said that tax collections, which are monitored quarterly, could pick up by then. A couple of weeks before the election, he also announced that the state had found more than $100 million in unexpended funds from the previous budget that could help weather the period of sluggish tax collections.
If the economy continues to soften, it may be next to impossible to get any tax changes through the Legislature two years from now, when all 120 legislative seats will be on the ballot. After that, Mr. Florio will have to guage what effect a tax increase will have on his re-election chances in 1993.
Something that could take the decision out of Mr. Florio's hands is the latest challenge to New Jersey's system of financing public education, which has made its way to the State Supreme Court.
 
Reliance on Property Tax
In 1973, the Democratic-controlled Legislature and Brendan T. Byrne, then the Governor, enacted the state income tax after the court ruled that the state's reliance on local property taxes to finance public education discriminated against poorer urban school districts and was unconstitutional. The court ordered the schools closed, which forced the lawmakers to pass the income tax after several unsuccessful attempts.
The latest challenge, Abbott vs. Burke, makes the same argument. Despite annual increases in state school aid, poor urban districts that lack the tax base on which revenue is derived are still unable to provide the same level of educational opportunity found in more affluent suburban districts, critics assert. An administrative court judge has agreed; the state education commissioner has disagreed, and the matter is before the court.
If the court orders a dramatic increase in state aid to poor districts, it could force a decision on raising taxes that would get Mr. Florio off the hook and provide a reason that few could attack - financing public education.
 
Auto Insurance a Priority
The day after his election victory, Mr. Florio reiterated that solving the auto insurance problem would be an early priority of his administration, and he announced that Douglas Berman, a lawyer who had been his campaign manager, would serve as chairman of his transition team.
Steven P. Perskie, a former State Senator from Atlantic County who stepped down from his seat on the Superior Court to work in Mr. Florio's campaign, will be director of the transition staff.
Other members of Mr. Florio's campaign will now move to the transition effort. They include Brenda Bacon, a campaign adviser who will be Mr. Perskie's deputy director; Karen Kessler, campaign finance director, who will be personnel director, and Angelo Genova, who will serve as legal counsel, as he did for the campaign. Jon Shure, campaign press secretary, will be communications director.
Mr. Florio said he had talked to Mr. Kean, who told him he was impressed by the size of the Democrat's victory. ''And he promised the best, most orderly transition ever undertaken in the state,'' Mr. Florio said.
