HEADLINE: WESTCHESTER OPINION;
The Census: How a Head Count Grew and Grew

BYLINE: By Lincoln Diamant; Lincoln Diamant, who lives in Ossining, is the author of ''Chaining the Hudson: The Fight for the River in the American Revolution.''

 BODY:
THE first United States census was taken almost two centuries ago. It was designed as a simple head count to regularize the composition of the House of Representatives, with one seat for every 30,000 citizens. (Excluded were American Indians not paying taxes.) No one dreamed that by 1990 the tabulation would blossom into a vast statistical analysis, both reflecting and regulating much of our economic life.
That first census was ordained by Article I, Section 2, Paragraph 3 of the Constitution, which reads, in part: ''Representatives...shall be apportioned among the several States which may be included within this Union, according to their respective numbers...The actual enumeration shall be made within three years after the first meeting of the Congress of the United States, and within every subsequent term of 10 years...'' 
Until the results of that first census were certified, 6 of the 65 seats in the first House were arbitrarily assigned to New York State.
The ''first meeting of the Congress'' that was mentioned in the Constitutional mandate took place in New York City, then the nation's capital, on March, 4, 1789. More or less on schedule, Congress implemented the census procedures two years later.
In less than six months, local governments in 14 states (Vermont had just joined the Union) finished their head count. In New York State, the census takers, led by William S. Smith, completed their job early, on July 26, 1791.
The totals, including the Westchester County figures, were forwarded to Philadelphia, the new capital of the United States, where they were compiled and certified by George Washington's Secretary of State, Thomas Jefferson. He transmitted them to Congress on Oct. 24, 1791.
The pen-and-ink tabulations were quickly set into type by Joseph Gales, an enterprising Philadelphia printer, in his little 56-page book, ''Return of the Whole Number of Persons With the Several Districts of the United States, etc.'' It became a best seller. The statistics were even reprinted in England, where the British may have been curious - or skeptical - about this new American procedure of apportioning at least half the Federal legislative seats by a head count.
The totals for Westchester County demonstrate the vast changes that have taken place since those first census takers broke down the country's population into five simple categories:
* Free white males 16 years old and older - militia age (5,939 was the total for the county).
* Free white males younger than 16 (5,330).
* All free white women of any age (10,958)
* ''All other free persons,'' an indiscriminate group that in 1790 numbered less than 2 percent of Westchester's 24,000 inhabitants (357)
* Slaves, who were still 6 percent of the county's total population (1,419). Slavery was not completely abolished in New York State until July 4, 1827.
Today, four of the statistics from the first census are of particular interest:
* In 1790, 7 percent of the state's total population lived in Westchester County; in 1980, it was 5 percent.
* Males and females showed the traditional almost-even division - 51 percent to 49 percent (that holds today).
* More than 47 percent of all the males were boys younger than 16.
* The county held 1,419 African-American slaves. (They were counted in Philadelphia as only 851, under the ''three-fifths'' clause of the Constitution. That clause was a compromise - affecting the representation count - between the Northern and Southern states that endured until the Civil War.
Population density for the county's 438 square miles has risen from about 55 people a square mile in 1790 to about 2,000 today. In the 1980 census, Westchester's total head count was 866,599. That is an increase of 3,500 percent over the 190-year period.
In the first census, almost all the inhabitants of Westchester were farmers; today the Bureau of the Census counts 95 percent of Westchester's citizens as living in ''urbanized areas.'' Median family income in 1980 was $27,278, with 6 percent of the population beneath the poverty level. And Westchester citizens are generally well-educated: 75 percent are high school graduates and 28 percent went to college.
Today's black population is 12 percent of the county's total, and 55 percent of all blacks are female, compared with 53 percent of all whites. The first census also ignored gender differences among all nonwhites.
The five headings of 1790 have evolved into almost 40 different statistical categories, including ancestry, marital history, fertility, language spoken at home, travel time to work, means of transportation, poverty status and characteristics of people 60 years and over.
The preservation of confidentiality is essential to any good census and the Bureau of the Census does not ''disclose information about specific individuals.'' In a few parts of the United States, in fact, it even ''suppresses census data on characteristics based on a small number of persons and/or housing units.'' The census privacy mandated by law is respected.
Within such protective guidelines, the 20th census of the United States - the 1990 Census - will soon be counting heads, to eventually tell the citizens of Westchester County exactly who we are and what we do.

HEADLINE: Campus Life;
Students Go for Pop Music, Pop Novels, Pop Tarts

 BODY:
What do Madonna, Tom Clancy, the Macintosh computer and Pop Tarts have in common? All are hot items on campuses these days, interviews with 300 students at 20 colleges and universities indicate.
Campus bookstores have been flooded with requests for books based on popular comic strips, including ''The Calvin and Hobbes Lazy Sunday Book,'' by Bill Watterson, Gary Larson's ''Pre-History of the Far Side'' and ''The Night of the Mary Kay Commandos'' by Berke Breathed, creator of ''Bloom County.''
Also selling well are the novels of Mr. Clancy, Stephen King and Tom Wolfe, all of whom have been at the top of bestseller lists with their novels ''Clear and Present Danger,'' ''The Dark Half'' and ''The Bonfire of the Vanities,'' respectively.
College bookstores are doing a brisk business in word processors and computers, especially those of the Macintosh variety. The Vassar Bookstore has sold 746 Apple Macintoshes since 1983, including 150 this year. I.B.M. personal computers and Smith-Corona word processors are top sellers, as are Zenith laptop computers, which students can fold up and take to the library or away on weekends. 
 
Fast-Selling Boxer Shorts
''Without my computer, I think, I'd be dead,'' said Sarah Doll, a senior at Vassar who is from Shaker Heights, Ohio.
Sweatshirts and pants with the school's logo set the fashion pace, as do boxer shorts (worn by both men and women).
''They're popular because you can walk around school in your underwear, and people won't look at you in a funny way,'' said Richard Crisler, a 1988 Duke University graduate, whose company, Yo Boxers, based in Durham, N.C., has sold 35,000 oxford-cloth boxers on college campuses since May 1988.
Shop managers report that during exam season, students buy snack foods and eccentric knickknacks to break the tension of nonstop studying. ''Survival foods'' like Pop Tarts, Pepperidge Farm cookies, Cup O'Noodles and diet soft drinks lead the shopping list, along with yo-yos, Nerf footballs and ''jaw breaker'' chewing gum. The campus stores at Duke sell 14,000 boxes of Pop Tarts each year to the 5,781 undergraduates, said Thomas Craig, manager of West Campus Stores.
At Georgetown University in Washington, coloring books, Mr. Potato Head toys and chewing gum that turns your teeth black are big sellers, said Sandy Manus, manager of The Corp, a student-run store. ''We sell lots of spontaneous items that people like to buy when they're feeling kind of silly,'' she said.
 
Big Car on Campus
The ''Goosh,'' a little ball composed of cut rubber bands, is a big item at the State University of New York at Buffalo. Jared Kurtzburg, a senior from East Northport, L.I., dubbed the novelty ''the yo-yo of the 90's.''
Clerks at campus stores report that Rolling Stone, Sports Illustrated, Time, Cosmopolitan and Glamour are the fastest-selling magazines.
Given the strict parking regulations and limited parking space at many schools, ''the popular car on campus belongs to someone else, so you don't have to worry about parking it or putting gas in it,'' said Jami Rhodes, a junior at Georgetown.
But if most students had their way, they would own Japanese cars like the Honda Prelude, Toyota Cressida, Acura Integra and Nissan Sentra, which they praised for low fuel and maintenance costs.
''They hardly ever need service,'' said Irene Anthony, a senior at California State University at Los Angeles. ''That's a big consideration if you're a college student with very little money.''
Among domestic automobiles, four-wheel-drive vehicles like Jeeps, Chevrolet Blazers and Ford Broncos are the hot wheels on campuses this fall, as are Mustang convertibles.
 
Many Business Majors
The cost of tuition often determines the types of cars gracing the campus parking lots. At Tulane University, where tuition, room and board total $19,200 a year, BMW's and Hondas glisten in the parking lot. At Ohio State, where out-of-state tuition, room and board total $5,628, small, used domestic models proliferate.
''You don't want to have a car that's new because it gets beaten up at school,'' said Andrew Poplos, an Ohio State junior from Westerville, Ohio, whose windshield was smashed recently after a raucous reveler tossed a beer bottle off a balcony. ''You just feel safer driving something you don't have to worry about.''
What's hot and what's not extend to academic concerns as well. Business, for example, seems to be the most frequently chosen concentration.
''It's pure and simple: money and power,'' said Nicholas Soulas, a senior majoring in business at Ohio State. ''Business seems to be the easiest way to make money, lots of money, and that's been the motto of the 80's.''
At the University of California at Berkeley, 2,145 students signed up for Introduction to Economics during the 1988-89 academic year, and some college bookstores are reporting heavy sales of Donald Trump's book ''The Art of the Deal.''
 
Choirs and Instrumental Groups
The classes filled to overflowing this fall range from the offbeat to the practical. At California State at Los Angeles, jazz dance and scuba diving are popular electives, and at Wisconsin, African storytelling draws 600 students each term. One of the more popular offerings at Colorado is a general physics course taught by Prof. John Taylor, who demonstrates basic principles of physics by lying on a bed of nails and walking over hot coals.
But at Cornell, where pre-med is especially popular, 2,000 students enrolled this fall in Introduction to Psychology.
Among extracurricular activities, singing in choirs and playing in instrumental groups are in style on many campuses. At the University of Miami, 15 percent of undergraduates belong to one of the 75 performing jazz and classical ensembles.
''Students like to hear fellow students perform,'' said Constance Lackey, a senior who serves on the Student Programming Council Board. ''Students here love music, and about any kind of performer will get an audience.''
Students' musical tastes are eclectic. While many like the pop sounds of Paula Abdul and Madonna, others prefer the rock of the Rolling Stones, Pink Floyd and the Grateful Dead. Albums from newer bands like U2, REM, the B-52's, 10,000 Maniacs and Fine Young Cannibals are especially in demand, store managers said.
Many students, like Peter Barreras, a senior at Wisconsin, prefer rap music. ''It's the cutting edge of music,'' he said. ''A lot of other music genres have stagnated.''
 
Pursuit of Exercise
Jack Campbell, owner of Poindexter Records in Durham, N.C., agrees. ''Nothing is particularly in, and nothing is particularly out,'' he said. ''The late 80's will be remembered as a time when there was no clear musical trend.''
Exercise, like working hard and eating well, is still a priority for students. Activities like aerobics, tennis and bicycling are favored by most students.
Fat-tired mountain bikes have become a staple on many campuses. ''Mountain bikes are the four-wheel-drive vehicles of the cycling world,'' said William Karpovich, a junior at Duke from Baltimore.
Wei-Ling Huber, a junior at Wisconsin from Franklin, Ind., said the $500 she spent on a bike and a lock was more than worth it. ''I figured that two years of bus passes would cost more than my bike did,'' Ms. Huber said. ''Also, it's really cool looking.''
Because most colleges and universities include the use of weight rooms, swimming pools and tennis courts in the cost of tuition, few students subscribe to athletic clubs or buy exercise equipment.
But some students, squeezed for time, cannot even use what the universities offer.
''Exercise?'' asked Andrew O'Brien of Yonkers, a senior at Georgetown. ''Are you kidding? College is no time to be fit.''

LENGTH: 1289 words

HEADLINE: Office Space Surplus Is Seen as Easing

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

 BODY:
DESPITE what many believe is the region's largest surplus of office space in a decade, Henry W. Fries, the new president of the Westchester County Board of Realtors, said the vacancy rate in the county was no cause for alarm.
''At the beginning of 1988, vacancy rates in the county stood at 22 percent,'' said the trade association's new leader. ''Now it's 16 percent. And by next summer, I predict, it will be even lower as current space is absorbed. Downtown White Plains already has one of the lowest vacancy rates in the nation; somewhere between 8 and 9 percent.''
There has been almost no new office construction in the county in the last year, Mr. Fries pointed out. ''The vacant space is being more easily absorbed because only 550,000 to 750,000 square feet of new space, which is a very small amount, came on stream last year.'' 
Also, he continued, there has been a renewed interest among companies in relocating to Westchester. ''Japanese tenants, in partcular, favor Westchester,'' he said. ''They like the tranquillity of the county, and the fairly easy commuting.''
 
Eyes on Japanese Tenants
Mr. Fries, who is the vice president of the commercial/investment and land division of Houlihan Lawrence in White Plains, said competition for Japanese tenants was so intense that his firm had a realtor representative in Tokyo to scout for prospective customers.
''Japanese clients will pay top dollar for office space and properties,'' he explained. ''For example, when Daiichi Financial Corporation of Tokyo wanted the Lakeover Country Club in Bedford, it paid $24.9 million for it. But real estate in the U.S. is a bargain compared to prices in Japan. We have several Japanese clients who are looking for properties; especially golf clubs.''
Recently, Japanese clients have shown a strong interest in acquiring school properties, Mr. Fries added.
''Ten years ago, when we were begging our customers to buy schools, we couldn't give them away,'' he said. ''Now that we have clients like Okanura Seminars looking for sites for Japanese schools in the Westchester area, old schools are scarce. Many of them have been torn down; others have been converted into residential condominiums.''
 
A Pharmacist in Real Estate
Mr. Fries, a licensed pharmacist, said he first became involved with commercial real estate when he owned a pharmacy in Goldens Bridge.
''At the time I was president of a civic organization, the Goldens Bridge Improvement Committee,'' he said. ''We embarked on what was surely the smallest urban-renewal project in the country, the Goldens Bridge Shopping Center. We had 25 shareholders from the community. Real estate, I found, was very different from standing behind a counter all day dispensing medicines. It was exciting. I was 37 and I decided, what the heck, I would change my career. I sold my pharmacy but I used my background to become a drugstore broker; and it was a fairly unusual specialty, so I managed to carve out a place for myself.''
Mr. Fries then joined Frances Billingsley Realtors of Katonah and opened the firm's first commercial division.
''In 1983 I joined Houlihan, which has now become the largest firm in the county. We have 450 licensed sales agents.''
Real estate and construction make up the largest industry in Westchester, he said. ''The market is extremely competitive. A successful commercial broker has not only to know the product and the market but must also be able to act as the client's consultant, banker, accountant and lawyer when those skills are needed.''
 
Dealing With Clients Assessed
Yet dealing with commercial clients is easier than dealing with home buyers, in Mr. Fries's opinion. ''With commercial clients, it's business as usual in a financial sense. Commercial clients are objective, mainly concerned with theeconomic feasibility of a project. No one rents office space because the bathrooms are yellow. What clients are most interested in is getting the biggest bang for their buck. Because office rents in Westchester average $23 to $25 a square foot, as compared with $40 to $45 for similar space in Manhattan, we have an edge financially.''
According to Mr. Fries, the Westchester County Board of Realtors, with 4,000 members divided equally between residential brokers and commercial brokers, is the third largest board in the state and the 25th largest in the country.
''We have more corporate headquarters here in Westchester than anywhere else in the country,'' Mr. Fries said. ''Our members have been influential in putting together some very big deals. And as corporations enter, residential house sales follow.''
But Mr. Fries acknowledged that should the General Foods headquarters building in White Plains come on the block, ''the deal will be too big to stay in the county, or even in the country.''
''The building is not officially on the market, but the word is they'll be asking $125 million to $175 million,'' he said. ''A property that size will be offered to an international marketing firm. My guess is that it will probably be bought by a foreign or a multinational company that wants to make a statement in the United States - and buys a high-visibility building in order to do it.''
In neighboring Fairfield County, many signature buildings still stand vacant. Loss of corporate tenants through mergers, acquisitions and takeovers has left Fairfield County with the highest office-vacancy rate in the New York, Connecticut and New Jersey area - and one of the highest such rates in the country.
 
A Look at Fairfield
''Fairfield County is somewhat different from Westchester,'' Mr. Fries said. ''As office construction in Westchester slowed, the pace of construction in Fairfield led to an overabundance of space. Even without the loss of corporate tenants, there would have been a surplus.''
Mr. Fries said Westchester was in direct competition with Fairfield, with both counties seeking the same tenants, but added: ''My feeling is that Westchester won't lose out, because we are better situated to labor pools in the metro area. We now have as many people coming to work in the county as we have leaving the county every day.''
According to Martin S. Berger, president of Robert Martin Company in Elmsford, a major developer of office parks, commercial buildings and residential condominiums, the rest of this year and 1990 will be a challenging period for realtors and developers. The period will be marked by ''a sharp reduction in the number of players in the marketplace,'' Mr. Berger said.
''In Westchester it will be a period of absorption, and in time we will see much of the space now vacant in Fairfield County also absorbed,'' Mr. Berger said. ''With fewer construction starts, there'll be less space coming on the market and vacant space in Westchester will get back to the normal ratio.'' Mr. Berger said he believes the corporate migration from Manhattan will be accelerated in 1990 as businesses continue to flee from such urban problems as crime, drug abuse and high taxes.
 
Employee Housing a Big Factor
Office construction in the 1990's, Mr. Berger said, will be characterized by mixed-use development projects that contain offices, residential units and retail shops.
''The lack of affordable housing for employees is still the big one in Westchester,'' he said, discussing problems. ''Judging from the success we've had with our project - the Seasons, a 312-unit condominium recently completed in downtown White Plains - the pent-up demand is still tremendous.''
The one-bedroom apartments in the Seasons, with an on-premise health club, are priced at $150,000. Mr. Berger said 120 of the units had been sold since they were put on the market in June.

HEADLINE: Builders Hit Hard by the Housing Downturn

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
JACK R. KALMAR of Bridgeport has been in construction for 25 years, but in 1987 he decided to phase out his home-building business.
''I've been in it a long time, and I'd like to think I know when to pull in my horns,'' Mr. Kalmar said. ''A recession is like a hurricane. When it has been a few years since you last had one, you know you're due.''
There is ample evidence that Mr. Kalmar's decision was wise. In the last two years the housing market in Connecticut has declined so precipitously that builders are going bankrupt, tradespeople are lowering their hourly rates, and houses are sitting unsold or changing owners through distress sales. 
And some builders say there may never be a return to the boom years of 1983 to 1988, when housing starts in the state peaked at nearly 30,000 units a year.
 
The Boom Years
''I don't think it'll ever come back to that level,'' said Richard W. Davis, the vice president of the Connecticut Home Builders Association. ''That was too much. I don't think I've ever seen such a period of sustained growth.''
''I think,'' Mr. Davis continued, ''that the labor force and the demographics of Connecticut will support production of 18,000 or 19,000 units a year, and that's the gap we're going to have to try to close, realistically.''
But this year, house builders in Connecticut will not approach 18,000 units.
A recent report by the State Department of Housing on the first nine months of the year showed 9,245 housing starts through the end of September - down 38.4 percent from the same period in 1988, the worst year since the housing recession of 1981 and 1982.
Every county has been affected, from Hartford County, which reported a decline of 16 percent, to New London County, which registered a drop of more than 61 percent.
Housing starts in Fairfield County dropped 47 percent; in Litchfield County, 44 percent; Middlesex County, 55 percent; New Haven County, 34 percent; Tolland County, 59 percent, and Windham County, 40 percent.
''We've seen a lot of layoffs,'' Mr. Davis said, adding that from now until Thanksgiving would be a critical period for the housing industry.
Builders, he said, are being forced to sell new homes at bargain prices or lose them to banks because they are unable to make their construction loan payments.
For example, Mr. Davis said, a builder might have constructed a house early this year at a cost of $150,000, and put it on the market for $180,000. But since then, the builder's interest payments might have added $15,000 to his costs. Therefore, he may feel he has to accept $165,000 now and pass up the opportunity to make a profit, rather than risk being unable to sell the house and make back his original investment. ''The simple explanation is, 'Time is money,' '' Mr. Davis said. Steven E. Martinek of Fairfield Homes, which manufactures building panels that can be put up and assembled into a house, said that a few years ago the factory was running two and a half shifts, with some workers putting in 50- and 60-hour weeks.
Now, there is no overtime; there is only one shift, and a couple of months ago he reduced his work force from 34 people to 24.
''I don't think I've seen things this bad in 15 years,'' Mr. Martinek said. ''We're averaging a couple of houses a week right now, but at full production we could ship five or six.''
Steven O. McGuire worked as a builder before he became a banker two years ago. As a ''work-out specialist'' for NESB Corporation, a bank holding company in south central and eastern Connecticut, Mr. McGuire helps builders who have projects on the verge of bankruptcy to determine the lowest possible selling price that would enable them to make a profit. He said that most builders he deals with have cut prices 20 to 30 percent.
''That in effect wipes out all their equity,'' Mr. McGuire said. ''But that's the discount that's necessary.'' The reduced profits have worked their way along the line, he said, so that carpenters who made $18 an hour two years ago now scramble for jobs at $8.50. He said he knew of three builders who went bankrupt in the last week of October alone.
Frank M. Rizzitelli, an owner of Rizzitelli Construction Company in Bridgeport, said that the unscrupulous builder could take advantage of laborers right now.
''I've had guys who've said they'd give me a week's work for nothing if I'd just hire them after that,'' Mr. Rizzitelli said. ''I wouldn't do that to anyone, but that's how desperate these guys have become.''
Mr. Rizzitelli said that he was building and renovating some commercial properties, but that he would not build any houses this year. Last year he built 30 units.
Builders who have stayed in housing have adopted different strategies. Mr. Kalmar, for example, now only frames houses as a subcontractor. Since that work is completed very early in a construction project, he usually gets paid.
''If a builder is going to run out of money, it's usually after the framer is paid,'' Mr. Kalmar said.
Mr. Rizzitelli said most builders have stopped putting up speculation houses, those built not for a specific buyer, but to sell on the open market.
''There are still some companies building for the people in the higher- income brackets,'' he said. ''But to build a house in the hopes someone will buy it, I think those days are gone.''
Mr. McGuire said that most of the builders he deals with give up and let the banks foreclose on homes and projects that have not sold in many months.
''By the time I get them, they've pretty much concluded that they're going to have to walk away from it,'' he said. Since banks typically finance 80 percent of a project's worth, if that worth drops 20 percent there is nothing left for the builder and no incentive for him to struggle to keep the property.
 
Home Equity Loans Cited
Mr. Davis said that the home-equity loan is one factor likely to delay the recovery of the market in new housing. When housing prices were escalating dramatically, banks encouraged peopleto borrow on their equity, which had in the past provided the money that people used to trade up to newer, more expensive houses. But instead of trading up, they are renovating their older residences.
Another factor impeding the recovery is an oversupply of expensive condominium units. So serious is the problem that some builders have begun auctioning condominium units, which was unheard of in Connecticut real estate until a few years ago.
''We went through a time when even if you didn't know anything about building, if you had some money you could buy some property, put up a house and make some money,'' Mr. Rizzitelli said. ''Now, you've got to really know the business if you're going to stay in business.''
Although Mr. Davis and other builders not believe the market will rebound to its highs of 1986 and 1987, Mr. Davis said he is not disappointed.
''Having to produce the number of houses that we did in the time that we had was stretching,'' he said. ''I don't think anyone was comfortable with that pace.''

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: November 12, 1989

SECTION: Section 4; Page 23, Column 2; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 1205 words

HEADLINE: VOICES OF THE NEW GENERATION;
Wrong on the Wall, and Most Else

BYLINE: By Eric Alterman; Eric Alterman, a senior fellow of the World Policy Institute, is writing a book about Washington pundits.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The Soviet Union embarks on a second revolution and reaches out for peace with the West; East Europeans demand freedom and democracy; East Germans tear down the Berlin Wall and flee their country. These and other amazing changes erupt in world politics, and not one of America's foreign policy gurus comes within a country mile of predicting them. In fact, most foreign policy elites have spent the last few years explaining them away and counseling the West to do nothing. It has been a long and rocky road for America's foreign policy elite since Mr. Gorbachev came to power in March 1985. Not since Copernicus, perhaps, have so many been so wrong so frequently with so little humility.
At first, our experts were telling us that Mr. Gorbachev would be no improvement on his predecessors. ''He has no new ideas,'' assured Carnegie Endowment Sovietologist Dimitri Simes when Mr. Gorbachev was named General Secretary. ''In many respects, more dangerous,'' warned Zbigniew Brzezinski. It will be ''two to four years'' before he can consolidate his power, noted Henry Kissinger. The message: Watch and wait. 
When Mr. Gorbachev began to unveil his program of radical reform, the music began to perk up a bit, but the song remained the same. Mr. Gorbachev then became a clever, almost Mephistophelean manipulator. While blinding us with perestroika, insisted Mr. Brzezinski, the Soviets were actually pursuing peredyshka - a breathing spell. Richard Nixon rehabilitated himself in the establishment's eyes with the view that ''under Gorbachev, the Soviet Union's foreign policy . . . has been more aggressive, not less.''
In Eastern Europe, we were told to expect more of the same. The respected Sovietologist Seweryn Bialer of Columbia University wrote in 1986 that the ''main thrust of Gorbachev's Eastern European policy is to strengthen the Soviet hold on its empire and to control the satellite parties more tightly.'' As late as February 1988, Mr. Bialer was still insisting that ''the Soviet leadership . . . has no intention of transforming the major national institutions.''
Once the Mr. Gorbachev's seriousness became undeniable, this chorus of disapproval grew cacaphonous. ''Gorby'' may be worthy of our sympathy, but he was likely to be overthrown by hardliners. The Harvard Sovietologist and frequently televised expert Marshall Goldman was remarkably consistent in predicting Mr. Gorbachev's imminent demise.
When maverick Moscow chieftain Boris Yeltsin was exiled to early (and short-lived) retirement in November 1987, Mr. Goldman told readers of this page that ''the question now is whether Mr. Gorbachev himself can avoid a similar fate.'' Less than a year later, when Mr. Yeltsin's arch-enemy, Yigor Ligachev, met a similar fate, Mr. Goldman returned to the Op-Ed page with exactly the same prognosis: Mr. Gorbachev acted in the face of ''an attempted coup,'' he explained, and might not last more than another six months.
As Poland sped toward democracy earlier this year, the same hypercaution reared its head. In February 1989, Mr. Brzezinski said that further events in Poland could spark a Soviet military takeover in Moscow. In fact, when the crunch finally came between Solidarity and the Communists over the composition of the new government, Mr. Gorbachev - still in power - sided with the union.
Recently, Mr. Gorbachev declared that the Soviet Union has ''no moral or political right'' to interfere in Eastern Europe. Two days earlier, Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze admitted that the invasion of Afghanistan and the controversial radar station at Krasnoyarsk constituted ''a serious violation'' of ''proper behavior'' and international law. As voluntary superpower confessions go, these remarks comprise a seismic event of the order of the California earthquake. What sayeth of the U.S. foreign policy establishment?
''This isn't an opportunity for us,'' Richard Perle said on the MacNeil-Lehrer Newshour. ''Not every Soviet proposal needs to be answered,'' echoed expert Stephan Sestanovich on the same program. Again, just watch and wait.
To be sure, there have been exceptions. The initial response of the Bush Administration was justly criticized as timid by many establishmentarians and a few have gone so far as to declare the cold war over. Secretary of State James Baker stepped up his praise of Soviet reforms and the upcoming summit meeting could lead to a belated awakening.
But as of yet no American of political consequence has suggested that the U.S. match the Soviet Union's military cutbacks with unilateral reductions. Nor have any of the establishment's members taken up Soviet offers of cooperation in environmental cleanup, international peace keeping or third world debt. The reappearance of the ''German problem'' has taken our experts almost completely by surprise. America watches from the sidelines as the postwar European order is reshaped and redefined.
Obstacles to change within the foreign policy establishment are several. First, some of its most prominent members, most notably Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger, seem sincerely to prefer the ''remarkably stable and predictable'' atmosphere of the cold war to the uncertainty of a thaw. (When Mr. Gorbachev proposed visionary arms cuts at the United Nations last December, Mr. Eagleburger complained about the timing of the speech.) Another problem arises with the inability of establishment luminaries to examine the assumptions that have shaped their thinking for 40 years. This isn't surprising given the limited contacts they have with the grassroots movements that are inspiring change in the East. As Henry Kissinger admitted at the time of Mr. Gorbachev's ascension, ''nobody'' in U.S. foreign policy circles ''really knows what the younger generation thinks in the Soviet Union. We don't have any contact with them.''
Meanwhile, those who have developed these contacts are almost universally scorned or ignored by the powers that be. Jerry Hough of Duke University predicted the Soviet reform movement in the 1970's. The British writer Timothy Garton Ash has documented grassroots politics in Eastern Europe for The New York Review of Books since 1984. Groups like the Campaign for Peace and Democracy/East and West in New York have worked with activists in five Eastern bloc countries for nearly a decade. Even before Mr. Gorbachev, they reported that pressure for democratic change was building from below.
Throughout Europe, governments, businesses and citizens' groups are forging a new order. Yet, virtually alone within the spendid isolation of the Metroliner corridor, the U.S. foreign policy elite is mired in its stagnant, Brezhnevite mindset.
The current establishment line on Mr. Gorbachev is that while he will survive Kremlin challenges, national animosities and economic inefficiencies will probably do him in. The prescription: Our sincere best wishes, but of course, we must be prudent and cautious. No change in policy.
The establishment has been singing this do-nothing tune for nearly five years now. The question Americans should ask as they watch the walls of arrogance reduced to dust in Eastern Europe: How long can we afford to keep listening?

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: November 12, 1989

SECTION: Section 7; Page 12, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1186 words

HEADLINE: CHARITY THAT STRANGLES THE POOR

BYLINE: By THURSTON CLARKE; Thurston Clarke is the author of ''Last Caravan,'' about famine in Africa, and ''Equator.''

 BODY:

LORDS OF POVERTY
The Power, Prestige, and Corruption of the International Aid Business.
By Graham Hancock.
234 pp. New York:
The Atlantic Monthly Press. $17.95.
Here is how Graham Hancock describes the villains of ''Lords of Poverty.'' They belong to a ''notorious club of parasites and hangers-on'' that has set ''record-breaking standards . . . in self-serving behaviour, arrogance, paternalism, moral cowardice and mendacity.'' They are ''unsavoury, greedy, stupid and dangerous,'' not to mention ''maladjusted, inadequate [and] incompetent.'' They work for organizations whose ''ethics are really very little different from those of a drug pusher,'' organizations that have ''condoned - and in some cases facilitated - the most consistent and grievous abuses of human rights that have occurred anywhere in the world since the dark ages.'' 
Mr. Hancock is not talking about Nazi war criminals, toxic waste dumpers or crooked investment bankers. He is talking about everyone, from top officials to field workers, employed by the multinational relief and development agencies - such as the World Bank, UNICEF, UNESCO, the United Nations Development Organization, the Food and Agriculture Organization (F.A.O.) of the United Nations, the European Development Fund of the European Economic Community - and by the bilateral agencies of the United States (A.I.D.), Britain, Japan and just about any rich country you care to name. In other words, he is talking about some of our century's most sacred cows, about organizations associated with words such as ''sacrifice,'' ''humanitarian'' and ''generosity'' (although Mr. Hancock would say this is because these are precisely the words their public relations departments use in their self-congratulatory campaigns).
Can these accusations be true? Does Mr. Hancock really mean that the Halloween pennies school children collect for UNICEF, and those sacks of emergency American grain that spill from the bellies of Air Force transports onto the tarmac of third world countries like litters of kittens, that the mighty World Bank dams, the countless A.I.D.-financed village water pumps and, in fact, just about all foreign aid is evil, and should immediately be stopped? Yes, he means exactly that. ''Aid is not bad, however, because it is sometimes misused, corrupt, or crass,'' he says; ''rather, it is inherently bad, bad to the bone, and utterly beyond reform. As a welfare dole to buy the repulsive loyalty of whining, idle and malevolent governments, or as a hidden, inefficient and inadequately regulated subsidy for Western business, it is possibly the most formidable obstacle to the productive endeavours of the poor.''
Mr. Hancock believes foreign aid is ''nothing more than a transaction between bureaucrats and autocrats,'' enriching only the international civil servants who administer it and the ruling classes of the third world countries - ''gangsters and psychotics'' - who steal or misuse it. The ''over-compensated'' civil servants, he insists, enjoy a higher standard of living than they could aspire to in their own countries, and in third world nations they fill jobs that would otherwise go to locals, while back at headquarters they hardly work at all. Their achievements and performance are never subjected to the rigorous evaluation that is normal in private business, or even in other government agencies, and because their profession is ''humanitarian,'' they are never required to demonstrate their worth in quantitative ways - despite the fact that A.I.D., the United Nations agencies and others disperse funds that have been forcibly extracted by taxation instead of donation.
He reinforces these charges with the kind of United Nations horror stories that have become familiar reading. We learn that personnel and associated costs absorb 80 percent of the organization's total expenditures, that some time ago the president and executive board of UNESCO received reimbursements of $1,759,548 for one year's travel and lodging costs, that there are 750 bureaucrats on the staff of the F.A.O. in Rome whose pensionable remuneration ranges from $70,000 to $100,000 a year.
While Mr. Hancock provides considerable evidence that aid has enriched the bureaucrats who administer it and the companies who supply shoddy goods at inflated prices, along with prosperous third world traders and urban intermediaries, there is no evidence, he says, that the poor of the third world have benefited at all. For foreign aid's successes are lucky accidents, whereas its most grandiose projects either ''wreck the lives of the poor'' or leave them untouched. In this regard, he is right to point out that any foreign assistance - including emergency food aid - given to murderous, corrupt regimes can only have the unintended consequence of strengthening the regimes, enriching their ruling classes and increasing the suffering of their populations, in part by blunting the righteous anger that might otherwise overthrow such governments.
To support his assertions Mr. Hancock has assembled a compendium of foreign aid fiascos that he claims are the rule, not the exception. There are small-scale bunglings: food donated to Africa by the European Economic Community during 1988 that was found to be contaminated by radiation from the Chernobyl nuclear disaster; laxatives, anti-indigestion remedies, frostbite medicine, low-calorie soup, chocolate-flavored dietary drinks, and food so old that San Francisco zoo keepers had stopped feeding it to animals, all sent to alleviate starvation in tropical countries.
And there are large-scale disasters: the A.I.D. fish-farming project in Mali that produced fish at an actual cost of almost $2,000 a pound; the donor-financed dam in Guatemala that has led to a 70 percent rise in residential electricity prices; the Sudanese sugar refinery turning out sugar that is sold in Sudan at a significantly higher price than imported sugar; and the World Bank resettlement schemes in Brazil and Indonesia that have destroyed rain forests, obliterated tribal peoples and sometimes left migrants poorer than when they left home.
I cannot agree with Mr. Hancock's extreme condemnation of the development industry. I have seen A.I.D. projects in Africa that were clearly successful and beneficial to the local people, and I have met too many people in the industry who were not monsters of greed and careerism. Nonetheless, much of my experience in Africa and Asia confirms the essential truth of his charges. Mr. Hancock has chosen to levy these accusations in a prose style so shrill and venomous that if books had hands, this one would be reaching out to strangle the United Nations officials who will no doubt be reading it at their desks in brown paper wrappers. This style sometimes distracts from his arguments, but it does not disprove them. Beneath the jumped-up language is a deadly serious book about a desperately important subject, a book that, despite its exaggerations, succeeds in standing the myth of foreign aid on its head, and demands a serious reply from the development industry.

303 of 749 DOCUMENTS

Copyright 1989 The New York Times Company 
The New York Times

PUB-DATE: November 12, 1989

SECTION: Section 7; Page 22, Column 2; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1517 words

HEADLINE: A HOT STREAK FOR DEMOCRACY

BYLINE: By ROBERT N. BELLAH; Robert N. Bellah is the co-author, with Richard Madsen, William M. Sullivan, Ann Swidler and Steven Tipton, of ''Habits of the Heart.''

 BODY:

DEMOCRACY AND ITS CRITICS
By Robert A. Dahl.
397 pp. New Haven:
Yale University Press.
$29.95.
Robert A. Dahl's ''Democracy and Its Critics'' could not have come at a more opportune moment. Events in Moscow and Warsaw, as well as in Beijing, have kept the word ''democracy'' on our front pages for many months. In the flurry of discussion, reporters have frequently asked how well the Russians or the Poles or the Chinese really understand democracy. Most of these journalists - like most of the rest of us - have complacently assumed that the question does not apply to Americans: who, if not we, understands government by the people? Yet when the idea of a McDonald's in Red Square is taken as a token of the triumph of democracy in the Soviet Union, one might well ask if we are entirely clear on the concept.
What Mr. Dahl, Sterling Professor of Political Science Emeritus at Yale University, has done, in a magisterial work that sums up and goes beyond his many decades of distinguished publications, is clearly and reasonably to describe what democracy means, both historically and at present; why our own democracy is still deeply flawed; and how we could reform it so that it would accord more closely with its claims. ''Democracy and Its Critics'' is a work of extraordinary intelligence and, what is even rarer, a work of extraordinary wisdom. 
Mr. Dahl writes clearly and effectively, keeping technical jargon to a minimum, so that he is accessible to the educated lay reader. But this is not an easy book. He does not flinch from giving detailed philosophical arguments for democracy, for the chief alternatives to democracy - namely, anarchism and guardianship - and for the defense of democracy against these rivals. He gives careful consideration to such issues as who is to be included in a democratic association; the virtues and difficulties of majority rule; and whether minority domination is inevitable even in a democracy. On all these questions, the discussion is fresh and illuminating, the treatment of alternative views careful and respectful, the difficulties in his own views spelled out in detail. An attentive reader of this book will receive a real education in the meaning of democracy.
Still, the power of the book comes not only from Mr. Dahl's careful regard for the arguments but from the historical framework in which he places the development of the democratic process. He describes two great historical transformations: the birth of democratic city-states in ancient Greece and Rome, and the emergence in the 18th century of large-scale representative democracies, which became more numerous and successively more inclusive in the 19th and 20th centuries (even though they still remain a minority among existing nations).
Finally, he asks - and this, I think, is his most important contribution - whether we may not be on the threshold of a third democratic transformation, involving a significant increase in citizen participation in our economic and political life. His raising this prospect is particularly refreshing at a time when others can only lament the decline of voter participation and the cynical manipulation of our political campaigns. It is clear that Mr. Dahl thinks a third transformation, though not historically inevitable, is necessary if we are to continue the moral progress of our recent past, which has included the involvement of women and minorities in the political process. It is the book's aim to help us envision the possibility of this change.
The third transformation does not mean, on the analogy of the second, the rise of large-scale representative democratic entities at the supranational level. With the exception of the Western European community, Mr. Dahl does not foresee such entities emerging in the immediate future. International relations, he believes, can be rendered democratic to only a limited extent, and chiefly through the influence that democratic forces within nation-states can bring to bear on transnational institutions. Here he may underestimate the strength of international public opinion, influenced by transnational voluntary associations such as Amnesty International, but he is surely right to be modest in his expectations about global democracy at this point.
He argues, however, that even nations whose independence of action is quite circumscribed can have vigorous democratic institutions domestically. Some of the smaller European states, such as Denmark and the Netherlands, are examples. Furthermore, in his view, democratization is a process that can and ought to go on at many levels below that of the nation-state, in the regions and localities of countries.
Still, the chief challenges to the possibility of the third transformation come at the national level and have to do with remaining political inequalities that limit the degree of democracy. He sees three major forms of inequality at the present time: ''differences in resources and opportunities for employing violent coercion; in economic positions, resources, and opportunities; and in knowledge, information, and cognitive skills.''
In his discussion of violent coercion, Mr. Dahl shows how the development of military technology requiring the participation of large numbers of ordinary people has helped the growth of democracy. In ancient Greece, armed infantry replaced the chariot warfare of the nobility, and in early modern Europe, the use of large numbers of musket- and later rifle-bearing infantry broadened the ranks of the citizen-soldier. Conversely, he demonstrates how the monopolization of the means of violence by small elites has operated to inhibit democracy. He recognizes that the technology of modern warfare has moved in a direction that has historically been associated with antidemocratic tendencies, but he holds that political control of the military in modern democracies mitigates the dangers.
One might argue that the emergence of nuclear arms and the proliferation of high-technology weapons since World War II have created, certainly in the United States, a powerful sector of society largely invulnerable to democratic control. In this view, national defense in the nuclear age has become such a trump that it gives the President extraordinary powers not envisaged in the Constitution and virtually voids legislative control over the decision to go to war. If this argument has merit, a significant shift toward international disarmament may be a prerequisite for the third transformation. Unfortunately, Mr. Dahl does not give this perspective sufficient attention.
With respect to economic inequalities, Mr. Dahl has argued before, and incisively again here, that there is a great anomaly in our business sector: institutions like corporations, where most of us spend a significant portion of our lives, are governed by forms of guardianship shading toward despotism, yet the society as a whole is supposed to be democratic. He takes it as axiomatic that: ''In an advanced democratic country the economic order would be understood as instrumental not merely to the production and distribution of goods and services but to a much larger range of values, including democratic values. The economic order would be seen as intended to serve not merely consumers but human beings in all the activities to which an economic order may contribute.''
Since economic resources are so decisively related to the acquisition and utilization of political power, only the institutionalization of effective economic democracy will move us forward in this respect. For example, Mr. Dahl would encourage not only the participation of workers in decisions involving the production process, which is already occurring in a number of American companies, but also worker representation on corporate boards of directors. el3> Finally, Mr. Dahl argues that the third democratic transformation requires us to reduce existing inequalities with respect to knowledge, information and cognitive skills. The danger here comes from monopolization, not by business managers, but by intellectuals, particularly policy makers. Mr. Dahl does not believe, as some have argued, that intellectuals form a ''new class,'' with a common ideology and common interests. He argues that the profound cleavages and disagreements among them help to lessen any such danger. But he does believe that only an educated general public and a series of ''attentive publics'' concerned with particular policy spheres can genuinely democratize the operation of the modern bureaucratic state, preventing rule by experts with no claim to superior moral insight - indeed, whose insight may even be impaired by their excessive specialization.
In short, beneath all the moderation and devotion to intellectual clarity that are so evident in this book, there is the moving presence of a profound passion for democracy. For Mr. Dahl, this remains the essential vision ''in the search for a society in which people may live together in peace, respect each other's intrinsic equality, and jointly seek the best possible life.''

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: November 13, 1989

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 2; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1407 words

HEADLINE: Governing Long Island: A Jurisdictional Jumble

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 12

 BODY:
On Old Country Road, a busy four-lane thoroughfare in Nassau County, the speed limit westbound is 30 miles an hour, but the speed limit eastbound is 40. The reason says a lot about why many Long Islanders are challenging the way their local government operates.
Down the center of Old Country Road runs the boundary between Mineola and Garden City, and each village sets the speed limit on its side of the street.
''Sure, it's ridiculous, but no one wants to give up any of their domain,'' said Lieut. Edward Drummond, commander for traffic safety of the Nassau County police, who enforce both limits. 
In the fragmented world of local government on Long Island, two counties and nearly 800 towns, villages, school districts and special taxing entities vie in a jurisdictional jumble that often results in duplicated services and exasperating inefficiencies.
Stirrings to reorganize local governments are being felt throughout the New York metropolitan region. In Connecticut, where county governments were abolished nearly 30 years ago, growing unease over regional problems like traffic, solid-waste disposal and housing has spurred talk of creating an intermediate level of government to coordinate efforts between the state and its 169 municipalities.
Just seven states - California, Illinois, Kansas, Minnesota, Ohio, Pennsylvania and Texas - have a greater number of local governments than New York, according to the Census Bureau, and even fewer share New York's overlapping structure of villages existing within towns within counties. #95 Villages, 127 School Districts ''It's all very confusing to voters and even to the people in government,'' the chairman of the Westchester County Planning Board, William N. Cassella, said. ''When the system does not perform well, it's difficult for citizens to hold someone accountable.''
Nowhere is the confusion and frustration more acute than on Long Island, one of the most heavily governed suburban regions in the country, with 2 counties, 2 cities, 13 towns, 95 villages, 127 school districts and more than 500 special districts, most of which have taxing powers, for services from garbage collection to hydrant rentals.
For years, a robust economy on the island of about 2.8 million people supported the proliferating governments. In the spirit of home rule, villages and towns freely expanded services like youth programs and nutrition classes for the elderly that paralleled existing county programs. But with the economy slowing, residents are questioning the consequences of too much government.
Property taxes have soared, inciting a tax revolt that helped defeat two Suffolk County legislators in primary races and one more in Tuesday's general election.
 
Mix-ups and Turf Battles
''My property taxes have gone to $5,000 a year from $2,800 four years ago, but I don't see any difference in my services,'' said Paul Cerniglia, a fish and wildlife inspector in Lindenhurst, a Suffolk County village of 27,000 people.
Mr. Cerniglia has only to look down his driveway to Strong Avenue, a well-trafficked two-lane road, to see Long Island governments in action. Within five blocks, four highway departments - the state, the county, Babylon Township and Lindenhurst - sweep and plow the roads.
''Most people have no idea who does what,'' said Mary Anne Weber, a spokeswoman for Representative George J. Hochbrueckner, Democrat of Suffolk, whose Congressional office handles 2,000 complaints a year, mostly from constituents frustrated in finding help for local problems like garbage pickups and broken water mains.
With so many crossing jurisdictions, mix-ups are common and turf battles are frequent. The 605-acre campus of the State University at Old Westbury is carved into five police and fire districts. It is not unusual, university officials said, to have two or three departments respond to an accident; in rare cases, if one department thinks another is answering the call, no one responds. #4 Shot, 4 Police Forces After a sniper shot four people in the Riverhead area last December, officials from four police forces with jurisdiction - Southampton Town, East Hampton Town, Suffolk County and the state - issued conflicting information about the incidents and privately criticized one another for hindering the investigation.
The struggle between local control and broader regional agencies extends from environmental protection to education to the economy.
Suffolk has one water authority that serves 75 percent of the county's 1.4 million residents. Nassau has 41 suppliers, each with staff and consultants. ''By dividing everything up, there's no one with overall responsibility for the resource,'' said Sarah Meyland, a former director of the State Legislative Commission on Water Resource Needs of Long Island.
Two years ago, the State Environmental Conservation Department imposed pumping limits on Nassau suppliers to prevent the water table from sinking dangerously low. If Nassau had one large water authority to address such concerns, ''it may not have been necessary to impose the caps,'' said the the regional director of the department, Harold Berger.
 
'They're Overgoverned'
There are 56 school districts in Nassau and 71 in Suffolk, and studies have found that consolidation would cut costs, increase efficiency and broaden offerings.
Local interests and state financial-aid formulas that discourage mergers often combine to create maddening situations.
In Suffolk, the Mount Sinai District is building a $24 million high school to accommodate its growing enrollment. A neighboring district, Comsewogue, closed two elementary schools recently and faces steadily declining enrollment.
''Talk to anyone in business, anyone building or expanding, and there's no question they're overgoverned,'' said James L. Larocca, president of the Long Island Association, the largest business organization in the region. ''The simplest permit subjects you to a miasma of processes and procedures.''
 
Affordability and Taxes
Nancy Booker operates a small youth agency in Bay Shore that provides tutors, counseling and recreational services to 475 children and families in the Bay Shore School District. Each month, she compiles three service reports to the governments that finance the agency, the Town of Islip, Suffolk County and New York State.
''I end up explaining myself over and over,'' said Ms. Booker.
Per capita spending by local governments in Nassau and Suffolk is $2,645, according to the Census Bureau, compared with $1,536 in Fairfield County, Conn., and $1,525 in Bergen County, N.J. Most Long Islanders pay more than 7 percent of their household incomes to property taxes, nearly double the amount that residents in suburbs of Boston, Washington, Los Angeles and Dallas pay, according to a survey by Newsday, the Long Island newspaper.
''People here moved away from the city to foster a certain way of life,'' Steven Levy, a Suffolk County Legislator from Holbrook, said. ''All that is irrelevant if you can't afford to live here in the first place.''
 
'I'm Bitter We Had to Leave'
That is what happened to Vincent J. Ruisi, a retired clothing designer who left Westbury for Citrus County, Fla., 18 months ago.
''We couldn't afford the taxes anymore,'' said Mr. Ruisi, 77 years old, who now pays $175 a year in property taxes, compared with $3,200 a year on Long Island. ''I'm bitter we had to leave. We wanted to stay.''
Taxpayer groups are demanding that governments cut costs and maintain services. Many political leaders and scholars said that they doubted the entrenched bureaucracies would budge.
''Local governments jealously guard their jurisdictional powers,'' said Philip Y. Nicholson, a history professor at Nassau Community College who has studied suburban problems. ''They like to make contracts. They like to make jobs, and they like to hold the purse strings.''
Yet there are glimmers of hope. Six schools in eastern Suffolk, ranging in enrollments from 16 to 1,225, are discussing a merger. The Town of Babylon recently agreed to sweep 31.5 miles of Suffolk roads within its borders, saving the county $160,000 over five years. This year the Town of Huntington eliminated its Office of Consumer Protection because it duplicated efforts of a county agency.
''The solutions won't be massive or generic,'' Mr. Larocca said. ''They will be a series of base hits rather than a major home run.''

HEADLINE: CLAMOR IN THE EAST: CITY WITH A PAST;
The Old Berlin: A Culture of Spies and Symphonies

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WEST BERLIN, Nov. 12

 BODY:
There were moments this weekend that recalled the years before the wall when there was a lively mingling between the people of the two sides of this divided city, and even a breath of the era when Berlin was the imperial German capital.
As in the days of the Kaisers, hundreds of thousands of Berliners promenaded on a warm Sunday afternoon, sightseeing on the showy streets like the Kurfurstendamm in the West and Leipziger Strasse in the East.
Except this time the people themselves were the riveting sight - one people who had been torn asunder, together again in one city.
''I had to be here,'' said Jurgen Busing, a 40-year-old environmental scientist who flew in from Brussels for the weekend. ''It cost me 1,000 marks, but it is worth it. Everything happens only once.'' 
For an American journalist who worked in Berlin before and during the building of the wall in 1961, the contrasts and parallels are compelling.
 
Spies and Counterspies
In the years before the wall, Berlin pulsed with excitement and danger. Many countries maintained huge intelligence operations. Agents were kidnapped right and left. Before he died last year, John Peet, an English journalist who had sought asylum in the East, recalled being approached by a Soviet intelligence officer in the 1950's and asked to pose as a British officer in one such snatch operation in West Berlin. He refused.
Hermann Kant, an East Berlin novelist, remembers being approached for an espionage mission by a Soviet intelligence officer and a Polish intelligence officer on successive weekends. They left him alone after all three met by coincidence in a restaurant.
In the early 1960's, the C.I.A. station had more than 130 officers working in Berlin, and at one point it was conducting 40 separate covert operations against the East. In those days, North Koreans from Pyongyang and South Koreans from Seoul journeyed halfway around the world to meet in Berlin - the only place where that was possible then. So did North and South Vietnamese. The wall put an end to much of that.
 
A People Used to Sadness
Today, all the panoply of postwar division seemed to recede - the uniformed troops of the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France, with their air corridors, their bases and their special rights as occupying powers - leaving just the Berliners.
Still, the shock of the sudden change leaves many, especially in East Berlin, wondering how quickly this moment might pass.
A physician in his 60's grimly recalled the euphoria of June 17, 1953, when workers led a revolt in East Berlin that ended under the treads of Soviet tanks, of hopes engendered by John F. Kennedy's visit to West Berlin in 1963, of the slight easing of conditions that followed West Germany's recognition of East Germany in 1971.
''I'm waiting for the hammer,'' he said, using the German slang for a crackdown.
 
Then and Now, Money Talks
It is startling to discover that the total number of Berliners today is again what it was at the beginning of World War II - four million, of which 2.2 million are in the West and 1.8 million in the East -a result of new jobs and new housing on both sides. At one time, several decades ago, the total population had hovered around three million.
In the days before the building of the wall, 60,000 West Berliners worked in the East and 10,000 East Berliners worked in the West. They were paid half in East German marks, a weak currency, and half in the strong Western marks.
For those in the East, an advantage lay in low-priced consumer goods that were heavily subsidized then as now by the Communist Government. That led to large-scale smuggling and black marketeering, a vestige of which continues.
When the wall went up, in 1961, Walter Ulbricht, then the East German Communist Party leader, said the open border had cost his country 100 billion marks and that he wanted it back. Some East German economists have since estimated the loss at double that.
 
The Human Traffic Stops
As long as the 28-mile border was open, Berliners went back and forth freely by car, subway and elevated train.
In the 1950's, for example, one could drive through the Brandenburg Gate that is the city's best-known architectural landmark, and undergo only a cursory document check by an East German policeman.
From 1959 on, these checks became more frequent and more thorough. East German physicians could pass through easily, but old women who came west to buy bird feed for their canaries were stopped, and sometimes their purchases were confiscated.
In 1961, the wall went up. Overnight, there were only five crossings, and from the East, almost no Berliner was allowed through.
 
Death's Several Faces
The hardening of the division separated the citizens in a most painful way: even telephone calls across the wall became fewer and farther between - and this in a city where every third West Berliner has relatives in the East.
Then came the deaths at the wall - of old people in Bernauer Strasse who tried to jump from their apartments on the border into the West and missed the outstretched safety nets, and of the young who were killed by border guards as they tried to cross, and even of some border guards themselves shot to death by snipers from the West.
Berlin - which had thrilled to the first zeppelin flights and, in the late 1920's, to the first German rocket experiments by Fritz Sanger and the young Wernher von Braun; Berlin, whose composers like Paul Hindemith, filmmakers like Fritz Lang, scientists like Werner Heisenberg, Otto Hahn and Albert Einstein, and theater directors like Max Reinhardt and Ernst Piscator, had made it one of the world's great cultural magnets - this city fell in its separate pieces into the shadows.
Certainly there was a fine philharmonic orchestra in the West and a fine comic opera in the East, among other cultural showpieces.
Certainly the ruins of World War II, which left mile upon mile of bombed buildings gaping like blackened rotted teeth, had been largely removed - replaced by many striking new structures and some lovingly rebuilt monuments. But something was missing - the spirit of the old city, on both sides.
 
'The Islander'
Gunter Neumann, the late songwriter, caught something of it in his verse about the typical Berliner called ''The Islander.''
 
Der Insulaner verliert die Ruhe nicht
Der Insulaner liebt keen Jetue nicht. . .
Der Insulaner hofft unbeirrt
Dass seine Insel wieder schones Festland wird.
 
(The Islander doesn't get upset
The Islander doesn't like a fuss. . .
The Islander keeps up his hopes
That his island will again become part of the mainland.)
Hanns Peter Herz, who worked with Mr. Neumann at the American-operated radio station RIAS here, recited that verse today and remarked: ''I used to say that Berlin was Germany in a nutshell. Now I can say we are, for the moment, mankind's capital.''
 
One Woman's Refuge Delayed
Elsewhere there are mixed feelings.
Rut, an East Berlin widow in her 50's, remembered planning to skip to the West in that fateful August nearly three decades ago and even depositing some bedsheets with a friend in West Berlin. The wall prevented her plan, and she continued at her job until now.
''I'm not going yet,'' she said, ''even though I already have the visa. I have to let it sink in for awhile. When I think of all the years we missed,'' she murmured. Her eyes were sad.
Thomas Mahmke, an East Berlin factory worker, said he had driven over for a couple of hours to the West, looked in some shops but passed up even the bargains, bought a curry-spiced sausage, and returned.
''It cost one mark and 90 pfennigs,'' - about $1 -he said. ''A bit expensive for us, but it tastes better than ours.'' Next time, he might take in a movie as he had in West Berlin before the wall went up. ''It is as if we were liberated,'' he said. ''It makes working worthwhile.'' One currywurst made it worthwhile? ''Jawohl!'' he replied.

HEADLINE: CLAMOR IN THE EAST: VIEW FROM WASHINGTON;
U.S., Its Vision Blurred, Avoids Crisis Mentality

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12

 BODY:
Administration officials said today that in view of the recent events in East Germany they are studying every ''way-out scenario'' imaginable for Europe, NATO and the Warsaw Pact, but for the moment they intend to sit tight, let the dust settle and not do anything that will be regretted later.
Indeed, there was no sense of crisis in Washington today, no special ''Berlin task force'' to monitor events. Officials were home watching the Washington Redskins football team on television, just as they were last Sunday when the Berlin wall was still a real barrier.
At the State Department, more energy seemed to be devoted to monitoring the leftist guerrilla offensive in El Salvador than the drama in East Berlin. 
This is not because Administration officials are indifferent to the events unfolding in East Berlin. It is rather that they evidently feel that the developments are generally in America's interests, and the product of American policies over the last 40 years, so there is little reason to get in the way.
Even if they wanted to put events on a different course, officials argue, they have few resources to accomplish this at the moment, and no clear, long-term vision of Europe yet that could guide them.
A top Administration policy maker, trying to explain the apparent contradiction between heavy American news coverage of Berlin and the absence of major activity in Washington, said: ''It is natural that symbols take on great emotional meaning in international relations. And of all the symbols, the division of Berlin and the Berlin wall is one of the greatest.
''Both the apparent and real breaches in the Berlin wall naturally lead to a rush of speculation that a new order is in the offing,'' he said. ''But it is not going to happen overnight.
''We are probably on the start of an era where American diplomacy can help shape the lines of a new international order,'' he added. ''But what is important at this point is not crisis management, but considered thinking about the shape of that new order and how we get there, and that's what we're doing.''
It appears that the only Administration decision has been to agree with the Soviet Union and West Germany to play down talk of any immediate reunfication of the two Germanys, and to refrain from doing anything that might inflame the situation.
Administration officials said that President Bush has an informal understanding with Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany that Washington will continue to speak positively about the ''principle'' of German reunification, even though this is anathema to many allies in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. In return, they said, Bonn must closely coordinate its activities with the United States and refrain from taking any immediate steps toward unification until a proper European security framework is established.
President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union indicated a similar preference in his letter to President Bush on Friday, officials said.
These understandings rang through loud and clear in remarks by a variety of American, Soviet and German diplomats over the weekend.
When asked about German reunification on the ABC News program ''This Week,'' Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said, ''In my view, it is at least premature to jump, to make the great leap - and it is a big leap - from right of free travel on the part of East Germans to the question of reunification.
''There are many things, it seems to me, that have to take place in between,'' he said. ''One of those is fair and free and even multi-party elections in East Germany. Another is movement to a free economic system, free markets, free enterprise.''
Earlier, Gennadi I. Gerasimov, the spokesman for the Soviet Foreign Ministry, was asked on the CBS News program ''Face the Nation'' whether the Kremlin was ruling out German reunification.
''Reunification is being talked about by people who are not in office, not in government,'' Mr. Gerasimov said. People in authority, he said, are not discussing it.
''We have two military organizations opposing each other, NATO on your side and the Warsaw Pact on the other side,'' he said, ''and the German Democratic Republic is a very important member of the Warsaw Pact for us, and we have our troops there just as Americans have their troops'' in West Germany. ''So how can you reunify it now? So we must wait and let events take its own course.''
When Mr. Gerasimov was asked whether Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Bush might share a view that Europe's borders must be kept as they are, he answered: ''I think that they may come to a common ground concerning that both countries, and actually everybody, is interested in stability, in not too much upheaval in Europe. I think this is in the common interests of both countries.''
On the NBC News program ''Meet the Press,'' Defense Secretary Dick Cheney made clear that for now, the Bush Administration sees NATO and the Warsaw Pact continuing to play important roles in Europe.
Asked what President Bush would say if Mr. Gorbachev proposed the dissolution of the two alliances, Mr. Cheney said: ''Well, I think he should say that that's totally inappropriate at this time. It seems to me that what we're witnessing in the East is partly the triumph, if you will, of Western strategy for the last 40 years, and the NATO alliance has been the heart of that.''

HEADLINE: Flossmoor Journal;
For Pickup, No Parking In Its Own Driveway

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FLOSSMOOR, Ill., Nov. 11

 BODY:
When they pass Jim Minx's driveway, some people scoff and roll their eyes. Others lament the decline of standards. One resident became so incensed that he took pictures of the awful sight to Village Hall, demanding action at once.
''But gee,'' said Mr. Minx, ''it's only a pickup truck.'' 
A pickup truck, indeed, parked blatantly in the driveway, a clear violation of law in this affluent Chicago suburb.
Flossmoor, an old community of 8,000 people, is known for good schools, well-tended lawns and expensive cars. It is not known for pickup trucks. As a real estate agent fretted, ''What will my clients think?''
Until March, it was illegal to keep a pickup truck even in one's own garage. The law was then liberalized so pickups may now be kept in ''an enclosed garage.''
Mr. Minx said he would be happy to put the truck, a small, well-maintained Mazda, in his garage. ''But I'm remodeling the house,'' he explained, ''and my garage is full of furniture.''
So he keeps parking the truck in his driveway, and Flossmoor police keep giving him tickets.
But Mr. Minx has not been paying them. Instead, he has filed suit in Federal District Court in Chicago, charging that his civil rights have been violated. ''It is my truck and my driveway,'' he said. ''I pay my taxes. I have my rights.'' The flap over Mr. Minx's truck has stirred passionate debate in Flossmoor, where some houses are valued at more than $1 million.
In the view of many residents, Mr. Minx is destroying an old established sense of esthetics here. They worry that the presence of pickup trucks might hurt property values. The presence of pickups could create ''a slum environment,'' John A. Komer warned in a letter to The Star, the local newspaper.
Mayor Frank Maher said many residents of Flossmoor, once home to executives of the steel companies, simply find pickup trucks ''offensive.''
''What if somebody's got a truck with wheelbarrows or lumber sticking out of it?'' he said. ''Nobody wants to look at that.''
Richard Rosenthal, a leader of the anti-truck residents, said he does not so much mind new trucks ''when they're nice and shiny.'' But they inevitably become ''rusty and bumpy.''
Mr. Minx says such a rationale discriminates against trucks. ''What about rusty, bumpy cars?'' he asks.
Mr. Rosenthal and others say Mr. Minx misses the point.
''In Flossmoor,'' Mr. Rosenthal said, ''people do not have rusty, bumpy cars.''
Some residents say the dispute is not really about trucks or cars but about economic class.
Mr. Minx, an Illinois state trooper, lives in a subdivision of town called Flossmoor Highlands, where houses are more modest. And some of his neighbors, who support him, say the wealthier residents across town are being pretentious.
''It's class discrimination,'' said Harold Nelson, a retired steelworker who lives across the street from Mr. Minx. ''Who drives pickup trucks? Blue-collar people, that's who. And that's what this is all about.''
The Highlands subdivision, where some houses are valued at less than $100,000, was annexed to Flossmoor about 20 years ago. Mr. Nelson said its residents have always been held in low regard.
''I saw the same thing when my kids were in school,'' he said. ''They weren't as well accepted because they came from this section of town.''
But Mr. Rosenthal said the issue centers on taste, not income.
''This has always been an affluent society here,'' he said. ''If these people can find a house in Flossmoor they can afford, then fine - but don't try to change the ways of the town.''
Mr. Minx said he found it puzzling that Flossmoor residents were not offended by the presence of pickup trucks owned by carpenters, bricklayers and plumbers who come into the village to do repairs.
''I guess it's all right to hire tradesmen,'' he said, ''just so that they don't live here.''
