HEADLINE: Fate of Bush Housing Plan Depends on Resolving Larger Tax Issues

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12

 BODY:
The fate of President Bush's proposal for a multibillion-dollar housing package to assist low-income families, first-time home-buyers and the homeless will hinge largely on how Congress and the Administration resolve the broader political battle over the budget and taxes, lawmakers and housing experts said today.
Mr. Bush's proposal, unveiled with much fanfare in Dallas on Friday, draws heavily on ideas and approaches already under consideration in Congress.
The lawmakers said that while it will clearly take time to find agreement between the President's proposals and those in Congress, Mr. Bush's interest in housing assistance is important after eight years of dismantling such programs by the Reagan Administration, and virtually guarantees that some form of major housing legislation will be enacted next year.
Indeed, even the name that Mr. Bush chose for his package - the Home Ownership and Opportunity for People Everywhere, or HOPE - is similar to the name of a bipartisan proposal now making its way through the Senate Banking Committee. The senators call their package HOP, for Housing Opportunity Partnerships. 
 
'Life and Momentum' for Plan
''HOP, HOPE, I'll go for anything,'' said Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the New York Republican who is co-sponsoring the Senate legislation with Senator Alan Cranston, Democrat of California. ''This gives the legislation life and momentum.''
As with his domestic initiatives on issues like drugs and crime, Mr. Bush's housing proposal leaves unanswered the critical question of how the new assistance will be financed. The President has called for a three-year program with a price tag of about $7.2 billion, divided between $4.2 billion in grants and subsidies and new or expanded tax breaks that will cost the Treasury an additional $3 billion.
The Congressional proposals also do not spell out financing. The Senate package, due to be considered by the Banking Committee on Thursday, carries a $3.8 billion price tag over one year and envisions that tax breaks similar to some of those proposed by Mr. Bush will be adopted separately by the Senate Finance Committee.
''Where the money comes from is an issue that the leaders in the House and Senate and the Administration are going to have to resolve in next year's budget struggle,'' said Donald Campbell, Mr. Cranston's senior housing aide.
To the extent that the Administration has suggested any source of money, it has pointed to one that most Democrats in Congress consider politically unpalatable and economically dubious, a cut in the capital gains tax. Such a tax cut raises money for a few years as investors sell off their holdings and pay the taxes they owe so they can take advantage of the lower rate. But over time, opponents contend, the tax cut would drain billions of dollars in revenue from the Treasury.
 
Battle Likely Will Resume
Mr. Bush, faced with fierce Democratic opposition in the Senate, has been forced to abandon his hope of winning a capital gains tax cut this year. But lawmakers in both parties expect the battle to resume with even greater intensity next year as Congress and the Administration scramble for ways to slash as much as $40 billion from the Federal deficit while making room for new spending on priority items like housing, education or anti-drug efforts.
''When Congress and the Administration want to find the money, they can, like they did with the savings and loan bailout,'' said Anthony Downs, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution and one of the housing experts who served on a special task force the Senate established to help draft its housing legislation. ''The question is, how much of a priority is housing?''
According to Government officials familiar with the program, the Administration is prepared to commit $250 million in new spending for housing programs in the fiscal 1991 budget that goes to Congress in January. But much of the President's initiative would rely on transferring money from existing housing programs or revamping those programs to encourage more private investment.
''You couldn't spend a billion dollars in the first year, even if you had it,'' Mr. D'Amato said. ''Despite the political posturing that we're going to get, Congress and the Administration are on the same wavelength. The reality of the fiscal situation is that the most ardent housing supporters on Capitol Hill recognize that the pot of gold simply isn't there.
''Instead of tens of billions of dollars for housing, we're going to have to settle for hundreds of millions and some new directions.''
 
Serious Differences Are Seen
But Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat who serves on both the House Banking Committee and the House Budget Committee, said that even if the Administration and Congress could agree on how much to spend for housing assistance, there are serious differences over the substance and direction of Federal housing policy. He noted that the Senate approach, while bipartisan, has never been well received by House Democrats, who believe that something must be done to expand the dwindling supply of low-cost housing.
''You can take all the public housing you want and convert it to tenant ownership, but that is not going to create a single unit of new housing,'' Mr. Schumer said, referring to one of the major components of Mr. Bush's proposal. The President's plan specifically precludes construction of new, low-income housing units, and the Senate plan places emphasis on rehabilitation of existing rental units.
Mr. Schumer said that while many House Democrats support the idea of tenant ownership and believe that some of the existing assistance programs need revamping the real need is for Federal financing of a housing production program. ''We need more dollars and better programs, and the Bush proposal has neither,'' he said.
The Federal Government is currently spending $7.1 billion a year on assisted housing, a decline of more than 70 percent from the $26.7 billion that was spent in 1980, or of more than 80 percent if the effects of inflation are taken into account. Mr. Schumer said that while the House and Senate may differ in their approaches, both would like to see the current figure increased to something over $10 billion next year.
''The bottom line is that in the area of housing, there is no substitute for money,'' he said. ''If $250 million is what the Administration has in mind for next year, then I've never seen more words and hype about less dollars than at any time in my political career.''

HEADLINE: Honor in the House - and Senate?;
Eliminate Honorariums

 BODY:
The list below details the honorarium fees that two prominent Senators, the majority leader, George Mitchell, and the minority leader, Robert Dole, received from private interest groups last year. The potential for conflicts of interest, real or apparent, is obvious.
Cleaner government requires stiff rules prohibiting such income combined with a reasonable pay increase for the lawmakers. Just such a package was recommended by a Presidential commission last year. But it failed when the size of the raise and the chance it would be approved without a recorded vote generated a furious public response. 
Now House Speaker Thomas Foley and the House minority leader, Robert Michel, are again trying to raise salaries as part of a broader ethics bill. They show commendable political courage. But they may not win approval without similar courage from the Senate's leaders, and the President.
Members of Congress deserve to be heard when they say they need more than their $89,500 annual salary. That may sound high; but many could earn much more in private-sector jobs, and the need to maintain two households is a genuine financial burden.
The salaries of other top Federal officials are linked to those of senators and representatives. Because of Congress's reluctance to vote itself pay raises, judges, Cabinet members and high-level civil servants have seen their paychecks eroded by inflation. That frustrates recruiting.
Congress, meanwhile, doesn't feel the same pinch. Under present rules, members may take back-door raises in the form of honorariums from interest groups with a heavy stake in legislation. These ethically questionable fees now total more than $9 million annually. Republican and Democratic leaders and members of powerful committees pocket the most.
This system erodes public trust and taints the business of Congress. The new House ethics plan, developed by a special bipartisan task force, offers the public and Congress an attractive alternative. It would forbid honorariums and replace the lost income with a cost-of-living adjustment in pay and a 25 percent raise beginning in 1991. Judges and other officials would also receive needed boosts.
The new House proposal is far more modest than the 51 percent pay increase rejected last January and, as necessary and reasonable, warrants adoption. President Bush, who prodded Congress last summer with pay and ethics proposals of his own, can help by backing up his general statement of support with a strong White House lobbying effort for the House bill.
Senators, who generally receive more in honorariums than members of the House, have greater obligation to press for change. Senators Mitchell and Dole say they favor the kind of approach embodied by the House bill. But the legislation they are considering would merely scale back Senate honorariums, not eliminate them.
For the nation's top lawmakers to mortgage themselves to monied private lobbies insults democracy. The new House ethics package offers a rare test of Congressional self-respect.

HEADLINE: Crops and Livestock Thrive Without Chemicals, Studies Show

 BODY:
To the Editor:
A crucial point in the debate on the effects of decreased farm use of chemicals concerns food production. As Jim Sinner points out (letter, Oct. 8), food production will determine the cost and, hence, the possibility of reducing this important source of environmental pollution.
Assessments of the economic consequences of large-scale reduction in farm chemicals have been based on arbitrarily assumed levels of yield reduction. However, it is possible to make such assessments more firmly by using the results of the many field experiments on organic agriculture carried out in the last 10 years. 
A search of the scientific literature has yielded 226 field comparisons of yields from conventionally grown crops and livestock with crops and livestock grown organically - that is, those produced without the use of any manufactured chemical fertilizers, pesticides or growth stimulants. The experimental data covered 26 crops and two livestock products - milk and eggs - and was measured at 21 sites in Europe and the United States.
Yields produced without any farm chemicals averaged 88 percent of those produced with the recommended optimum levels of application. In more than a quarter of the comparisons, yield differences were less than 10 percent, more than half the yield differences were less than 20 percent, and in nearly three-quarters of the comparisons, yield differences were less than 30 percent.
In 49 out of the 196 comparisons, crops not receiving farm chemicals gave greater yields than those conventionally grown, while half the 30 animal products compared showed greater yields from livestock that had not received chemically grown feedstuffs, feed additives or antibiotics.
There was no evidence from analysis of the experimental data to show that the use of farm chemicals affected year-to-year variability in yields, either climatically induced variability or that caused by transitional or conversion effects.
This experimental finding, that the reduction in yields associated with the nonuse of farm chemicals averaged only 12 percent, has important economic and environmental implications. Equally significant is the challenge to agricultural science to explain this surprising refutation of the commonly held view that heavy applications of farm chemicals are essential for a productive agriculture.
 
GERALD STANHILL
 Bet Dagan, Israel, Oct. 24, 1989
The writer is coordinator of research in organic agriculture at the Volcani Center of Israel's Agricultural Research Organization.

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
List of Promises From Dinkins: Checking It Twice

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
Somewhere between the poles of consistency and expediency lie valid reasons to break campaign promises.
Keeping them is not necessarily a test of leadership or even fidelity. Events may force different priorities. So may the broader perspective demanded by higher office. But campaign pledges are worth remembering as a benchmark against which to measure how far a candidate, once elected, has strayed or grown. 
When David N. Dinkins was elected Manhattan Borough President in 1985, he promised to make housing, education, personal safety, health care and employment his priorities, to pay special attention to communities in jeopardy and, while striving for balance, to empower constituencies that were underserved. He largely kept to that agenda, though the limitations of his office, at least, necessarily left him longer on promise than performance.
It would be impossible to compare Mr. Dinkins's record as mayor with what might have been had 20,000 or so voters changed their minds and elected Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican. But it is possible to measure it over the next four years against his campaign promises. Here are the highlights in capsule form:
Crime: Double the 825 police officers and supervisors assigned to community patrol. Hire an additional 2,500 officers.
Assign an officer to every subway train at night while maintaining present platform patrols. Press for tougher penalites for crimes committed by gangs of three or more. Punish every crime, first offenses included, with penalties ranging from community service and house arrest to boot camps and prison. Oppose more jail barges as ''not a reasonable alternative.'' Create an all-civilian police complaint review board.
Drugs: Begin random drug tests as a condition of probation and parole and return those who test positive to prison. Give drug treatment on demand. Provide a guard in every school and drug education in every grade.
Housing: Require developers of commercial space to build, or help finance, affordable housing. Penalize landlords who keep habitable apartments vacant for more than a month. Freeze the tax burden on single-family homes. Accelerate housing rehabilitation, particularly for individuals.
Education: Transform school buildings into community centers open all year and evenings. Oppose tenure for principals in specific schools. Involve parents in local school boards and appoint a parent of a public-school student to the Board of Education.
Health and Welfare: Open 25 school clinics in medically underserved comunities. Provide prenatal care for every pregnant city resident. Scrap a needle-exchange program for drug addicts. Expand neighborhood health clinics and services and benefits for poor children and troubled families.
Economic Development: Impose binding commercial rent arbitration for small businesses. Provide economic incentives to small businesses, light manufacturing and emerging industries. Encourage regional cooperation. Expand opportunities for government contracts for businesses owned by women and minority groups. Make hiring of city residents a condition for city assistance to businesses ''whenever possible.'' Create an adult education institute. Make zoning and tax concessions for companies contingent on their providing child-care space or assistance.
Environment: Impose a moratorium of up to four years on garbage-burning incinerators. Speed recycling programs to handle 50 percent of the garbage by 1997. Shift vehicles owned and licensed by the city from gasoline to alternative fuels, beginning next year with 10 percent of all vehicles purchased. Improve the racial climate.
Last week, Mr. Dinkins offered a first look at his agenda. Visiting City Hall after an election he had almost lost, in part because of questions about his personal finances, the Mayor-elect, encouraged by Mayor Edward I. Koch, lobbied to loosen an ethics law. Few question the wisdom of delaying the law, which by more severely limiting future employment of city government officials could disrupt the transition by provoking a stampede among them. Yet some questioned the judgment of elevating a sensitive issue that was not even a campaign promise to a seemingly top priority.
That could hint at a short honeymoon for Mr. Dinkins. His most ardent supporters may be hopeful, but other New Yorkers, among them the nearly one-half who voted for somebody else last week, presumably harbor lower expectations. Low expectations for many public officials rarely breed disappointment.
''David has one asset,'' said Mark Green, a Dinkins adviser. ''He's invariably underestimated.''
And therein may lie his greatest promise.

HEADLINE: Teachers' Leader Ready to Reap Gratitude

BYLINE: By NEIL A. LEWIS

 BODY:
As the president of the United Federation of Teachers, New York City's teachers union, Sandra Feldman is one of the most powerful figures in the city's public sector.
Now she and her union are poised to see their influence magnified even further when both a new Mayor and new Schools Chancellor take office in January.
The incoming Chancellor, Joseph A. Fernandez, was the union's first choice to head the city's public school system.
For the Mayor-elect, David N. Dinkins, Ms. Feldman and her members provided an important early endorsement in the Democratic primary and vigorous support in his successful general-election campaign against Rudolph W. Giuliani.
In private conversations, so numerous as to be almost public, Ms. Feldman has been claiming a large share of the credit for helping Mr. Dinkins become the city's first black mayor. 
When Mr. Fernandez arrives in January from Miami, where he has led the Dade County schools, he will bring a philosophy of increasing the influence of teachers in running their schools and presumably some gratitude for the U.F.T.'s support.
In endorsing Mr. Dinkins, the union, with its 102,000 active and retired members, broke with its recent practice of not backing anyone in mayoral primaries. Ms. Feldman engineered the change.
To do so, she eschewed the advice of her longtime mentor and predecessor as U.F.T. president, Albert Shanker. Mr. Shanker had initially recommended that the union support Richard Ravitch in the Democratic primary.
But Ms. Feldman argued that the union's interests were best served by backing Mr. Dinkins. She felt comfortable with the candidate philosophically, and she thought he would win.
The Mayor-elect has also been a good friend of Ms. Feldman's husband, Arthur Barnes, since their boyhood days in Harlem. The two men are so close that many expect Mr. Barnes, the head of the Urban Coalition, to get a high-level job in the Dinkins administration.
In addition to the manpower that comes with any union's support, the U.F.T.'s endorsement provided Mr. Dinkins with the public approval of an organization widely seen as white and middle-class and, to a lesser extent, Jewish.
The image is largely accurate. About 70 percent of the city's 62,000 active teachers are white, and most of them are among the oldest. About 19 percent of the teachers are black, and almost 10 percent are of Hispanic heritage. The racial makeup of the student population has been changing more quickly: fewer than 20 percent of the city's public school students are white.
Fewer than a third of the teachers are men, and they are concentrated in the high schools.
 
Teachers Versus Parents
The image of the union as white and Jewish was forged during the 1968 teachers strike, which became one of the city's most brutal racial conflicts. The strike, which began over an experiment to give parents in the Ocean Hill-Brownsville section of Brooklyn a role in running the schools, pitted white, mostly Jewish, teachers against black parents and their supporters.
The strike deeply affected many people who now have leadership roles in the public schools, especially Ms. Feldman. At the time of the strike, the union was six years old and an uncertain factor in city affairs. The strike, ostensibly over the local school board's efforts to get rid of several union teachers, gave the U.F.T. an opportunity to coalesce and demonstrate its influence.
It thrust Mr. Shanker into the forefront of city politics and, with him, Ms. Feldman, his personal assistant. He sent her into Ocean Hill-Brownsville at the beginning of the strike ''to provide a union presence,'' she recalled in an interview.
''He picked me because I was tough,'' she said.
 
'No Role Here'
It was through Mr. Shanker's patronage and support that Ms. Feldman rose to head the union, succeeding him in January 1986. She is paid an annual salary of $119,000.
Ms. Feldman acknowledged that when she became president she was at first uneasy about being seen as merely Mr. Shanker's surrogate at the U.F.T. while he moved on to head the American Federation of Teachers, the smaller of the two major national teacher unions. ''I knew I had to establish myself,'' she said.
Asked whether Mr. Shanker had a lingering role in U.F.T. affairs, Ms. Feldman answered abruptly, ''He has no role here.'' She said she dreads comparisons with him.
Friends of both said that right after she assumed the union's presidency, Ms. Feldman felt a strong need to demonstrate her independence. Nowadays, they said, she is more secure about her leadership.
''When there are very weighty things, I give him a call,'' she said, although she added, ''I don't talk to him a lot.''
 
Tougher Economic Times
Bert Pogrebin, who has served for many years as special counsel to the Board of Education in contract negotiations with the U.F.T., said the union under Mr. Shanker ''was probably one of the most effective labor unions in the city.'' He said the union dominated labor relations at the board until the city's fiscal crisis in the mid-1970's, and even after that. Teachers, he said, ''expected Shanker to deliver everything.''
Ms. Feldman, he said, has to contend with tougher economic times for the city. Nonetheless, she negotiated a contract three years ago without resorting to arbitration, as Mr. Shanker did three years earlier.
The current contract expires at the end of next September, just as school begins. Ms. Feldman made it clear in the interview that in coming negotiations she wants to increase teachers' salaries, now ranging from $25,000 to $50,000. ''Teachers have to be valued,'' she said.
The mayor is the principal figure in setting the city's budget, which helps determine teacher salaries and how much is spent on some educational programs.
Although Ms. Feldman was a full-time teacher for only three years, she is admired by her members for her awareness of their emotional needs, especially their craving for respect and their sensitivity to criticism.
 
'Like a Miracle'
Ms. Feldman, who is 50 years old, grew up in poverty in a Coney Island tenement. She descibed her childhood as difficult and one redeemed by school, which she found to be a wondrous place.
''When I got to school, it was like a miracle,'' she recalled. ''I remember my very first moment there, being made to line up with the other kindergarten kids in the lunchroom of P.S. 188.
''I loved the smell of the school. I loved the smell of the teachers with their perfume.''
While she is rapturous about the long ago of her childhood, she is less comfortable talking about the 1968 strike, which so affected the public schools. ''I hate it when it keeps getting brought up,'' she said. ''It was so long ago.''
The strike's most lasting legacy was the decentralized system of administration that was put into place in 1969 and still endures. The city was divided into 32 districts, each with locally elected boards to govern the elementary and middle schools. The high schools continued to be administered by the central Board of Education.
 
Teachers on Boards
Many teachers who had opposed decentralization moved swiftly to turn the new system to their benefit, running for election to the local school boards. While teachers, along with principals, could not run in the districts where they worked, they could become members in other districts, often trading favors among themselves. Board of Education employees, mostly principals, accounted for nearly a third of the local school board members until a recent law prohibited them from serving. Teachers accounted for about 10 percent of the seats.
In addition, in elections where the turnouts were as low as 3 percent of eligible voters, the U.F.T. found it could easily influence the makeup of school boards through endorsements and campaign contributions. Until a recent change in policy, the union would also challenge nominating petitions of candidates it opposed. Such candidates were usually overmatched by the union's formidable legal and financial resources.
Ms. Feldman noted that the U.F.T. supported the new law prohibiting teachers and other Board of Education employees from serving on local school boards. After several of the local boards came under investigation on corruption charges, the union had to respond to complaints that it had worked to elect most of those politicians. Ms. Feldman said the union has become more careful in its endorsements and withheld support last May from those under investigation.
She said she shares the growing concern among officials and educators that the 20-year-old decentralized system has to be changed.
''I think everyone in New York has felt for a while there have to be significant changes in the decentralized system,'' she said.
The change she most looks forward to is Mr. Fernandez's efforts to bring to New York the innovations he has tried in Miami. Mr. Fernandez has said he will try to replicate what he called the ''Miami experiment,'' in which schools are largely run by committees composed of teachers, principals and parents.
''I don't expect we'll be totally in agreement with everything he wants done,'' Ms. Feldman said. But when asked what issues come to mind on which they might disagree, she said she could not think of any.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
Adjustments Expected in Mexico Pact

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Mexico is getting far less in new loans than it hoped for when it worked out a debt agreement with its bankers in July. Because of this, bankers involved in the agreement say that some difficult last-minute adjustments are likely to be necessary.
While the figures are still not final, bankers estimate that Mexico will receive no more than $4.5 billion in new money over four years - half the $9 billion it hoped for when the debt accord was signed in July.
The debt restructuring plan came after four months of negotiations and was the first under the Bush Administration's new debt-reduction strategy. Under the proposal, which covers $52.7 billion in Mexico's medium- and long-term debt to commercial banks around the world, banks must choose between accepting a 35 percent reduction in the value of their existing loans, offering new loans or doing a combination of the two. 
 
Smaller Debt Burden
This preference for debt reduction and the shortage of new loans means Mexico's overall debt burden will be cut a little more than originally anticipated. That will help in the future but provides less economic relief now. Originally, the package had been estimated to provide $2 billion to $3 billion a year in new assistance.
This last-minute problem also illustrates some of the difficulties of restructuring debt by giving banks the choice between debt reduction and new loans. While debt reduction has been tried before, this is the first time it has been combined with new loans as an official policy, backed by the United States, its allies and key international financial institutions.
Shafiqul Islam, a senior fellow at the Council of Foreign Relations in New York, called the approach ''a bad idea in principle and in tactics.''
 
''It Will Work''
Despite the expected need for adjustments, several bankers, all of whom asked not to be identified, said they expect the deal to go through. ''It will work,'' one banker said. But the lack of new money may lead to renewed criticism among bankers of the Administration's debt strategy, which is called the Brady plan for Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady.
Bankers said the Mexicans and some bankers were still trying to encourage more banks to offer some new money along with debt reduction. But many banks, especially those that have recently increased their reserves against loans to the third world and taken large losses, are resisting such suggestions.
 
Problems With Canadian Lenders
Several bankers said that Canadian banks seem to be posing the biggest problem. One American banker said he thought some Canadian banks might not be unhappy if the deal failed.
Citibank, which heads the advisory committee of banks that negotiated the debt agreement, is alone in opting all for new money. Its chairman, John S. Reed, has pushed that approach aggressively, partially because of the bank's large exposure in Mexico.
Japanese banks have opted mostly for principal reduction, bankers said, but a few have offered new loans. Both Bank of America and the Swiss Bank Corporation, which is a co-chair of the committee, have opted for a combination of debt reduction and some new money.
A. W. Clausen, Bank of America's chairman, said the bank would mostly take debt reduction. But the commitment to some new money, he said, shows confidence in Mexico's future.
But the Swiss Bank's reason for choosing to make some new loans, one official said, was to preserve the structure of the co-financing agreement it has with the World Bank on loans made to Mexico in 1986.
Several British banks are doing all debt reduction, while one or two are said to be still considering a combination.
The obstacle to completing the deal is that there may not be enough money to provide the guarantees promised. One option is to reduce the existing principal on loans by 35 percent and get interest at market rates. The other is to accept a fixed interest rate of 6.25 percent on the existing face value of the loans.
In the original proposal there is $7 billion for these guarantees or enhancements from the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank, Japan and Mexico. The money would provide for 18-month rolling guarantees on the interest reduction bonds and the purchase of Treasury bonds needed to guarantee the remaining principal on the debt reduction bonds.
With fewer new loans and more debt reduction than forecast, the expected cost of the guarantees is rising, bankers said.
One top banker said there are only two possible sources for more guarantee money - the banks and Mexico. Mexico would have to provide more money from its reserves or the banks would have to accept a lesser guarantee. What is being discussed in this vein is interest guarantees of less than the 18 months assumed, the banker said. But the banks already agreed to ''stretch'' these enhancements once with a $1 billion letter of credit in September.
The original assumption discussed by both the Mexicans and bankers after the intitial agreement in July was that banks would choose interest rate reduction on 60 percent of the existing loans, principal reduction on 20 percent and new loans on 20 percent.
As of now, with more than half the replies in, new loans are less than 10 percent, and they are not expected to go above that when the selection process is finished at the end of the month. There was a bonus fee for opting for new money by Oct. 31 but one banker said, the ''new money was very light.''
Another problem with the lack of new money is that it may indicate that fewer banks will be willing to lend to Mexico in the future, which could hurt growth.
Far more than 20 percent of the choices, however, are for principal reduction.
Salomon Brothers, in a new analysis of the debt reduction options, concluded that the interest rate reduction bond is more valuable in terms of cash flow than the prinicpal reduction bonds. But the study also suggests that to hedge against the movement of interest rates, the banks could buy some principal reduction bonds.
 
Inflation Outlook
The president of Mexico, Carlos Salinas de Gortari, said in his State of the Nation address last week, that the Government was now expecting less new money. And he also indicated that inflation this year could be higher than expected.
Mr. Islam of the Council of Foreign Relations said that if Mexico appeared to face greater problems in meeting its near-term financing needs it could erode some of the new confidence that was generated with the signing of the debt agreement. This would also hurt near-term growth prospects because the return of capital the Mexicans have been counting on could slow down.
In another debt negotiation, banks had until Friday to respond to the Philippine Government's offer to buy back up to $1.3 billion of its debt at 50 cents on the dollar. The outcome is expected to be announced this week.
 
Japanese Courted
NAGOYA, Japan, Nov. 12 (Reuters) - Latin American finance ministers and central bank governors met here today in an attempt to attract Japanese investment.
The three-day symposium is being sponsored by the Inter-American Development Bank and Japan's Export-Import Bank and will be addressed by several Latin American economic ministers, as well as executives of banks that have lent money in the region.
Private sector bankers said they expected the Japanese Government to promise financial support to several Latin American and Caribbean countries. A Japanese Finance Ministry official said an agreement to provide all or part of a promised $2.05 billion in loans to Mexico over the next three years was likely to be signed.

HEADLINE: More Aid for Addicts on the Job

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
Hundreds of American employers, angry and frustrated about drug-related losses in productivity, accidents, absenteeism and surging medical expenses, have begun offering counseling programs to addicted employees in recent months in an intensified campaign against drug abuse in the workplace.
''The number of chronic abusers and addicts is at record levels, both in the workplace and outside,'' said Mark A. de Bernardo, director of labor law at the United States Chamber of Commerce. Government and industry experts say drug and alcohol abuse is costing the employers more than $100 billion a year.
Employers and Government experts say that many drug abusers also have problems with alcohol, which remains the most serious substance-abuse problem. Counseling programs typically offer help with both drugs and alcohol. 
 
Joint Efforts by Corporations
Many of the small and medium-sized companies, which make up 99 percent of the nation's employers, have recently overcome their earlier reluctance to confront drug abuse problems and are joining in the campaign.
In California, Florida, Texas, Michigan, Washington and at least six other states, large corporations have recently formed groups that share information and resources to help deal with the problem. And they are helping smaller companies start anti-drug operations.
''There's been a phenomenal growth rate in the number of companies offering employee-assistance services in the last year, as a result of employers' concerns about substance abuse,'' said J. Michael Walsh, director of workplace initiatives for the National Institute on Drug Abuse, a Federal agency.
For example, 80 companies signed contracts to purchase therapy programs for alcohol and drug abuse in the last year from Human Affairs International, a unit of the Aetna Life and Casualty Company, which supplies employee-assistance services to both large and small employers. And thousands of companies that have Federal contracts are now required to adopt anti-drug policies, under provisions of the Drug-Free Workplace Act, which went into effect on March 18.
The assistance programs, which are often coupled with company drug-testing policies, are now available to more than 26 million workers - three times as many as five years ago, when the crack form of cocaine emerged as a major problem. 20 Million Workers Use Drugs Nationwide, an estimated 20 million American jobs are now held by people who use illicit drugs like marijuana, amphetamines, cocaine and crack, a smokable form of cocaine.
Company counselors say they are encountering a growing number of employees and their relatives who are using alcohol, crack and other drugs in combination, and they report that they are having difficulty keeping pace with such multiple addictions, which they say are the biggest killer. But despite these new problems, industry leaders feel they have important assets in offering therapy.
''The workplace is an easier place to deal with drugs than any place else,'' said James E. Burke, chairman of the strategic planning committee of the board of Johnson & Johnson, the medical products company. ''You have more control, and you can build a supportive environment, which is sometimes difficult to do in the community.''
Richard Lesher, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, said: ''Employers have the most effective weapon in the war on drugs, the paycheck. If you and I believe that our jobs are contingent on our being drug-free, it creates a powerful incentive.''
 
The Search for Answers
''We are really dealing with problems of work performance, which also include marital and family problems, stress and emotional problems,'' said Ron Finch, employee-assistance director at BellSouth, the telephone company based in Atlanta. ''A lot of drug and alcohol abusers are trying to medicate themselves.''
The big Detroit automobile makers and many other large employers are providing space in hundreds of plants and offices across the country for Alcoholics Anonymous and Narcotics Anonymous meetings, which serve employees, their relatives and people from nearby communities.
 
An Employee Who Got Help
''I try to attend at least two Narcotics Anonymous meetings a week,'' said R. Craig Redner, a 39-year-old food-catering salesman in Novi, Mich., a Detroit suburb. He said that he had been addicted for years, first to heroin and later to crack, and that his employer had helped him to stop using drugs.
''Our goal is not to find people and kick them out; that merely dumps people on society,'' said John F. Maciarz, a General Motors Corporation spokesman. ''Our major objective is to turn them back into the successes they once were.''
Mr. Redner said: ''The final two weeks, I was actually free-basing on the job. My boss at Gary's Catering said if I didn't get help, he would let me go.'' Mr. Redner said he was hospitalized for two weeks, which his company's health plan paid for.
''They hired me back the day I got out,'' he said. He continued with ''one-on-one therapy'' for seven months. Since then, Mr. Redner said, ''I have been straight for a year and nine months.''
 
New Jersey-New York Efforts
In one of many regional programs in which corporations are cooperating in attacking drug problems, business executives will meet on Thursday to discuss anti-drug strategies under the auspices of the New York Business Group on Health and the New Jersey Business and Industry Association in Ridgewood, N.J.
Thousands of executives have attended a variety of drug conferences this fall organized by Hoffmann-La Roche Inc., the Swiss-owned pharmaceutical concern, and other sponsors. Irwin Lerner, president and chief executive of Hoffmann-La Roche, said the goal was to ''sensitize business organizations around the country'' to bring the campaign back to local areas.
Mr. Burke, who recently retired as chief executive of Johnson & Johnson, heads another cooperative program. It has created hundreds of anti-drug messages that have been broadcast free or published without charge in newspapers and magazines. The broadcast time and ads, if purchased, would have cost $310 million.
General Motors and the United Automobile Workers union are sponsoring a 13-week television series on televison station WBKD in Detroit in which recovering alcoholics and drug abusers like Mr. Redner tell their stories.
 
Help for Families
As drug abuse has spread, executives increasingly have had to deal with colleagues and relatives in need of help. ''We got into drug testing when it was determined that the chief executive's driver was using drugs,'' the employee-assistance director at one company said.
Bruce Liebert, 38 years old, a self-employed aquarium sales and maintenance man in Houston, said his wife's insurance at her job at the Exxon Corporation had paid for treatment at Spring Shadows, a Houston drug program, for his longtime cocaine addiction.
''After 18 months, I went off on another binge and shot coke for, like, a day and a half,'' he said. ''The end was a few mornings after. I ended up on the steps of my church, totally devastated.''
Mr. Liebert said the church sent him to Canaan Land, a treatment center in Alabama. Since then, he said, he has been free of drugs for two years. ''Now the whole thing that keeps me straight is helping people,'' he explained. ''I was asked to speak at Exxon to the executives. It's a problem with everybody, not just down in the ghetto.''
 
The Cost Factor
''Corporations can easily spend more for drug treatment than cancer, AIDS or open heart surgery,'' said Otto Jones, president of Human Affairs International in Murray, Utah, which provides employee-assistance services to insurers and employers that cover five million people.
''Drug users will incur 300 percent more medical costs, on average, than the rest of a company's employees,'' he said. ''The users lose twice as much work as the average employee and are five times more likely to be involved in accidents off the job.''
Spending on employee health care has been increasing by 15 percent a year for the last 12 years.
''The high-cost case is often the child of an executive in a dual-career family who is institutionalized for more than a year,'' Mr. Jones continued. ''The parents just wanted to put them someplace, and often the institutions got them on other kinds of drugs just to manage them.''
When experienced workers are in short supply, providing help takes on an added economic rationale. ''With the workplace pool of potential employees shrinking, it makes real clear sense to try to rehabilitate employees rather than terminate them,'' said Jack Rose, an employee-assistance administrator with the Lockheed Corporation in Burbank, Calif.
 
Increased Use of Testing
Testing for drugs has become an important part of the program at many American corporations, and experts say thousands more will soon be testing as they comply with the new Drug-Free Workplace law. According to a Labor Department survey last year, 17 million people worked for employers in the private sector that test for drugs.
Johnson & Johnson, like many large companies, tests all job applicants for drugs. ''Companies put the message out there: 'Don't apply!' '' said Helen Axel, executive director of human resources research, at the Conference Board, a business research group in New York.
Employees may be tested if they are involved in accidents or other unusual behavior. At Johnson & Johnson, people in high-risk jobs are tested without advance notice, several times a year. Those identified as drug users are directed to the company's assistance program, which is tied in with counseling to cope with psychological stress and to promote physical fitness.
 
Unions Oppose Coercion
Labor unions generally support employer drug counseling and therapy programs. But the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and many member unions oppose coercion in drug programs and oppose testing as a violation of privacy.
''Job loss is an effective deterrent, but the threat of job loss should be restricted to failure to perform the job,'' said Noel Beasley, a vice president in Chicago with the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union. Drug testing, he added, reduces the incentive for people to enter rehabilitation voluntarily.
Mr. Rose at Lockheed said a record of having offered assistance was important in defending lawsuits claiming ''unlawful'' dismissals in states like California.
The Supreme Court recently upheld the legality of testing railway employees after accidents and the legality of pre-employment testing for Federal customs agents. Challenges to random drug testing of employees are making their way through the courts.

HEADLINE: Pacific Economic Group Makes Progress at Meeting

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CANBERRA, Australia, Nov. 12

 BODY:
The inaugural Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation meeting, attended by representatives of 12 countries last week, achieved modest progress.
United States officials said the new group might develop common positions involving other international groups, including the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development and the International Telecommunications Union.
''We have not completed all the decisions that hopefully we will ultimately take, but this is a very clear and substantial step forward and should be welcomed worldwide,'' said Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, who led the United States delegation. 
The delegation also included Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher and the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills.
 
Who Participated
Other countries represented included Japan, Canada, South Korea, New Zealand, Australia and the six members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, or ASEAN, Singapore, Malaysia, Thailand, the Philippines, Indonesia and Brunei.
China, Taiwan and Hong Kong did not participate, in the face of opposition from some ASEAN nations. Trade officials at the meeting said the group's effectiveness would be limited by their absence.
Negotiations are to continue on participation by China, Taiwan and Hong Kong, with the possibilities ranging from full membership to observer status.
The meeting of the new group was intended as a message to the European Community that the Asia-Pacific region is committed to the success of the Uruguay Round of trade liberalization talks being held by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
 
Low-Key Strategies
The United States and Japan followed similar low-key strategies at the conference, with both sides emphasizing substantive projects for the region.
The organization's structure reflects proposals made recently in the United States for increasing dialogue between governments in the Asia-Pacific region, which has seen the most rapid expansion of any area in the world economy in the 1980's.
The recent transition in some East Asian economies from labor-intensive production to technology-based manufacturing has created a need for both capital investment and technology transfer. To help meet these needs, Japan outlined a human resources development program that includes provision for a center in Osaka to train managers and engineers and money to support technical training in the region.
In a move to allay the concerns of Indonesia and Malaysia, which fear that ASEAN'S identity would be threatened by the new, larger group, the six non-ASEAN countries agreed to certain concessions.

HEADLINE: Producers of Electricity Criticize Clean Air Plan

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
President Bush's plan to reduce acid rain by limiting pollutants from the smokestacks of electric utility plants is drawing criticism from some of the nation's cleanest utilities as well as the dirtiest.
Those that burn natural gas and low-sulfur oil instead of high-sulfur coal are complaining because the Bush proposal would require them to cut pollution from existing plants if they want to build new ones. This, they say, is nearly impossible because there is little room left for improvement.
Utilities that use oil argue that the companies that use coal can easily clean up older plants because coal is so dirty to begin with. The oil-burning utilities also say the bill does not recognize their costly efforts, mostly to control sulfur dioxide, a pollutant released into the air when the sulfur in coal or oil is burned. 
Environmentalists are skeptical of all these arguments. ''This is another in a series of very creative excuses utilities have come up with,'' said Constance M. Mahan of the National Audubon Society.
''They're dirtier now because the law permitted them to buy cheaper and dirtier fuel, and that's what they're doing,'' said David G. Hawkins, a senior attorney at the Natural Resources Defense Council and a former assistant administrator for air programs at the Environmental Protection Agency. ''They're trying to do the classic thing polluting firms have always tried to do: maximize their permission to pollute.''
 
Objections From the Northeast
A related objection has been raised by some coal-burning utilities that have already cleaned up. For example, utilities in Wisconsin, under a 1985 law, have already cut their emissions below the level that Washington now proposes, and complain that they would be in a better position today if they had not cleaned up four years ago. And utilities that have not cleaned up are complaining that it would be very costly for them to do so.
Combined with those objections, the the objections of the oil- and gas-burners in the Northeast may make the President's proposed amendments to the Clean Air Act more difficult to get through Congress.
One of those objections by the Northeastern utilities is that the President's proposal would require electric companies that already meet the new standard to match the level of emissions they achieved in 1985. At that time, the utilities could buy abundant natural gas at low prices, resulting in very low pollution. Most have shifted back to oil, because of price changes and higher electric demand.
''It's arbitrary, and we're being unfairly penalized,'' said Frank M. Lee, manager of environmental affairs at the Boston Edison Company, complaining about the selection of 1985 as the base year. He added that his company could do little more to clean up, because it is already buying low-sulfur oil, as Massachusetts requires.
''If acid rain is a problem, our customers have already paid the price for clean air,'' he said. ''We've already paid our dues.''
But Mr. Hawkins of the Resources Defense Council counters: ''If you start handing out allowances to people who burn gas, where do you draw the line?''
At Northeast Utilities, which serves most of Connecticut and part of Massachusetts, Emmanuel S. Forde, a spokesman, said the company was already using fuel with a sulfur content so low that if it had to make further efforts to clean up in order to expand, ''you might have to find a fuel with minus quantities of sulfur.''
 
Many States Have Rules
Most East Coast states have rules that have already accomplished the kind of cleanup that Mr. Bush proposes for utilities in the Midwest that use high-sulfur coal. For many years, New York and Connecticut, for example, have required many generators to use oil with a sulfur content no higher than five-tenths of 1 percent, although cheaper oil with a sulfur content of 2.4 percent is available. In oil, a sulfur content of 1 percent yields 1.2 pounds of sulfur dioxide per one million B.T.U.'s of heat produced, the level that the Bush proposal sets for coal plants in the Midwest.
The Bush proposal is stated in terms of sulfur dioxide output for a given amount of heat produced, regardless of the fuel used. The quantity of heat used as a standard is one million B.T.U.'s, or British thermal units. A B.T.U. is the amount of heat needed to raise the temperature of a pound of water by one degree Fahrenheit. One million B.T.U.'s of heat can run a turbine to produce 100 kilowatt-hours of electricity.
The proposal retricts emissions of sulfur dioxide to no more than 1.2 pounds per million B.T.U.'s used. If the utility already meets that standard, the maximum sulfur dioxide output is set at the level achieved by the utility in 1985.
In New York, the Consolidated Edison Company, one of the cleanest fossil-fuel-burning utilities in the country, said in a statement that the proposal had ''dire implications for the social and economic prospects of New York City and Westchester,'' its service area. The reason, the company said, is that it burned an extraordinarily large proportion of gas in 1985, and would have difficulty reaching that level again. If it wants to add plants, it said, it would have to make existing plants cleaner still.
In 1985, Con Edison's system average was 0.15 pound of sulfur dioxide per million B.T.U.'s; last year, because high demand required burning more oil, the average was 0.19 pound.

HEADLINE: Treasury Sales to Be Concluded This Week

 BODY:
The Treasury's quarterly refinancing, which was postponed for a few days last week as a result of Congress's delay in increasing the nation's debt ceiling, will be concluded this week. Only the three-year note auction was held last week.
Today the Treasury will hold its regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills and will auction 10-year notes. Tomorrow the existing 8 1/8 percent 30-year bond issue will be reopened and auctioned, and on Thursday the Treasury will conduct a regular monthly auction of one-year bills. 
Last Friday, the outstanding three-month bill was bid at 7.72 percent, while the six-month bill was bid at 7.58 percent. The outstanding one-year bill is bid at 7.31 percent. In when-issued-trading the yield on the 10-year Treasury note was 7.88 percent, while the yield on the 30-year bond was 7.89 percent.
The following new fixed-income issues are scheduled this week:

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Stage Seems Set for Lower Rates

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The positive tone in the credit markets that has largely prevailed since mid-year is apt to remain in place well into 1990, analysts said, setting the stage for further reductions in interest rates.
Recent developments, including an unexpected but welcome move by the Federal Reserve Board to shave short-term interest rates and the dramatic thaw in relations with the Eastern bloc have helped reinforce the bullish attitude.
There is a growing sense among a number of economists that business conditions may be far weaker than recent data suggest.
 
'The Market Was Misled'
''The market was misled by the report on output in the third quarter and by the October employment report,'' said Joseph Carson, a senior economist at Chemical Bank. 
Since the preliminary report was issued last month, figures on capital spending, spending on housing and inventory investment have been revised downward, Mr. Carson said.
As a consequence, when a revised measure of real economic growth for the quarter is released later this month, it is likely to show a much lower level of activity than the 2.5 percent rate that was originally reported.
''I think the revised number could be down as much as a full percentage point,'' Mr. Carson said. ''And growth in the fourth quarter is likely to be 1 percent or less. Businesses are becoming less and less certain about a quick turnaround.''
Healthy income growth so far this year suggests that a sharp drop in consumer spending is unlikely, preventing the slowdown from turning into a recession.
But Richard Berner, an economist at Salomon Brothers, said the gains might be short-lived.
''The benefits to discretionary spending power from the summer's dip in energy and other goods prices are waning,'' Mr. Berner notes in the firm's weekly ''Comments on Credit.''
''A less favorable mix between real growth and overall inflation will erode consumer purchasing power and impede the substantial slide in interest rates required to refuel growth in interest-sensitive demands.''
 
Growth Forecast
Despite worries about the consumer and, more important, the economic impact of a continued squeeze on corporate profits, analysts at Salomon forecast growth of 1.5 percent through the middle of next year.
Market participants will be attuned to developments in Washington, where members of the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee, the central bank's policy-making arm, will begin the first of two days of meetings on Tuesday.
After the Fed's easing move last week, analysts do not anticipate the meeting to produce a further immediate change in policy. But additional cuts in the overnight Federal funds rate, which was lowered most recently to 8.5 percent, are likely soon, some said.
''I expect the Fed to ease the funds rate by another quarter of a point before the end of the year,'' Mr. Carson said. ''And by spring we expect to see the funds rate fall by another full percentage point.''
The Fed's action last week prompted some analysts to surmise that a cut in the prime lending rate would be imminent. Indeed two small lending institutions did lower the prime to 10 percent last week.
But officials at large money center banks, who asked not to be identified, said it was unlikely that large lending institutions would cut the prime rate until the funds rate has fallen an additional 25 basis points, to 8.25 percent. The bank officials noted that other financing costs, like the rate on three-month Euro-dollar deposits, have not fallen as rapidly as the Federal funds rate.
Aside from an economic outlook that remains fundamentally positive for the bond market, in the near term recent developments in Eastern Europe in general and East Germany in particular could provide further support.
''As a result of what appears to be historic developments in Europe, over the next couple of weeks we will see more money gravitating to the United States,'' said Ward McCarthy, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a firm in Princeton, N.J., that specializes in analysis and comment on the bond and foreign exchange markets.
''In the near term there will be confusion and uncertainty,'' as a result of the political upheaval in Eastern Europe, Mr. McCarthy said. ''In those sorts of situations, the dollar becomes a magnet.''
Robert A. Brusca, chief economist at Nikko Securities International, said that in comparison with other capital markets, ''interest-sensitive instruments are performing best in the United States.
''With the dollar remaining quite stable, we are going to see a lot of money pouring into this country,'' he said.
The influx of East German refugees into West Germany may provide some short-term stimulus to the dollar, but the longer-range implications of recent developments could reverse that move.
''Over the next few months, the effect of large unrestrained inflows of East Germans means more aggregate demand and more rapid growth in West Germany,'' said Charles Taylor, an international economist at Prudential-Bache Securities. ''To meet this higher aggregate demand, look for higher West German interest rates and a correspondingly higher Deutsche mark.''
The relative attractiveness of America's fixed-income market will be tested at Treasury auctions today and tomorrow, when the Government is expected to sell a total of $20 billion worth of 10-year notes and 30-year bonds.
In recent years strong foreign demand for these securities has been seen as a necessary prerequisite for successful auctions.

HEADLINE: Argentine Chief Clashes With Labor

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 13

 BODY:
Saying he is prepared to face ''a thousand strikes'' to rebuild the Argentine economy, President Carlos Saul Menem has entangled himself in a growing dispute with organized labor, the traditional backbone of his Peronist party.
Job actions are spreading across the country. Public-transportation drivers today ended a weeklong strike in Buenos Aires and other major cities; the metal workers' union says it plans sporadic stoppages for the next two weeks, and a number of other unions are seeking wage settlements that go far beyond Government guidelines.
Finally, Saul Ubaldini, whom Mr. Menem has ousted as the head of the General Labor Confederation, is refusing to vacate the union headquarters, and his organization appears more likely than any other political group to assume the leadership of the political opposition. Mr. Ubaldini is a member of the President's party, officially called the Justicialist Party. 
 
Behind the Dispute
The confrontation is a result of Mr. Menem's commitment to restructure or sell off inefficient and deficit-ridden state companies, to promote exports and to hold down inflation. He is also burdened by $64 billion in foreign debt. No interest on the debt has been paid to creditors for nearly two years.
After rising to a monthly rate of almost 200 percent in July, inflation has tumbled dramatically, hitting 5.9 percent for October.
But the relative success in fighting inflation is based on wage and price guidelines negotiated with business leaders shortly after Mr. Menem took office in July. They are intended to bring stability while the Government tries to rouse the economy by letting state-owned companies go private and creating a more efficient tax-collection system.
The Government has set a guideline of 15 percent for wage increases for the period from October through the end of the year. But it has said it will permit larger wage increases in the private sector as long as business leaders, including the owners of the bus lines, do not raise prices to cover the new costs.
Implicit in this policy is the hope that privately owned industry, faced with Government roadblocks to higher prices, will increase output to meet wage demands. There is also the issue of whether business owners will be forced to give up some of their profit margins, which are believed to be much higher here than in the United States, Japan or Western Europe.
The bus strike took riders and the Government by surprise when it began on Nov. 6. The strike snarled Buenos Aires and many provincial capitals for part of last week, but by the end of the week about half the buses were back on the streets, with the owners or their family members at the wheel. Today, public transportation appeared almost normal.
 
What the Drivers Earn
Striking bus drivers were receiving a basic monthly wage of 36,000 australs, or about $55, until October. They asked for an increase to 88,000 australs. After several rounds of bargaining last week, ordered by the Government, the owners raised their offer to 80,000 australs, but the drivers rejected that. Business leaders say the actual wages of bus drivers are two or three times the basic wage, the result of overtime and off-the-books payments, a common practice to avoid taxes.
Although Mr. Ubaldini, the secretary general of the General Labor Federation, was an important figure in Mr. Menem's election campaign, it became apparent soon after the new President took office that the two would have differences over Mr. Menem's plan to turn aside the Peronist tradition by which the state responds affirmatively to most labor demands.
Convinced that Mr. Ubaldini intended to block his economic plans, Mr. Menem first offered the labor leader a diplomatic post abroad, which he rejected.
Then Mr. Menem created a ''liaison board'' of leaders of the General Labor Federation favorable to his ideas, a group made up largely of leaders of unions in private enterprise and led by Guerino Andreoni of the shopworkers' union. Eventually, that group forced new elections for secretary general of the federation and Mr. Andreoni won after the Ubaldini group boycotted the vote.
Mr. Ubaldini and his aides, however, have continued to occupy the C.G.T. headquarters.
''This is the workers' house,'' he said on Friday. ''This is their leadership, and we're not leaving here.''

HEADLINE: New Lebanese President Names Premier

BYLINE: By ALI JABER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 13

 BODY:
President Rene Moawad appointed a centrist Muslim with long experience in Lebanese politics as Prime Minister today and asked him to form a Cabinet.
The new Prime Minister is Selim al-Hoss, an American-trained economist and advocate of Christian-Muslim co-existence who assumed the role of head of government in 1987 and continued to act as Prime Minister during the last year in a Muslim Government that existed in competition with a Christian government led by Gen. Michel Aoun. Mr. Hoss had also served in two previous Governments, and his appointment had been rumored for several days.
Mr. Hoss resigned as Prime Minister Nov. 5, when members of the Lebanese Parliament elected Mr. Moawad as President under a revised Constitution. The charter, which was drawn up with Arab League approval, is designed to reunite Christians and Muslims under one government by redrawing the power balance between them. It increases the relative power of Muslims to take account of changes in the population since 1943, when the previous Constitution was adopted. 
 
The Leaders Meet
General Aoun and his followers have resisted the new arrangement, but some important elements of the Christian community support it, as do Lebanon's Muslims, Syria and the United States.
After the appointment of Mr. Hoss as Prime Minister, President Moawad, a Maronite Catholic, and Mr. Hoss, a Sunni Muslim, met with Hussein Husseini, the Speaker of Parliament and a Shiite Muslim. Under the Constitution, the three top Lebanese posts are held by representatives of the three dominant religious groups in the country.
Officials close to the Prime Minister said he would seek a Cabinet with 28 ministers, six of whom would represent Lebanon's militias and have no portfolios. The rest would be specialists in areas like the economy and education, or be chosen from Parliament.
The appointment of Mr. Hoss was immediately challenged by General Aoun, who commands the main Christian forces in Lebanon and remains the leader of a rival military cabinet. General Aoun and many of the Christians who dominate in East Beirut oppose Mr. Moawad because he supports a Syrian military role in helping to end Lebanon's 14-year civil war.
The appointment of Mr. Hoss ''would not change anything since the process from the start was unconstitutional,'' the general said today. General Aoun has dismissed the election of Mr. Moawad as illegal and declared Parliament dissolved. He had accused Parliament of compromising Lebanese sovereignty after its remaining members signed the Arab League-sponsored peace accord in Saudi Arabia last month. The accord rested on Syrian promises to redeploy the 40,000 Syrian troops in Lebanon, but did not contain a timetable for their withdrawal.
Today's appointment marked the fourth time that Mr. Hoss has been chosen for the Prime Minister's post since 1976, when he was named to head a Government that tried to rebuild Lebanon after the first two years of civil war.
He has been serving as acting Prime Minister since Rashid Karami was assassinated in the post in June 1987, and he continued in that role last September when an interim Muslim government was formed in competition with General Aoun's Christian cabinet.
Mr. Hoss, who is 60 years old, received a doctorate in economics from Indiana University.
 
U.S. Ambassador May Visit
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (Reuters) -The United States is considering sending its Ambassador back to Lebanon for a brief visit to present his credentials to President Moawad, Administration officials said today.
The Ambassador, John McCarthy, and his staff left Beirut in early September after anti-American protests outside the United States Embassy in East Beirut. The officials want to arrange the trip to show support for the new leader. They declined to discuss a date, citing security reasons.

GRAPHIC: Photo of Selim al-Hoss, who was named Prime Minister of Lebanon yesterday. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: A Puzzle for Zimbabwe: Too Many Elephants

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARARE, Zimbabwe, Nov. 13

 BODY:
Elephant hunting is a big business in this debt-ridden southern African country, a sport indulged in by wealthy Americans able to spend as much as $30,000 for a three-week outing in the bush.
But the popularity of big-game hunting among Americans has left the Bush Administration in an awkward position. On the one hand the United States has strongly supported international efforts to ban the ivory trade, which leads to the devastating poaching of elephants. On the other hand, the Administration has gone on record as backing the stalking of elephants for sport, a pastime popular among well-to-do Americans who covet whole elephant tusks as trophies. 
The contradictory American approach has led to wildlife efforts that seem to be at odds. Although Washington supports international efforts to ban the ivory trade, the United States Agency for International Development recently awarded Zimbabwe and two neighboring countries an $18 million grant for wildlife management that encourages controlled elephant hunting.
Zimbabwe is rich in elephants, and the animals often wreak havoc on fragile arable lands. The country now finds that the enthusiasm in the United States for an international ban on the ivory trade, passed last month at a meeting in Switzerland, is likely to mean the end of Americans coming here on expensive safaris. The safaris helped the Government profit from the necessary culling of elephant herds.
Under Congressional legislation enacted last year and intended to preserve the African elephant, the importing of elephant tusks as trophies was banned except under quotas established by the Conference on International Trade in Endangered Species, which met in Switzerland last month.
But the importing of whole tusks as trophies was banned at the Switzerland meeting, along with imports of ivory for use in jewelry, daggers and carvings. The United States delegation at the meeting stressed the Bush Administration's support for big-game hunting and initially said the ivory ban would not affect hunting for trophies.
After the passage of the ivory ban and the abolition of the trophy quotas, the head of the American delegation, Constance Harriman, Assistant Secretary for Fish and Wildlife in the Department of Interior, tried to get a new set of quotas on tusks enacted. She was rebuffed by other countries, who said it was unreasonable for the United States to favor an ivory ban and also support the importing of tusks as trophies.
For Zimbabwe, the ban on ivory and the United States law forbidding the importing of elephant trophies is a setback to wildlife conservation programs that experts say could be a model for Africa. Unlike many countries in eastern Africa and some in the southern region, where elephants have nearly been killed off by poachers, Zimbabwe has flourishing elephant herds.
 
Safaris Are Very Profitable
Hunting safaris bring in $15 million to Zimbabwe each year, and the sale of tusks from culled elephants brings $1 million more, said Dr. Rowan Martin, deputy director of the Wildlife Department here. Under the Zimbabwean conservation program, which the $18 million A.I.D. grant is supposed to encourage, the country is urging poor farmers to regard elephants and other wildlife as assets rather than as nuisances that trample crops.
With this in mind, farmers in areas with wildlife-conservation programs share in the revenue from safaris as well as in the sale of ivory from culled elephants. In some regions, farmers have set aside parts of their communal farming land to sports hunting because it is more profitable than grain.
''From a conservation point of view, the ivory ban and the hunting legislation is a disaster,'' said Dr. Martin. ''In Africa we want to have a high value on our natural resource of wildlife.''
Dr. Martin said the Government would continue to give export permits to hunters who want to stalk elephants here. ''We're not going to help the United States enforce its law, because we think it is a ridiculous law,'' he said.
Hunters could either try to get their trophies in illegally or leave them in Zimbabwe until the United States legislation is revised, he said.

HEADLINE: MILITARY SPENDING BY SOVIETS SLOWS

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13

 BODY:
United States Government analysts have concluded that the Soviet Union cut military spending in 1989, as President Mikhail S. Gorbachev promised, officials said today.
Some Administration officials, among them Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, have acknowledged in recent weeks that the Soviets have made cuts in the production of conventional weapons, including tanks.
But until now no one in the Administration has stated publicly that overall Soviet military spending for this year will take up a smaller share of the country's gross national product than it did in 1988. The analysts interviewed today say that is in fact the case. 
The analysts making the estimates declined to be identified, but they are among the most authoritative specialists on Soviet military power in the Government.
''We can't tell you the exact amount yet,'' one of the analysts said in an interview. ''But we can confirm that the trend is down and it will involve a reduction in defense spending in real terms.''
 
Final Estimate Due in April
The analysts who reached this conclusion work for Government agencies that monitor internal Soviet developments. Their analysis will form the basis of the annual report on the Soviet economy that the Administration provides each year to the Joint Economic Committee of Congress.
The final estimate of Soviet military spending in 1989 will be provided to the committee around April 1990.
In April, the Joint Economic Committee was informed by Government intelligence experts that Soviet military spending in 1988 was about 15 percent to 17 percent of the Soviet G.N.P., the total value of goods and services produced by the Soviet Union. That constituted a slight increase in military spending from a year earlier.
Although they do not have final figures for 1989, the analysts suggested that their estimate of Soviet military spending as a percentage of the Soviet G.N.P. would slip to between 14 percent and 16 percent.
 
A 'Real Reduction'
Since they also estimate that Soviet G.N.P. for 1989 will be roughly the same as it was in 1988, or perhaps slightly higher, the analysts say this will mean a ''real reduction'' in Soviet military spending. About 50 percent of the Soviet spending goes to manpower, and the rest to new weapons and maintenance.
Because of the difficulties in assigning a real dollar value to the Soviet ruble and other anomalies of the Soviet economy, the analysts declined to put an exact dollar value on the amount of the projected cutbacks.
The C.I.A. estimated in 1988 that Soviet military spending amounted to about $300 billion.
In its annual report to Congress, the Pentagon said that American military spending in recent years had accounted for about 6 percent of the G.N.P. of the United States. ''Up to now Government officials have only hinted at the possibility that total Soviet defense spending may actually be down for 1989,'' said Richard F. Kaufman, a Soviet expert with the Joint Economic Committee of Congress. ''It is interesting that what they have seen in the first 10 months of the year is a strong enough trend for them to conclude that spending will be down for the year.''
 
Revision Is Likely
Even after the official estimate is provided to the Joint Economic Committee in April for the prior year's defense spending, it is often revised upward or downward in the next year or two as more information about the Soviet economy becomes available, Mr. Kaufman said.
As the estimates by analysts for 1989 are completed and are fully distributed throughout the Bush Administration in coming months it will undoubtedly influence the debate about how the United States should respond to Mr. Gorbachev.
Only last week, Vice President Dan Quayle said in an interview with NBC News that Soviet ''military spending, contrary to all these statements that are going on in the Soviet Union over the last four years, has increased.''
''The United States has decreased its military spending, not the Soviet Union,'' he said.
The Vice President's spokesman, David Beckwith, said that Mr. Quayle was referring to the last four years as a whole.
''In 1988 our estimate was that defense spending was growing in the Soviet Union,'' the analyst said. ''What we are seeing in 1989 are actual reductions. They seem to be serious. They have gotten themselves into a terrible economic bind. We can't put an exact number yet on 1989, but we can clearly see the trend.''
''I would expect something like this,'' said Abraham S. Becker, director of the Rand Corporation-U.C.L.A. Center for Soviet Studies, and an expert on the Soviet economy. ''Their G.N.P. was clearly having extraordinary difficulties, so the estimate of virtually no growth is reasonable. At the same time, there is also good evidence they are reducing military expenditures, so we should expect a drop in both actual military expenditures and its ratio to G.N.P.''
The latest official United States Government statement on total Soviet military spending for 1989 came in September, when the Pentagon published its annual report, called ''Soviet Military Power.''
