HEADLINE: Clamor in the East: Legacy of Yalta and Potsdam;
Cold War Sealed Germany's Division

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE

 BODY:
When the war in Europe ended with Nazi Germany's surrender in May 1945, the victorious Americans, British, French and Soviets did not envision the permanent division of Germany and Berlin.
These long-term divisions occurred as the United States and its allies squared off against the Soviet Union and its allies in the postwar confrontation that became known as the cold war.
Yet the divisions had their roots in decisions made during the war and just afterward, when, as Norman J. G. Pounds, an Indiana University professor of geography, once put it, ''the development of the cold war was only vaguely sensed, and the division of Germany was not expected to last more than a very few years.''
 
Zones of Occupation
At the Teheran conference in December 1943, Allied leaders discussed dividing Germany into separate occupation zones with Berlin, in the words of British planners, ''a separate joint zone, occupied by each of the three major allies'' - Britain, the United States and the Soviet Union. France was later included in the arrangement. 
The subject came up again at the Allies' Quebec conference in September 1944, and there, as Churchill later observed, ''the occupational zones were decided rather hastily.''
The following February, the Allied leaders agreed on various aspects of postwar Germany at the Yalta conference, held in the Soviet Ukraine. They put these agreements into effect at the Potsdam conference in July and August 1945 on the outskirts of Berlin.
There, they gave the main governmental authority in the four zones to the Allied commanders for each zone. They also set up a four-power Allied Control Council for questions involving Germany as a whole, and they divided Berlin into four sectors. In addition, they agreed that parts of prewar Germany lying east of the Soviet zone were to be split off and placed under Polish or Soviet control.
 
The Hostility Deepens
Despite the measure of unity achieved at Potsdam, as time passed, suspicion, rivalry and hostility grew between the Western Allies and the Russians. The cleavage also deepened, step by step, between the Western zones and the Soviet zone until the two sides became separate, independent German nations with membership in opposing military alliances - and with separate armies.
An early development in this process came when the Allied Control Council, composed of the commanders of the four occupying armies, worked poorly. The council essentially went out of operation when the Soviets informally withdrew from it in 1948. Similarly, they withdrew from the Kommandatura, a four-power body responsible for governing Berlin. The city's Western sectors came to be essentially unified.
In 1948, the Soviets gradually imposed a blockade on West Berlin, and by August, travel and transportation by land and water between the city and West Germany was cut off. Gen. Lucius D. Clay, the military governor of the American zone, saw the blockade as a power play and pressed the view that it was crucial for the Americans to remain in West Berlin.
He told the Pentagon, as he recalled in his memoirs: ''If we withdraw, our position in Europe is threatened. If America does not understand this now, then Communism will run rampant.'' But the Soviets later asserted that they had mounted the blockade merely to keep a currency reform in western Germany from harming their zone's economy.
 
Berlin Airlift Succeeds
The blockade went on until May 1949. The Allies, with the United States in the lead, mounted the Berlin airlift - sending food and other supplies to the beleaguered West Berliners on relays of aircraft from June 1948 until September 1949.
In that year, with West Berlin unbowed, East Berlin was designated as the capital of the newly created East German nation, the German Democratic Republic.
Afterward, West Berlin formally became one of the states of the new West German nation - the Federal Republic of Germany, which was established in 1949 after a single government had been set up the previous year for the American, French and British occupation zones.
The Western occupation ended, and in 1955 West Germany was acknowledged as a sovereign state and became a member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. In the same year, a sovereign East Germany became a member of the Warsaw Pact.
 
Sharp Economic Differences
With the passage of years, the standard of living in West Berlin and West Germany became so clearly superior to that in the East that East German refugees poured across the still-open boundary between East and West Berlin. The East Germans had earlier taken steps to curb westward emigration across their border.
A continuing exodus through Berlin - largely of productive, younger East Germans - was humiliating and economically costly to the East German Government.
Finally, in August 1961, its police virtually sealed the border between East and West Berlin, and East Germany began the construction of what became a guarded, concrete-and-barbed-wire border wall stretching for almost 30 miles between the eastern and western parts of the city.
The Allies complained but took only limited countermeasures, notably the sending of American tanks in a tense but temporary face-off with Soviet armor at Checkpoint Charlie in Berlin.
Eventually the tension abated, and over the years, various East-West transit agreements were reached for both Germanys and for Berlin. Eventually too, in 1973, the two Germanys acquired separate seats at the United Nations.

GRAPHIC: Photo of an East German border guard patrolled, on the western side, along a barbed wire barricade in August 1961 as West Berliners demonstrated against the closing of border crossings. (UPI); American tanks, foreground, faced a Soviet armored unit in a tense, but temporary, confrontation at Checkpoint Charlie as border was sealed. (AP)

HEADLINE: Clamor in the East: The European Community;
West Europe Is Called Open To Trade With East Germany

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HAKONE, Japan, Nov. 13

 BODY:
A leading trade official of the European Community said today that Western European nations were ''prepared to offer comprehensive agreements on commerce and economic cooperation'' to East Germany in the coming weeks.
Frans Andriessen of the Netherlands, a vice president of the European Community's executive body, left open the possibility that East Germany could apply for membership, saying that ''nothing can be excluded at this point.'' But he said such talk was ''still quite premature.'' 
''That is not the agenda right now,'' said Mr. Andriessen, who is directing the plans of the community for economic integration in 1992. ''The agenda is whether East Germany can continue to foster democracy and economic reform. And the first step is free elections.''
His comments came during an informal annual meeting with the trade ministers of the United States, Canada and Japan at this mountain resort.
 
A Possible Reordering
The main purpose of the meeting is to negotiate changes in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, known as GATT. But the ministers also took the opportunity to discuss a possible reordering of East-West trade relations and economic cooperation in view of the events in Berlin.
The United States is being represented at the talks in Japan by Carla A. Hills, Washington's Special Trade Representative.
Mr. Andriessen did not say what kind of economic aid the community was prepared to offer East Germany, which is trying to invigorate its economy and slow the flood of workers across its newly opened border. He is expected to provide additional details on Wednesday during a speech in Tokyo.
East Germany is a member of Comecon, the Council for Mutual Economic Assistance, which groups the Eastern European and Soviet economies.
 
'Huge Burden' on West Germany
Meeting with reporters today, Mr. Andriessen said it would take the European Community years to absorb the hundreds of thousands of people who have flowed across the borders to West Germany this year.
''This enormous amount of people moving at once creates problems on both sides,'' he said, with East Germany facing a labor shortage and West Germany struggling to create jobs. ''Many of them are not skilled people, so this could place a huge burden on West Germany,'' he said.
While West Germany has a strong demand for skilled labor, economists have expressed fears that the new emigres will find no place to work or live, and severely strain the country's welfare and taxation system. Mr. Andriessen stopped short of suggesting that East Germans think twice before resettling.
''It would be useful if the situation in East Germany became such that no one felt they needed to leave,'' he said. ''But it is another thing for use to recommend what they should do.''
Mr. Andriessen said he planned a trip to East Germany before the end of the year to discuss aid and expand a ''low-key commercial agreement'' with East Germany. ''It might be possible that they want an agreement of a wider scope,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Solidarity's Envoy;
BUSH GIVE WALESA MEDAL OF FREEDOM

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13

 BODY:
Lech Walesa arrived in Washington tonight on his first visit to the United States, looking for funds and support to help build a Poland that he hopes will become ''the America of the East.''
President Bush welcomed Mr. Walesa at the White House, bestowing the Medal of Freedom on the Solidarity leader who led a movement for change that helped displace a Communist government for the first time in Eastern Europe.
In a ceremony tonight in the East Room, before Congressional leaders and Polish-American guests and labor leaders, President Bush hailed Mr. Walesa as ''the spiritural godfather of a new generation of democracy.''
 
Symbol of 'a Lost Era'
''You were called a 'nobody,' '' the President said. ''But Lenin and Stalin have been disproved, not by presidents or princes but by the likes of an electrician from Gdansk and his fellow workers in a brave union called Solidarity. The Iron Curtain is fast becoming a rusted, aboandoned relic, symbolizing a lost era, a failed ideology.'' 
Visiting as East Germans continued to pour throught the newly opened Berlin wall and as yearnings for democracy change Eastern Europe, the Polish labor leader was expected to receive an enthusiastic reception on visits to Washington, New York, Chicago and Philadelphia this week and to Caracas, Venezuela, on Monday.
The President and Mrs. Bush plan to host a small private dinner for Mr. Walesa Tuesday night.
Mr. Walesa was scheduled to speak Tuesday at the AFL-CIO convention and Wednesday at a joint session of Congress. He will be only the second foreign visitor without an official government position to address the legislators. The Marquis de Lafayette, a French general who helped the United States win the American Revolution, spoke at a joint session in 1824.
As Solidarity has changed into a powerful political party, Mr. Walesa has chosen to remain the power behind the throne, supporting the goverment run by his former adviser, Tadeusz Mazowiecki.
 
'Attachments to Freedom'
Hailing the changes that are electrifying Eastern Europe, the President said that some had wondered in the years since World War II ''why we stayed in Berlin.''
''We stayed because we knew,'' he said, ''we just knew, all America, that this day would come.''
Mr. Walesa appeared to be fighting back tears tonight as he listened to Mr. Bush. When it was his turn, he spoke in a strong, happy voice wearing his medal on a ribbon around his neck and standing on a stool provided by the President so that the short, stocky electrician could have stand higher behind the lectern.
He said that, in finally coming to meet his American friends, ''one of the greatest dreams of my life has thus been fulfilled.''
He said that he admired America ''not because it is big or powerful or rich, although you could envy that,'' but because Americans had created a nation of democratic institutions and ''human attachments to freedom.'' $591 Million in Aid Proposed Congress is trying to give Mr. Walesa some, if not all, of the money he wants for his country. On Tuesday, the Senate is expected to consider a foreign aid bill that would provide about $591 million over three years in various forms of aid designed to promote democracy, private enterprise and the development of a free-market economy in Poland.
The legislation has been stalled for several weeks in the Senate, because of wrangling over how much money is appropriate and because of an attempt by Republican Senators to attach Mr. Bush's proposed reduction in the capital gains tax to the measure. Once the Senate approves its version of the bill the leaders of both houses hope to act quickly on a compromise version so the final package can be in place before Congress adjourns later this month.
Even if the legislation is approved, however, another measure that actually allocates the aid money faces the possibility of a Presidential veto. Mr. Bush has said he would veto the bill if Congress passes the current version, which includes money for the United Nations Fund for Population Activity, which the Administration contends is participating in the management of a program in China that involves coercive abortions. Congressional and White House officials are looking for a compromise.
 
Canadian Efforts Criticized
OTTAWA, Nov. 13 (Reuters) - Mr. Walesa sharply criticized Canadian aid efforts today as too little and too late.
''What Canada is proposing right now would be similar to giving a corpse a beautiful new tie,'' Mr. Walesa told a parliamentary committee on the last day of a three-day visit to Canada.
Last month Canada announced $36 million in new aid to Poland and Hungary and the establishment of a development fund.
Prime Minister Brian Mulroney met Mr. Walesa for about half an hour, then pledged further steps, including a rescheduling of repayment terms on Canada's loans to Poland.

HEADLINE: 'Unpopular Measures' Urged for Soviet Economy

BYLINE: By ESTHER B. FEIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Nov. 13

 BODY:
Warning that consumers' trust is ''running dry'' and that the economy is in danger of ''a creeping return backward,'' President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's chief economic adviser called today for adopting ''strict and unpopular measures'' to invigorate the country's fledgling economic restructuring program.
At the opening session of a three-day conference on radical economic reform, the adviser, Deputy Prime Minister Leonid A. Abalkin, told top officials of the government and Communist Party and the country's leading economists that Mr. Gorbachev's program of perestroika was doomed unless officials devised a comprehensive and doubtlessly painful strategy for putting it into practice.
''Without instituting strict and unpopular measures, we will be thrown back,'' Mr. Abalkin said. Many people have wonderful ideas about a healthy Soviet economy, he said, but ''nobody knows how to get from our current situation to this beautiful picture.'' 
The high-level gathering, attended by Mr. Gorbachev and other members of the Communist Party's ruling Politburo, takes place against a dire economic backdrop, with industrial growth mired at 1 percent for the third quarter of this year, the value of the ruble dropping on both the official and black markets and consumers increasingly pessimistic about the government's ability to change the situation.
The conference is an attempt by the leadership to form a consensus among the country's officials and economists on the direction and methods needed to ''jump start'' the perestroika program, which has been foundering since it was approved by the Communist Party at a plenum in June 1987.
But serious disagreement among the participants was apparent from the start. Some of those present in the Grand Hall of Columns attacked Mr. Abalkin's proposals as being either too radical or too insipid.
 
Stock Market Foreseen
The plan includes diverse forms of property and ownership, using the market as the main mechanism for regulating the economy, loosening price controls and introducing partial convertibility of the ruble.
It also foresees the establishment of a stock market, anti-monopoly laws and the conversion of the state-controlled economy to a mixture of state-run industries, publicly owned enterprises and private cooperatives, all to be implemented within six years.
Abel G. Aganbegyan, a senior government economic adviser and a deputy chairman of the conference, said the leadership was being too overprotective of the population and too willing to soften the blows that fundamental restructuring demands. ''Urgent measures are those which are felt by the people,'' Mr. Agenbegyan said. ''Those with no effect, only existing on paper, are not real measures.''
Ed Hewitt, an American expert on the Soviet economy, said that if the plan as drafted was implemented within the designated six-year period it had a ''decent chance'' for success.
''They spent these past few years learning by doing and learning by crashing,'' Mr. Hewitt said at a break in the session, which was broadcast on closed-circuit television to journalists at the Foreign Ministry press center.
The thorniest issues being debated at the conference, and in general in the Soviet press and in the new Soviet legislature, are price reform and private property.
Mr. Gorbachev and many economists have argued about the need to do away with artificial price controls, but their efforts have been stymied by public opposition. This month, the Soviet legislature rejected a proposal to raise prices on luxury items like cigarettes, caviar and beer, saying it would hurt too many people.
And while the program calls for ''diversity of the forms of property'' as a ''fundamental condition for the economic freedom of citizens, the proposal has many opponents. An article on Sunday in the Communist Party newspaper Pravda, laying out proposals for a new party code, suggests that party members who support private property would do well to ''belong to some other organization.''

HEADLINE: Tidioute Journal;
An Answer To Prayer In Water Made Pure

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TIDIOUTE, Pa.

 BODY:
This picturebook borough, with its white church steeples and suspension bridge across the Allegheny River here in the northwest corner of state, never quite recovered from the Great Depression that wiped out its oil and timber industries.
When the community's water became contaminated in 1987, many residents were ready to give up on the place and move on. But the story has a happy ending, or at least a prayer for one.
''When the water became contaminated, it was the last straw,'' said Sara Davis, a member of the borough's business development association. ''We all considered wearing T-shirts saying, 'Last one out of Tidioute, turn out the lights.' '' 
In recent years, fires took a third of the storefronts on Main Street, a tornado wrecked many houses and many young people moved away to find work. The population of Tidioute (pronounced tidTID-ee-oot) became predominately elderly and poor.
Then, on the Christmas Eve of 1987, state officials found that the stream supplying Tidioute's 840 residents with water was contaminated with Giardia lamblia, an organism causing severe intestinal illness. The village could not afford to upgrade its water-treatment plant - a tank of chlorine in a dilapidated shed - and banks became reluctant to write new mortgages. Real estate prices sagged.
The hero of the story is a state program with an unromantic name -the Pennsylvania Infrastructure Investment Authority, or Pennvest. The agency solved Tidioute's problems by subsidizing the cost of a $485,000 water filtration system, which is to begin operation this month. When it does, residents will no longer have to boil their tap water.
Pennvest provides local governments with up to $500,000 in low-interest loans and grants for projects involving drinking water or waste water improvements. Launched with $1 billion raised by bond sales last year, Pennvest is designed to subsidize up to 1,500 projects over the next 25 years. So far, $357 million has been spent on 218 projects.
The drinking water part of the program is designed to help small systems comply with Federal standards, in particular one requiring water authorities to filter all surface water supplies to remove disease-causing microorganisms. Pennsylvania has more than 2,100 small water systems, and the state relies on surface water more than any other in the nation. Pennsylvania has also led the nation in the number of waterborne disease outbreaks, reporting 28,760 cases from 1971 to 1985, according to the Federal Centers for Disease Control.
''It knocked my block off that this state led the nation in waterborne diseases,'' said Gov. Robert P. Casey. ''I felt we needed to clean up our water for health and safety, but also as a tool for economic development.''
Across the nation, there are thousands of small communities like Tidioute. Community water systems that each serve fewer than 3,300 people now account for 92 percent of all Federal regulatory violations, according to the Environmental Protection Agency. But communities have not been pressed to toe the line on regulaations because state and Federal agencies say they lack the resources for enforcement. Of the 97,000 violations issued by the Federal agency last year, enforcement actions were taken by Federal and state agencies in only 2,450 cases. The Federal agency maintains that most violations involve lapses in paper work and water-quality monitoring.
But the National Wildlife Federation plans to sue the Federal agency to make it enforce its regulations. About 13 million people drank water last year that the Government considered unsafe, said Norman L. Dean, a federation spokesman.
Without programs like Pennvest, small communities across the nation will be hard pressed to comply with existing water standards, said Arnie Edelman, the environmental program adviser with the National Association of Towns and Townships, a lobbying organization. So far, only a dozen states have any program comparable to Pennsylvania's.
In Tidioute, meanwhile, the residents are counting their blessings. At a recent banquet that celebrated the completion of their new water purification system, Dana Bierer, a local developer, said this grace: ''Thank you, Father, for the water project. We pray that it will work.''

CORRECTION-DATE: November 21, 1989, Tuesday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article on Nov. 14 headed ''Tidioute Journal,'' about a Pennsylvania town that overcame water pollution problems, understated the sum made available by the state to improve drinking water and waste systems. A state agency, Pennvest, offers grants of up to $500,000 a community and loans of up to $10 million or in some cases more.

HEADLINE: Enough Foot Dragging on a Rail Link Vital to New York City

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your Oct. 27 editorial supporting completion of the Oak Point link, a railroad trestle connecting rail lines to a planned rail freight terminal at the Harlem River yard in the South Bronx, is right. Completing this long-planned project would save New York City businesses more than $100 million a year in transportation costs and dramatically reduce traffic congestion and air pollution by removing hundreds of thousands of truck trips from New York City streets. Taking freight traffic off city streets and putting it on railroad cars is vital to the city's economic and physical health. It is unfortunate that this project is on the point of abandonment. 
You are incorrect, however, in blaming the New York State Legislature. The Legislature appropriated funds for the link, and even added language to the fiscal year 1988-89 budget declaring the link the ''highest state priority'' and prohibiting the State Department of Transportation from spending funds to study abandoning it. Unfortunately, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo vetoed this language.
It is the Department of Transportation that first stalled the link for years and then, after having paid a private contractor $45 million for work on the link, decided the work had been done incorrectly, released the contractor from its obligations and halted all further work. Now, after having wasted $45 million, the department says it does not have enough money to complete the link and is looking for alternative limited uses for the Harlem River yard without completion of the link.
The public is entitled to expeditious completion of the link and to an explanation of how $45 million was expended to no purpose. All we have been told so far is that ''an engineering mistake was discovered.'' We need to know who was responsible for the ''mistake.'' Either the $45 million should be recovered from the contractor, or some senior Department of Transportation officials should be held publicly accountable.
The history of the Oak Point link is one of ineptitude and foot dragging. A vital project that should have been completed in 1982 is at a standstill seven years later, $45 million has been wasted, and the Transportation Department proposes to cover up this sordid history by abandoning the entire project. The department should be reminded of its responsibilities, the project should be completed, and those responsible for the delays and the waste of money should be held to account.
 
JERROLD NADLER
Assemblyman, 67th District
 Albany, Oct. 31, 1989

HEADLINE: A Judge Delays Rules On Tenant Succession

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Nov. 13

 BODY:
A state judge today issued a temporary order preventing the state's housing agency from enforcing new rules that would give unrelated people the right of succession in rent-stabilized apartments.
The rules were issued last week, and were to take effect immediately. The order issued today by a State Supreme Court justice in Albany prevents them from taking effect until at least Nov. 28.
The order was a result of a lawsuit brought by a landlords' group, the Rent Stabilization Association.
The rules were adopted by the state's Division of Housing and Community Renewal in response to a decision by the state's highest court earlier this year that extended the right of succession to nontraditional family members in rent-controlled apartments.
The rules extended those rights to people in almost one million rent-stabilized apartments, mainly in New York City.

HEADLINE: F.D.A. Commissioner Reassigned In Aftermath of Agency Scandals

BYLINE: By PHILIP J. HILTS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13

 BODY:
The Bush Administration has shifted Food and Drug Commissioner Frank E. Young to a less influential job created for him at the Department of Health and Human Services.
Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, the department's Secretary, in announcing the shift today, cited no reasons for the change. But Dr. James O. Mason, the Assistant Secretary of Health and Dr. Young's immediate supervisor, said he asked the commissioner to leave his position and to accept the new job, citing a variety of reasons, including discovery of corruption in the agency's regulation of generic drugs..
Dr. Young's five-and-a-half-year tenure at the Food and Drug Administration, which has suffered budget and personnel cuts over the last decade, has been praised by industry for a more cooperative attitude about regulation and the streamlining of the approval process for life-saving drugs. But he was also criticized by Congressional leaders and consumer groups for the looser regulatory approach that they contend led to some of the agency's problems. 
 
A Slow Response to AIDS
Among those are a slow response to the AIDS epidemic, Dr. Young's temporary and costly halt of imported Chilean fruit after discovery of two cyanide-laced grapes, the scandal over corruption in approval of generic drugs, the proliferation of misleading health claims on food packages and the newly emerging controversy over deaths and injuries from medical devices.
In announcing the move, Dr. Sullivan emphasized Dr. Young's acceptance of his new post of Deputy Assistant Secretary of Health for health science and environment. ''Frank Young is a man of great intelligence,'' Dr. Sullivan said. ''His scientific credentials are impressive. I know that he will apply his skills as tirelessly in his new position as he did as commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration.''
Dr. Young would not comment on the reasons for the shift. ''Looking back is never a good idea,'' he said in an interview tonight. ''For a variety of reasons, change is appropriate now.''
 
Oversees Quarter of Economy
The agency now regulates one quarter of the nation's consumer economy, according to some estimates, but has had fewer resources to handle increasing responsibilities. In 1979 the agency had about 8,100 employees, compared with the current 7,500, despite the added burden of AIDS and other work. The budget grew little. Dr. Young's tenure has been called a transitional one in which the agency shifted from an adversial stance toward industry to a ''partnership'' with industry.
This deregulatory approach earned him praise from industry and from others like some AIDS activists who benefited from the speedier approval of drugs.
Critics, however, have said the looser regulatory approach has led to a series of regulatory catastrophes, from the proliferation of misleading health claims on food packages to the recent revelations that at least three agency officials took bribes from generic drug manufacturers, that two generic drug manufacturers submitted false data to the agency, and that manufacturing and record-keeping problems existed at a dozen generic drug companies the F.D.A. investigated.
Dr. Mason said Dr. Young's major achievement in his years at the agency was overseeing the move to a quicker approval of life-saving drugs. The average approval time for such drugs has dropped from 7.1 years before Dr. Young's tenure to 4.7 years.
AIDS activists have said that while they do not believe Dr. Young acted quickly enough to get drugs to those dying of AIDS, they do credit him with responding to their criticism. ''I have no doubt that he believed he was changing the agency attitude from one in which it tried to save people from harming themselves to one allowing dying people to take some of the risk themselves,'' said Jim Eigo of the activist group AIDS Coalition to Unleash Power.
Dr. James Wyngaarden, nominated to be associate director for health sciences in the White House Office of Science and Technology Policy, said Dr. Young ''has done a spectacular job, taking on larger and larger responsibilities while his resources were going down.
''He gave the job real stability after there had been great turnover,'' Dr. Wyngaarden said, ''and he showed a real willingness to tackle hard issues.''
 
Reagan Administration Blamed
Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, was one of those chiefly responsible for pressing the investigation of the generic-drug scandal. ''Frank Young had the misfortune to preside at the F.D.A. during a time when it was virtually guaranteed that rogues and knaves would prosper,'' Mr. Dingell said. ''His intentions were good and he did his best when problems were brought to light. But he was handicapped by both the budgets and attitudes of an Administration that let the agency go to seed.''
Dr. Sidney M. Wolfe, director of the consumer activist Public Citizen Health Research Group called Young ''the worst F.D.A. commissioner'' in the 18 years that Dr. Wolfe's group has monitored the agency. He cited Dr. Young's failure to ban unpasteurized milk, which a court later forced the agency to do, and his belated requirement forcing aspirin manufacturers to warn consumers that taking aspirin during some illnesses has been linked to the rare but fatal Reye's syndrome.
Federal officials said Dr. Young would leave the agency Dec. 18 and soon thereafter would be replaced by an interim commissioner. No names have been mentioned publicly for the job, but one Federal official said a leading contender is Dr. Burton J. Lee, the President's personal physician.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1, Column 3; Science Desk

LENGTH: 2773 words

HEADLINE: Governments Start Preparing for Global Warming Disasters

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS

 BODY:
IN the quickening international debate over global warming, the spotlight has played mostly on the question of how and whether to control the growing emissions of carbon dioxide and other gases that trap heat in the atmosphere.
Now another concern is starting to come to the fore as well. No matter what action is taken, some scientists say, there are already enough of these ''greenhouse'' gases in the atmosphere to cause a major warming, and more are certain to accumulate before the buildup can be halted.
As a result, climatologists, social scientists, planners and government officials are beginning to focus on how society might adapt to rising sea levels, shifting agricultural zones, changing climates and other problems that global warming would bring if it occurs on a significant scale.
Already, state and local governments along the coast of the United States are starting to plan for a possible long-term rise in the sea level, and a few have taken action to cope with it. In the Netherlands, planning is well advanced for an expansion of that country's system of dikes, dunes and other coastal defenses, and the Dutch are also offering their expertise to Indonesia and the Maldives. 
Agricultural researchers are stepping up efforts to develop heat-resistant and drought-resistant crops that might gradually replace traditional crops if the climate changes.
And the electric power industry in America is planning how to meet the increase in the demand for power for air-conditioning that would surely result from global warming. In one of the first studies, the Electric Power Research Institute has calculated that for every 1.8 degrees Fahrenheit in climatic warming, power demand in the summer would rise 2 to 3 percent in the New York metropolitan area - enough to have a sizable effect on the region's limited generating capacity.
These stirrings are somewhat tentative, both because of uncertainty about the whole question of global warming and because of a tendency on the part of some environmentalists and politicians to play down the question of adaptation for fear it will divert attention from what they see as an overriding need to limit production of the greenhouse gases.
But reining them in is bound to be difficult. The world economy runs on fossil fuels, and burning these fuels generates increasing amounts of carbon dioxide, the most important greenhouse gas. Weaning the world away from them is likely to be a long and costly business. For developing countries especially, fossil fuels are tightly linked to prospects for development and a better life for their peoples, leaving those countries reluctant to give up the fuels.
As the difficulty of reducing greenhouse emissions has come home, the focus has shifted somewhat ''from prevention to a focus on adaptation,'' said Michael H. Glantz of the National Center for Atmospheric Research in Boulder, Colo. Dr. Glantz, a social scientist, heads a group that studies the impact of climatic change on societies. And while a number of environmentalists, scientists and officials continue to believe that the first priority should be a reduction of emissions of greenhouse gases, some are now saying that adaptation must be considered as well.
In a report to President Bush earlier this year, the National Academy of Sciences argued that adaptive measures should be assigned a high priority. ''We are already irrevocably committed to major global change in the years ahead,'' the report said, expressing the view prevalent among climatologists. ''The elevated concentrations of greenhouse gases produced to date by human activities will persist for many centuries and will slowly change the climate of the earth, regardless of our actions.''
Still, although many scientists agree on the broad outlines of global climate change, the system is so complex they cannot predict exactly how great the change will be or when and how it will affect specific regions.
This uncertainty means that in planning for a broad range of long-term activities like coastal development, construction of ports, location of waste-disposal sites, water projects and agricultural enterprises, flexibility is crucial, the academy told Mr. Bush.
In studying and planning for the expected impact of global warming, the Environmental Protection Agency is emphasizing this need for flexibility. ''You've got to leave yourself leeway,'' said John Hoffman, the director of the agency's global change division.
The planning options for industrialized countries, with all their resources, are numerous, the academy's report said. But that is not the case for many developing countries. For instance, a one-meter rise in sea level, which some experts consider likely by the end of the next century, would cover broad areas of Bangladesh, Indonesia and Southeast Asia holding some of the world's largest populations and richest agricultural lands. Those countries, experts say, simply do not have the resources to deal with such a disaster.
Some experts, moreover, express concern that the industrialized countries, following a well-documented human tendency, will not take adaptive action until disaster is near, when it may be too late.
 
The Science
Complexity Makes Prediction Chancy
In the greenhouse effect, energy from the sun is trapped in the earth's atmosphere by carbon dioxide, methane, chlorofluorocarbons and other trace gases. The more gases, the more heat is trapped.
Carbon dioxide, the principal greenhouse gas, is emitted by the burning of fossil fuels. Scientists say atmospheric concentrations of all these gases combined have increased from about 280 parts per million of carbon dioxide at the start of the industrial age almost 200 years ago to the equivalent of 400 parts per million today. At the present rate of increase, scientists say that the level will grow to 570 parts per million, more than double the pre-industrial level, possibly as early as 2030.
Scientists calculating from mathematical models of the earth's atmosphere say this doubling could cause the atmosphere to warm by 3 to 8 degrees Fahrenheit. By comparison, the atmosphere has warmed by about 9 degrees since the end of the last ice age. But climatic and atmospheric change is so complex that there is great uncertainty about the predictive accuracy of the models.
How long it will take for maximum warming to be reached is uncertain because the oceans slow such warming. Most scientists expect the maximum warming to take place by the second half of the next century.
If change is slow enough, the Environmental Protection Agency said earlier this year in a report to Congress, adaptation may be manageable. But a sudden or rapid change, it said, might make it problematic.
 
Sea-Level Rise
Defending Coasts Is a Concern
A rise in sea level is ''one of the most certain impacts of climate change,'' the agency said in its report to Congress. Higher global temperatures would probably cause glaciers to melt, as well as leading to an expansion of the oceans because warm water occupies a larger volume of space than cold water. If levels of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere double, sea levels will rise; estimates of the average rise are from 1.5 feet to 6.5 feet. Some leading experts regard a rise of 1 meter, a little more than three feet, as most likely. They expect it to occur gradually in the next century, affecting coastal areas where about a billion people, a quarter of the world's population, now live.
In adapting to global warming, ''the primary issue is coastal defense,'' said Michael Oppenheimer, a senior scientist with the Environmental Defense Fund. ''Planning for sea-level rise must be done decades in advance of the actual unfolding of the consequences. If you're going to protect such areas with seawalls, or carry out a careful retreat of populations, which will be inevitable in some cases, or protect houses, those are measures that must be planned many decades ahead of time.''
Gjerrit P. Hekstra, an ecologist in the environmental protection branch of the government of the Netherlands, said defending a settled coastline or coastal city from rising seas requires ''a complete restructuring of your hydrological infrastructure - ship channels, dikes, canals, rivers, everything.''
Dr. Hekstra's country has been doing that for many decades, and the experience of the Netherlands may prove instructional for much of the rest of the world. For the Dutch, adapting to a sea-level rise means simply an expansion of the elaborate, modern coastal defense system it has developed in the last 30 years. Government studies have shown that to protect the country from a sea-level rise of 1 meter will require an investment, over the long term, of up to $10 billion. The Netherlands has already spent $15 billion on coastal defense in the last three decades.
Coastal defense means building dikes and piling up sand on the coast to strengthen dunes and sculpting rivers and canals to keep sea water from penetrating the soil and ruining both fresh water supplies and agricultural land. Dr. Hekstra said it is his opinion as a private ecologist that all this is well within existing technology and requires only money.
''So I don't think your country and my country is the real problem,'' he said. That is not to minimize the problem, he said, since the United States would have to spend billions of dollars to defend coastal cities and developments against a one-meter rise in sea level and might well have to abandon some low-lying regions altogether.
''We can cope,'' Dr. Hekstra said. ''But not Indonesia, not Bangladesh, not Vietnam. They don't have the resources to do it. Who's going to pay the bill for the developing countries?'' In the United States, the E.P.A. has made extensive studies of the effect of a rise in the sea level, and most coastal states are beginning to plan for it. Questions being examined include not only coastal defense but matters like beach erosion and the intrusion of salt water into rivers and bays where it would foul drinking-water supplies. Possible solutions to salt-water intrusion include the construction of barrier dams in estuaries and canals to divert the salt water from drinking water intakes. Close attention is also being paid to the control of hazardous-waste disposal sites in areas likely to flood.
Most of the efforts are in early stages. But ''I haven't talked to a single coastal state that isn't doing some hard thinking about this and where the government is starting to put together some plans,'' said Thomas W. Curtis, the director of the natural resources group of the National Governors' Association.
South Carolina, North Carolina, Maine and Florida, with sea-level rise in mind, have all enacted standards designed to control construction on their shorelines.
 
Water Resources
Shortages Likely For California
Some predictions of climate change, admittedly chancy, forecast drier conditions for much of the American West, with serious consequences for a region where water scarcity is already a major factor of life and prosperity. The E.P.A. study for Congress, for instance, found that California's water demand could increase, even as water supplies decrease. The decrease would come about partly because more snow would melt in the winter and less in the summer. Since reservoirs do not have the capacity to store all the winter runoff, spring and summer water supplies would drop.
Experts say that a number of adaptive measures could help in such a situation. These could be as simple as lining irrigation systems so that less water is wasted or expensive solutions like building larger reservoirs or even such a harsh measure, should water become scarce enough, as imposing high prices on it.
''Despite a growing awareness of the problem, the institutions involved in managing our water resources are not really taking account of the greenhouse effect,'' said Peter H. Gleick, director of the global environment program of the Pacific Institute for Studies in Development, Environment and Security, a nonprofit research institute in Berkeley, Calif.
''The difficulty is that we don't know how precipitation patterns are going to change,'' said Dr. Oppenheimer of the Environmental Defense Fund. This, he said, underscores the limitations of adaptation.
 
Agriculture
Crop Adaptation Seems Promising
No more critical activity stands to be profoundly affected by global warming than agriculture, but scientists also consider it one of the most adaptable.
Almost all the crops now grown in the United States, for example, originally came from some other part of the world and were adapted to this continent.
Building on this tradition, the Federal Department of Agriculture is preparing to ease the way for whatever transplants might be required by global warming. Jim Duke, an economic botanist at the department's research center in Beltsville, Md., has been collecting data for some years on the temperature and rainfall conditions in which 1,000 agricultural plants flourish. He is now preparing to use this data in mathematical models of climate, which would tell what crops would adapt best if, for instance, New York's average temperature rose three degrees and its rainfall also increased.
The E.P.A. report to Congress said that warming might force abandonment of 10 to 50 percent of the Southeast's agricultural acreage.
''We might lose the conventional crops'' in the Southeast, said Dr. Duke. ''But assuming we didn't go dry, we would bring in semitropical crops. It's just a matter of selecting variety. We could bring in a wealth of tropical fruits and vegetables.''
At the same time, agricultural researchers around the world have long been striving, through both genetic and cultivation techniques, to make many crops more adaptable to harsh environments. Gary Evans, a special assistant for global change issues at the Department of Agriculture, said, ''We are augmenting most of our current plant-stress programs with an eye to what would take place if temperature or moisture shifted.''
Researchers are also striking out in new directions with important implications for adaptation to global warming. At the University of Arizona, for instance, researchers led by Carl N. Hodges are experimenting with getting plants to grow in sea water. If they succeed, the technique could save fresh water in arid areas near oceans.
In Israel's Negev Desert, a team led by Yosef Misrahi of Ben Gurion University of the Negev is growing fruits and nuts at temperatures higher than 115 degrees. In the same area, the Jewish National Fund, the Israeli agency in charge of forestry and land conservation, is experimenting with a genetically improved species of loblolly pine, using seedlings donated by the Georgia-Pacific Corporation. Much of this sort of research is directly related to the prospect of global warming.
 
Prospects
Seeds of Change In Hurricane
Even before Hurricane Hugo, Charleston, S.C., was attuned to two of the major effects scientists expect from global warming: a rising sea level and more frequent and more potent hurricanes. It had already required new buildings near the shore to be built far enough off the ground to escape flooding, which they did in the hurricane. The city had also begun installing pumping stations to insure proper drainage, unlike the situation with sewers that work by gravity, which do not drain when rising water covers their outlets.
But the hurricane certainly made a difference. ''The hurricane deepened our resolve,'' Mayor Joseph P. Riley of Charleston said, ''and made us more confident that our decisions along those lines were wise ones, and it certainly deepened our commitment to new ways of thinking and acting.''
That, according to the conclusions of a study directed by Dr. Glantz of the National Center for Atmospheric Research, is how action to combat a long-term threat usually gets started. A number of case studies sponsored by the center found that a catalyst was usually necessary before governments would act. Once they did act, ad hoc responses were favored over longer-term, planned responses.
These responses, the study concluded, ''have often built into the existing social structures an additional degree of rigidity'' that make it more difficult to adapt flexibly.
Those charcteristics illustrate the difficulties of adaptation, Dr. Glantz said, especially in a situation so fraught with uncertainty as global warming, where the threat, however serious it ultimately proves to be, may not become readily apparent for years or even decades.

HEADLINE: Review/Television;
Adam Smith Examines Trade With Russia

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
The Soviet Union is no doubt as meager an exporter of consumer goods as the experts on tonight's edition of ''Adam Smith's Money World'' report, but under Mikhail S. Gorbachev it has come up with a couple of hot sellers for America's public affairs programs - glasnost and perestroika.
Tonight's interesting example, on Channel 13 at 9:30 P.M., asks what's in it for the United States? With a Marriott Hotel opening in Poland, Estee Lauder taking beauty to Budapest and Pepsico's expanding operations in the Soviet Union soon to feature a Pizza Hut close by the Kremlin, the question is plainly in fashion.
Donald Kendall, the head of Pepsico, who has been doing business with the Russians for a decade, notes that the Soviet Union is Pepsi-Cola's biggest overseas market. The Soviet worker, with so little to spend his rubles on, can evidently afford a Pepsi and thereby participate in the American dream. The made-for-Moscow commercials for the soft drink are a gas. 
In a conversation with George J. W. Goodman (Adam Smith in the flesh and spectacles), Mr. Kendall urges American businessmen to try to satisfy the long unsatisfied desires of Russia's consumers quickly, before the Europeans and Japanese move in. All those millions eager for a chance to buy kitchen appliances, clothes and much else besides Pepsi hold out a seemingly irresistible invitation to the American entrepreneurial spirit.
But as several Russia-watchers caution, the invitation is hedged with hazards. The American go-getter has to be prepared for the built-in obstacles of Communist society. There are such practical difficulties as a lack of trade agreements and the unconvertibility of the ruble - and one knowing observer compares many Russians' attitude toward money to the attitude of schoolgirls toward sex - a sort of frightened fascination.
Moreover, the experts note that the dissatisfation and unrest now prevailing in the Soviet Union do not make a reassuring climate for investors. Things are not going all that well for Mr. Gorbachev's economic restructuring, and as Andrei Stroyer, a Soviet official who has been studying American business methods, observes, there may not be much time. ''The only way for our country,'' he says, ''is reform, very active and very fast.'' But can it come fast enough? And if Mr. Gorbachev's promises are not realized and the chronic shortage of all sorts of goods is not soon alleviated, will the old-line antagonists of a liberated market return to power? What American businessman wants to put money into so shaky a situation?
On the brighter side, Mr. Kendall holds out the hope that as both Moscow and Washington reduce their expenditures on arms and increase trade, the American economy can only benefit. The Soviet Union, he points out, is one of the few countries with which the United States has a favorable balance of trade, so why not increase it.
A half-hour is hardly enough time to begin a discussion on so big a subject, but by focusing on the American interest in perestroika, tonight's program becomes manageable, and no doubt there will be follow-ups. Sunde Smith's production, particularly the use of those Pepsi commercials, keeps things lively, and Mr. Goodman's interviews are as businesslike as they usually are in his ''Money World.''

COMPANIES

HEADLINE: Price Revolt Spreading On Prescription Drugs

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
Beginning a buyer's revolt against sharply rising prescription drug prices, a growing number of state government and employer health plans are trying to force pharmaceutical companies to trim prices on brand-name products.
To back up their demands for discounts and rebates, the state and private health plans are threatening to drop some products from their lists of drugs approved for reimbursement.
The lists already favor low-priced generic versions of drugs that have lost patent protection. But now the health plans are demanding bids from makers of competing brand-name drugs that have no generic equivalents. Some health plans are even talking of boycotting some products of companies that refuse to cooperate. 
 
A Price Surge Since '80
''We want to send a signal out to the physician, the pharmacy and the manufacturer that there has to be an end to tolerance of rising costs,'' said Dan Heslin, director of employee benefits at Rockwell International, an aerospace company that is negotiating with drug makers on prices and is even opening its own pharmacies to buy drugs in bulk at lower prices.
The price of drugs has risen 88 percent since 1980, ''and it continues to go upward,'' said Senator David Pryor, Democrat of Arkansas, chairman of the Senate Aging Committee, which plans hearings on prescription drug prices for Thursday.
The Labor Department said prescription drug prices rose 9.2 percent in September from the month a year earlier, more than double the Consumer Price Index. Americans will spend $40 billion on drugs and related products this year, according to Federal statisticians.
 
Drug Makers Fight Back
The drug companies have been fighting the price demands. In California and Kansas, for example, they have been lobbying for legislation that would prohibit state Medicaid programs from excluding higher-priced products, arguing that such policies amount to second-class medical treatment for the poor. And while some pharmaceutical companies have agreed to discuss prices with some large employers and insurers, the purchasers say the companies have refused to give discounts and rebates on brand-name products, except to hospitals and large health maintenance organizations.
Hospitals and some H.M.O.'s have secured price concessions because they shortened the lists of drugs their physicians prescribe, putting pressure on the manufacturers to make deals. But patients not in H.M.O.'s who are covered by employers and Medicaid buy their drugs at thousands of pharmacies that do not have unified buying power. (The Medicare program for the elderly and disabled does not cover prescription drugs outside the hospital, and an expansion of the program to cover such expenses is virtually dead in Congress.) In the political battling over drug prices, the health plans leading the revolt are supported by advocates for the elderly, who use more than 30 percent of all prescription products, and for people with AIDS.
They cite as examples the $6,500 annual cost of AZT, the only federally approved AIDS drug; $6,240 a year for erythropoietin, for anemia associated with kidney dialysis, and $1,375 a year for Eldepryl, a promising new drug for Parkinson's disease.
''Seventy percent of elderly Americans have no insurance for prescription drugs,'' Senator Pryor said.
 
'A Collision Course'
John Rother, legislative director in Washington for the American Association of Retired Persons, an advocacy group, said, ''Drug prices are on a collision course with the political interests of business, older people and government.'' John R. McHugh, president of the group's mail-order drug service, said, ''The brand-name manufacturers' prices in the last few years have been unconscionable.''
Representatives of the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association, an industry trade group, said prices were rising because the revenues had to finance large research and development programs. They said the companies spent $6.5 billion on research, or 16.3 percent of their $46.2 billion in worldwide sales last year. ''Costs of labor, materials, taxes and promotion have also increased in recent years,'' said Gerald J. Mossinghoff, the association president.
He said drugs, including those for ulcers and high blood pressure, had yielded enormous savings in overall spending on hospital care.
Securities analysts said drug makers have often raised prices to increase earnings even though sales as measured in units have been stagnant over all - about 1.5 billion prescriptions a year since 1982. #21% Increases in '89 The Upjohn Company, for example, has raised the price of both Xanax, a tranquilizer, and Halcion, a sedative, by 21 percent since January, as the number of prescriptions written for both products was dropping, said Ronald Nordmann, an analyst at Paine Webber Securities.
Because benzodiazepines like Xanax and Halcion can be addictive and their effects are often compounded by alcohol, physicians have begun to limit prescriptions for both drugs. New York State restricts the number and frequency of benzodiazepine prescriptions. And a Food and Drug Administration advisory committee recently recommended that Upjohn be required to warn that travelers who use Halcion may have memory lapses.
The drug makers say drugs often have only a few years of strong earnings before losing ground to new products and, after their patent protection runs out, to low-priced generic versions. Robert H. Uhl Jr., an analyst at Salomon Brothers, said that by 1993 two dozen drugs with a combined total of $5 billion in annual sales will have lost patent protection.
 
Industry Highly Profitable
But pharmaceuticals are one of the country's most profitable manufacturing industries: Pretax profits were 22.6 percent of sales in the first half of 1989, compared with 7.8 percent for all manufacturing, the Commerce Department said. By another measure, pretax earnings amounted to 42.7 percent of shareholders' equity, compared with 21.5 percent for all manufacturing.
Rising costs for drugs are a major concern for large employers like the General Motors Corporation, which says it will spend more than $300 million this year for drugs for active and retired employees, up more than 20 percent from 1988.
''A lot of that comes right off the bottom line of their earnings report,'' said Mason Irving, a health-care expert at Arthur D. Little, a consulting firm in Cambridge, Mass.
The Big Three auto makers' major health plan, the Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association of Michigan, has obtained price rebates from drug manufacturers for its health maintenance organizations, said Thomas A. Needham, a senior pharmaceutical consultant with Michigan Blue Cross. ''We may try to expand the rebates to all our business,'' he said.
 
Prices Compared
H.M.O.'s, which are prepaid health plans, and hospitals draw up lists of approved drugs, known as formularies, in consultation with doctors and pharmacists. When there is a choice of products deemed equally safe and effective, price becomes an important consideration.
''We negotiate with manufacturers and all vendors,'' said John Middleton, president of Diversified Pharmaceutical Services, a unit of United Healthcare Inc., an 800,000-member H.M.O. based in Minneapolis.
Rockwell, which has 110,000 employees, operates its own pharmacy at a plant in Iowa and is planning to open pharmacies for its employees in Texas and California. Mr. Heslin said manufacturers had offered to supply drugs to Rockwell employees by mail at special prices.
 
'Truly an Oligopoly'
Five Los Angeles-area aerospace companies - Rockwell, Lockheed, Hughes Aircraft, TRW and Northrop - have commissioned a study of ''the cost-effectiveness of direct pharmacy contracting,'' said Michael J. Barberi, a principal with Mercer Meidinger Hansen, a benefits consulting firm. ''The drug manufacturers are truly an oligopoly,'' he said. ''But employers are getting closer to the door to influencing drug prices.''
Stephen Schondelmeyer, director of the Pharmaceutical Economic Research Center at Purdue University, said: ''In many cases, the purchasers of health care are now as large as the pharmaceutical manufacturers. We're seeing a leveling out of market power between purchasers and producers.''
Deere & Company, a farm machinery manufacturer, operates its own health maintenance organization with 175,000 members. ''Both brand-name and generic drug manufacturers have expressed an interest in talking to us,'' said Richard J. Van Bell, Deere's personnel and health care operations director.
 
Bids Sought
Officials of Medicaid are also pressing for rebates in at least 14 states. Medicaid will spend $3.3 billion on prescription drugs in 1989.
The manufacturers have rebuffed the states in most cases, but last year, when Kansas called for competitive bids on 30 drugs, ''several companies, including brand-name manufacturers, responded,'' said John W. Alquest, the state's Medicaid commissioner. Bids were accepted on six products, each a lower-priced generic version of a brand-name drug. ''If a doctor prescribes the brand-name, we just won't pay for it,'' he said.
Mr. Alquest said drug manufacturers had tried without success to persuade the Kansas Legislature to prohibit the bidding program.
Last month, the California Legislature authorized the state's Medi-Cal program for low-income patients to add or delete drugs from its approved list, thus strengthening the state's bargaining power. Norman Hartman, a Medi-Cal spokesman, said the manufacturers had rebuffed earlier requests to negotiate, and had ''dumped a ton of money trying to defeat the law.''
Medi-Cal has been paying $54.90 for 300 milligrams of the anti-ulcer drug Tagamet, made by SmithKline Beecham, said Richard Iniguez, a Medi-Cal section chief. But because of negotiated discounts, he said, California hospitals and prisons paid $38.50 for the same amount, Los Angeles County Health Department hospitals paid $41.59 and the Veterans Administration paid only $27.60.
Employers, insurers and pharmaceutical industry experts said concerns about drug prices have been compounded by recent Congressional votes to cut back the Medicare program for catastrophic illness, which would have paid for some prescription drugs for elderly Americans. But Senator Jay Rockefeller, who heads a bipartisan Senate-House commission on health care, said a bill to revive a drug benefit would probably be introduced next year.

HEADLINE: Talking Business with Olsen of Digital Equipment;
Testing I.B.M. On Mainframes

BYLINE: By John Markoff

 BODY:
Kenneth H. Olsen, president and founder of the Digital Equipment Corporation, has made a career of doing well the things that International Business Machines Inc. does not do. But in October Mr. Olsen's Maynard, Mass., company introduced its first mainframe computer, moving into a market where growth is slowing and I.B.M. jealously guards its territory.
 
Q. Some people believe that I.B.M. owns the mainframe market, and that this market may become obsolete. Why did you choose to enter it now?
 
A. It is owned by I.B.M. in this country, but the Japanese have a big part worldwide. One of the things that we have that is unique, that makes our VAX popular, is that you can grow it in increments - you don't have to buy the big one to start with. As the job grows and the company grows, you can add to it. That makes it very attractive. 
 
Q. What is the place for your VAX computer architecture in the future?
 
A. If you want to tie things together or make a commercial system, then you have to go with VAX or an I.B.M. system; you have no choice. You're not going to put a commercial system on a desk. You're not going to spread your bank's data out on desks. You want absolute reliability and security.
 
Q. Can you look around the economy today and see whole areas of application that haven't existed?
 
A. Oh yes, very much. We've always been a little bored with supermarket retailing. But other areas of retailing badly need computing, and they know it.
 
Q. Are your sales abroad growing more rapidly than here? There's a suggestion that you found Europe and Japan more receptive and dynamic in some ways than the American economy.
 
A. Capital investment in Japan is 18 to 20 percent of their gross national product. In this country it's almost half that. And the thing that is terrifying for the future is the trade balance is going to mushroom in the wrong direction because we're investing less and less, and they're investing more and more. We look at Europe and think they're going to become protectionist in 1992, and if they're protectionist we'll become even more protectionist.
 
Q. How does Digital play its hand? Do you look abroad for your real growth?
 
A. We keep a stiff upper lip. This year we're investing $1.5 billion in research and development and $1.3 billion in capital equipment, most of it in this country.
 
Q. Have you considered participating in I.B.M.'s X-ray lithography semiconductor development program?
 
A. They've talked to us about it, but it doesn't fit in with our plans. My point is that it isn't specific technology. Semiconductor memories are a good example. Semiconductor memories go to the country with the lowest cost of capital. The cost of capital is a major part of the cost of semiconductor memories. When politicians say that they are going to get semiconductor memories in this country, it's like saying we're going to grow bananas in North Dakota. Only a politician would think he could do that, but it ain't going to work.
 
Q. If Japan has a lower cost of capital, and it has a large capital market, why can't you dip into that and even out that advantage?
 
A. I'm not bashing the Japanese when I say this, but we're having a contest with them in which they're generating low interest rates to support their business and we're taxing exports, keeping our interest rates high.
 
Q. Is U.S. Memories, a proposed consortium of chip makers, a little bit like trying to grow bananas in North Dakota?
 
A. No, in terms of being a great success and being competitive. It's more than just getting a few people together and spending a few dollars. But whether it is a good idea to try is another thing. We ought to have the technology here.
 
Q. Are supercomputers a kind of national asset that the United States should do something about?
 
A. Supercomputers are important, but they're not the overwhelming thing. They don't replace guns.
 
Q. Robert Tappan Morris, who in 1988 wrote the program that crashed the national computer network, worked briefly for your company. Do you think he should be punished?
 
A. On different days I say different things. The attitude of many of our people is that it's a shame to ruin such a creative competent human being who did a dumb thing. The other point of view is that you have to make an example of him. I tend toward the view, don't ruin a human being, but I know the weakness of that, too.
 
Q. Do you think there are potential markets in Eastern Europe and Moscow?
 
A. Yes and no. Somebody ought to sell to the Russians because we have a vested interest in their being successful.

HEADLINE: Dow Is Slightly Higher as Caution Persists

BYLINE: By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

 BODY:
The stock market posted a very modest gain yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average rising 0.82, to 2,626.43, amid investor caution about the course of the economy and interest rates.
Advancing issues on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered declining ones by slightly more than 8 to 7, with 812 shares up in price and 675 lower.
The market opened mixed as investors took a ''wait-and-see'' stance before a half-dozen key economic reports are released later this week. It remained in a range of about six points higher to six points lower throughout the day. 
The prices of Treasury securities fluctuated throughout the day but ended up with small gains.
Reports on retail sales, industrial production and capacity utilization data for October will be released today. Tomorrow, inventory and sales data are scheduled to be issued; on Thursday, the balance of trade report, and on Friday, housing starts.
In the broader market yesterday, the New York Stock Exchange composite index tacked on 0.32, to 188.22, while the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks added 0.45, to 339.55.
Volume on the Big Board expanded to 140.8 million shares, from 131.8 million on Friday.
''The stock market at 2,626 seems fairly valued,'' said Harold A. MacKinney, the chairman of the investment policy committee at the Fleet Financial Group in Providence, R.I. ''Earnings for the third quarter have been disappointing to some investors, but the stock market seems to have digested the bad news quite well.''
A $1.6 billion bid for Combustion Engineering provided some fuel for the market, as the stock soared 13 1/2, to 39. The gain by Combustion, based in Stamford, Conn., was more than 50 percent and just under the $40-a-share, or $1.6 billion, bid from ASEA Brown Boveri Ltd. of Sweden and Switzerland. Combustion, which analysts said was receiving ''top dollar,'' was also the most active stock on the Big Board, with a volume of more than 5.5 million shares.
 
Nynex Rises to $80
Nynex, rose 1 3/8, to 80. The telephone company, based in New York, said bargaining committees for the two unions representing its 60,000 striking workers were reviewing a proposed settlement on wages and benefits reached by union and company negotiators over the weekend.
Ford Motor, the nation's No. 2 auto maker, slipped 1/4, to 44 3/4. The company said it was recalling about 1.5 million 1985 to 1987 model Ford Escort and Mecury Lynx vehicles to modify or replace the driver's seat track. Elsewhere in the group, General Motors dipped 1/8, to 44 1/8, and Chrysler was unchanged at 20 1/4.
Dow Chemical rose 2 1/2, to 93 1/2. John Garcia, an analyst with Wertheim Schroder & Company in New York, upgraded his rating on Dow to ''attractive,'' from ''neutral,'' because of the political changes sweeping Eastern Europe. He also reiterated his ''attractive'' rating on Monsanto, which jumped 1 5/8, to 116 1/4.
 
Germany Fund Off
The Germany Fund slipped 3/4, to 12 3/4. On Friday, the stock climbed soared 2 3/4, to 13 1/2, in the wake of the easing of restrictions on East German travel to West.
Merck plunged 3 7/8, to 76 1/8. P. Roy Vagelos, the company's chairman, said earnings growth in the near term would slow because of the drug maker's long-term plans and projected research and development expenditures.
The Dallas Corporation, which makes doors and related products, soared 9 1/2, to 23 5/8. The company said it had signed an agreement with the Bessemer Securities Corporation, under which DCO Holding Corporation, a Bessemer subsidiary, would acquirethe outstanding shares of Dallas at $24 each.
In other trading, Philip Morris was up 3/8, to 42 1/4; American Express, off 1/4, at 34 3/8; Unisys, off 3/8, to 13 1/4; Avon Products, down 1 1/2, to 35; Occidental Petroleum, off 2, to 29, and I.B.M., up 1/8, to 98 1/4.
On the American Stock Exchange, the Amex market-value index added 0.23, to 371.70, while in over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index dipped 0.25, to 455.94.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Precious Metals Prices Rise On Gold Demand in Europe

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Prices of precious metals continued to advance yesterday on stronger demand for gold in Europe and a resumption of platinum buying by Asian interests.
Dealers in New York and London said some buying came from Swiss brokers acting on behalf of United States investment funds.
At the close in New York, the price for spot December Comex gold delivery was up $4.10 an ounce, to $392.70, while the December silver contract at the Commodity Exchange rose 5.8 cents an ounce, to $5.318. The spot January platinum delivery at the New York Mercantile Exchange climbed $4.80 an ounce, to $514.40. 
''The dramatic events in central Europe, while welcomed by most people in West Germany and other relatively well-off countries, have also raised fears that mass migrations from the East could undermine their economies,'' said Bette Raptopoulos, metals specialist at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. ''And when Europeans are worried, they tend to hoard a bit more gold.''
While the dollar remains the preferred currency, Ms. Raptopoulos noted, ''many overseas investors do not believe there is much further room for appreciation in the dollar or dollar-denominated investments, especially with our economy showing more and more signs of weakening.''
Meanwhile, the rise in precious metals reawakened interest among Asian investors and jewelry makers who had let their stocks of metal run down for much of this year of weakening gold, platinum and silver prices.
William B. O'Neill, research director at Elders Futures Inc., said: ''Gold was the first of the sensitive metals to wake up, initially after the Oct. 13 stock market decline and most recently by the events in Europe. Now, platinum is starting to move up as well. But the outlook for silver remains clouded by the huge overhanging supply of the metal. At 228 million ounces, Comex silver stocks are at or near record levels.''
Perhaps equally significant, Mr. O'Neill said, ''is that gold is no longer moving in lock step with the dollar, as has been the case for almost two years.'' He added: ''Consequently, we now find increased interest by investment funds in gold and, to a lesser extent, in platinum. But the main market for platinum remains Japan.''
While the Japanese interest in platinum reflects its use in making a multitude of industrial products, including automotive anti-pollution devices, it has long been the metal of choice among jewelry buyers in Japan. Aside from being rarer and often more valuable than gold, platinum is preferred by the Japanese because they consider it less ostentatious than gold or silver or even precious stones.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Drifts Mostly Lower As Traders Focus on Mark

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar drifted lower against most major currencies yesterday as traders were preoccupied with the West German mark.
Foreign exchange dealers said there was little interest in either buying or selling dollars. 
Most buying was focused on West Germany's currency. There has been speculation that the country's interest rates could be raised as the Government tries to counteract the stimulative impact of an influx of East Germans as that Communist nation eases restrictions.
Higher West German interest rates would increase the return on mark-denominated investments and tend to spur demand for the currency. Dealers also said the mark rose as a technically driven rebound from a steep slide on Friday.
''People aren't sure about the positives and negatives of the German situation,'' said Simon Fischer of Bear, Stearns & Company. ''People are trying to assess what the implications are for the dollar.''
The anticipation of several United States economic reports due this week also inhibited interest in the dollar. A weakening in growth could cause the Federal Reserve Board to strike a more generous credit posture, leading to lower interest rates, many analysts say.
This week's statistical lineup includes reports today on retail sales and industrial production plus a reading on Thursday of the merchandise trade deficit, a figure that frequently moves the markets.
In New York, the dollar finished at 143.925 yen, up from 143.40 yen. A pound cost $1.582, more expensive for buyers than Friday's $1.5773.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late rates Friday, included: 1.8615 West German marks, down from 1.8670; 1.64145 Swiss francs, down from 1.6440; 6.3135 French francs, down from 6.3255; 1,359.75 Italian lire, down from 1,362.50, and 1.16845 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1696.
