HEADLINE: Many Economists See Fed Delay on Rates

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13

 BODY:
Despite mounting evidence that economic growth has slowed to a crawl, the Federal Reserve is likely to shun further immediate steps to trim interest rates, many economists said today.
The dominant view is that the central bank's main policy body, the Federal Open Market Committee, will conclude at its meeting on Tuesday that the clear, albeit modest, rate cut of a week ago is all that is needed, or can be afforded, for now.
''We think there will be no further policy move,'' said Kathleen Stephansen, senior economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, noting that the rate on Federal funds - overnight loans among banks - promptly fell one-quarter percentage point, to 8 1/2 percent, after last week's rate cut, which was reportedly decided upon in an unusual telephone meeting. Over the longer term, however, Ms. Stephansen said the funds rate could slide to 7 3/4 percent by summer if, as she expected, the economy's path remains only barely positive. 
The Open Market Committee, composed of the seven members of the board of governors plus the presidents of the 12 regional Federal Reserve banks, has eight scheduled meetings a year, with Tuesday's intended to set the nation's monetary course for the subsequent five weeks. Occasionally, the Fed finds it necessary to take action between meetings by convening by telephone.
The Fed has so far refused to officially acknowledge last week's session, but economists and analysts are convinced that published accounts of the move, presumably inspired by the steady recent stream of poor to mediocre economic and profit reports, are accurate.
''The market accepts it as a fait accompli,'' said Kevin Logan, chief economist for the Swiss Bank Corporation.
Most analysts believe that the Fed responded to the evidence of a deteriorating economy and not, as an apparent minority suspects, to concern about stress in the financial system, particularly among regional banks.
The current issue of Grant's Interest Rate Observer, a New York-based bond market newsletter, said: ''Asset-quality problems have spread from the Southwest to the Northeast and to North Carolina and Florida. With the Resolution Funding Corporation already in need of new funds, with the Federal Government breaking records in debt issuance, with the wheels coming off the 'junk bond' market and with new lows quietly being plumbed in the third world debt market, the Federal Reserve does not need a new credit crisis.''
Whatever the Fed's motivation, analysts believe that the meeting on Tuesday will probably not impel further action even if the reports on October industrial production and retail sales are weak. Output, compiled by the Fed itself, is foreshadowed by the previously published employment data, and the report on retail sales has been notoriously unreliable.
Some analysts say more will be learned this week about policy from an account of the preceding Open Market Committee meeting than from market action relating to the current meeting.
On Friday, as is usual on the third day following a scheduled meeting, the Fed will publish what it calls the ''record of policy actions'' - often erroneously called minutes - for the committee's session on Oct. 3. Mr. Logan said he was very eager to see whether recent Fed easing had followed some kind of schedule or whether it was in response to specifically cited developments.
Analysts will also be looking at the Fed's meeting record for an account of the reported telephone conference call last week, which is expected to show up as an addendum covering events since the scheduled meeting.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1605 words

HEADLINE: With a Recess Near, Congress Scrambles To Save Tax Breaks

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14

 BODY:
In Congress's rush to adjourn before Thanksgiving, the list of important legislative initiatives that will be postponed until 1990 is growing fast. But little on Capitol Hill stands in the way of a popular tax break, especially one that taxpayers already enjoy, and lawmakers in both parties were scrambling today to save nine that have already expired or are due to expire at the end of the year.
The Senate, in fact, attached all of these, plus several others, to a measure providing economic aid to Poland and Hungary.
The tax breaks include a credit to businesses for research and development expenses, a credit to developers for investment in low-income rental housing and an income exclusion for workers whose employers have provided education assistance benefits.
Individually, the breaks are not popular with all members of Congress. Serious questions have been raised about whether some of them, including the research and development credit, achieve any of the purposes for which they were intended. 
Collectively, however, the tax breaks enjoy an almost mystical legislative status. They have survived the months of budget battles and partisan wrangling that made temporary casualties of measures like child care assistance, Medicare reforms and even the President's pet initiative, a cut in the capital gains tax.
If Democrats have their way, the extensions of the expiring tax breaks -or ''extenders,'' as they are known on Capitol Hill - will be included in the deficit-reduction plan under negotiation between the House and Senate. The theory is that the breaks will attract enough bipartisan support to insure that the package is enacted.
Last week, the House Ways and Means Committee proposed that the deficit-reduction plan incorporate a one-year extension of the tax breaks, which would cost the Treasury more than $1.6 billion in the 1990 fiscal year and more than $4.5 billion between 1990 and 1994.
In a counteroffer today, the Senate Finance Committee suggested a six-month extension, a period more suitable to Republicans, who see that expiration date as a golden opportunity for reviving the capital gains tax cut. The six-month extension would cost the Treasury just over $1 billion in the 1990 fiscal year. The Ways and Means panel, however, is holding fast to a full-year extension.
 
Republicans Have Doubts
But Republicans, particularly those in the Senate, are not altogether happy about tying the tax breaks to deficit legislation that President Bush has suggested he might veto. So 12 extenders cropped up as the amendment attached to the Poland-Hungary aid bill. The amendment, providing a six-month extension, was sponsored by Senator John C. Danforth, Republican of Missouri, and was agreed to by voice vote today, The Senate later approved the full bill on a vote of 99 to 0.
Supporters of the various breaks were elated by today's Senate action, taking it as a signal that President Bush was prepared to accept the extensions and was happy to leave lawmakers to sort out in the next few days which piece of legislation would finally incorporate them.
By late today senators in both parties were suggesting that the extenders might be kept in both bills just in case.
Mr. Bush's position on the extenders has been far from clear over the last six months. In testimony to Congressional committees and in conversations with individual lawmakers, Administration officials have offered conflicting positions, some suggesting that he would favor extension of the research and housing credits and others that the President would oppose all of them because the budget squeeze did not permit extending them this year. Last week, however, Mr. Bush called for extension of the low-income housing credit as part of a housing assistance proposal he announced in Dallas.
To underscore the importance of the housing credit for cities faced with shortages of low-income rental units, half a dozen mayors were on Capitol Hill today to urge that lawmakers find a way to renew it; several pressed their cause in a visit to President Bush at the White House.
Business organizations, municipalities and other interest groups with a stake in one or more of the breaks have been making their pitches more quietly, but no less urgently, in behind-the-scenes lobbying.
The groups have pushed for permanent extension of the tax credits, particularly those for research and development and low-income housing, two areas where long-term planning is crucial. But permanent extensions for all the credits would cost the Treasury $3 billion to $5 billion in this fiscal year alone - a daunting amount at a time when lawmakers are struggling to agree on how to shave $14 billion from the deficit and win Mr. Bush's approval for the reduction plan.
 
'Valuable Commodity'
''Predictability is a highly valuable commodity in the housing world, and this doesn't allow us with confidence to carry forward with projects or to raise investment funds,'' said Paul Grogan, president of Local Initiatives Support Corporation, a New York-based nonprofit housing and community development organization, of a temporary extension. Mr. Grogan said, however, that even the six-month extension would be enough to save a 1,000-unit rental rehabilitation project in New York City.
Mr. Grogan's organization pools the credits allocated by states and municipalities for housing construction or rehabilitation and then arranges for the participation of private investors who benefit by being able to apply their share of the tax credit against a Federal income tax liability. Mr. Grogan said a corporation or developer investing $1 million in such a project could expect a 15 percent rate of return on that investment.
Over the last three years, supporters of the credit say it has resulted in 210,000 low-income rental units.
The on-again, off-again approach to the tax breaks has played havoc with employees whose companies pick up the tab for their studies. A tax break enacted in 1978 had allowed workers to exclude from their taxable income up to $5,250 of tuition paid by employers. But the exclusion, which expired at the end of 1987, was renewed retroactively for a brief period in 1988 and then lapsed at the end of that year.
 
Coping With Uncertainty
To cope with the uncertainty about whether it will be renewed this year, some companies began withholding taxes from employees' paychecks to cover the tuition that may be subject to a tax liability. Under the proposals being considered by the tax-writing committees, the exclusion for employer-paid tuition benefits would be restored retroactively for 1989 and then extended for six months. Without the extension, a worker under current law can avoid tax liability for the education benefits only if the education is related to a current job.
''It is extremely important that we take every step to support American companies that want a trained and skilled work force,'' said Representative Frank Guarini, a New Jersey Democrat who has been the chief proponent of extending the credit in the Ways and Means panel.
There has been considerable disagreement among lawmakers and economists about whether the 20 percent credit for research and development enacted in 1981 does much for research. Robert Eisner, a professor of economics at Northwestern University, is convinced that it does little.
''To a large extent it's a ripoff,'' he said. ''It is giving money to companies who would be doing the same thing anyway.'' Mr. Eisner's studies during the mid-1980's indicated that from 1975 to 1981, before the credit took effect, spending on research grew at an annual rate of 6.2 percent, while from 1981 through 1987, research spending rose by 3.8 percent.
Mr. Eisner noted that as the credit is now structured, it actually has the perverse effect of discouraging research spending because some companies would get a larger break by spending less. Partly in response to such criticisms, the proposals for extending the credit would include modifications in the way it is calculated.
Martin Bailey, a professor of economics at the University of Maryland, said that with the modifications, the credit should increase research spending by 10 percent over what it would otherwise be.
''There is a substantial social benefit from R.&D. that exceeds any benefit just going to the company,'' he added. Mr. Bailey, who helped conduct a study for the corporate-sponsored Council on Research and Technology, said the study showed that between 1981 and 1985 the credit raised research spending by 3 to 7 percent over what it would have been.
 
Concentrating Their Efforts
There are 11 tax breaks that expire at the end of this year. But the tax writers in both the Senate and the House are concentrating their efforts on saving the seven breaks with the broadest support, as well as two popular measures that expired previously. Besides the credits for research, low-income housing, and the exclusion for education benefits, the nine include: a tax credit for employers who hire disadvantaged workers; a provision that allows self-employed individuals to deduct a portion of their health-insurance cost; and a credit for certain energy conservation measures.
The other popular measures involve the research allocation rules and exemptions for mortgage bonds and manufacturing bonds.
In addition to these, Mr. Danforth's amendment includes one that allows tax-free withdrawals from certain employee stock ownership plans, one for employer-provided group legal services and an accounting change in rules that govern the Railroad Retirement Trust Fund.

HEADLINE: Brazilians Vote Today for President In a Free and Unpredictable Election

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 14

 BODY:
After a gap of 29 years, Brazilians vote for president Wednesday in the first round of elections expected to set the direction for Latin America's largest nation in the 1990's.
With 82 million voters headed for the polls, Brazil takes a key step toward becoming the hemisphere's second most populous democracy after the United States.
For 80 percent of the voters, the election represents the first chance to vote for president. Given the electorate's inexperience, analysts today could only agree on one prediction - that Fernando Collor de Mello, a 40-year-old center-right former state governor, will be one of the two candidates making the runoff scheduled for Dec. 17. 
The other slot is hotly contested by two socialists, Leonel Brizola, a fiery 67-year-old former governor, and Luis Inacio da Silva, a 44-year-old trade unionist with strong Marxist support.
 
'Lula' Draws Huge Crowds
In a thundering finale to his campaign, Mr. da Silva, widely known as ''Lula,'' drew crowds of more than 100,000 to a series of weekend rallies in Rio de Janeiro, Minas Gerais and Sao Paulo. Known as Brazil's ''industrial triangle,'' these three states account for 44 percent of an electorate distributed over 26 states and territories.
Favoring Mr. da Silva, the name Lula leads the list of 21 candidates on the ballot, and his party, the Workers' Party, is widely considered the best organized in Brazil.
''My guess is that the Workers Party will probably have five times more people at the voting stations than anyone else - and that means a lot in a country where 70 percent of the people don't have a party and 35 percent don't have a candidate,'' said Alfred Stepan, a visiting political scientist from Columbia University who has written several books on Brazilian politics.
Nervously watching Mr. da Silva climb in the polls, Mr. Brizola lashed out last week against his younger rival.
''Lula is unprepared and incompetent,'' he said, and ''needs more training and less vanity, because experience is not gained from one day to the other.'' Mr. da Silva is the only major contender who lacks a college education.
 
Voting Is Obligatory
Mr. Brizola was deeply marked by the 15 years he spent in exile during the late 1960's and 1970's when Brazil was ruled by Army generals. Mr. da Silva, a federal deputy, has called his rival ''a salesman of old records.''
Indeed, the Brazil that votes Wednesday is radically different from the Brazil that last voted for President in 1960, a year when Mr. Brizola, was governor of Rio Grande do Sul state.
With the extension last year of voting rights to the illiterate and to 16-year-olds, this election will be decided by Brazil's poor. Voting is obligatory in Brazil, with violators facing a series of fines and sanctions.
In the fullest expression of democracy in Brazil's 100-year history as a republic, 57 percent of the population is eligible to vote. By contrast, only 22 percent of the population could vote in 1960.
But despite a 17-fold increase in Brazil's gross national product in the last 30 years, this nation remains riven by one of the world's sharpest inequalities in income distribution.
 
'Aberrant' Income Disparity
Two-thirds of Brazilian families survive on less than $500 a month. With massive migration to cities since 1960, rural poverty now lives cheek by jowl with urban wealth.
''Today they live in the same cities, on the same streets,'' Helio Jaguaribe, a Brazilian political scientist, wrote in his recent book, ''Brazil: Reform or Chaos.''
''In no country of the world, not even in India, are there such aberrant contrasts,'' he said.
Indeed, in India, the poorest 60 percent of the population receive 30.1 percent of the national income. The richest 20 percent receive 49.4 percent of the national income.
In Brazil, the poorest 60 percent of the population receive 16.4 percent of the national income. The richest 20 percent receive 66.6 percent.
 
Few Readers but Many TV Fans
Furthermore, Brazil's economic growth of the last 30 years has failed to make a dent in abysmally low levels of education. Only one-fourth of the electorate lining up at polling booths on Wednesday will have finished primary school.
In a country of 144 million people, the four most influential newspapers of Rio and Sao Paulo sell a total of just one million copies a day.
''Brazil has one of the lowest levels of newspaper readership in Latin America,'' said Eliane Alvarenga, a Sao Paulo researcher on mass communication here. ''Brazil has an oral tradition. Today people are acculturated by television.''
Largely because of television, an unlettered population does not necessarily mean a politically illiterate population. With televisions now in 72 percent of households, up from 5 percent in 1960, an estimated 94 percent of Brazilians watch television regularly.
Ratings surveys estimate that the nightly hour of free political advertising from mid-September until Sunday drew a daily audience of 35 million people.
With the future of the world's eighth-largest market economy at stake, analysts also note that there is little correlation in Brazil between poverty and leftist political voting patterns.
The most recent Gallup poll here gives the largest slice of poor voters, 34 percent, to Mr. Collor, the center-rightist. Mr. da Silva comes in second with 14 percent.
 
The Anti-Corruption Candidate
Mr. Collor's deep appeal to the poor is attributed to his vigorous campaign against corruption. Last year, he captured the nation's fancy by uprooting ''marajahs,'' or overpaid, corrupt government officials, from state bureaucracies.
The leader in the polls since May, Mr. Collor has seen his support slide in the last three months from 45 percent to 25 percent. Seeking to avoid further slippage, he refused to debate other candidates on television.
A largely invisible presence in the campaign has been Jose Sarney, Brazil's highly unpopular president. Since Mr. Sarney took office in March 1985, consumer prices have risen 170,719 percent. Many economists predict an explosion of hyperinflation after the December runoff election.
All 21 candidates are running against Mr. Sarney, including Ulysses Guimaraes, the nominee of his own party, the Brazilian Democratic Movement Party, PMDB.
Although this party controls 22 of Brazil's 24 state governorships, Mr. Guimaraes regularly wins approval ratings of about 3 percent in public opinion polls.
On Sunday, a headline in the O Estado de Sao Paulo newspaper offered an epitaph: ''PMDB navigates for 23 years and dies on the beach.''

HEADLINE: Millionaire Hands Out Money to Help People Start Businesses

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Me., Nov. 12

 BODY:
Barbara Erickson was in the unemployment line here recently when someone told her that a local millionaire was giving money to help people start small businesses.
Ms. Erickson and a thousand others, some from as far away as New York State, telephoned the millionaire, T. David Franklin, a 31-year-old former computer salesman. Ms. Erickson, an illustrator, was one of the 15 selected to receive his money.
Three weeks ago, Mr. Franklin placed classified advertisements in newspapers here saying, ''Local millionaire will put you in business. Street people and welfare applicants can apply.'' 
 
Strain Breaks Answering Machine
Street people and welfare applicants did apply, as did commodity brokers, engineers, former convicts and the husband of an anchorwoman for a television news program. Mr. Franklin's answering machine broke under the strain.
The businesses proposed included the plausible and the absurd, Mr. Franklin said. One person wanted to market a special potion to cure every medical problem known to man.
''The first night I couldn't sleep at all, I was so shaken by the response,'' Mr. Franklin said. He made the offer because he believed that many people were willing to work hard but lacked direction and money. And, he said, he has long been involved in civic affairs, starting at age 12 when he sold merchandise door to door so his Boy Scout troop could buy tents.
''I don't want to invest in the stock market when I can invest in people,'' he said.
Mr. Franklin, who is from Baltimore, estimates his net worth at just over a million dollars, most of it from about 20 buildings he owns in Maine, Maryland and New Hampshire.
He said he hopes the people he chose for investments will be able to repay him, but he will not charge interest. He also hopes the group will set aside money from profits to perpetuate the project.
 
Mail Sorting to Housecleaning
Until quitting earlier this year to invest in a computer company in Portland, Mr. Franklin had sold computer systems for three years for Convergent Dealership Systems, a subsidiary of Unisys Corporation based in Hunt Valley, Md. His supervisor, Pat Agnew, said he was a good producer, earning several trips as bonuses. When he quit his job, he had about $200,000 from retirement benefits and other bonuses to invest.
Mr. Franklin said several hundred of the people who called him had good ideas, but he decided to select 15 because he wants to help manage the businesses, teaching the owners basic business principles. He does not know precisely how much money each will receive because he intends to study each proposed expenditure and sign all the checks.
He chose a varied group of proposals: mail sorting for large companies, credit card sales, housecleaning, photography, a handyman business, commodities trading, blood sampling, business equipment repair, crafts, property management, painting, comic book publishing, making Art Deco pins, medical transcription and word processing.
Four of the people he chose are in business now, six are on public assistance, two are employed by other companies and the rest are ''just getting by,'' Mr. Franklin said.
Ms. Erickson, the artist, will do watercolors of people's homes. Mr. Franklin's offer came at an opportune time, she said. She had been laid off from her job in marketing at a retail clothing concern in September and money was becoming tight. But, she added, it was not only money she was seeking from Mr. Franklin but also the business lessons.
''You pray every night and say what direction am I supposed to go, and then this happens,'' Ms. Erickson said. ''It's always been a dream to have my own business.''
 
'This Guy Is a Dream'
Andy Beaudet, the president of AAris Corporation, the computer company Mr. Franklin invested in, said: ''He knows a lot about getting companies started. I give him a lot of credit for doing something the government should be doing.''
Bonnie Robinson, whose idea for starting a housecleaning business appealed to Mr. Franklin, said she has wanted to end her reliance on welfare but could not find a way. She receives $326 a month through the Federal Aid to Families With Dependent Children program.
''Me and my daughter are living bad,'' she said. ''We run out of everything before the month ends, and I know you can make a lot of money cleaning. This guy is a dream. I just want enough to get me on my feet, to make sure my daughter has the best.''
Mr. Franklin said he realizes he must be careful with people like Ms. Robinson because he does not want to jeopardize her Federal benefits before her business can support her.
''I have a chance to help people make their lifelong dreams come true without a concern for money,'' he said. ''This gives me a great deal of satisfaction.''
Several people who know him said they do not believe he is showing off. ''I truly believe he's civic minded,'' Mr. Beaudet said. ''He's never put a press release out, only took out that small ad. And this comes at a really good time because so many people need a helping hand.''

HEADLINE: About New York;
Using the Big Top To Put Normalcy In the Lives of 500

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

 BODY:
rrTomorrow morning a group of 500 people have a special invitation to the Big Apple Circus, now playing at Lincoln Center. They will be entertained by death-defying aerialists, stampeding Pekingese dogs, a dancing elephant and much, much more. Most won't see a thing. They're blind. But they will taste the cotton candy, bounce to the rollicking circus music, smell the pachyderms, read a Braille program and feel wind from galloping horses. And, through earphones, they'll hear a running commentary by two sportscasters.
''This is easily the most difficult thing I've ever had to do,'' said Marty Glickman of WCBS News radio, who will be doing act-by-act with a colleague, Bill Daughtry. 
At a recent performance, the two scouted the action to prepare descriptions for people who may have never seen anything. The goal is to be as concrete as possible. An acrobat swings so fast his hair is standing straight up. A buffalo is a horse covered with a shag rug. Mr. Glickman anxiously asked if he could describe an entertainer's pants as being ''as white as snow.''
''Yes,'' answered Tammy Barry, superintendent of the school run by the Jewish Guild for the Blind, which is bringing the 500 blind and visually impaired spectators. ''They know snow is white.''
What Jay D. Leventhal knows about snow is that it is a pain in the neck. The 31-year-old Queens native has been blind since age 2 but went to regular schools. He encountered his first snowbanks at Syracuse University. ''It can be disruptive,'' he said of navigating with a cane. ''You lose all your landmarks.'' Since 1982, Mr. Leventhal has worked at the American Foundation for the Blind at 15 West 16th Street. His job has been testing products for the workplace and then helping the blind with the new technology. After interrupting his reading - a scanner funneled the page of a journal into a computer, which spoke the words in a flat voice - Mr. Leventhal was glad to chat about his work.
He has interviewed 1,160 blind and visually impaired people about how they cope with their jobs. They include lawyers and psychiatrists who just need tape recorders to mathematicians who need vast computer systems. He also answers questions from employers. Which computer array, for example, best displays large type?
It is an intriguing form of networking. Several weeks ago, a blind woman in Phoenix called to say she was interested in solar research. Mr. Leventhal referred her to a California man who owns a small solar company. A blind politician once wanted to know if there were any blind elected officials in case his opponent tried to use his disability against him. Mr. Leventhal found several. The American Foundation for the Blind sells intriguing things through its catalogue. Talking thermometers, tape measures and wallets. Tactile poker chips. A bacon crisper blind people can use and a Braille monopoly set. But for those who prefer to shop in a store, why not drop by a retail establishment that opened just yesterday?
It is the Lighthouse Shopping and Information Center at 111 East 59th Street, operated by the Lighthouse, the not-for-profit visual rehabilitation agency. The Lighthouse used to operate a craft shop in the same space. There is still some of this - the creations of a woodworker who scavenges to find different kinds of wood, for example.
But the focus is on things to help the visually impaired lead a more normal life. There are talking watches (one speaks English and Spanish), a talking scale with a voice sufficiently accusatory to force pounds off anybody, and a radio that brings in television stations. There are self-threading needles, a Braille Scrabble set and a telephone that repeats each number dialed.
If you buy a Braille Christmas card, the store will add your name in Braille for no charge. Gift-wrapping of everything is free, and there is no sales tax.
Barbara Silverstone, the Lighthouse's executive director, said the store represents a shift toward thinking of visually impaired people as intelligent consumers rather than clients or patients.
''This isn't a mystery,'' she said. ''This isn't strange. Visual impairment can happen to anybody.''
The bottom line of today's eye chart is that things seem to be getting better and more bountiful for blind people. But there are vast distances still to go. As many as four-fifths of this well-educated group are unemployed.
Oh, one last thing. Mr. Glickman, the sportscaster, is nagged by a worry. With tomorrow's ''Circus of the Senses'' only hours away, he is up in the air as to how to describe a baboon.

HEADLINE: A Novice Reigns as Bridgeport Mayor

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

DATELINE: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 14

 BODY:
Strange political twists seldom surprise anyone in this gritty city on Long Island Sound. After all, P.T. Barnum, the showman and circus master, was once mayor here. So was Jasper McLevy, a Scrooge-like Socialist who reigned for 24 years until 1957. So was John C. Mandanici, a target of death threats and car firebombings, who, during a failed 1981 re-election bid, often wore a bulletproof vest while campaigning.
But last week's election of Mary C. Moran, a Republican, as mayor of Connecticut's largest city jolted even jaded Bridgeporters. 
Mrs. Moran, a self-described housewife and real-estate broker, has no experience in elective office and was virtually unknown to the public until two months ago. The city's first woman to become Mayor, she defeated a two-term incumbent, Thomas W. Bucci, a Democrat who tried to end the city's long-running debt crisis with a $60 million state bailout plan.
Even more shocking was Mrs. Moran's victory margin: 11 percentage points. Republicans in Bridgeport are outnumbered 4 to 1 by Democrats.
''There is an expression here,'' said Michelle Sullivan, Mrs. Moran's acting press secretary. ''They never vote you in - they vote you out.''
Mrs. Moran's victory may signal dissatisfaction with Mr. Bucci more than approval of her austerity platform, which calls for cutting city services, except for police and fire, and increasing taxes only in an emergency, like an impending bankruptcy.
In the last week, though, Mrs. Moran's newness, charm and effervescence have inspired a small rejuvenation in this city of 143,000 people.
''She is fresh and exciting,'' said former Mayor Nicholas A. Panuzio, a Republican and chairman of Black Manafort Stone & Kelly, a Washington-based lobbying and consulting concern. ''She'll be a high-profile mayor.''
''It's all somewhat surprising,'' added another former mayor, Leonard S. Paoletta, who was upset by Mrs. Moran in a seven-way Republican primary two months ago. ''But if the people really respond to her administration the way they responded to her campaign, she could be the one to turn the city around.''
The inauguration, traditionally held at City Hall, was moved to the stately Klein Memorial Auditorium to accommodate the overflow crowd of 1,500 who attended the emotional, two-hour swearing-in ceremony Monday night.
The 56-year-old Mayor blinked back tears as the band of Central High School, her alma mater, welcomed her with the song ''Maria'' from ''West Side Story.'' ''It was as close as they could get to 'Mary,' '' Mrs. Moran said.
Throughout the evening Mrs. Moran's husband, Stephen, a truck driver for Airborne Express, seldom left her side. ''I'm ecstatic,'' he said, noting that his buddies at work now call him ''Mr. Mom.'' ''It's a dream come true,'' he said. In her inaugural address, Mrs. Moran, previously known to many local Republicans only as a loyal party foot soldier and a defeated city clerk candidate in 1977, promised to hire what she has called a ''drug czar,'' a police chief to replace the recently retired one, a chief financial officer and an economic development administrator.
Mrs. Moran, who received much of her support from the city's business community and the more affluent North End and Black Rock sections of the city, also emphasized that her primary goal would be to keep property taxes from rising and to slash nonessential or nonproductive city workers from the payroll.
''We are a city in trouble, and austerity has to become our theme,'' she said Stress on Finances ''Ed Koch would always ask his constituents in New York, 'How'm I doing?' '' Mrs. Moran added. ''In Bridgeport the question will be, 'Are you getting your money's worth?' ''
Mrs. Moran's campaign manager, David DeFelice, credited her surprising victory to anger over Mr. Bucci's handling of the city's financial crisis. He said Mr. Bucci had raised taxes by 31 percent over four years. He also called Mrs. Moran's backers the ''taxpayer constituency'' and said Mr. Bucci had put the city ''into state receivership.''
Mr. Bucci, who during the campaign cast his opponent as a pro-developer candidate who would allow condominiums to be built throughout the city, credited his loss simply to a desire for change.
''We were the bearers of bad news, especially on the financial side,'' he said shortly after his defeat. ''The voters wanted a new messenger. They wanted someone fresh, someone new, someone with no experience.''
 
Industrial Decline a Factor
Bridgeport financial problems are rooted primarily in its fall in the last 30 years as an industrial hub. A century ago the city was one of the manufacturing centers of the world.
In this time P.T. Barnum built a castle with minarets named Iranistan, which served as the architectural model for many buildings in the city. He donated most of the land for Seaside Park, where there is a statue of Barnum.
There were other problems besides the decline of the city's factories. Suburban flight was one. Mayor McLevy's long tenure and legendary frugality also left the city with a substandard infrastructure and social services. Corruption exemplified by Mr. Mandanici's administration - 19 members were indicted on various charges, 15 convicted - contributed to the city's miseries as well.
Over the last decade, though, sloppy tax collection, routine overestimates of revenue and overall mismanagement, mostly in administrations preceding Mr. Bucci's, left the city millions of dollars in debt and with a dangerously low credit rating.
The city received an infusion of capital two years ago when the state agreed to back $60 million in bonds to help pay off municipal debts. But in return, the city was forced to relinquish its fiscal oversight to a review board made up of state and local officials.
 
'Old and Deep' Trouble
''The roots of our financial trouble are old and deep,'' Mrs. Moran said. ''And what has demoralized many citizens is the rush of events and revelations over recent years which suggest a hopeless situation, one out of control.''
But before Bridgeport can rebuild its troubled fiscal foundation, Mrs. Moran said, it has to spend more time repairing its image.
''The prestige of our city is down, and the morale of our city is down,'' she said. ''But I am ready, willing and able, and I will lead this city back.''

HEADLINE: Community Shrinks From Crack's Embrace

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES

 BODY:
With its handsomely restored brownstones, well-organized block clubs and political activism, the southern part of Bedford-Stuyvesant contradicts the popular view of it as a crumbling and dangerous ghetto.
''We know most people on our block,'' said Maurice Reid, 48 years old, administrator of the Center for Law and Social Justice at Medgar Evers College, who bought a 17-room brownstone on Bainbridge Street with his family 10 years ago. ''This is a community. Every place else I've been has had a lot of people, but no sense of community.''
Like communities throughout New York City, however, this part of Bedford-Stuyvesant is engaged in a wearying, day-in day-out struggle with drugs. Crack, residents say, is posing a mortal threat to the neighborhood's fragile stability. 
 
Neighborhood 'Reclaiming Itself'
Dissatisfied with the level of police protection they receive, clergymen, educators and many of the middle- and working-class people who make up the bulk of the neighborhood are trying to fight back. They have sponsored seminars on neighborhood security for residents, set up block-watcher programs and formed civilian patrols. A nun who is the principal of a Roman Catholic elementary school has spent so much time battling nearby drug dealers that she won an award from the Federal Education Department.
''As the community organizes itself, it is reclaiming itself,'' said the Rev. Fred Lucas, pastor of the Bridge Street African Methodist Episcopal Church, the oldest black church in Brooklyn.
To outsiders, the name Bedford-Stuyvesant conjures up images of decay and degradation - of drug dens, crumbling tenements and ragged urchins romping in rubbish-strewn lots.
But the neighborhood's southern half, loosely bounded by Broadway and Atlantic Avenue on the north and south, and Marcus Garvey Boulevard and Saratoga Avenue to the east and west, is honeycombed with broad streets studded with grand brownstones dating from the turn of the century. Residentially, most of Bedford-Stuyvesant's blight is concentrated in its northern fringes near Myrtle Avenue and on its eastern edge.
The southern blocks embrace the Stuyvesant Heights Historic District, a 13-block enclave of 430 buildings dating from the 1870's. ''Bedford-Stuyvesant is basically a community of blocks,'' said Edwin Marshall, a planner for the city. ''You can walk down one street and find beautiful blocks. But if you go one or two blocks over, you find abandonment and blight.''
The fear of residents is that their community will be caught in the same explosion of violence that has engulfed nearby areas of Brooklyn. Through July, the 81st Precinct, which encompasses the southern half of Bedford-Stuyvesant, recorded 17 murders there. During the same period there were 24 homicides in the neighboring Bushwick section, 30 in nearby Crown Heights and 55 in East New York.
 
Residents See Misconceptions
''This area has been coming back economically and politically,'' said James P. Sullivan, 45, former president of Community Board 3, which includes Bedford-Stuyvesant. ''The drug problem threatens everything.''
Longtime residents resent what they see as the misconceptions about their neighborhood. ''When I was working, my colleagues couldn't conceive of me living in Bedford-Stuyvesant,'' said Anna Gary, 63, a retired secretary who lives with her daughter and grandchild in a house on Macon Street that was first owned by her parents. ''They visualize you walking out into your yard and confronting guys with guns.''
The black professionals who moved into Bedford-Stuyvesant to take advantage of the neighborhood's low housing prices are also proud homeowners.
The influx of young black professionals has helped stem population loss. From 1970 to 1980, Bedford-Stuyvesant, which is nearly all black, lost almost a third of its 196,600 residents. By 1985, the last year for which figures are available, the area's population had rebounded by only a few hundred, to 133,800.
 
Sharp Rise in Drug Activity
Southern Bedford-Stuyvesant has 130 block associations, more than 100 churches and a reputation for political strength. Its State Assembly District, the 56th, produced 28,384 votes for Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins, the third-highest total among all the city's 60 Assembly districts.
But the growing sense of vigor and community is jeopardized by the growing drug menace. The police report 232 arrests for sale and possession of drugs in the 81st Precinct during the first nine months of 1989, an 18 percent increase over the same period last year. But reports of drug activity phoned into the 81st Precinct by the public have risen by 40 percent for the same period. The police say this increase indicates both stepped-up drug activity and a willingness of the community to do something about it.
''People in the community are the best informed and the best source of information I have,'' said Deputy Inspector Wilbur Chapman, commander of the 81st Precinct.
For now, cooperation between the police and southern Bedford-Stuyvesant appears good, police and community leaders say. Residents say, however, the police can do more. Some want a tactical narcotics team, a special police unit that conducts intensive sweeps through a drug-infested neighborhood.
 
Not Hemorrhaging
''I made an impassioned pitch for T.N.T.,'' Inspector Chapman said. ''My rationale was that this is a neighborhood that is taking a stand. I felt that we could hit the pockets where there is trouble and probably wouldn't have to come back for a long time.''
The patrol commander of Brooklyn North, Assistant Police Chief Thomas Gallagher, says that he is sympathetic to the argument but that manpower constraints force him to pay most attention to neighborhoods that are hemorrhaging, rather than those that are merely bleeding.
''I understand the desire to go in and nip it in the bud,'' he said. ''But I would like to reserve T.N.T. for the most needy areas.'' The nearest such operation is in the 83d Precinct, in Bushwick.
Residents find little solace in such reasoning. ''I guess we have to get to the stage where we have shoot-outs on the street before they take action,'' said Mr. Sullivan, the former community board president. ''We need them to do something before the problem gets really bad.''
 
Nun Chases Dealers
Typical of the community's desire to aid in the fight against drug dealers are the efforts of Sister Mary Jane Raeihle, 49, principal of St. John the Baptist School, a Roman Catholic elementary school on Lewis Avenue.
In the last four years Sister Mary Jane has chased away drug dealers loitering near the five-story school, pressured the city to seal a nearby abandoned building that had become a crack house and told the police about suspicious activity.
''The people in the neighborhood know I inform the police on what's going on,'' Sister Mary Jane said. ''Sometimes they are afraid to be seen talking to me on the street, so they tell me in church after Sunday Mass.''
St. John students even videotaped drug deals on the street near the school and sent copies of the tape to Mayor Edward I. Koch. That resulted in an invitation for Sister Mary Jane and several of her students to meet with Mr. Koch. ''Nothing has changed,'' she said.
 
'Love for the Children'
Sister Mary Jane said that she and her staff have been threatened and that the school had received at least two bomb threats.
''You'd be a fool not to be afraid,'' said Frank Coughlin, 31, a religion teacher at St. John who has shooed drug dealers away from the school. ''But it's not the first thing you think of. Love for the children and concern for their safety, that comes first.''
As a result of the efforts of Sister Mary Jane and her students, St. John was one of 47 schools honored in June for excellence in drug prevention by the Federal Department of Education.
Parents of St. John students say they think Sister Mary Jane's efforts have borne some fruit. ''I think it's a little better around here,'' said Patrick Bowers as he stood outside the buff-colored school one recent morning with his great-granddaughter, Chakima Bowers, 7, a third grader. ''I don't see as many people on the street as I used to.''
Yet given the allure of crack, and the vast sums to be made from it, some wonder if efforts like Sister Mary Jane's are little more than holding actions.
''They'll never get rid of it; it's too built in,'' said Tracy Kirkland, striding quickly towards St. John, her 5-year-old son, Tyreek, in tow. ''The best you can do is make sure it doesn't get any worse.''

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
Dartmouth Divestment Announced

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 14

 BODY:
Dartmouth College has said it will sell off $11.5 million in investments in companies doing business in South Africa by the end of the year.
The Board of Trustees of the school, where South Africa's apartheid policies have been hotly debated, said Monday it would also refrain from such investments in the future. 
James O. Freedman, Dartmouth's president, read an announcement from the board at a faculty meeting, and 250 to 300 students who were present cheered.
The board said that the investments had ''great symbolic meaning'' and that disputes over them undermined Dartmouth's ability to achieve educational goals.
Since 1972, Dartmouth has adopted investment policies that prohibit investments in South African companies, financial institutions from making loans to the South African Government, companies from supplying goods and services that are involved in enforcing apartheid and companies from conducting business in South Africa that have failed to follow certain employment practices.
The school's investments in companies conducting business in South Africa have declined to $11.5 million, or less than 2 percent of its endowment, from a high of $63 million, or 15 percent, the trustees said.
In November 1985, students built shanties on the Dartmouth green to protest apartheid. The following January, 12 students, including 9 members of The Dartmouth Review, an independent conservative weekly, attacked the shanties with sledgehammers, saying that the school should not be held hostage by any group and that the shanties were erected illegally.

HEADLINE: Alcohol Warning: Impact Is Debated

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14

 BODY:
Under a law that is to go into effect Saturday, alcoholic beverages produced after that date will have to have warning labels alerting consumers to the dangers of drunken driving and drinking during pregnancy.
The law requires all alcoholic beverages sold in this country to carry the warning ''in a conspicuous and prominent place.'' While some companies, like the Miller Brewing Company, have already begun to label their products, most warnings will not appear for several months.
The new warning will read: ''1) According to the Surgeon General, women should not drink alcoholic beverages during pregnancy because of the risk of birth defects. 2) Consumption of alcoholic beverages impairs your ability to drive a car or operate machinery, and may cause health problems.'' 
The regulations governing the text and placement of the warning, written by the Federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, are temporary. The bureau will probably issue permanent regulations by the end of the year, said Dot Koester, a spokeswoman for the agency. The warning does not have to be in advertising.
Advocates of labeling say the current wording does not go far enough and are urging the bureau to strengthen it. They also say that the temporary rules do not give the warnings enough prominence. The rules require containers of more than eight ounces to present the warning in letters no smaller than two millimeters, the size of capital letters in this article. Letters on containers less than eight ounces can be one millimeter.
''It's almost impossible to read,'' Senator Albert Gore, Democrat of Tennessee, said today at a news conference announcing a campaign to call attention to the warnings. ''The A.T.F. has purposely allowed the industry to come up with a label that is illegible.''
Ms. Koester of the bureau said, ''Certainly we'll be considering everybody's complaints,'' in drawing up final regulations.
The law is the first time the Federal Government has required the industry to warn the public about its products. Senator Strom Thurmond, Republican of South Carolina, who wrote the legislation, had sought similar measures every year since 1969.
The bill was passed after a compromise in September 1988, made in light of growing anti-drug sentiment and after medical evidence was presented linking alcohol consumption during pregnancy to birth defects. President Ronald Reagan signed the bill into law on Nov. 18, 1988. Companies may be penalized up to $10,000 a day for not complying. Representatives of the alcohol industry have opposed the law, fearing that the labels would harm sales. The Distilled Spirits Council of the United States, a trade association representing manufacturers of liquor sold in this country, said in a statement that the law was not necessary because consumer awareness of the dangers of alcohol ''is and has been extraordinarily high.''
But F. A. Meister, president and chief executive of the council, said recently, ''Although we do not believe that any additional reminders are necessary, we are prepared, as a responsible industry, to comply fully with the requirements.''
Senator Thurmond and Representative John Conyers Jr., Democrat of Michigan, who introduced Mr. Thurmond's legislation in the House, contended in a letter earlier this year to Stephen E. Higgins, director of the alcohol bureau, that the law should be strengthened.
''Alcohol is a drug,'' the lawmakers wrote. ''Its misuse is perhaps the most costly of all substance abuses, responsible for more than 100,000 deaths a year, $116 billion in lost money to our economy, thousands of birth defects, tens of thousands of addicted Americans and broken families, and a series of health disorders and diseases.''
Christine Lubinski, representative of the National Council on Alcoholism, said in an interview that the warnings were not strong enough and that the Bush Administration's anti-drug policy had ''quietly left out the biggest drug problem in this country, which is alcohol.'' Ms. Lubinski is one of many advocates who argue that warnings should also cite alcohol's link to hypertension, liver disease and cancer; its potential hazards when combined with other drugs, and its possible addictive qualities.
Advocates also hope the final regulations will require bigger warnings placed prominently on the products.
Ms. Lubinski said: ''In our view, the requirements of the temporary rule represent the lowest common denominator of compliance with the law.''
Jeff Becher, vice president of the Beer Institute, which represents American brewers, said the institute believes that the regulations proposed by the alcohol bureau are reasonable and that the the labels are readable.
Tom Hills, a spokesman for the bureau, said in response to critics of the temporary rules, ''I think they should wait to see the final regulations. We had to put out something within 90 days of passage of the law.''

HEADLINE: Review/Film;
Japan's Comedy Legend Comes to the United States

BYLINE: By CARYN JAMES

 BODY:
In Japan, the character of Tora-san is as familiar and popular as Mickey Mouse is in America, as bumbling and endearing as Ralph Kramden, as durable as James Bond. Since 1969, 41 films have centered on this cheerful, middle-aged street vendor who embodies traditional values of family and home life while remaining an unambitious, unattached drifter in an increasingly buttoned-down, economically driven society. Tora-san has become so spectacularly successful that for years sociologists have pondered the cultural roots, class consciousness and moral implications of these decidedly unsophisticated comedies. 
''Tora-san Goes to Vienna,'' the latest in the series and the first to be commercially released in this country - it opens today at the Carnegie Screening Room - is more successful as a sociological study than as a comic film. It has the plodding pace and easy sentimentality of ''Family Ties Goes to London,'' or any other made-for-television movie that tries to enliven an aging sitcom formula by dropping the characters into fresh, photogenic settings.
As usual, Tora-san solves a problem, is disappointed in love and inevitably returns to his extended family, including a sympathetic sister who explains that Tora didn't reject the world; it rejected him.
But Tora's evidence suggests that the modern world is worth rejecting. An overworked businessman named Hyoma throws himself under a train on which Tora is riding. The train stops in time, the good-hearted Tora throws a party with Hyoma's money, and the businessman is so cheered up that he sets off for a vacation in Vienna, taking Tora along in gratitude.
Yoji Yamada, who has directed all but two of the Tora-san films, races through Vienna as if he were churning out a hack travelogue. The city is merely backdrop for Tora's predictable homesickness, which he shares with a pretty Japanese tour guide.
Even before the hero leaves Tokyo, though, the film maps out its themes. Tora sees in Hyoma the effects of ''severe competition among white-collar workers'' and warns his nephew, who is struggling to pass college entrance exams, ''Your type will soon get sick.'' It is easy to understand why audiences might escape from their own workaday competition by cheering for Tora-san, and more difficult to understand why they find him funny.
Slangy expressions in the subtitles suggest some untranslatable dialogue. But even the perfectly accessible visual jokes - Tora wears sandals to visit Mozart's statue and eats Cup O'Noodles in his hotel room -seem lame. Japanese audiences have 20 years' worth of familiarity to build on; Americans coming in late may be as baffled as if they had just been introduced to someone's favorite uncle, who turns out to be an awfully banal guy.
 
YOU HAD TO BE THERE - TORA-SAN GOES TO VIENNA, directed by Yoji Yamada; screenplay (in Japanese with English subtitles) by Mr. Yamada and Yoshitaka Asama; photography by Tetsuo Takaba; music by Naozumi Yamamoto; art direction, Mitsuo Degawa; produced by Kiyoshi Shimazu and Kiyo Kurosu; released by Kino International Corporation. At Carnegie Screening Room, Seventh Avenue at 57th Street. Running time: 111 minutes. This film has no rating.

The Economy
Lawmakers in both parties are scrambling to save nine tax breaks due to expire at the end of the year. The Senate yesterday added them to an aid package for Hungary and Poland. [Page A1.] 
Early November sales of domestically produced cars plunged 23.1 percent, prompting analysts to predict plant shutdowns and layoffs. [D1.] Hurt by auto sales, retail sales fell 1 percent in October, the first decline in eight months. [D3.] Industrial production tumbled 0.7 percent last month. [D2.]

HEADLINE: Delta Order For Boeing, McDonnell

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
Delta Air Lines, announcing plans to expand what is already one of the most modern fleets in the industry, said yesterday that it was ordering or placing options on 260 aircraft worth about $10 billion with the Boeing Company and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation. The total is one of the largest orders in the history of the industry.
Ronald W. Allen, chairman and chief executive of Delta, the nation's third-largest airline, said the company has orders or options for 160 of McDonnell Douglas's new MD-90 aircraft worth about $6.4 billion. Delta's order means that McDonnell Douglas can begin making the plane, a derivative of McDonnell Douglas's popular MD-80. 
Delta has chosen a 150-seat version of the plane, which is powered by V2500 engines made by International Aero Engine, a venture owned by United Technologies, Rolls-Royce, Japanese Aero Engines, Fiat Aviazione and the MTU unit of Daimler-Benz.
 
Help for McDonnell
The company is also buying 100 Boeing 737-300 aircraft worth about $3.6 billion, which will have 120 seats. The plane will be powered by CFM56-3 series engines from CFM International, a joint venture of General Electric and Snecma of France.
While the large order will help McDonnell Douglas stay in the commercial aircraft business, analysts said the company would not make much money because it gave Delta low prices. They said Boeing, the industry leader whose planes are far more in demand, would get a better price for its planes.
Phil Friedman, the airline analyst for Drexel Burnham Lambert, said the company would have to develop new airplanes instead of relying on derivatives.
 
Strengthening Its Hubs
Delta plans to use the short- and medium-haul planes to strengthen its biggest hubs at Atlanta and Dallas, as well as smaller hubs in Cincinnati, Salt Lake City, Los Angeles and Orlando, Fla.
The carrier already had 260 aircraft on order. Its present fleet of 406 planes is one of the youngest among the large American carriers, with an average age of 8.4 years.
Delta's stock closed down 25 cents yesterday, at $66.375, on the New York Stock Exchange. Shares of Boeing, which has been hampered in its ability to build planes by a six-week strike, fell 50 cents, to $55.375, and McDonnell Douglas stock rose 12.5 cents, to $69.25.
Several of Delta's competitors among the leading airlines have bought new aircraft recently, and in the past year, a number of even larger aircraft orders have been placed.
Last April United ordered 370 airplanes worth $15.74 billion from Boeing, the largest aircraft order ever. The same month, GPA Group Ltd., the world's biggest aircraft leasing company, ordered $9.4 billion worth of planes from Boeing.
Mr. Allen said the order gave Delta a lot of flexibility. He said that if the economy continued to be strong, Delta could keep some its older planes and use the new planes to expand.
If the economy slows, he said, the planes will be used mostly to replace older aircraft.
Mr. Allen said most of the planes would be purchased by Delta from its cash flow although Delta may decide to lease some of the planes.
He said that Delta could buy the planes without sharply changing its debt structure, although the airline had a $1 billion line of credit to draw on if needed.

HEADLINE: U.S. Auto Sales Drop By 23.1%

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Nov. 14

 BODY:
Early November sales of domestically produced cars plunged 23.1 percent, prompting gloomy predictions from industry analysts of more plant shutdowns and layoffs in the near future.
''Clearly we're in a full-blown automotive recession with plenty of implications for the industrial sector,'' said Scott Merlis, an analyst for Morgan Stanley & Company. ''The next three to six months in Detroit are going to be tough.''
If sales continue to fall for the rest of the month at the same rate as in the first 10 days, Mr. Merlis said, ''it would be tantamount to the bottom falling out of the market.'' 
 
More Plant Closings Likely
Some auto plants have already been shut temporarily, and more could be closed before the industry's traditional Christmas holiday break, which lasts for about a week and a half, or sometime in the first quarter 1990.
In either case, analysts said, fourth-quarter profits were likely to be reduced by the drop in shipments to dealers, an increase in discounts and rebates offered to customers, or both.
The seasonally adjusted annual rate for the period was 5.6 million. There were nine selling days this year and last.
The lagging sales came despite extensive rebates of up to $1,000 on certain models. But some analysts said the latest rebates are less than what was being offered in August and September on 1989 models and are offset by higher prices on 1990 models.
 
Big Three Sales Down
In October, car and light-truck sales by the General Motors Corporation, the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation fell 14.1 percent from the year before. That slump helped push all retail sales for October down by 1 percent, the first decline in eight months. In other economic reports, industrial production tumbled seven-tenths of 1 percent and the operating rate at factories and utilities fell to 82.8 percent in October. [Pages D2 and D3.] In the Nov. 1-10 period, sales at G.M., the nation's largest auto maker, fell 29.1 percent, to 62,549 cars. Ford's car sales were off 23.5 percent, to 43,808, and Chrysler's car sales were down 22.5 percent to 20,766.
The Honda Motor Company, which has become an important domestic producer in the last few years, postedan unusual decline, reporting sales of 7,431, down 30.5 percent.
The Big Three and five Japanese auto makers reported retail sales of 143,467 cars in the period, compared with 186,521 in the comparable period last year. The Nissan Motor Corporation and the Toyota Motor Corporation reported gains while the Mazda Motor Corporation's domestic-car sales were off 11.8 percent.
 
Slower Decline for Japanese
Although the Japanese auto makers that make cars in the United States have also experienced softer sales, their business has been stronger than that of the United States companies. As a result, the Japanese are increasing their market share.
Light-truck sales for the period totaled 92,283, which included sales of mini-vans, pickups and utility vehicles, a 15.3 percent decline from 108,976 in the period last year.
 
Nissan Light-Truck Sales Up
G.M.'s light-truck sales were off 20.9 percent; Ford's 14.3 percent, and Chrysler's 9.9 percent. Nissan's light-truck sales jumped 30.6 percent.
Analysts were divided on whether the slow sales, which started in October, partly constituted a sales ''payback'' for the aggressive discounts offered in the fall. Typically a period of strong sales spurred by discounting is followed by a period of unusually weak sales, after which the trend returns to roughly the same level it was before discounting.
''Consumers are not interested in buying cars at these prices,'' said Harvey Heinbach, an automotive analyst for Merrill Lynch & Company. ''By this time the payback should be starting to ease.''
Charles Brady of Oppenheimer & Company said: ''I was a little disappointed sales didn't bounce back. We've had a pretty strong run of sales and whether it takes three or four or five 10-day periods to get back to normal; you have to be patient.''
Ward's Automotive Reports, an industry trade publication, estimated on Monday that fourth-quarter car production would be about 1.68 million units, down from 1.89 million units last year. Analysts, however, agreed that the fourth-quarter total is still too high given the current level of sales.
On a preliminary basis, production planners for the auto makers have been telling Ward's that first-quarter production will be about 1,781,000, down from 1,899,000 in the period a year ago. But Ward's said the planners were not sure whether the estimates were realistic ''because of the changing market.''
''It's probably too late to cut production much in the fourth quarter,'' said Ed Yardeni, chief economist for Prudential-Bache Securities, since auto makers must give suppliers some notice so they can curtail shipments of parts. ''But they'll have to slash production in the first quarter.''
Slow retail sales cause the inventory of unsold cars and trucks to swell, which in turn increases dealers' financing outlays. For the last several months, franchised dealers have been ordering fewer cars from the factories in an effort to keep the inventory manageable. That has caused temporary shutdowns.

HEADLINE: At Last, a Practical Electric Vehicle?

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TEANECK, N.J., Nov. 14

 BODY:
In the quest for clean air, the utility industry today introduced a high-technology entry to curb pollution from autos: an electric van that speeds along at up to 72 miles an hour, and can run for more than 100 miles without having to be recharged.
The shiny maroon vehicle, housed in the body of a Chrysler van, is a prototype that the producers hope will be in production in about three years. But at a national conference here, begun today, the Electric Power Research Institute also showed off less advanced models based on the body of a General Motors van, which customers can order today for delivery next year.
''Go out and kick the tires -they're real,'' said Richard E. Balzhiser, president of the power research institute, which is sponsoring the two-day conference. 
 
Long a Dream
Replacing gasoline with electricity in vehicles has been talked about and tinkered with since the early days of the automobile, and particularly since the 1973 oil embargo. But the cars have never had the range or durability to be very useful. Today, however, improved technology and the prospects of tougher environmental enforcement are beginning to make electric vehicles look more practical.
Moreover, even advocates concede that electric vehicles will be a modest niche market for the foreseeable future, mainly used as delivery trucks, service vans and the like that travel short distances each day. Optimists predict that the potential market is more 100,000 electric vehicles a year, compared with a total American market of 15 million cars and light trucks.
Still, the first factory production of an electric vehicle in North America in recent years, with the General Motors van body, is scheduled to begin in May. The power research group, a nonprofit utility consortium based in Palo Alto, Calif., hopes to sell 500 next year.
''We are looking for a foot in the door that will convince the population,'' Mr. Balzhiser said.
According to C. Dennis Bausch, a vice president of Vehma International Inc., a developer of the General Motors-based van, North American production of the G.M. Vandura, the Ford Econoline and the Chrysler Ram models comes to 440,000 a year. Half are for commercial use and, he estimated, electric vans could substitute for perhaps half of those -120,000 a year..
 
Clean-Air Campaigns
The main force behind the push for electric vehicles is that clean air is suddenly a national priority. Nearly 60 percent of the population of the United States lives in areas that do not meet Federal clear air standards. One area that violates the standards, Los Angeles, has mandated that 40 percent of passenger vehicles and 70 percent of freight vehicles run on clean fuels by the year 2000. And Glenn Barr, a Los Angeles Deputy Councilman, said the vehicles shown here demonstrated that the technology exists to make those vehicles electric.
In fact, the higher-technology Chrylser-body van, still a prototype, shows that substantial progress has been made. Its nickel-iron batteries are 30 percent lighter than standard lead-acid batteries storing the same amount of power, an important consideration since a heavier battery means more energy to move the vehicle, and therefore less range. And the fuel economy of the new van is half a kilowatt-hour per mile, a substantial improvement over earlier models.
The model about to enter production is known as the G-Van, after General Motors' designation of the body style. It was developed by the power research institute; Vehma, a subsidiary of the Magna International Company, a Toronto-based auto parts maker; Chloride EV Systems, which made the batteries, and General Motors, with support from the Southern California Edison Company.
Although it uses lead-acid batteries, it also represents technical progress. In test rides today, it accelerated acceptably, but designers are still working on the whine of the motor.
 
It's Not Cheap
Like all electrics, this van uses no energy when it is not moving, in contrast to internal combustion engines, which continue to burn fuel while idling. Thus, the advantage of electric vehicles is magnified as traffic worsens, engineers say. But it had better have an advantage, because it sells for $32,000, roughly double the cost of a four-cylinder gasoline model.
Yet with opinion polls showing a popular willingness to spend more to protect the environment, the appeal of the electric vehicle is obvious. The vehicles produce no pollution at the point of use, and the power plants that supply them are substantially cleaner sources of energy than gasoline engines. The research institute, comparing the G.M.-based electric van with its gasoline cousin, found a 97 percent reduction in pollution.
The attraction is obvious for the utilities, too. A single electric car would use about one and a half times as much electricity as a typical household, said Lawrence Hamlin, manager of research at Southern California Edison. The utility has enough slack capacity to run 600,000 vehicles, which would add $90 million a year to profits, Mr. Hamlin said.
The new Chrysler-based van is meant to be charged by a 220-volt circuit - the kind used in households to run electric ovens or central air-conditioning - at 40 amperes. That amount of electricity is the rough equivalent of running every electric-using device in a typical house. Some industry officials foresee more advanced technologies, like power lines buried in the pavement from which cars pick up electricity..
First, however, the business is struggling to get off the ground. The van will be sold through General Motors dealerships. Marketing plans for the Chrysler-based van are less certain.
In the face of that uncertainty, however, there is appetite. Martin F. Gitten, a spokesman for Con Edison, said his company had already tested some cars converted to electricity, and ''everywhere you took them, it was like the Pied Piper of Hamlin, it drew a crowd.''
''There is a public fascination,'' he said. ''All we need now is the technology.''

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Monetary Policy: A New Old Twist

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
FOR nearly a century, monetary theorists have been searching for their Holy Grail: a way to figure just the right amount of money to keep the economy on an even keel. Now two more pilgrim-scholars, David Glasner, an economist at the Federal Trade Commission, and Earl Thompson, a professor at the University of California at Los Angeles, are hot on the trail.
It is too early to say whether their clever variation on a long forgotten proposal of the great pre-Keynsian economist, Irving Fisher, will stand up to critical scrutiny. But the idea, described in surprisingly readable detail in Mr. Glasner's new book, ''Free Banking and Monetary Reform'' (Cambridge University Press, $32.50), should intrigue anyone who thinks that even the Federal Reserve can make mistakes. 
At awesome risk of oversimplification, strategies for fine-tuning money and credit fall into three categories. Those who believe in a gold standard (or a standard based on other commodities) think the best monetary policy is one that runs on automatic pilot. They would fix the value of the currency to the weight of the commodity - say $400 for an ounce of gold.
Commodity standards work: When prices rise people trade their cash for metal, reducing the money supply and dampening inflation. When prices fall they exchange gold for cash, easing credit and stimulating business activity.
But ebbs and flows in the supply of the standard commodity can in themselves become the engine of inflation. The discovery of gold and silver in the New World, for example, caused a great inflation in 16th-century Europe. That is one big reason why monetarists, believers in the second approach, prefer an indirect method of fixing the quantity of money to the direct fixing of its value in terms of precious metal. Unfortunately, though, the successful working of a quantity standard is even more problematic.
The definition of money is elusive in a modern deregulated economy with a dozen different ways to hold liquid assets. And however money is defined, it is hard to control the supply with any precision. Moreover, control of the monetary ''aggregates'' has proved to be a highly imperfect means of controlling either prices or output.
The alternative to a value or a quantity standard for money is the third category - seat-of-the-pants pragmatism. And since 1982 the pragmatists at the Fed have managed to contain inflation without generating sustained unemployment. But past victories hardly insure future ones, and the Fed's luck may not hold indefinitely.
That is where the Glasner-Thompson idea fits in. They start with Irving Fisher's plan for the ultimate commodity standard. As in a gold standard, currency would be redeemable for gold. But the amount of gold received would be linked to an index of prices for the whole economy, rather than some fixed weight of the metal.
The Fisher approach really would end inflation: Unlike a monetarist approach, no slippage is possible because control over the value of money is direct and automatic. But the price of price stability a la Fisher could prove very high in the event of an economic shock. Robert Hall, an economist at the Hoover Institution in Palo Alto, Calif., estimated that a successful effort to contain 100 percent of the price impact of the 1974 OPEC oil shock would have resulted in 15 percent unemployment.
Glasner-Thompson would soften the potential blow to output and employment in a novel way, linking currency value to an index of money wages rather than a broader index of prices.
A bit of inflation (or deflation) would thus be possible as real wages rose or fell around average wages fixed in nominal terms. But the resulting potential slippage in prices would serve as a welcome buffer to rapid changes in output and employment. And the likely bounds of both inflation and unemployment, Mr. Glasner argues, would be far narrower than they are in today's world of discretionary monetary policy.
Something akin to a price-index standard for money has been used in Chile with apparent success for some years. For the moment, though, the Glasner-Thompson approach is an intellectual curiosity in the industrialized world. Radical ideas, even good ones, are easy to ignore when the world seems adequately served by familiar old ones. And as Mr. Glasner ruefully admits, this idea is so complicated that it would even be hard to sell in a buyer's market.
But times could change. A stumble by the Fed, and people might again begin to wonder why we trust a handful of bankers and bureaucrats to take care of monetary policy, when monetary policy just might be able to take care of itself.

HEADLINE: Factory Operating Rate And Output Show Drops

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14

 BODY:
Industrial production tumbled seven-tenths of 1 percent last month to its lowest level in three and a half years, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, as an aircraft strike and the California earthquake hammered the economy's already sluggish manufacturing sector.
The Fed said that without the strike at the Boeing Company and the disruptive effects of the San Francisco earthquake, ''the total index would have been nearly unchanged in October, continuing its recent sluggish trend.''
The decline was the steepest since a 1.3 percent plunge in March 1986.
Industrial production, which was unchanged in September, has shown weakness in recent months, as the Fed kept a tight grip on credit to slow the economy and curb inflation. 
 
Report on Factories
But while the Fed's interest-rate policies were having an adverse effect on the manufacturing sector, another report indicated the central bank was being successful in keeping inflation in check.
In that report, the Fed said the operating rate of the nation's factories, mines and utilities fell eight-tenths of a percentage point, to 82.8 percent in October. Analysts generally consider an operating rate of 85 percent or more to be inflationary because it could lead to shortages and thus higher prices.
Factory use had dipped in September to 83.6 percent from 83.8 percent in August.
The October output was foreshadowed by the Labor Department's report earlier this month of a loss of 13,000 manufacturing jobs in October, a drop in the average manufacturing workweek and virtually no factory overtime.
But David Jones, an economist with Aubrey G. Lanston & Company in New York, said the sluggishness was worsened by the strike, which caused a four-tenths of 1 percent decline, and the earthquake, which was responsible for a two-tenths of 1 percent drop.
''If you take into account the special factors, we were down just one-tenth of 1 percent,'' he said. ''That is much more consistent with the pattern of preceding months in which the industrial sector is showing weakness while the others, particularly the service sector, are holding up well.''
John Silvia, an economist with Kemper Financial Services in Chicago, said fairly steady consumer spending coupled with a weak manufacturing sector indicated ''a little bit of a two-tier economy showing up again, similar to what we had earlier in this economic expansion.''
Industrial production at manufacturing plants that make both durable and nondurable goods fell eight-tenths of 1 percent in October after falling two-tenths of 1 percent in September.
Durable manufacturing was off 1.5 percent, compared with a drop of three-tenths of 1 percent in September and a gain of four-tenths of 1 percent in August. Nondurable manufacturing rose one-tenth of 1 percent after falling that level in September and rising one-tenth of 1 percent in August.
 
Output at Utilities Up
Output was unchanged at mines, compared with gains of 2.1 percent in September and six-tenths of 1 percent the previous month. Output at utilities was up five-tenths of 1 percent after a 1.2 percent advance in September and a decline of seven-tenths of 1 percent in August.
The Fed said its industrial production index in October stood at 141.4 percent of its 1977 base, down from 142.4 percent a month earlier.
At the same time, it said the manufacturing-plant operating rate fell from 83.7 percent in September to 82.8 percent last month. The rate had peaked at 84.7 percent in January.
The rate at factories producing durable goods - big-ticket items expected to last more than three years -dropped 1.4 percentage points, to 80.9 percent. The rate at factories producing nondurable goods fell two-tenths of a percentage point, to 85.5 percent.
The operating rate at mines was up one-tenth of a percentage point, to 84.6 percent, while it rose four-tenths of a percentage point, to 81.2 percent, at utilities.
