HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Sugar Prices Reach Highs On Lagging Global Output

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
World sugar prices resumed their advance yesterday and posted new contract highs in New York. The yearlong rise in prices of free-market sugar also exerted upward pressure on the controlled domestic market.
At the close of the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York, the March 1990 world sugar delivery, the most actively traded contract, soared 37-hundredths of a cent a pound, to a contract high of 15.24 cents. The closing low for the contract, 8.40 cents, was set on Oct. 10, 1988. The previous closing high was 15.19 cents, set on Friday. 
Meanwhile, the thinly traded spot January domestic sugar contract rose a tenth of a cent a pound, to 23.20 cents.
''The cause of the rise in world sugar is simply that global output in 1989-90 is expected to fall short of consumption for the fifth year in a row,'' said Harri Schwartz, head of tropical commodities research at Cargill Investor Services.
The F. O. Licht Organization, the leading statisticians of the industry, said global sugar consumption in the year ended Aug. 31 was roughly 107 million metric tons, while the output was 104.8 million tons. Licht, based in Hamburg, West Germany, projected consumption in the current year to exceed output by 109 million to 108.8 million tons.
 
Out-of-Reach Luxury
But rising output has failed to keep pace with consumption in recent years. One reason is that sugar is still an out-of-reach luxury in much of the world. In most developing countries, economists link sugar consumption to improvements or declines in living standards because it is considered an essential part of the diet. That is why retail sugar prices in much of the third world are often kept low by government subsidies.
In the United States, sweeteners made from corn are increasingly taking a share of the market. Now, for example, 90 percent of domestic caloric soft drinks have high-fructose corn sweeteners.
Most recently, sugar prices have been responding to increasing imports by the Soviet Union, the world's largest sugar producer. Soviet output comes almost entirely from sugar beets. The sucrose from beets is indistinguishable from that obtained from sugar cane.
 
'Caught in a Bind'
In the latest statistical sugar crop year, which ended Aug. 31, the Soviet Union produced an estimated 9.4 million metric tons of sugar. Brazil and Cuba ranked second and third, as each produced about 8 million tons, while the United States output from sugar cane and beets was fourth with 6.6 million tons.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Posts Sharp Decline; Mark's Advance Continues

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell sharply against all major currencies, while the West German mark continued to take center stage in foreign exchange.
Gold prices gained ground. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery settled at $393.30 an ounce, up $2.30 from late Monday. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted a late bid for gold at $392.50 an ounce, up $2.40. 
Currency dealers said continued signs of an economic slowdown in the United States helped depress the dollar by renewing speculation that the Federal Reserve would lower interest rates. A reduction in rates could hurt the dollar's value.
The Government reported yesterday that retail sales slipped 1 percent in October while industrial production declined seven-tenths of a percentage point that month.
 
German Rate Rise Seen
But dealers said attention in the marketplace was again concentrated on cross trading as the mark continued to climb. They said the flood of East Germans crossing into West Germany has raised the possibility of higher inflation in West Germany and higher interest rates there.
The dollar fell to 1.8540 marks from 1.8615 in London, and to 1.8350 marks from 1.8615 in New York.
In Tokyo, where trading ends before Europe's business day begins, the dollar closed up 0.25 Japanese yen, to 143.80 yen. It traded at 144 yen in London, and at 143.05 yen in New York, down from 143.925.
The dollar was also weaker against the British pound. Sterling bought $1.5810 in London, up from $1.5805 late Monday. It traded at $1.5945 in New York, up from $1.5820.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's quotes, were: 1.6175 Swiss francs, down from 1.64145; 6.2280 French francs, down from 6.3135; 1,343.00 Italian lire, down from 1,359.75, and 1.16975 Canadian dollars, down from 1.16845.
Silver prices were mixed. On New York's Comex, silver for current delivery rose to $5.408 an ounce, from $5.297 late Monday.

HEADLINE: After 54 Years, River's Quirk Gives Up a Clue in a Killing

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWPORT, Wash.

 BODY:
Cold and violent, the Spokane River runs gray this time of year, concealing quirks of nature and forgotten crimes, mysteries flowing away with the river itself.
A few months ago, the river gave up one of its secrets: the murder weapon in a 54-year-old unsolved killing that was the subject of the nation's oldest active homicide investigation.
With the aid of the rusted pistol recovered from the river bottom, the sheriff of a wilderness county on the Idaho border has identified a 90-year-old suspect in the 1935 case. In the process, he has opened a window on a Depression-era subculture of black-market food and corrupt police detectives, a desperate world in which men killed for cheese. 
From the beginning, this was no ordinary murder; here in Pend Oreille County it was the crime of the century. Sheriff George Coniff, a good man by reputation, was shot four times on the night of Sept. 15, 1935, when he confronted two men who were breaking into a creamery to steal cheese and butter, prize black-market commodities during the depths of the Depression.
 
Detective Is Named as Killer
Fifty-four years after the slugs from a .32-caliber gun were removed from Mr. Coniff's body, one of his successors, Anthony Bamonte, learned about the case while researching a history of homicides for his master's thesis. Sheriff Bamonte came across an old police report in which a detective from Spokane was named as the killer.
The detective was named in 1935 by a man who told a police investigator that he had been involved in the creamery burglary. The investigator wrote down the information at the time but kept it in a confidential report. But in a memo addressed to his superiors and a neighboring sheriff 15 years later, the investigator, saying he wanted to clear his conscience before he died, told of his earlier confidential report and urged that the case be reopened.
But it never was, partly because the neighboring sheriff died shortly thereafter.
The man who said he was involved in the burglary had described a pattern of creamery burglaries in the 1930's, with extensive dates and details. The man said the 1935 crime was masterminded by Clyde Ralstin, a Spokane police detective.
According to the police report, the stolen creamery products were exchanged and sold through the detective's ranch and a restaurant owned by another man. Man With 'Dirty Conscience'? The report was apparently never investigated at the time by the Spokane police, whose ranks included survivors of the era of $10 bribes. But with the report as his clue, Sheriff Bamonte asked the Spokane Police Department, in the county just south of his, to help reopen the case.
''Could there be an old man out there somewhere with a dirty conscience?'' Mr. Bamonte wrote to the department.
When a local newspaper published an article about Mr. Bamonte's interest in the case, it spurred the memory of Daniel Mangan, a retired Spokane detective who is now 86 years old.
Mr. Mangan told Sheriff Bamonte he believed Detective Ralstin was the 1935 killer. He knew, he said, because two days after the killing, he and a fellow officer were told by their captain that an officer was in trouble. They were handed a gun, wrapped in paper, and told to dispose of it.
Asked by Sheriff Bamonte why they would do such a thing, Mr. Mangan, who has suffered two strokes since his interview with the sheriff, told of widespread corruption. Every officer had something on others, he said.
''I got envelopes in the mail and there would be $10 bills in the envelope with my name,'' he said.
 
'He Always Wanted to Tell'
The retired officer led Sheriff Bamonte to a bridge over the roaring Spokane Falls, a favorite spot for suicide, and said it was the place where he and his partner had thrown the gun.
''He always wanted to tell somebody this,'' Rosemary Miller, Mr. Mangan's daughter, said in an interview.
Next, Mr. Bamonte found Officer Mangan's former partner, Bill Parsons, in a Spokane nursing home. Mr. Parsons, though barely able to breathe without supplemental oxygen, had a vivid memory of the case. A rookie in 1935 who rose to become Chief of Police in the 1960's, Mr. Parsons told Sheriff Bamonte the same story about Detective Ralstin and the gun that Mr. Bamonte had already heard from Officer Mangan and added details about graft among Spokane police officers in the 1930's. A few weeks after his interview, Mr. Parsons died.
''You don't realize how far we've come until you get something like this that shows just how corrupt your average policeman used to be,'' Mr. Bamonte said.
Last August, after a long spell of dry weather, the flow of the Spokane River changed, exposing rocks and mud where half a century earlier the water ran deep. There, wedged between the rocks, Mr. Bamonte found a rusty hunk of metal beneath the bridge. A laboratory report later confirmed that it was a .32-caliber pistol like those issued to Spokane police officers in the 1930's.
 
Police Also Suspect Detective
The sheriff was ecstatic. At last, he believed, he had found the murder weapon. Now, he wanted to talk to Mr. Ralstin, who had reported his .32-caliber revolver stolen not long after the Coniff killing.
Prodded by Mr. Bamonte's discoveries, the Spokane Police Department opened an investigation of its own, interviewing witnesses, studying the police reports unearthed by Sheriff Bamonte and assisting with the laboratory analysis of the gun. Lieut. Gary Johnson, head of the department's internal affairs office, said the department concluded that its former detective was the likely killer of Sheriff Coniff in 1935.
Mr. Bamonte tracked Mr. Ralstin, who is now 90, to the modest home he owns on Flathead Indian Reservation land in Montana. The retired detective refused to talk to the sheriff.
His lawyer, Philip Grainey, said in an interview that Mr. Ralstin ''absolutely denies'' that he killed George Coniff. Mr. Grainey said his client's poor health prevented him from cooperating in the investigation.
''I'm very concerned that a criminal interrogation might just kill this old man,'' said Mr. Grainey. If Mr. Bamonte has enough evidence, ''he should put up and file charges or shut up and let this man die in peace,'' said Mr. Grainey.
 
More Evidence Is Needed
Because there is no statute of limitations on first-degree murder, Mr. Bamonte hopes that charges will eventually be filed against the former detective. But the prosecutor for Pend Oreille County (pronounced pond oh-RAY), while praising Mr. Bamonte for ''an amazing job just to get this far,'' said more evidence was needed.
''If some old codger comes forth and says this former cop told him he did it, we may file,'' said the prosecutor, Tom Metzger. ''But I'm not holding my breath.''
Even if Mr. Ralstin is never tried, Mr. Bamonte believes that a certain level of justice has been achieved and that a psychic duel is settled.
''He knows that I know,'' said Mr. Bamonte. ''I might not have every fact. But it's there. I won't let him die thinking he got away with it.''

HEADLINE: VENTURE PLANNED BY G.E. IN HUNGARY

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
Moving to take advantage of political and economic change in Eastern Europe, the General Electric Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy control of a Hungarian light-bulb manufacturer for $150 million, making it the largest Western investment in Hungary since World War II.
The General Electric deal with the Tungsram Company, one of Hungary's largest industrial concerns, represents the kind of economic payoff that Eastern bloc nations have been seeking as they adopt political reforms and economic policies more attuned to market forces. Under the terms of the deal, G.E. will broaden the Hungarian company's range of lighting products, and transfer management skills and manufacturing technology to Tungsram.
 
A Pace Setter in Change
Long considered the most entrepreneurial of the Eastern bloc nations, Hungary has led the way in the recent wave of change in Eastern Europe. Since May 1988, when the Communist Party's General Secretary, Janos Kadar, was deposed, Hungary has carried out far-reaching economic and political reforms. Restrictions on foreign investment were virtually scrapped, allowing 100 percent ownership of local enterprises, to help the stagnant Hungarian economy. 
In explaining the deal, John F. Welch Jr., General Electric's chairman, stressed the improving economic climate in Hungary for business and confidence that the trend would continue.
''This is the right business in the right place at the right time,'' Mr. Welch said, noting that the deal was ''made possible by the Hungarian Government's policy of encouraging foreign investment and looking to world markets.''
In a statement, Andras Gabor, the president of Tungsram, said: ''Hungary is on the way to democracy and the development of a free-enterprise system. G.E.'s participation in Tungsram gives us the opportunity both to grow our lighting business and to embrace this process of change.''
General Electric agreed to spend $150 million for a 50 percent stake in Tungsram plus one share, giving G. E. control of the Hungarian company. General Electric, one of America's largest industrial corporations, also has the option to buy an additional 20 percent of Tungsram.
G.E. will take over management of the company after the purchase is closed, which is expected before the end of the year. Plans call for the new entity to market bulbs bearing both the G. E. and Tungsram brands. Existing Tungsram products will continue to bear that brand, but higher-technology products introduced by G. E. will carry the G. E. brand.
A spokesman for General Electric said negotiations with Tungsram had been under way since the summer, after the state-owned Hungarian Credit Bank had signaled that the lighting company could be bought when it sold a large stake in Tungsram to a consortium of Western banks led by the Austrian Girozentrale. To complete the deal with General Electric, the Hungarian bank will repurchase those shares and sell them to G. E. Called a Logical Choice Hungary, according to analysts, was a logical choice for one of the biggest Western investments in Eastern Europe. ''Hungary has described itself as the easternmost Western country,'' said Daniel A. Sharp, a foreign-policy consultant to American corporations. ''It has long had a history of entrepeneurial management.''
Mr. Sharp added that while Hungary was the most desirable Eastern European country for Western companies, there was even greater potential in East Germany if economic reforms took hold there. ''You start with Hungary, but then you look to East Germany, because that's where the money is.''
The Tungsram deal is viewed by General Electric as a way to enlarge its ''modest position'' in the European lighting market, according to Mr. Welch. G. E. officials said Tungsram's product lineup would be broadened by the addition of General Electric products including industrial lighting, automotive lamps and miniature halogen and infrared quartz bulbs.
 
Will Introduce New Techniques
The company said it planned to ''invest substantial technological and human resources'' in the venture ''to modernize plant and equipment and to introduce state-of-the-art management techniques.
The Tungsram deal is just the latest action General Electric has taken to bolster its presence in Europe in the run-up to the 1992 deadline for the 12 Western nations of the European Community to establish a single, barrier-free market. The company formed a joint venture this year with Ericsson, the Swedish company, to market mobile radios and cellular telephones, and formed a link with the unrelated General Electric Company P.L.C. in Britain to sell appliances and electrical distribution equipment in Europe.
 
Gain in Trade Expected
Tungsram already sells some products in Western markets, and analysts foresee the G. E. deal as part of a larger trend of West-to-East investment that will increase trade.
''This is a harbinger of movement toward economic integration in Europe,'' said Elliott Zupnick, director of the Institute of Western Europe at Columbia University. ''I think you will see Hungary, Poland and East Germany as associate members of the European Community.''
General Electric officials described Tungsram as a 90-year-old company specializing in light bulbs with sales of $300 million a year. They said that about 80 percent of its sales come from exports, which are about split between Eastern and Western Europe.
 
A Deal in 1913
Ties between the two companies go back a long way. ''In 1913 we gave them some technology for filling light bulbs with gas and obtained a small equity stake in return,'' said Bruce Bunch, a General Electric spokesman. He said it was not clear if the shares were sold or nationalized in later years.
Mr. Welch said General Electric was prepared to make other deals in Eastern Europe and elsewhere if they fit the company's basic plans. ''We have a strategy of trying to be No. 1 in 13 global businesses,'' he said. ''We are not looking in Eastern Europe for a 14th or 15th business. But if we can enhance our existing businesses, we are looking everywhere.''
G. E. officials said they were not concerned about eventually being able to repatriate profits from the Hungarian investment. And Professor Zupnick viewed that statement and the controlling stake that General Electric was taking, with an option for further investment, as a vote of confidence in the future of Hungarian reforms.
''It means that they plan to transmit profits back to the United States at some point,'' he said. ''That says a lot about what they see for the convertibility of currency and the movement of capital.'' The Hungarian currency, the florint, is not currently convertible into Western currencies.

HEADLINE: CUTS ARE EXPECTED FOR U.S. FINANCING IN HIGH-TECH AREA

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
Supporters of increased Government backing for initiatives to maintain American high-technology industries said yesterday that they believe the Bush Administration plans sharp cuts in Defense Department programs that bolster commercial research and development.
Reports have circulated in Washington since Monday that the Administration has directed the Pentagon to cut back financing for high-definition television research and other high-technology efforts. Such programs, which have both military and civilian uses, are viewed by many as vital to American competitiveness.
In a letter sent to President Bush last night, four legislators said they had learned of classified and unclassified documents that called for cutting programs financed by the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, or Darpa. 
 
Critical to Electronics Industry
The programs include high-definition television, an advanced technology that provides a much sharper picture and is considered critical for both the Pentagon and the consumer electronics industry; X-ray lithography, a sophisticated manufacturing technology needed to make semiconductors in the 1990's, and the Pentagon's Manufacturing Technology program, which is intended to develop robots and other computer-assisted equipment.
The letter - signed by Representatives Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri and Mel Levine and Norman Y. Mineta of California, all Democrats, and Senator John Heinz, Republican of Pennsylvania - also said a number of reports from other members of Congress and White House officials indicate that the Administration intends to end all backing for Sematech, a Government-industry consortium that is trying to develop advanced semiconductor manufacturing equipment and gets $100 million a year from the Government.
 
'Economic Insanity'
The letter said eliminating any of the programs would be ''economic insanity.''
Senator Albert Gore Jr., Democrat of Tennessee, also sent a letter to President Bush last night questioning the Administration's actions on high-technology financing. The Senator said he plans to send a letter to his Congressional colleagues today expressing his concern that current financing not be cut back.
White House officials would not comment on the reports, and Dr. Craig Fields, director of Darpa, also had no comment.
In recent years the Defense agency has played a central role in supporting critical United States high-technology industries by financing and coordinating a series of research programs ranging from support for developing advanced chip-making equipment to research into high-definition television, known as HDTV, which gets about $10 million a year in Federal backing. Darpa is also the Government agency that backs Sematech. ''We have a frightening situation in which the ideologues in this Administration are trying to dismantle the most important programs within our Government which focus on the key technologies of the future,'' Mr. Levine said in an interview last night.
Several Congressional staff members and officials at Government agencies said they had been told that Deputy Defense Secretary Donald J. Atwood had in recent days sent an internal document, called a Program Budget Decision, to Dr. Fields that calls for placing a number of recently released HDTV research contracts on hold. Several companies that have received grants from the agency recently said yesterday that they had not heard of any proposed cuts.
Richard G. Darman, the White House budget director, also reportedly sent a memorandum to the Defense Department last week calling for a much broader range of cuts in the 1991 budget. The cuts would cover projects backing research and development into technologies that would be useful for both military and civilian applications.
Several Government officials raised the possibility that the reports are part of an Administration effort to rein in the 1991 Federal budget, which is expected to include cuts in military spending.
''The Bush Administration appears to be on the brink of abandoning our best high technology in the name of budgetary expedience,'' Mr. Mineta said.
 
Merger at Defense
Last week the Administration confirmed that it was planning to merge the Defense Manufacturing Board, organized in March to advise the Pentagon on manufacturing matters, into the Defense Science Board, an older body that provides advice to the department on technical matters. Robert C. McCormack, an agency official, said at the time that the merging of the two bodies was a way of strengthening Defense Department research activities.
In an interview last week, Mr. McCormack said there was no intention to cut Sematech funds.
Members of the Bush Administration have been locked in a debate over how to strengthen American high-technology industries to meet the challenge from Japan and other nations. The lines have been drawn between those in the Administration who insist the Government should play a bigger role in providing money, antitrust relief and other support for industry, and those who argue that such help is not only unfair but probably a waste of taxpayers' money as well.
Mr. Darman and Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, are widely reported to be opposed to extensive Government backing for high-technology research consortiums. One White House official said Mr. Darman believes that the research programs are not as valuable as many high-technology supporters have argued and that the programs can have only a limited impact on America's industrial base. Mr. Darman argues that the technologies are better developed with funds from business and industry.
Meanwhile, Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher and D. Allan Bromley, the President's science adviser, have generally been viewed as supporting high-technology initiatives.
 
No Full Commitment
In September, the Administration backed away from a full commitment to backing HDTV research. At the time, Mr. Mosbacher said he was dropping his plan to develop a Government-industry HDTV initiative in favor of a broader policy of support for high technology.
If the reports are accurate, it would indicate that the Administration is preparing to reject a series of recommendations that are expected to be made on Tuesday by a national advisory committee on semiconductors. That panel is expected to propose that the Government establish a multibillion-dollar venture-capital operation intended to resurrect the American consumer electronics industry. The group, made up of high-level semiconductor industry leaders and Government officials, is known as the National Advisory Committee on Semiconductors.
Former Reagan Administration officials also said yesterday that they were concerned about the reports of a Government pullback from high-technology research. Robert Costello, who as the Pentagon's top procurement officer under President Reagan began many civilian-military research and development programs, including Sematech and the Pentagon's HDTV program, said yesterday that he had heard the reports and was ''bewildered'' by the actions.
''I don't understand these people,'' said Mr. Costello, now a scholar at the Hudson Institute. ''If that's what they're doing and it's some kind of economic policy, I think they don't understand what the consequences will be for our national defense.''

HEADLINE: Clamor in the East: Gratitude and a Request;
In Talk to Congress, Walesa Urges A Marshall Plan to Revive Poland

BYLINE: By NEIL A. LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15

 BODY:
Lech Walesa, the founder of Poland's Solidarity movement, called for a second Marshall Plan today as he addressed a joint meeting of Congress. He warned that without the sort of commitment that helped rebuild Western Europe after World War II, the situation in his country could become dangerous.
The former shipyard electrician began by expressing his gratitude for the support his movement received from Americans in the years that it was supressed and driven underground. He also gave thanks for the support the United States has given to more recent political and economic changes in Poland. 
Nevertheless, to the accompaniment of repeated rounds of hearty applause, Mr. Walesa made it clear that more assistance would be needed to keep Poland from becoming so poor that it could destabilize the region.
''We are not asking for charity or expecting philanthropy,'' he said. ''But we would like to see our country treated as a partner and a friend.'' [Excerpts, page A22.] He chided Americans for offering a surplus of good wishes but a paucity of money. ''We have heard many beautiful words of encouragement,'' he said. ''These are appreciated, but being a worker and a man of concrete work, I must tell you that the supply of words on the world market is plentiful but the demand is falling. Let deeds follow words now.''
 
Boisterous Reception
Mr. Walesa's entrance was announced in much the same manner reserved for the President before a State of the Union Address. ''Mr. Speaker, the leader of Solidarity,'' said the doorkeeper. Mr. Walesa entered the chamber to a boisterous reception and as he made his way down the center aisle, members of Congress struggled to get close and shake his hand.
Among those vigorously applauding Mr. Walesa was Yuri V. Dubinin, the Soviet Ambassador to Washington, who was sitting in the audience.
Mr. Walesa became the third person to address both houses of Congress jointly who was not a sitting head of state. The first was the Marquis de Lafayette, the French nobleman who helped finance the American Revolution, who appeared in 1824, and the other was Winston Churchill, who spoke after he was no longer the British Prime Minister.
But today's event was more like the appearance three years ago of President Corazon C. Aquino of the Philippines - a celebration of a person largely identified with a country's turn to democracy.
Senator Barbara A. Mikulski, a Maryland Democrat whose great-grandmother came from Poland to Baltimore for an arranged marriage, was one of those in the audience who wept during the address. ''I never thought this day would come,'' she said afterward. ''I just didn't think it was Poland's destiny to be free.''
At a banquet in Mr. Walesa's honor at the Capitol tonight, the guest of honor excused himself before the speeches began, pleading fatigue.
Representative Dan Rostenkowski, Democrat of Illinois, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, gave an emotional speech that touched on his own Polish heritage. Of Mr. Walesa, Mr. Rostenkowski said: ''He's freedom. We've got to help these people.'' Mr. Walesa, describing in his address the efforts of the new non-Communist Government in Warsaw, said, ''Our task is viewed with understanding by our Eastern neighbors and their leader, Mikhail Gorbachev.''
But he also said the imposition of a Communist economy on Poland for 40 years had brought it to the ''verge of utter catastrophe,'' and that ''all the countries of the East bloc are bankrupt.'' He recalled that at the end of World War II, Stalin pressed Poland to reject an invitation to take part in the Marshall Plan.
''It is worth recalling this great American plan which helped Western Europe to protect its freedom and peaceful order,'' Mr. Walesa said. ''And now it is the moment when Eastern Europe awaits an investment of this kind - an investment in freedom, democracy and peace, an investment adequate to the greatness of the American nation.''
At a lunch meeting with Senators after his speech, he offered a gloomy assessment of the consequences if the new Solidarity-led Government fails to get control of the economy.
Speaking of his own turn of fortunes, which led him from the shipyard to the Nobel Peace prize and a key political role, he said through a translator, ''I was happier as an electrician and did not understand how difficult it was to make that jump to the public arena.''
 
Poles Proud of Walesa's Speech
WARSAW, Nov. 15 (AP) - Poles expressed pride and satisfaction at Mr. Walesa's speech today to the joint meeting of Congress, which was broadcast live nationwide on Polish TV and radio.
Hundreds of people gathered around TV sets in Warsaw's main train station to watch the speech.
''I think he expressed what many Poles could have expressed,'' said a police officer who declined to give his name. ''It was the right thing to do and it was a pleasure to listen to him.''

CORRECTION-DATE: November 23, 1989, Thursday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article on Nov. 16 about an address by Lech Walesa to a joint meeting of Congress described the precedents incorrectly. He was the fourth foreigner other than national leaders to address such a meeting. Winston Churchill was not the second such person; he was Prime Minister all three times he spoke to Congress.

HEADLINE: Bush Aides Call for Higher Airline Liability Limit

BYLINE: By RICHARD WITKIN

 BODY:
The Bush Administration urged Congress yesterday to ratify a treaty amendment that would increase airline but bar award of additional damages based on an airline's fault or misconduct.
In testimony before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Government officials said the current $75,000 damage limit on flights to and from this country was woefully inadequate.
Jeffrey Shane, an assistant secretary in the Transportation Department, said he personally would be inclined to recommend renouncing the treaty forming the initial basis for damage limits if there was no prospect of considerably higher awards. These would come from the amended treaty and a proposed supplementary insurance plan. 
 
Lawyer Opposes Amendment
The proposed treaty amendment was strongly opposed by Lee S. Kreindler, the chief plaintiffs' lawyer in cases growing out of the bombing of Pan American World Airways Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, last December. He said the treaty amendment, by setting a higher damage limit without exceptions, would simply be protecting airlines from the embarrassment of having lawyers ''poking around in their record of fault and wrongdoing.''
Mr. Kreindler said the Pan Am group that provided security in loading the first leg of Flight 103 in Frankfurt, Germany, was run by a man with a criminal record who promoted and demoted people based not on their skills but on personal and sexual relationships.
The projected treaty amendment on damages is included in the so-called Montreal Protocols, a modification of a much-amended 1929 treaty known as the Warsaw Convention. The convention, initially intended to protect fledgling airlines from damage suits that might bankrupt them, currently provides that an airline is not liable for damages over $75,000 per person on an international flight unless it can be shown to have been guilty of willful misconduct.
 
Willful Misconduct
Courts have found willful misconduct in only two or three cases. But airlines have frequently settled cases out of court for amounts considerably above the limit to avoid the cost and risks of a trial.
In the early 1980's, a effort was made to increase the potential damage limits. The United States signed the Montreal Protocols, which would now raise the limit to about $127,000. And companion legislation was introduced creating a supplementary compensation program that would provide up to $200,000 more per case.
The extra $200,000 would come not from the airline involved but from a fund supported by an international ticket charge.
Though the Foreign Relations Committee overwhelmingly supported the treaty amendment, it fell short of the two-thirds vote required for ratification when it came to the Senate floor.
The issue is not expected to be resolved until the 1990 term.
 
Why It Lost in 1983
In supporting the new treaty amendment, Mr. Shane of the Transportation Department said the 1983 defeat in the Senate came because many Senators thought the proposed damage limits -$117,000 at the time in the treaty and $200,000 in the supplementary plan -were inadequate.
He said that his department, along with the Departments of State and Justice, had drafted a new supplementary plan.
The new plan would remove the limit on economic damages, generally based on a victim's future earning power, and it would also permit recovery of noneconomic damages, like pain and suffering. But it would not permit recovery of punitive damages.
Stuart M. Gerson, assistant attorney general, said the new treaty amendment and supplementary plan ''would provide a welcome alternative to the present system, which can embroil innocent passengers in expensive and time-consuming litigation.''
But Mr. Kreindler said that the best alternative was to renounce the treaty on damage limits altogether.

HEADLINE: Bolivia Declares a State of Siege After Breakdown in Strike Talks

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Nov. 15

 BODY:
The Government declared a three-month state of siege today and rounded up at least 700 teachers and labor leaders a day after negotiations with striking teachers broke down.
Three teachers on a 24-day hunger strike were taken to private clinics where they were in critical condition.
Many of the teachers and labor leaders who were arrested were sent to detention centers in the Bolivian tropics, said Raul Loayza, the Under Secretary of the Interior. 
The Union of Education Workers has been demanding that the country's 80,000 public school teachers, who earn $75 a month, be paid a $103 bonus to compensate for a rise in the cost of living. The Government says it cannot afford the bonus because of the state of the economy. Education spending takes up 18 percent of the country's budget.
 
Elections Called the Spur
The state of siege allows the police to arrest and hold people without charge for 48 hours without a judicial order. Rules governing public meetings and other activities must be determined by state governments.
The center-left government of President Jaime Paz Zamora said it acted to guarantee peaceful local elections next month.
There was little police presence in La Paz and other cities, and business and commercial activity was normal. Power stations in the capital were guarded by soldiers but no violence was reported.
In recent days, teachers and students clashed with the police in La Paz, and the Government closed schools two weeks ago when tens of thousands of workers marched in support of the teachers.
Mr. Paz Zamora's Government, trying to maintain an austerity plan, said in the state of siege decree that the illegal strike created ''a climate of social unrest with demands that the state cannot attend without risking the economic and financial stability of the country.''
 
Cost of Living Is High
The minimum monthly wage is $25. The cost of living, meanwhile, is one of the highest in South America, with the prices of poultry and dairy products comparable to those in the United States and Europe.
Mr. Paz Zamora, who heads the Movement of the Revolutionary Left, a Social Democratic group, pledged to maintain stability after taking office Aug. 6 and has continued austerity measures of the previous Government.
The measures include a wage freeze and lower Government spending to combat a 1985 annual inflation rate of 24,000 percent. The rate has since dropped to 12 percent, and the economy is expected to grow by 2.5 percent this year after years of decline.

HEADLINE: Salvadorans Ask U.S. for Arms Aid

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15

 BODY:
The Government of El Salvador has asked the United States for arms and ammunition to help beat back a guerrilla offensive, American officials said today.
The request was the first since the rebels began a series of attacks in San Salvador, the capital, on Saturday.
''The Salvadorans asked us for munitions, and we more or less agreed to provide them,'' an Administration official said.
Another American official said, ''We are working with the Salvadorans to replenish stocks on an emergency basis.'' He said that El Salvador was not getting anything more than it was already scheduled to receive, but that deliveries would be expedited. El Salvador is supposed to get $85 million worth of military aid in the current fiscal year, the same amount as in the fiscal year that ended Sept. 30. 
The request for arms and ammunition was made through the United States military assistance group in El Salvador, headed by Col. Milton R. Menjivar of the Army.
 
Tracing Users of Weapons
Administration officials said that El Salvador had also asked for laboratory equipment to help the authorities identify people who had been using firearms - presumably rebels who put down their arms and flee San Salvador with civilian residents.
''We are reviewing the request and intend to provide the help if we can,'' an American official said, referring to the tests for chemical residues of gunpowder and gunshot. ''An individual who showed up positive on such tests might well be a guerrilla or a deserter from the Salvadoran Army, and in either case, the authorities would want to arrest him.''
In San Salvador, thousands of civilians fled their homes today, terrified by bombing, strafing and gunfights in the streets and alleys.
Timothy O'Leary, a spokesman for the United States Agency for International Development, said the Administration was assessing Salvadoran needs for food, clothing, medical supplies and other equipment. Agency officials said they might send special shipments of medicine, tents and water containers.
Heavy casualites in El Salvador are creating an urgent need for medical help, American officials said. An aide to Representative Bill McCollum, Republican of Florida, said, ''If the need is confirmed, we will go to American pharmaceutical companies and ask them to donate medicine, and we will arrange for distribution of the supplies in El Salvador.''
 
State Department Statistics
Richard A. Boucher, deputy spokesman at the State Department, said, ''Military sources have told us that 146 Salvadoran troops, 461 guerrillas and 50 civilians have died thus far, and that more than 1,000 Salvadorans have been wounded.'' The actual numbers are almost certainly higher than indicated by these ''early and incomplete figures,'' he said.
Mr. Boucher said the Bush Administration had ''full confidence'' that President Alfredo Cristiani of El Salvador and his armed forces could ''deal with the guerrilla offensive.''
However, Administration officials said civilian casualties were inevitable, in part because rebels of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front were based in densely populated working-class neighborhoods. ''We think it's the height of hypocrisy for the F.M.L.N. to go into neighborhoods and use civilians as a shield, and then complain about civilian casualties,'' Mr. Boucher said.
A senior Defense Department official said the Pentagon had ''no knowledge'' about targets hit in aerial attacks by armed helicopters of the Salvadoran armed forces.
 
Areas of Combat
The fighting today was limited mainly to areas in and around San Salvador and San Miguel, a province capital in eastern El Salvador, the official said, adding that roads and bridges remain open throughout the country.
He reported that Salvadoran security forces were on alert over the weekend because they knew that the guerrillas ''had been building up to this offensive for two months.''
Members of Congress today denounced the guerrillas and expressed hope that President Cristiani would use the minimum force needed to dislodge the rebels from their strongholds.
Bob Dole of Kansas, the Senate Republican leader, said that liberals in the United States had been slow to criticize what he called a ''terrorist assault'' by Salvadoran guerrillas. If the Nicaraguan contras, supported by the United States for the last eight years, staged such an attack on Managua, he said, ''the liberals would be queued up'' to condemn them.
 
Condemnation of Rebels
Representative Dave McCurdy, Democrat of Oklahoma, said the Salvadoran rebel offensive showed that ''the F.M.L.N. is a desperate and violent organization that hopes to achieve through terror in the cities what it cannot achieve at the ballot box.'' He said Mr. Cristiani was responding with ''considerable restraint.''
Representative Joe Moakley, Democrat of Massachusetts, said the fierce fighting showed the need for his bill to halt the deportation of Salvadorans currently in the United States. The bill has been passed by the House and is being considered in the Senate. Salvadoran officials have said that 500,000 of their countrymen, representing about 10 percent of the population, may be living in the United States.
The Foreign Minister of Nicaragua, the Rev. Miguel d'Escoto Brockmann, said today that human rights abuses by the Salvadoran Government and Salvadoran death squads provided some justification for the latest guerrilla offensive. ''There is obviously a link between the Government and the death squads,'' he said.
In an interview here, Father d'Escoto said: ''Cristiani is a decent person. I have no problem with him.'' The Nicaraguan Foreign Minister said that Roberto d'Aubuisson, whom he described as ''a bloodthirsty butcher,'' retains substantial power in El Salvador as a leader of Mr. Cristiani's right-wing Arena party.

HEADLINE: Aid to Cambodia Non-Communists Is Detailed

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 15

 BODY:
With growing concern in Congress that any American military aid to non-Communist forces in Cambodia could work to the ultimate benefit of the Khmer Rouge guerrillas, officials have described the way the current system functions.
The United States, like Britain and the countries of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, insists that it has no ties to Cambodia's Khmer Rouge guerrillas and provides them no aid of any kind. China is the Khmer Rouge's sole supplier, officials say, with the help of the Thai Government, which provides transit facilities for Chinese aid and protection for Khmer Rouge notables on Thai soil. 
Aid to the non-Communist Cambodian factions is channeled though an Asean-sponsored organization called the Working Group, which formally consists of Thailand, Malaysia and Singapore, but in which American military and intelligence officers participate, as do representatives of the non-Communist Cambodian factions. The Working Group, based in Bangkok, funds the non-Communists and buys them arms.
The Thais and Malaysians do much of the training. The Singaporeans pay for most of the arms, including American weapons made under license in other countries, like South Korea or Taiwan. Those weapons include M-16 assault rifles and anti-tank missiles.
The Americans provide both overt and covert financial aid, but only to purchase nonweapons supplies or fund training in subjects like logistics, map reading and military organization.
Overt aid of $5 million in the fiscal year just ended goes for supplies like medicine and tents. The request for the fiscal year just begun is $7 million.
The covert American aid of some $20 million to $24 million a year, spent by the C.I.A., goes to buy uniforms, some vehicles, rice and canned fish and to reimburse the Thais and Malaysians for the costs of training in ''nonlethal'' skills. The covert funds also pay for some political offices in Bangkok, Tokyo, Bonn and Paris and for two radio stations reaching Cambodia.
The Americans do not provide detailed satellite reconnaissance information to the Cambodians to aid battlefield strategy, though C.I.A. satellite experts sometimes come to brief the Thais or the Working Group.
 
Congressional Monitors
The House and Senate Intelligence committees are heavily involved in monitoring the spending, in part because of widespread abuses in the past, especially by the Thais. Cash no longer goes directly to the Cambodians or the Thais to buy goods, but supplies are purchased by the Americans and then handed over. But cash for the political offices and radio stations is provided by direct payment to the Cambodians.
The Congressional oversight is so thorough, some Asean officials complain, that planning is difficult. But the oversight is also said to insure that no American or Asean aid goes knowingly to the Khmer Rouge. That is not true of United Nations aid, however, which goes to support the 350,000 or so displaced Cambodians living in camps just inside Thailand along the Cambodian border.
These camps exist as bases and captive constituencies for all three resistance factions, including the Khmer Rouge, and food and rations, despite efforts by United Nations officials, are siphoned off to aid the guerrillas.

HEADLINE: Kremlin Faces Conservative Tide Against Change

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Nov. 15

 BODY:
The Gorbachev Government aclnowledged today that it was bucking an ever more conservative tide of public and political resistance as it prepared to press the national Parliament to endorse radical economic reform.
''The saving of the drowning person is the task of the one who is drowning,'' Deputy Prime Minister Leonid A. Abalkin said, trying to spur the national will toward painful change and strongly rejecting the notion that outside help from the United States can ease the pain significantly.
There can be no further procrastination in the already deferred reforms needed in the antiquated practices of Soviet marketing, pricing, currency and property management, Mr. Abalkin warned, speaking after a special three-day conference of political and economic specialists who looked into the nation's gravely troubled economy.
 
Array of Basic Changes
'''Without restructuring, our country has no future,'' Mr. Abalkin said, pointing toward the next session of the full Parliament on Dec. 12 as the critical forum for moving the long-planned changes beyond the drawing board where they have lingered through most of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's nearly five years as the Soviet leader. 
The elements of the restructuring program have been well known for some time, encompassing a six-year-long array of basic changes in everything from property ownership to the price of bread, changes that are traumatic enough to be giving fresh pause in the gradually democratizing forum of public debate. The only alternatives, the economist warned, were a retreat to rationing and other restrictions that will worsen the downward economic spiral.
''The main goal in the coming year is to assure that the situation does not get worse, that we stop this movement toward the brink of the chasm,'' he declared.
In what amounted to a campaign speech for the latest economic drive, President Gorbachev implored students at a national conference here to resist the growing tendencies to panic and loss of faith.
 
Mindful of Polls
Mr. Gorbachev, clearly mindful of recent polls showing widespread pessimism about his economic program, noted that the future was endangered both by conservatives nostalgic for old-fashioned tyranny and skeptics who favor ''total renunciation of the experience of socialism.''
Mr. Abalkin, an economist and political strategist for the Kremlin program, said the main discovery for him in the three-day conference of experts was not the anticipated complaints that the changes were not radical enough, but rather the increasingly conservative mood of criticism and resistance.
''Maybe it reflects the general situation in the country,'' he said, conceding that the novelties of organized public opinion and the nation's new more competitive, more outspoken electoral process now complicate the process of radical change in this long-time dictatorship.
''There will be a shift to the right,'' the economic chief declared glumly in estimating the looming political fight. ''It will complicate our program but it will not make us retreat,'' he promised.
''If we do not manage our program and stabilize our economy in the next year, a rationing system would become inevitable, and this would be the end of the reform,'' he said, obviously working to bestir the missing ingredient from President Gorbachev's economic prescriptions, strong public support. In fact, rationing is already in effect in most regions for sugar, and is being introduced in some areas for meat and cheese.
'''Congress can be very contradict ory,'' he added, speaking on the basis of a setback earlier this month when the fledgling Parliament rejected the Government's proposals to raise the price of popular goods like cigarettes, beer and caviar. He sidestepped the basic question of what might happen should the Parliament reject the reform program. ''Let them find someone else who can pursue a better program,'' he said, adding that he did not think this would happen.

HEADLINE: Super Negotiator;
With Borders Open, His Job Is Over

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST BERLIN, Nov. 15

 BODY:
After a quarter-century of arranging passage across the Berlin wall for some of the most celebrated prisoners of the 20th century - from spies to C.I.A. pilots to heroes of the human rights movement in the Soviet Union - Wolfgang Vogel may have just lost most of his law practice.
''If I should become unemployed through the changed circumstances, it would be a very happy unemployment indeed,'' he said, sitting in a study lined with pictures of his most famous cases.
Mr. Vogel was a shadowy figure when he first came to public attention in the West in 1962, when he negotiated the exchange of the downed C.I.A. spy plane pilot, Francis Gary Powers, for the convicted Soviet spy Rudolf Abel and an American student accused of spying in East Germany.
 
Fixer for Both Sides
Nearly a quarter of a century later, he was involved in the 1986 exchange, across the same Glienecke Bridge in the north of Berlin, that freed Natan Sharansky, then known as Anatoly B. Shcharansky, from a Soviet prison camp where he had been jailed for his human rights activities. 
And for nearly as long as the 28 years the Berlin wall divided East from West, Mr. Vogel negotiated the release of thousands of East German political prisoners, their release paid for in hard cash by the West German Government at rates that have risen from $10,000 to $50,000 a head since 1964, according to German officials.
East German officials do not publicly acknowledge this shadowy business at all. West German officials do not like to talk about it, but it began under the auspices of the West German Lutheran Church, which like so many German institutions had more links under and around the wall all these years than it let on.
 
Old Ties to the West
In a way Mr. Vogel, an East German who drives a yellow West German Mercedes, personifies them. His wife, Helga, is from West Germany, and he could travel freely between East and West long before last Thursday, when the new Communist Party leadership under Egon Krenz gave the same right to all 16 million East German citizens.
Mr. Vogel was in West Berlin when that announcement, in effect making the wall porous while leaving it standing, was made. ''I was in West Berlin on the night it went up, the 13th of August 1961, too,'' he said.
For years, East German leaders thought the end of the wall would mean the end of German Democratic Republic. Whether that judgment was right or wrong is not yet something Mr. Vogel is prepared to talk about, nor are his close ties with the deposed Communist leader whose judgment it was, Erich Honecker, now believed to be ill and in a hospital suffering from cancer.
 
A Voice for Honecker
Mr. Honecker called in the lawyer last summer, after the Soviet bloc began to come apart, to try to persuade hundreds of East Germans who had sought asylum in West German embassies in East Berlin, Budapest, Prague and Warsaw that they would be allowed to leave for West Germany if they would first return home.
A few hundred did from Prague, after Mr. Vogel was able to show the Government's good faith by getting it to let two small children whose relatives had simply handed them over the fence to strangers in the West German Embassy grounds, out of the country to rejoin their parents, who had reached West Berlin.
But by last month, tens of thousands of people were flocking to the West German Embassy grounds in Prague. Mr. Honecker, anxious not to spoil the Oct. 7 celebration of East Germany's 40th anniversary, consented to let some go west, but the authorities were taking reprisals against their relatives back at home.
 
The Final Straw
And the case that finally drove Mr. Vogel to speak was a family that tried to cross the Neisse River into Poland illegally. The father made it and got out to West Germany, the mother was caught and sent to prison in East Germany and the two small children were put into an orphanage.
''It is impermissible, on the one hand, to allow special exit to West Germany and, on the other hand, to impose prison terms for similar conduct,'' he said then. ''The criminal prosecutions against demonstrators who have committed no acts of violence are also legally questionable.''
Shortly afterward, Mr. Honecker was ousted by the Communist Party Politburo, and last week Mr. Krenz declared the entire East German border with West Germany open for the first time since 1961.
 
Act of Desperation
The sudden decision surprised Mr. Vogel no less than other East Germans, who saw in it an act not so much of calculation as of desperation.
He is as skeptical now of people who say they have always been reformers as of those who lay all the blame for what went wrong on Mr. Honecker's shoulders. ''Everybody has to ask themselves now what they did or failed to do that led to this pass,'' he said.
The new leadership has announced plans for a new law permitting travel abroad without any bureaucratic restrictions. It has said that there will be a new law spelling out the right to assemble freely and petition the Government for grievances, and that the criminal law will be reviewed.
This may quickly lead to a reduction in the number of political crimes, including ''flight from the republic,'' which have kept Mr. Vogel in business over the years.
''Maybe I can even think of enjoying retirement,'' he said, as the telephone rang incessantly with calls from clients and West Germans asking him to go over there for meetings and parties to celebrate his role in bringing about the end of the wall.

HEADLINE: Clamor in the East: Pressure Off Bush;
U.S. Finds Relief in Stand By Gorbachev on the East

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15

 BODY:
President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's warning that it is too early to talk about restructuring Europe was received with satisfaction in Washington today.
The Soviet leader's comments, made during a meeting in Moscow on Tuesday with Foreign Minister Roland Dumas of France, made it clear that the Soviet Union, like the United States, was not ready to talk about reunification of Germany, a senior Administration official said.
Mr. Gorbachev has also signaled that he is not willing to tolerate anti-Soviet activity in Eastern Europe or secession from either the Warsaw Pact or the East bloc economic alliance, the official said. Breathing Room for U.S. The official indicated that the United States could work within that framework, and he also appeared to be suggesting that Mr. Gorbachev's strictures give the Administration some breathing room from the high expectations that have arisen for the summit meeting Dec. 2 and 3 on Soviet and American warships anchored off the coast of Malta. 
The opening of the Berlin wall and the easing of travel restrictions in East Germany and Czechoslovakia have given rise to speculation about an impending reunification of Germany and other dramatic events. But the official said Mr. Gorbachev's comments highlighted some of the underlying restraints on rapid change.
In a speech today to the A.F.L.-C.I.O., President Bush said: ''We're not meeting to negotiate the future of Europe. The peoples of Eastern Europe are speaking their own minds about that future.''
Mr. Bush, who called on business, labor and Government to be ''partners and activists'' in helping Poland restructure its economy, said he wants to ''to talk with President Gorbachev about the opportunities to move beyond containment in U.S.-Soviet relations.''
The senior official said the White House hoped that Mr. Gorbachev's remarks will rebut Congressional critics of the Administration who have been saying, as they did last spring before the NATO summit meeting, that Mr. Bush should offer a bold response to the changes in Europe, strong leadership in unsettled times and a clear vision of a new order that could emerge from the current upheaval.
 
A Preference for Quiet
In the past, the White House has often seemed to be ignoring such criticism and, when it reached a fever pitch, pulled out a dramatic initiative, like the proposal on reducing conventional armed forces that Mr. Bush brought to the NATO meeting or the announcement of the secretly arranged Malta meeting. It remains to be seen whether that will happen in Malta.
This time, however, the criticism did not stop after the announcement of the December summit meeting because the changes seemed so momentous and Mr. Bush's response was deemed by his critics to be tepid and not expressive of American excitement about the European changes.
As has become his established practice, Mr. Bush has been restricting planning for the December summit meeting to his closest aides - Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d; John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff; Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser, and his deputy, Robert M. Gates.
Administration officials said that they did not feel pressure, either from their allies or from the pace of events, to change their stance toward the European events and that Mr. Gorbachev's own political and economic problems put the pressure on him, not Mr. Bush.
''Gorbachev has made it clear that there are some very real red lines,'' one senior official said. ''We have time to think about what to do with our institutions.''
Another senior official said the Soviet Union had assured the United States that it would not intervene militarily in Eastern Europe, nor would it use force to crack down on ''peaceful dissent'' within its own borders. ''But they make it very clear that they'd feel free to use whatever force was required to resolve interethnic rivalries that might result in either bloodshed or violence,'' the official said.
''If you start getting into questions about secession and independence, for instance of the Baltics, they've got a very firm view that is a 'no-no' because it could very well lead to the complete dissolution of their entire nation,'' the official said.
 
Speech by Eagleburger
He said Mr. Gorbachev had not sought, nor received, any assurances from Mr. Bush about how the United States would respond to a Soviet crackdown on political dissent, nationalism or ethnic unrest.
In a speech today to the staff of Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty, Lawrence S. Eagleburger, the Deputy Secretary of State, said: ''There are a good number of nationalities and ethnic groups in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe who have a very poor record of peaceful coexistence and whom we hope will learn to live together by choice and by virtue of a common stake in an emerging democratic order.''
Mr. Eagleburger's speech suggested that the Administration has better coordinated the statements of its top officials, who had been offering conflicting interpretations of the European upheaval recently.
While Mr. Eagleburger had spoken before about the potential for European instability in Mr. Gorbachev's reforms, he said today that ''glasnost and the process of liberalization which has accompanied it offer the first real hope in the postwar era that the Soviet Union and the nations of the West may someday be linked in a community of shared values.''
 
Dole Defends Bush
On Capitol Hill today, Senator Bob Dole, the minority leader, sprang to Mr. Bush's defense. ''He deserves our support,'' Mr. Dole said in a fiery speech. ''He doesn't deserve our nitpicking and petty politicking.''
But Richard A. Gephardt, the House majority leader, continued to criticize Mr. Bush, saying he should convene a NATO summit conference before the Malta meeting. ''I think in this kind of a situation, it would be most important for him to be in a face-to-face meeting with all of the Western leaders at one time,'' Mr. Gephardt said in an interview.
The White House has taken pains to say that it is consulting constantly with its allies. In the last six days, Mr. Baker has talked several times with the French, British and West German Foreign Ministers, one official said.
President Francois Mitterrand will brief Mr. Bush either by telephone or through his embassy after a weekend meeting of the European Community, according to American officials and West European diplomats here. Mr. Bush will also meet with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain at Camp David on Nov. 24.

HEADLINE: Clamor in the East: Remarks to Congress;
Excerpts From Address by Walesa

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a speech today by Lech Walesa to a joint meeting of Congress:
In the days before the Second World War, there were many people who asked: Why should we die for Gdansk? Isn't it better to stay at home? But war soon paid them a visit, and they had to start dying for Paris, for London, for Hawaii. This time too, there were many who complained: There is that Gdansk again disturbing our peace.
But the recent developments in Gdansk carried a different meaning. This was not the beginning but the true end of that war. This was the beginning of a new, better, democratic and safe era in the history of our world. There is no longer a question of dying for Gdansk but of living for it. 
Peacefully and prudently, with their eyes open to dangers, but not giving up what is right and necessary, the Poles gradually pave the way for historic transformations. We are joined along this way, albeit to various extents, by others: Hungarians and Russians, the Ukrainians and people of the Baltic Republics, Armenians and Georgians, and, in recent days, the East Germans. We wish them luck and rejoice at each success they achieve. We are certain that others will also take our road, since there is no other choice.
 
Understanding From Gorbachev
I ask now: Is there any sensible man understanding the world around him who could now say that it would be better if the Poles kept quiet because what they are doing is jeopardizing world peace? Couldn't we rather say that Poles are doing more to preserve and consolidate peace than many of their frightened advisers? Could we not say that stability and peace face greater threats from countries which have not yet brought themselves to carry out long-ranging and comprehensive reforms, which do their utmost to preserve the old and disgraced ways of government, contrary to the wishes of their societies?
Things are different in Poland. And I must say that our task is viewed with understanding by our eastern neighbors and their leader Mikhail Gorbachev. This understanding lays foundations for new relations between Poland and the U.S.S.R., much better than before. . . . ...
In the Second World War, Poland was the first country to fall victim of aggression. Her losses in terms of human life and national property were the heaviest. . . . . In 1945 she was, theoretically speaking, one of the victors. Theory, however, had little in common with practice. In practice, as her allies looked on in tacit consent, there was imposed on Poland an alien system of government, without precedent in Polish tradition, unaccepted by the nation, together with an alien economy, an alien law, an alien philosophy of social relations. . . .
The atrocities were followed by persecutions of all those who dared think independently. All the solemn pledges about free elections in Poland that were made in Yalta were broken.
Exclusion From Marshall Plan
. . . Stalin forbade Poland to use aid provided by the Marshall Plan, the aid that was used by everyone in Western Europe, including countries which lost the war. It is worth recalling this great American plan, which helped Western Europe to protect its freedom and peaceful order. And now it is the moment when Eastern Europe awaits an investment of this kind - an investment in freedom, democracy and peace - an investment adequate to the greatness of the American nation.
But on our path there looms a serious obstacle, a grave danger. Our long subjection to a political system incompatible with national traditions, to a system of economy incompatible with rationality and common sense, coupled with the stifling of independent thought and disregard for national interests. All this has led the Polish economy to ruin, to the verge of utter catastrophe. The first government in fifty years elected by the people and serving the people has inherited from the previous rulers of the country a burden of tremendous debts they incurred and subsequently wasted, of an economy organized in a manner preventing it from satisfying even the basic needs of the people.
The economy we inherited after almost five decades of Communist rule is in need of thorough overhaul. This will require patience and great sacrifice. This will require time and means. . . . Today all the countries of the Eastern Bloc are bankrupt. The Communist economy has failed in every part of the world. . . .
We know that America has her own problems and difficulties, some of them very serious. We are not asking for charity, or expecting philanthropy. But we would like to see our country treated as a partner and a friend.
We have heard many beautiful words of encouragement. These are appreciated, but, being a worker and a man of concrete work, I must tell you that the supply of words on the world market is plentiful, but the demand is falling. Let deeds follow words now.

LENGTH: 988 words

HEADLINE: Bush Backs House Plan on Raise and Ethics Rules

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15

 BODY:
President Bush today endorsed a package that would raise the salary for House members and top Government officials by more than a third and tighten rules on ethics.
Mr. Bush's endorsement was widely seen as crucial in assuring passage of the measure, which already has the support of Republican and Democratic leaders in the House. At a news conference this afternoon, the leaders predicted that the bill would win approval by the House on Thursday, culminating a yearlong effort to revise the House rules and raise the lawmakers' pay.
''I believe it will receive a strong majority from both parties,'' said Thomas S. Foley, the Speaker of the House. 
 
Senate Working on Plan
Senate leaders are working on a separate package governing their salary and outside income. In addition, a bipartisan group introduced an ethics bill today intended to tighten restrictions on travel, gifts and lobbying by senators, senior senate staff members, and top Federal officials once they leave the Government.
The Senate could consider the House package as early as Friday, in additional to whatever measure their own leadership produces.
In a letter to Mr. Foley today, President Bush endorsed both the salary increase and the ethical provisions of the measure. ''I fully support the reforms you are prepared to bring before the House of Representatives this week,'' Mr. Bush declared. ''I am also pleased that you have made essential adjustments in compensation for individuals in all three branches of Government.''
The package, whose details were made public today, includes a 7.9 percent salary increase that officials said was meant to make up for inflation for House members, judges and top Government officials, to take effect in 1990. It also includes a 25 percent pay increase in 1991 for those officials, along with another adjustment that year tied to cost-of-living increases. House leaders estimated it would raise the salaries for those officials from a current level of $89,500 to about $125,000 in 1991.
Mr. Bush's statement of support came after last-minute negotiations between the House and the White House. Lawmakers felt the measure would be impossible to pass without a strong statement of Presidential support to help protect House members against a public outcry and potential harm in next year's elections. Earlier this year, when a 51 percent pay increase was proposed, public opposition was so strong Congress eventually abandoned the effort.
Officials said the the current package was also the most extensive revision of the ethical rules and standards of the House in more than a decade, an effort to clarify and strengthen the guidelines that were at the heart of the ethical storm on Capitol Hill this year that toppled the Speaker of the House, Jim Wright of Texas.
 
'Restores the Public Trust'
''We want to make sure Congress restores the public trust by doing a better a job of writing, understanding and living with ethical standards and rules,'' said Representative Vic Fazio, the California Democrat who was co-chairman the bipartisan group that produced this package, along with Representative Lynn Martin, Republican of Illinois.
The measure would ban the outside speaking fees that many House members receive and which many critics consider veiled efforts to curry favor. It would also impose new limits on outside earnings. Currently, members can earn up to 30 percent of their Congressional salary in outside income. The new package would cut that to 15 percent and prohibit the earning of directors fees, legal fees and other professional services income.
Robert H. Michel of Illinois, the House Republican leader, noted today that the Constitution stipulates that lawmakers shall be ''paid out of the treasury of the United States'' and said it was time for the House to end its reliance on outside sources of income.
''Either because of our ineptness, our incapability or our cowardice in addressing the subject of pay for members, we've resorted to a circuitious route by way of outside income and honoraria,'' said Mr. Michel, a prime mover behind this package.
Under the package, a House member would still be able to give a speech and have the sponsor donate the money to charity.
 
Rewrite Rules on Gifts
The measure also rewrites the rules on gifts, which were the subject of fierce disputes and conflicting interpretations in the Wright affair. Currently, House rules say members cannot accept gifts worth more than $100 from anyone with a ''direct interest'' in legislation. Mr. Wright and the ethics committee had sharply differed over the definition of ''direct interest.''
The new rules simply ban the acceptance of gifts worth more than $200 a year from anyone other than a relative.
The measure would also limit the travel expenses a member could accept for participation in an event or conference. Currently, the rules do not spell out a specific time limit; the new rules would say a member could accept no travel expense for a trip lasting more than four days, and for a trip overseas lasting more than seven days.
It also abolishes a provison in the law governing the use of campaign funds. Currently, members elected before 1980 can convert campaign funds to personal use once they retire. Under the new rules, such members would have to retire by 1993 to convert that money to personal use.
The rules also provide for a variety of new reporting requirements. And, reflecting the reservations many lawmakers said they felt about the ethics committee process in the aftermath of the Wright affair, the measure would significantly revamp the way the House investigates and disciplines its own members.
Currrently, the same committee functions essentially as grand jury and judge, deciding whether to bring charges and then deciding whether the charges are warranted. This measure would create separate subcommittees to perform those functions.

PUB-DATE: November 16, 1989

SECTION: Section A; Page 30, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 369 words

HEADLINE: Showdown for Congressional Honor

 BODY:
President Bush's welcome endorsement enhances prospects for House passage of an ethics package that would begin to break the cozy financial ties between the nation's top lawmakers and government favor-seekers. That shifts the main focus of the ethics debate to the Senate, so far reluctant to act on fundamental reform.
The House is expected to vote today on a reasonable pay raise combined with a ban on the backdoor honorarium fees most members now pocket for speaking and meeting with private interest groups. 
The honorariums have become an open scandal. Representatives and senators collected more than $9 million in such fees last year alone. Meanwhile, the lack of Congressional pay increases has held down salaries of Federal judges, Cabinet officers and other high officials, whose pay remains linked to that of Congress.
Ralph Nader, who helped defeat a more ambitious 51 percent pay raise proposed by a Presidential commission in January, also opposes the new pay initiative as unneeded and undeserved. His stance ignores reality. Adjusted for inflation, the $89,500 annual salary paid to lawmakers is less than the $42,500 Congress was paid 20 years ago. And it grows harder and harder to recruit talented people for important Federal positions when rookie lawyers in major law firms are paid nearly as much as senior Federal judges, and some state health officials earn more than the Secretary of Health and Human Services.
Approval of the House package would be a challenge to the Senate, still debating the terms of its own ethics plan. Some senators prefer to take a modest cost of living increase and leave the indefensible honorarium system essentially intact.
Along with the President, House Speaker Thomas Foley and the House minority leader, Robert Michel, deserve much praise for accepting the need to end honorariums and face the heat generated by any bill containing a Congressional pay raise. Today's roll-call in the House will say much about members' opinions of themselves, their institution and the public's ultimate good sense.
A positive vote would leave the Senate alone to explain why elected officials can't get along without hefty salary supplements from favor-seekers.

HEADLINE: Preservation of New York Adirondack Park Wins Wide Support

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The Commission on the Adirondacks in the 21st Century has held 12 meetings in the last three weeks; six in and near the Adirondack Park, six more across New York State from Buffalo to New York City. The commission has listened to hundreds of people express their concerns for the future of the park. Your Oct. 26 report of the Saranac Lake meeting, stating that the region and state are at odds, does not make clear that the meeting was an anomaly in tone and content. 
Testimony for strengthened efforts to preserve the open space character of the park has been overwhelming. At public meetings in Glens Falls, Watertown, Old Forge, Plattsburgh and Schenectady, scores of park residents called for strong, innovative action to protect the park's natural resources and local communities.
Again and again, the commission has been told that regulatory loopholes should be plugged; a continuing fund source for state land acquisition should be created; the state's easement program should be used widely to protect timber resources; economic development should be on a scale appropriate to the park; a single vision of a park should focus on the activities of all state agencies.
Even at the Saranac Lake meeting, it was evident that there are not two camps - one for protecting the park and one against. A complex mosaic of concerns was expressed. The six-million-acre Adirondack Park is the largest park in the United States outside Alaska and includes the greatest wilderness system east of the Mississippi. Some 58 percent of the land within the park's ''blue line'' boundary is privately owned. The remainder is state land held ''forever wild'' as part of the Forest Preserve.
The crazy-quilt pattern of state and private land means that the use made of each has impact on the other. The pace of subdivision and development (permit applications increased more than 200 percent from 1986 to 1988; 50,000 new lots created in the last 20 years) has aroused deep concern for the future of the park. Changes in the economic forces affecting the timber and agricultural industries have also created serious concern for the future.
The striking thing about the recent meetings on the future of the Adirondacks is not that a few wish to eliminate the Adirondack Park Agency, but that most wish to see the values of the park reflected and preserved through effective land-use management and economic development that is both appropriately scaled and sustainable.
 
PETER A. A. BERLE
Chairman, Commission on the
Adirondacks in the 21st Century
 Albany, Oct. 31, 1989
