HEADLINE: Misleading Birth Data

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your Oct. 31 report that United States births are reaching the 1950's levels of four million is misleading.
The 1988 population was 246 million, more than 60 percent above the 1950 population of 152 million. Now we have nearly the same number of births. We need a birth rate of 2.05 per woman of childbearing age to maintain a zero-growth population. The birth rate by your own figures has been below 2 since 1973.
Our population will continue to increase for two reasons: (1) net immigration to our country, and (2) extended life expectancy. The drastically shifted ratio of retired to employed people will face major problems in the economy. The aberration is the coincidence of a lower birth rate and a larger population producing nearly the same number of births as in the 50's.
 
ROBERT KAHN
Lafayette, Calif., Nov. 2, 1989

HEADLINE: On Not Flying Into a Greenhouse Frenzy

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The White House is to be commended for not rushing into a hasty agreement to apply controls on the emission of carbon dioxide, the principal greenhouse gas (news story, Oct. 27). Despite so-called international pressure, generated mainly by lower-level bureaucrats to force the hand of the President, and huge news media publicity about impending doom, there is considerable doubt in the scientific community about the greenhouse climate warming. 
John Sununu, White House chief of staff, rightly questions the economic wisdom of limiting use of fossil fuels, including oil and coal. Policies suggested are often counterproductive. Extreme conservation measures -e.g., rapidly replacing older energy-using equipment - waste money, resources and energy. We don't want to force people to throw out all cars but compacts. Many renewable energy sources (e.g., solar) are not yet competitive - or folks would be buying them without coercion.
Many antipollution policies lower energy efficiency, putting more carbon dioxide into the atmosphere: methanol production uses up to 50 percent of the input energy; smokestack scrubbers lower the efficiency of electricity generation; chlorofluorocarbon phaseout means lower-efficiency refrigerators and air-conditioners.
In any case, unilateral actions would produce only marginal results, slightly postponing the date when effective greenhouse gas content doubles. Even costly and coercive controls would merely shift the ''doubling date'' from perhaps 2040 to 2045. And studies show that carbon dioxide controls shift costs from developing to industrialized countries.
Prudent policies exist: gradual improvements in efficiency in response to higher energy prices; a highway user fee (gasoline tax); nuclear energy wherever cost-effective. All these are worth doing even if there is no greenhouse effect. But is the public ready and are politicians courageous enough?
 
S. FRED SINGER
Director, Science & Environmental
Policy Project, Washington Institute
 Washington, Oct. 31, 1989

HEADLINE: ABROAD AT HOME;
What Bush Could Say

BYLINE: By Anthony Lewis

 BODY:
My fellow Americans, You and I share a rare moment in the lives of any people. A new chapter is opening in human history, and we are privileged to see it. I come to you tonight to speak of the great change that is taking place, and of the part I believe our country can play in it.
The people of Eastern Europe, who for 40 years have been denied the right to decide their own fate, are reclaiming that right. The walls of fear and isolation are crumbling. 
You know me as a cautious man, one who thinks a wise politician should be prudent. I want to assure you that I have felt the same emotions you have at the scenes of the crowds crossing the border in Berlin. It is not an easy thing to put into words, but the feelings are there: wonder, happiness, awe.
Americans have reason to feel some pride, too, in what is happening. For our steadfastness helped to make it possible. Harry Truman drew the line at Stalin's aggression. Dwight Eisenhower brought together, as their first commander, the European and American forces of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. John Kennedy stood at the Berlin wall and voiced our commitment to freedom.
But what we are seeing these days is not a victory for party or country. It is a victory for humanity. That is the spirit in which we should approach the many questions that now face us: not to gloat but to think how a new Europe can be free and prosperous and stable. Those aims are in the interests of all the states involved, East and West.
The first thing to say is that the issues are primarily for Europeans to decide. America is not going to tell them how to write the new page in their history. When I meet President Gorbachev next month, I can assure you I will not try to make some kind of a deal with him about the future of Europe. Malta will not be Yalta.
And you know, I do not think Mr. Gorbachev will want to do that either. It is right to say here what we all know, that the human yearning for freedom has broken through at this time because a Soviet leader recognized that it was not in conflict with his country's real interests.
Many of us were skeptical when President Gorbachev said the members of the Warsaw Pact should decide their own futures. We remembered Hungary in 1956, and Czechoslovakia in 1968. But he has stood by his words, and they are daily becoming deeds. We think the changes in Eastern Europe will be helpful to perestroika, his effort to reconstruct the Soviet economy. And we wish him well.
But the United States and the Soviet Union are inevitably part of the transition to a new Europe. There are 550,000 Soviet soldiers in Eastern Europe, and 300,000 American soldiers in West Germany.
Any sudden unilateral slash in those forces could be destabilizing. The right place to talk about reductions is in the negotiations already under way. Those talks are now urgent. We both have better things to do with our young men and women than to maintain troops in a Europe that is finding its own destiny.
And we have better things to do with our resources. To speak only of our own country, we Americans know that we have many unmet needs: for better schools, health care, highways and bridges, the renewal of our cities. We can hope, now, that in time we will be able to maintain an adequate defense at lower costs - and use the savings for those other needs.
Without intruding on our European friends, I think I can say one thing more. Their vision of security is based not alone on arms, but on political and economic relationships. Europe today has a structure, the European Community, that acts as a magnet of interdependence and increasing unity.
The United States has been in favor of greater European unity from the beginning. The Marshall Plan, when we offered it to a Europe devastated by war, called on the Europeans to create cooperative institutions. We supported Konrad Adenauer and Charles de Gaulle and the other great statesmen who brought France and Germany out of their ancient enmity to become close allies. We supported the creation of the community.
We are not afraid of a strong, free, united Europe. We know something about the difficulties of bringing independent states to a common enterprise; the creation of the United States 200 years ago was not so easy. But we are convinced that in Europe, as in America, there can be diversity within unity, bringing greater security and liberty for all.
I know I speak for all Americans when I say that we are watching the other side of the Atlantic with admiration and anticipation. Thank you, and good night.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: ESSAY;
Those Poor Devils

BYLINE: By William Safire

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
United States Government officials who are charged with estimating the scope of the Soviet threat have told The New York Times they think Moscow's spending on arms in 1989 has been less than in 1988.
If true, that marks a stunning change. For his first four years, Mikhail Gorbachev talked reform but placated his power base in the Red Army by increasing arms spending. In his fifth year, except for strategic weaponry, he has begun to cut back. 
Our analysts (they like to be identified as analysts) say the amount spent on arms, which had been estimated at 16 percent of national output, is down this year to 15 percent, compared with 6 percent in the U.S.
That estimate of that level is in dispute; Anders Aslund, the Swedish economist who was twice quoted in Secretary James Baker's testimony to the Senate Finance Committee last month, has long held that the actual percentage, including dual-use production, is far higher, making the strain on the Soviet system even more intolerable.
But set that long-burning dispute aside; more important than the actual level of non-strategic spending is its downward trend. It means that Mr. Gorbachev has been forced by circumstance to begin to risk offending his army leaders.
He does this with great caution: in planning to cut the size of the army by 10 percent, he has promised to raise the salaries of those remaining by 8 percent, saving little in the near term. And the 100,000 officers cannot be mustered out right away, say our analysts, because no civilian housing is available for them and their families.
The great question: Why is the Kremlin doing this? The answer was suggested in the same briefing in which we learned that less is being spent on tanks, planes and guns.
The Soviet Union's deficit last year was 9 percent of its national product. That was frightening to Soviet leaders; when the U.S. deficit reached 3 percent of our G.N.P., American politicians were scared into the Gramm-Rudman automatic discipline. But the Soviet rate was triple our own.
Now, with all the belt-tightening and market experiments, what does Mr. Gorbachev's perestroika balance sheet show this year? Our analyst's preliminary estimate for the 1989 Soviet deficit is nearly 14 percent of Soviet national product.
The estimate of that sea of red ink comes from the crowd here that has been consistently underestimating Soviet arms spending and economic difficulty. The deficit reality is probably worse, up around 20 percent. No wonder the Kremlin leadership is finally cutting conventional arms spending. It has no choice; that country is going over the cliff.
Imagine what would happen here if the American budget deficit ballooned to 14 percent, or $700 billion a year. To avert disaster, Republicans would grimly propose cuts in defense and Social Security. Democrats would be for raising taxes and clapping controls on spiraling wages and prices. Either way, we would treat the crisis seriously.
Faced with that crisis, caught in a cycle of shortages and strikes, Mr. Gorbachev is merely beginning to reduce arms spending with as little pain as possible to the officer corps. Otherwise, he is emulating Nero's fiddling: with prices controlled as deficits rise, he prints more money to chase after fewer goods and rails against the import of capitalism.
What should he do? Dean Charles Wolf of the Rand Graduate School urges genuine monetary reform: to sop up the unspendable cash overhang, create a ''new'' ruble with large holdings converted into nontradable 10-year bonds, sell many state assets to the people - and then let the market determine all prices.
''There'd be riots in the streets if we did that,'' a top economic adviser to Mr. Gorbachev told me last year. They still resist the salvation of the profit motive; gradualism is killing them.
The last thing America should do is to take the heat off with trade, aid, bonds, GATT invitations and like palliatives. It is not for us to subsidize their subsidy of Cuba or to reduce their difficulty in modernizing weaponry.
Red ink concentrates the mind. At Malta, Mr. Bush should press for the great conventional-force meltdown to parity and an immediate end to the Soviet underwriting of Caribbean Stalinism; he might helpfully suggest a leap into a market economy.
The President adjures us not to taunt or gloat if our longtime adversaries seek to stay afloat by jettisoning heavy cannon. That is in the American tradition: when his crew shouted as a salvo hit an enemy ship off the coast of Cuba, Capt. John Woodward Philip called out, ''Don't cheer, men, those poor devils are dying.''

LENGTH: 1078 words

HEADLINE: When an It Is Labeled A He or a She

BYLINE: By SANDRA SALMANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WINTERTHUR, Del., Nov. 10

 BODY:
The Hall of Flame in Phoenix houses one man's formidable display of fire engines - the largest in the world, according to its brochure. In nearby Scottsdale, the Mouse House is an exhibition of 3,000 mice fabricated from cloth, plastic, wood and other materials that had been collected by the same man's first wife.
Men collect images of power; women collect the diminutive and the domestic. One always suspected it, but now it has the official stamp of academia from two business professors who have been researching the subject of collecting. From a sampling of 200 collectors, the professors, Russell Belk of the University of Utah and Melanie Wallendorf of the University of Arizona, reported that men tend to collect cars, rare books and sports items, while women go in for animal replicas and the decorative arts. 
Their findings were among the papers presented at a conference Nov. 9 to 11 on gender and ''material culture,'' anthropologists' term for the study of the objects made and used by a civilization. The conference was sponsored by Winterthur Museum and Gardens. Winterthur, near Wilmington, is the former country estate of the Du Pont family and is now a museum for American artifacts from the 17th to the 19th centuries.
For three days, some 200 academicians and museum curators explored the way gender has been stamped - either explicitly, through design, or implicitly, through perception - on objects from diapers to cars, and how gender imprinting affects the way objects that are innately neuter are treated.
Researchers cited several areas of design, like cars and interior decorating, where objects have become increasingly neutral. But they also found many objects, like toys or Princess telephones, in which gender differences have been created or reinforced through marketing, and other areas, like cosmetics, where perception of gender identity has resisted the best marketing efforts of manufacturers.
Material culture holds a somewhat uneasy place in academia; a graduate student at the conference grumbled that one of her professors dismissed it as ''pots and pans history.''
But Michael Aaron Rockland, chairman of the American studies department at Rutgers University, noted that the ''nice thing about material culture is that there are things you can talk about.''
Most people at the conference were women, and there was a general lament that objects stamped as feminine are instantly devalued or trivialized. For example, Dr. Belk noted that visitors must pay to get into the fire-engine museum, while entry to the Mouse House is free.
If there was any consensus, it was ''a call for a gender-free approach'' to how behavior is evaluated, said Kenneth Ames, a professor of early American culture at Winterthur, which also offers graduate-degree programs in art conservation and the history of American civilization.
Baby clothing, which was neutral for centuries, was branded with gender identities relatively recently, said Dr. Jo Paoletti, an associate professor in the department of textiles and consumer economics at the University of Maryland. For 300 years, American infants of both sexes were dressed alike, generally in white frocks. That changed shortly after the turn of the century, Dr. Paoletti said, when psychologists suggested that gender identification was influenced by nurture as well as nature.
Boys got trousers, girls got dresses and the sexes were color-coded. Around World War I, the boys wore pink (''a stronger, more decided'' color, the literature of the day declared), and the girls blue (''delicate, dainty''). It was only after World War II that pink and blue assumed their current identities; Dr. Paoletti was unable to explain why.
Now infants' clothes, along with their toys, are even more gender-specific, Dr. Paoletti said. ''The baby boomers were the first generation to be color-coded'' in today's color schemes, she noted. There are Luvs diapers for boys (blue, decorated with trains) and for girls (pink, with balloons). Even christening gowns - the last vestige of the dress for boys - have been phased out in favor of robes with white satin bow ties.
Initially, the automobile's inventors thought the internal-combustion machine, which was fast, dirty and had a hand crank, was masculine. They tried to sell women on sluggish electric models, said Dr. Virginia Scharff, a historian at the University of New Mexico. When women said they preferred the gasoline-powered cars, she said, manufacturers replaced hand cranks with electric starters and enclosed the cars.
''Each improvement that made the car safer or more comfortable was treated as a concession to women, catering to their softness,'' Dr. Scharff said. In fact, she continued, ''it allowed the car makers to protect the masculine image of men'' while giving them the changes they wanted, too. Now, ''the automobile has become more androgynous,'' she said.
Many of the papers focused on the American quilt, which has increasingly been elevated from a craft to an art. Researchers complained that by moving the quilt from the bed to the museum wall, art critics and curators have overlooked its original significance. They noted that women used quilt-making as a means of forming friendships and raising money for their communities.
Dr. Beverly Gordon, an assistant professor in the department of environment, textiles and design at the University of Wisconsin, said men and women perceive quilts differently because they relate to objects at different distances: men prefer more abstract, impersonal distances, and women favor intimate spaces.
One matter of hot debate was where an AIDS quilt that serves as a national memorial fits into the tradition of women's quilt-making. The quilt, made by the friends and families of people who have died of AIDS, consists of 11,000 panels, each 3 by 6 feet. It is so immense that the Names Project, the San Francisco group in charge of it, recently said it would no longer be displayed in its entirety.
''The scale doesn't relate,'' Dr. Gordon said. ''It's not an intimate object.''
But Betty Blair, a Ph.D. candidate at the University of California at Los Angeles, maintained that the AIDS quilt embodies qualities traditionally considered feminine: it is nonthreatening and permits mourning.
Finally, she said, the quilt, like women, emphasizes relationships. In some patches, she said, ''the quilters have put their own names. People are literally sewn together.''

THE ECONOMY
 
Supporters of Government backing for initiatives to maintain American high-technology industries said the Bush Administration plans sharp cuts in Defense Department programs that bolster research and development. [Page A1.] Sun Microsystems and Unisys said they would not participate in U.S. Memories, a company being formed to produce computer memory chips. [D1.]

An Ohio appeals court threw out the convictions of the former owner of Home State Savings, Marvin Warner, and one co-defendant that resulted from the collapse of the savings institution. [D2.]
 
Rapidly expanding Federal insurance and credit-assistance programs expose the Government to losses of $5 trillion, an amount equal to the value of the economy's annual output. [D6.]
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
Moving to take advantage of change in Eastern Europe, G.E. said it had agreed to buy control of a Hungarian light-bulb maker for $150 million, the largest American investment in Hungary since World War II. The deal represents the kind of payoff that East bloc nations have been seeking as they make political and economic changes more attuned to market forces. [A1.]
 
John Reed of Citicorp said Argentina's creditor banks will not talk with Argentina about reducing its $64 billion foreign debt until they get a ''good faith'' payment on back interest. [D2.]
 
COMPANIES
 
Abandoning its yearlong effort to sell the Sears Tower, Sears, Roebuck said it would instead seek to raise $815 million by taking out a mortgage on the building. [D1.]
 
Northrop named Oliver C. Boileau, a former president of General Dynamics, to oversee its B-2 Stealth bomber program. [D1.]
 
Southland is considering major changes, saying that slowing sales in its 7-Eleven stores had raised doubts about its ability to generate enough cash for its debt payments in 1991. [D5.]
 
Smith International agreed to be acquired by Dresser, an oil services giant, in a deal valued at $675 milllion. [D5.]
 
Airbus said it had reached a preliminary agreement to sell five A310 airliners to Aeroflot, the Soviet airline. Airbus said the agreement included options for five more aircraft. [D5.]

Prices of Treasury securities moved higher in slow trading as dealers awaited fresh economic data. [D19.] Yields of money market mutual funds were mixed for the week ended yesterday, as tax-exempt funds rose while taxables declined. [D15.]
 
Silver futures prices soared to six-month highs while gold and platinum fell back. [D20.]
 
The dollar ended higher in domestic trading against major foreign currencies after declining overseas. [D20.]

HEADLINE: Inventories Up by 0.2%; Sales Off 0.3%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15

 BODY:
Growth of business inventories outpaced business sales in September, the Government said today in a report that analysts said contained a warning of growing backlogs because of the slowing economy.
The Commerce Department reported that inventories held on shelves and backlots climbed two-tenths of 1 percent, to a seasonally adjusted $791.8 billion, after advancing four-tenths of 1 percent in August.
Business sales, on the other hand, fell three-tenths of 1 percent, to a seasonally adjusted $524.6 billion, after a 3 percent gain the previous month. 
 
Ratio Rises to 1.51
The business activity produced a slight increase in the inventory-to-sales ratio to 1.51, meaning it would take 1.51 months to exhaust inventories at the September pace. It was 1.50 in August.
''At the moment, the ratios do not appear excessive,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist for the Boston Company. ''But they show the first signs of increases related to a declining business climate.''
Robert G. Dederick, chief economist at the Northern Trust Company in Chicago, agreed that on the surface the report suggested inventories were not yet a problem.
''But there are some warning signals in it of some excess at the consumer level,'' he said.
Inventories often rise during periods of slow economic growth as output exceeds demand, a process that could lead to production cuts and loss of jobs. The economy has been experiencing sluggishness as the Federal Reserve tries to contain inflation by keeping a tight rein on credit.
 
Retail Inventories Rise
Retail inventories, up 1 percent in September, were of particular concern since an earlier report indicated they could be worse in October. The Commerce Department said Tuesday that retail sales fell 1 percent in October, including a 5.1 percent decline in car sales.
Manufacturers' inventories, which represent about 45 percent of the total, slipped one-tenth of 1 percent and wholesale backlogs, accounting for 25 percent of the total, dropped three-tenths of 1 percent.
Manufacturers' sales, on the other hand, fell 1.6 percent in September. Retail and wholesale sales were both up seven-tenths of 1 percent.
Overall inventories were 6.4 percent above those of a year ago. Sales rose 6.7 percent over September 1988.

HEADLINE: Citicorp Head Urges Argentina to Make a Debt Payment

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 15

 BODY:
The chairman of Citicorp said today that creditor banks would not talk with Argentina about reducing its $64 billion in foreign debt until they had received a ''good faith'' payment on back interest, estimated at $5.3 billion. No interest has been paid since April 1988.
The chairman, John S. Reed, did not cite a specific sum during a news conference here, but other financial experts said the committee of creditor banks rejected an Argentine offer of $50 million last week. 
About $40 billion of Argentina's total foreign debt is owed to commercial banks, and Citibank has the largest outstanding bank debt, $1.5 billion.
Ricardo Handley, Citibank's president in Argentina, said the banks had said, ''Give us a signal that this time this is serious.''
Mr. Reed, in Buenos Aires to observe the institution's 75th anniversary in Argentina, painted a generally optimistic picture of the progress in resolving the third world debt crisis, but indicated that Argentina would be one of the slower and more difficult cases.
''The Argentine economy isn't doing as well as the others, and it may take two years to get an agreement,'' he said, after describing more positive situations in Mexico, the Philippines, Chile and Venezuela.
Mr. Reed, who met on Tuesday with President Carlos Saul Menem, said ''Mr. Menem understands very well the direction in which he has to go'' in restructuring the Argentine economy but still has to ''orchestrate'' it.
Referring to the options under the Bush Administration's plan for resolving the third world debt crisis, the Brady plan, named for Treasury Secretary Nicolas F. Brady, the Citicorp chairman said the possibilities were: ''Either pay it, exchange debt for something else, go into the market and buy it, or make an arrangement like Mexico's involving exit bonds.''
But, Mr. Reed added, neither the banks nor the Argentine Government knows yet how these possibilities may be applied to Argentina's debt. ''This is going to take time,'' he said.
He indirectly criticized the Argentine Government for having spent $400 million in reserves a few weeks ago to defend the exchange rate of the national currency, the austral, on the black market. At the beginning of last week, the Government halted its intervention, and the American dollar quickly rose about 30 percent above its official rate. The amount spent defending the austral equaled about a month's interest on the foreign debt.
''Seeing the Government spend that money causes concern among bankers,'' Mr. Reed said, ''because that money has now left the country.''
He estimated flight capital, holdings by private Argentines outside the country, at $45 billion to $50 billion, but some professional estimates are as high as $60 billion.
Argentina, with the third-highest foreign debt in Latin America, after Brazil and Mexico, also has one of the highest ratios of flight capital to debt.

HEADLINE: G.A.O. Sees Losses in Loan Efforts

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15

 BODY:
The myriad of rapidly expanding Federal insurance and credit-assistance programs exposes the Government to losses of $5 trillion, equal to the value of the economy's total annual output, the General Accounting Office reported today.
Not only are defaults in the programs continuing to increase, the Congressional investigative agency said, but the full magnitude of past losses has not yet been fully recorded because of poor management and inconsistent application of accounting principles by the managing government agencies.
The programs include guaranteeing the repayment of home mortgages, insuring crops and bank deposits and making direct loans to farmers and businesses seeking export orders. Those guaranteeing loans alone number 110, with the programs administered by the Department of Housing and Urban Development accounting for nearly half of them, the report said. 
 
Student Loan Program
The data also noted that the Guaranteed Student Loan Program, managed by the Education Department, experienced one of the highest default rates, growing to more than $1.4 billion in 1988, from $486 million in 1983.
Representative John D. Dingell, a Michigan Democrat who requested the tabulation, said in releasing the report that it also showed that the Government was playing a ''shell game'' by not including some of the programs in the Federal budget to hold down the deficit, thereby masking the future liability of taxpayers. The programs create contingent liabilities that show up in the budget as expenditures after a default or other loss occurs.
''In effect, every single American has co-signed a note for $20,000,'' Mr. Dingell said, saying that present budget-cutting efforts involved mere ''pocket change'' compared with potential outlays from the Government's loan and insurance activities.
Mr. Dingell added that while ''not every program is in trouble,'' some are ''in a serious enough state to be cause for concern.''
The compilation by the G.A.O., which began this summer, drew mainly on existing data but is believed to be the first to put such figures in one place, said Jeffrey C. Steinhoff, who supervised the work.
He said that while the Government in recent years had improved its recognition and documentation of financial management deficiencies, defaults and other trends continued to worsen.
The office, however, made no policy recommendations in the report.
The document placed the programs into one of four categories: insurance commitments, which are valued at $3.6 trillion; outstanding loans of $666 billion by Government-sponsored enterprises; outstanding guaranteed loans of $550 billion, and outstanding direct loans of $222 billion.
Reflecting budgetary restraints, direct loan commitments have declined by $35 billion, or by 13.6 percent, since 1985, but the totals for the other categories are mounting rapidly. In 1965, the four categories totaled $438 million, less than 10 percent of their current $5 trillion.
 
'Cannot be Ignored'
''While the Government will undoubtedly not be required to provide financial assistance for its total exposure associated with these programs, its continuing and growing exposure to losses cannot be ignored,'' the G.A.O. said in the report.
Such Federally sponsored organizations as the Federal National Mortgage Association and the Federal Home Loan Banks generally do not have their obligations expressly guaranteed by the Government, but the agency said that Washington's ''past willingness to assist'' meant that it would be expected to cover losses.
The premiums charged for various loans or guarantees, the agency said, are often designed to cover only a portion of program costs.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Tighter Money And Stock Prices

BYLINE: By Richard D. Hylton

 BODY:
A TIGHT money supply has traditionally been a harbinger of coming contractions in the financial markets. When there is less monetary growth or liquidity is low, it is generally believed, there will be less money around to push up the prices of assets, including stocks.
With some of the shifts in the developed economies over the last decade and the closer coordination of monetary policies and currency valuation among the Group of Seven nations, measuring the money supply has become a more tenuous enterprise. Close integration of national financial markets has made it possible to move enormous sums of money across borders quickly and efficiently. But integration also makes it harder to know just how much is in a particular economy. 
For the last 18 months or so, the growth of the money supply has been anemic, reflecting the Federal Reserve's tight policy. Since May or June, the rate of monetary growth in the United States increased slightly as growing concern about recession led the Fed to ease its grip slightly. But the increases in liquidity still trail growth in the gross national product.
''What we're seeing in the long-term trend is that the Federal Reserve is tightly controlling liquidity over all, but in the shorter term they have loosened in the last three months,'' said Larry Kudlow, senior economist at Bear, Stearns & Company. Mr. Kudlow, who follows the adjusted monetary base and total bank reserves to keep tabs on liquidity in the economy, and many other Fed watchers see little long-term policy impact from the recent easing.
Despite the evident link between tight money supply and contracting equities markets, it would seem that the stock market lately has largely ignored the downward pressure that the lack of extra money in the economy could be expected to have on stock prices, but a few analysts are taking note.
According to Suresh L. Bhirud, Oppenheimer & Company's chief portfolio strategist, the market has been too focused on takeover speculation to notice that the monetary liquidity numbers have been pointing to a drop in high-flying stock prices. He regards the 190-point drop of Oct. 13 as another indication that asset prices have peaked and will be heading down. Mr. Bhirud is forecasting continued consolidation of the market by year-end and a mini-recession by the third or fourth quarter of 1990.
''We had a contraction in money growth until June, and it was calling for some sort of contraction in the stock market and that has now taken place,'' he said, adding that further contraction might not be in jolting declines but a trending downward.
Despite shifts in the traditional correlation between money supply figures and real economic and market activity, Mr. Bhirud argues that in this unusually protracted bull market it pays to watch the amount of money in the system.
''The low liquidity in general means that there will be a downward pressure on asset prices, not just stocks,'' he said. ''Asset prices have been bid up, and there's just not enough money out there to support higher prices. When this develops, the most illiquid assets, like real estate, for example, start first to turn down in price. The real estate market has already turned down.''
Mr. Kudlow, who agrees that the Fed has been following a ''scarce money'' path, views the fight against inflation, however, as being what the equities market is most concerned about, so that tight credit policies encourage higher stock prices.
''The markets savor relatively tight money because market sentiment wants lower inflation that brings down interest rates,'' Mr. Kudlow said. ''The stock and bond markets do not want a loose Fed policy; they like the monetary scarcity because it foreshadows low interest rates and improves confidence in dollar-denominated financial assets.''
The key question here is whether the market is most concerned at this point with the inflation rate or the high stock prices in the context of declining corporate profits and slow money growth. It seems likely that as the reality of falling earnings and tight money sink in, investors may start taking their profits and waiting for the next downturn.
''When you are in a period of significant cyclical weakness,'' Mr. Bhirud said, ''that is, if the economy is weak or corporate profits are bad, then low inflation becomes almost irrelevant. If returns on assets are declining, and corporate profits are clearly going down, people tend to sell before things get too bad.''
As for foreign capital propping up stock prices, according to Mr. Bhirud and other investment strategists, foreign buying of American stocks has come to a screeching halt since Oct. 13, although foreigners have been buyers of Government securities.
''We've had the foreign liquidity coming in, but now it has stopped,'' said Abby Joseph Cohen, Drexel Burnham Lambert's senior investment strategist. Mrs. Cohen added that foreign investors were now waiting to see what happened here before they committed new capital.

HEADLINE: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
Moody's Lowers Ratings On Debt of Massachusetts

 BODY:
The ratings on as much as $8.5 billion in Massachusetts debt have been reduced by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and the Standard & Poor's Corporation placed the state under review for possible downgrading.
The action of Moody's reduced the state's long-term debt rating to Baa-1, from A. It came on the eve of a sale by Massachusetts of $140 million short-term general obligation notes for financing a deficit in the Medicaid program that provides financial support for medical bills of the needy. 
The rating change by Moody's reflects the agency's concern over the magnitude of the state's projected deficit of $721 million. The agency said that a rise in taxes might be needed.
Meanwhile, Standard & Poor's kept its rating on the state at A, but placed it under review for possible downgrading if Massachusetts did not resolve its difficulties by next month.
When borrowing in the debt market, lower debt ratings mean that lenders will demand higher compensation in the form of higher interest rates for the borrower.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Declines Overseas, But Posts Advance in U.S.

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended higher yesterday in domestic trading against major foreign currencies after declining overseas.
Gold prices fell in New York after rising overseas. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery closed at $391.30 an ounce, down $2 from late Tuesday. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted a late bid for gold at $390.90 an ounce, off $1.60.
Ronald Holzer, a vice president and chief dealer for Harris Trust and Company, in Chicago, attributed the dollar's gains in New York partly to ''a small correction from yesterday's selloff ahead of the trade figures.''
The Commerce Department is scheduled to release this morning the merchandise trade figures for September, and the market sentiment is that it will show a narrowing of the deficit to $8 billion to $9 billion.
But Mr. Holzer said that if the report discloses further economic weakness, particularly by showing a decline in United States exports, the dollar could head lower.
''The fundamentals are still working against the dollar,'' he said.
 
Data Point to Slowdown
Several recent economic reports have pointed to an economic slowdown, which spells bad news for dollar investors because it could signal lower interest rates. Lower rates tend to depress a currency.
In New York, the dollar rose to 143.795 yen, from 143.05 yen on Tuesday. The pound fell to $1.5803 from $1.5945.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Tuesday's quotes, were: 1.8390 West German marks, up from 1.8350; 1.6265 Swiss francs, up from 1.6175; 6.2495 French francs, up from 6.2280; 1,351.75 Italian lire, up from 1,343.00, and 1.17095 Canadian dollars, up from 1.16975.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Philip Morris Ads Anger Congressman

BYLINE: By Randall Rothenberg

 BODY:
A CONGRESSIONAL opponent of tobacco advertising is expected to introduce evidence today that he says indicates that the Philip Morris Companies' ad campaign extolling the Bill of Rights was specifically undertaken to head off further restrictions on tobacco advertising. But the company takes issue with the interpretation by Representative Thomas A. Luken, Democrat of Ohio.
Representative Luken, chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee's Subcommitee on Transportation and Hazardous Materials, is scheduled to convene hearings this morning on Philip Morris's $30 million Bill of Rights campaign, which it has undertaken with the National Archives, a Government agency.
Under an agreement signed in August, Philip Morris is to pay $600,000 to the Archives, which will locate such materials as recordings of past Presidents for the campaign. Critics of the tobacco industry assailed the deal, but the Archives defended it as a way of supplementing budget. 
In the upper house, Senator Edward M. Kennedy proposed legislation yesterday that would give the Government control over tobacco products and finance an anti-smoking campaign. The Massachusetts Democrat said he decided not to propose tough limits on cigarette exports and advertising to increase the chances that the bill would pass.
The legislation, which is still being drafted, would call for a total of $185 million in Federal spending next year on an anti-smoking advertising campaign, grants to states, schools and businesses that promote anti-smoking programs and money to establish a new Center for Tobacco Products.
The center would for the first time give the Federal Government regulatory control over the contents of cigarettes. Packs of cigarettes would be required to carry information either on the package or inside about the various tobacco additives, ''many of which are carcinogenic,'' Mr. Kennedy said.
Mr. Luken questions whether the mere mention of Philip Morris's name in the television commercials, and the appearance of its name in print ads that do not contain the Surgeon General's warning about the health hazards of smoking, violates laws restricting the content and placement of tobacco ads.
Philip Morris, which owns Kraft General Foods and Miller Brewing, says the ad campaign has no connection to its tobacco advertising or cigarette brands, of which Marlboro is the leader. Although the company has long had a Philip Morris cigarette brand, it announced last month that it was changing the brand's name to PM.
An aide to Mr. Luken, Ben Cohen, said the subcommittee, which oversees the Federal Trade Commission, had a copy of a letter from a public relations agency that worked for Philip Morris in 1986 stating that an essay contest undertaken then was created to forestall legislation against tobacco advertising.
''Why should we believe them when they say the thought of tobacco advertising never crossed their minds, when they tried this on a smaller scale three years ago?'' Mr. Cohen asked.
Mary A. Taylor, the director of special projects at Philip Morris, said the 1986 essay campaign ''was specifically aimed at tobacco advertising,'' and disputed any notion that there was a hidden motive to the advertising then, or to the current campaign. ''That's comparing apples and oranges and walnuts,'' she said.
The company's ads announcing the essay contest said, ''We believe that a tobacco advertising ban, currently under consideration in Congress, is a clear infringement of free expression in a free-market economy.'' The contest rules asked essay writers to ''specifically question the ramifications of a tobacco advertising ban.''
Mr. Luken's office said he would also maintain that Philip Morris's new television ads violated the 1971 ban on broadcast tobacco advertising. Mr. Cohen said the appearance of Philip Morris's name in the ads conflicted with a 1982 interpretation of the law by William F. Baxter, then the Assistant Attorney General in charge of the Justice Department's antitrust division. Mr. Baxter wrote a letter contending that the televising of a cigarette brand's logotype placed on the floor or posts of a boxing ring during a match could constitute a violation of the law.
Mr. Luken said that informal opinion could be read to apply to names of cigarette brands that appear in ads or on programs.

HEADLINE: Soviets to Liberalize Emigration, Hoping to Gain U.S. Trade Deal

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16

 BODY:
Soviet officials here and in Moscow promised today that Soviet emigration laws would soon be revised to permit freer emigration from the Soviet Union. In return, they asked that the United States lift trade barriers against Soviet exports.
At news conferences in the two capitals, Soviet officials seemed to be hoping that President Bush would recommend removal of the trade barriers in time for his meeting early next month with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev off the coast of Malta.
Administration officials and members of Congress indicated that the United States was unlikely to respond so swiftly. 
The Soviet Ambassador to the United States, Yuri V. Dubinin, said that the Soviet Parliament would soon approve legislation liberalizing emigration procedures for Soviet citizens, and he said, ''We expect positive steps from the American side,'' including ''full normalization'' of trade relations.
Soviet pleas for more favorable tariff treatment appear to have become more insistent as Soviet economic problems have deepened. A meeting of senior Soviet and American officials here this week set the stage for a trade agreement that would lower more than a half-century of high American tariff walls against Soviet exports.
Details of the legislation were not immediately available. Soviet officials said it would retain some restrictions on emigration for people considered to have had access to state secrets.
Richard Schifter, the Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights and Humanitarian Affairs, gave the Soviets high marks for their efforts and said that the Administration would look favorably on the legislation if its provisions are carried out ''as we hope they will be.''
Members of Congress and some Jewish groups also welcomed the Soviet efforts, but said that details of the legislation were too sketchy for Mr. Bush to grant the Soviet request for trade benefits at this time.
Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher said the Soviet Government might become eligible for more favorable treatment under American trade laws ''within the next one to three months'' if it carries through on its promise. But it might take longer, he said.
The State Department emphasized Mr. Bush's position that the emigration bill must not only be passed but also ''implemented'' before the United States would suspend trade barriers imposed on Moscow in the last 15 years. A 1974 law, known as the Jackson-Vanik Amendment, says that Communist countries may not receive favorable tariff treatment or credits from the United States unless they permit free emigration by their citizens.
The Soviet legislation would apply to Soviet citizens who wish to travel abroad and return to their homeland, as well as to those who want to settle permanently in another country.
Trade experts say that not many Soviet products would be competitive in the American market. But if the United States removed trade barriers, Soviet officials believe there would be an increase in American investment in the Soviet Union.
Ambassador Dubinin acknowledged that the Soviet legislation, which received preliminary approval on first reading on Monday, has not been published in the Soviet Union. American officials said they did not have the text of the draft law and therefore could not evaluate its details.
 
Rights Group Commends Moscow
Senator Dennis DeConcini of Arizona, chairman of the Commission on Security and Cooperation in Europe, a human rights group, praised Moscow for taking a first step to revise its emigration laws. In a joint statement, Mr. DeConcini, a Democrat, and Representative Steny H. Hoyer of Maryland, the co-chairman of the commission, said, ''We will not support a waiver of the Jackson-Vanik Amendment until the Soviet law receives final approval and a period of implementation takes place.''
In an interview, Mr. Schifter said that the United States had had two principal concerns about Soviet emigration. ''Applicants for exit permits who left security-sensitive jobs 10, 15 or even 20 years ago were denied permission to leave,'' he said. ''In addition, some adult applicants who were unable to obtain the consent of their parents for their departure could not leave.''
''It is my understanding that the new law would deal with both these issues,'' Mr. Schifter said. ''If it does, and if its provisions are implemented as we hope they will be, our concerns will have been met.''
Under the bill, Soviet citizens with access to state secrets could be forbidden to emigrate for up to five years. It is not clear whether this provision is retroactive, nor is it clear whether Soviet citizens denied exit permits for the last five years could immediately leave the Soviet Union.
 
'Just a Technical Matter'
Mr. Dubinin said that such questions, considered to be of paramount importance by Soviet Jews and their advocates in the United States, were ''just a technical matter.'' In general, he said, the new law will be administered in a generous spirit, and ''there will not be obstacles of a technical nature.''
But Micah H. Naftalin, national director of the Union of Councils for Soviet Jews, expressed concern that ''Jackson-Vanik will be prematurely waived in the euphoria of the moment'' when Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev meet.
Mr. Dubinin said he did not know exactly when the emigration bill would become law. Soviet emigration has already increased dramatically, with Soviet Jews, evangelical Christians and Armenians accounting for most of the exodus in the last 18 months. The United States, overwhelmed with applications from would-be Soviet refugees, has established new procedures to restrict their admission to this country.
President Bush has set a limit of 50,000 on the number of Soviet citizens who can be admitted to the United States as refugees in the current fiscal year.
 
Some Questions Remain
Pamela B. Cohen, president of the Union of Councils for Soviet Jews, said her organization had a list of 253 Soviet families denied permission to leave the Soviet Union ''on a variety of pretexts.'' The list, she said, includes 105 families denied exit permits because of access to state secrets and 121 who could not get the necessary permission from relatives.
Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn, said, ''The Soviet Union has made real and dramatic improvements in emigration policy, but has still not said whether it will release all the long-term refuseniks.'' Thus, he said, it would be premature for the United States to lower tariffs by giving the Soviet Union ''most-favored-nation treatment'' under the trade laws.
Mr. Dubinin, like Soviet officials in Moscow, said there was ''absolutely no linkage'' between the Soviet emigration bill and recent events in Eastern Europe, where thousands of East Germans have fled their country. He noted that the bill liberalizing Soviet emigration procedures was introduced in the Soviet Parliament in August.
But American officials said the Soviets displayed no sense of urgency about the legislation until this month.

HEADLINE: Kaufman View On a Recession

 BODY:
Interest rates are likely to decline as the economy slows, but the beneficial effects of lower rates may not be enough to forestall a recession in the United States, Henry Kaufman, the economist, said yesterday.
''The question is whether small declines in interest rates can overcome the retarding influence'' of huge debt burdens on consumers and corporations, he said in a meeting with reporters before speaking to the Money Marketers, a New York University group. 
Mr. Kaufman, the president of Henry Kaufman & Company, a money management firm, was formerly the chief economist of Salomon Brothers. He said he believed that chances of a recession were ''much better than 50-50'' in the next three years, but added that 1991 was more likely than 1990 for a beginning.
When a recession does begin, he said, the Government will be hampered by already-high budget deficits from pursuing an aggressive fiscal policy. It will fall on the Federal Reserve to quickly ease credit to avoid a deep recession, ''more or less regardless of whether the inflation rate is unacceptably high at the time.''

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Issues Stage a Retreat

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities gave ground in spotty trading yesterday, as dealers took some profits and awaited further developments that might allow the Federal Reserve Board to ease interest rates.
The Government's release of merchandise trade data for September, with results much better than expected, prompted a brief flurry of buying early in the session. But sell orders began to emerge as the market moved higher.
''There is a growing awareness that there is no number due out over the next two weeks that will make the Fed ease policy,'' one Government bond trader said. ''The Fed will probably wait until they see the November employment data on Dec. 8 before they do anything. And between now and then we have to take on some fresh supply of two-year and five-year notes. I think the economy looks very weak, but given the near-term outlook, and with prices at these levels, you might as well sell.'' 
In addition to the Treasury note sales, which will be announced next week, participants in the credit markets face the second large infusion this autumn of intermediate- and long-term securities from the Tennessee Valley Authority.
Yesterday the T.V.A. said it would sell a total of $3.5 billion worth of seven-year notes and 40-year bonds through an underwriting syndicate led by Morgan, Stanley & Company. Because of strong demand for the 40-year issue, which is not callable for 10 years, the size of the bond offering was subsequently raised to $2 billion from $1.5 billion.
The securities are likely to be offered to investors today.
Price talk in advance of the issue put yields on the seven-year notes at 50 basis points, or hundredths of a point, over the prevailing yield on the 8 percent seven-year Treasury notes.
In advance of the actual pricing, investment bankers familiar with the transaction said the bonds were being offered to investors at a yield of 1.10 percentage points to 1.15 percentage points above the prevailing yield on the 8 1/8 percent Treasury bonds of 2019.
Last month an offering of $4 billion worth of T.V.A. securities was snapped up by investors. The offering is part of the T.V.A.'s plan to refinance $6.7 billion in high-interest debt.
For the most part, word that the nation's trade deficit contracted to $7.94 billion in September, the lowest level since late 1984, from a revised $10.1 billion in August, left credit market investors unmoved.
''Aside from the fact that this September figure tells us nothing about what the economy has done since, the trade number was basically a good news/bad news sort of figure,'' said Robert Chandross, chief economist at Lloyds Bank. ''It was good because the improvement was better than expected, but bad because it shows that the economy was stronger than we might otherwise have thought.''
As noted, the flurry of buying in the Treasury market following the trade report gave dealers an excuse to take profits later on.
By late in the session, the Treasury's 8 1/8 percent bonds of 2019 were offered at a price of 103, down 1/8 of a point, to yield 7.86 percent.
In the secondary market for Treasury notes, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 100 15/32, down 3/32, to yield 7.80 percent. And the 8 1/4 percent five-year notes were unchanged on the day, at 102 1/8, to yield 7.70 percent.
Activity in the Treasury bill market was highlighted by the sale of $9.7 billion of new one-year bills.
At the auction the bills were sold at an average rate of 7.17 percent, the lowest rate on a one-year bill since the auction on June 30, 1988. At the last one-year bill auction on Oct. 19, the bills were sold at an average rate of 7.35 percent.
In the secondary Treasury bill market, three-month bills were offered late yesterday at a discount rate of 7.65 percent, up three basis points. Six-month bill rates rose by two basis points, to a late offered rate of 7.40 percent.
In the taxable corporate bond market, the Consumers Power Company yesterday offered $200 million of 10-year notes at competitive bid.
A bid from a group led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets won the issue. The 8 7/8 percent notes, which mature Nov. 15, 1999, were priced at $99.434 to yield 8.961 percent, 1.15 percentage points over the prevailing yield on 10-year Treasury notes.
The issue, which is noncallable for life, is rated Baa-3 by Moody's Investors Service and BBB-minus by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Traders in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds said that the price of most issues slipped by about 1/8 of a point yesterday. Participants in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds said that prices of most issues were unchanged on the day.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday that all three measures of the nation's money supply rose during the week ended Nov. 6. The report had no impact on prices in the credit markets.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Altered TW Deal Angers Holders

 BODY:
IF a customer buys a box of corn flakes and finds less than the label promised, a refund can be expected and obtained. But on Wall Street, things are not so easy, and some buyers of new shares in TW Holdings Inc. are furious.
The financing plan for completing TW Holdings' takeover of TW Services Inc. was changed. TW's operations include the Denny's, Quincy's and El Pollo Loco restaurant chains. As a result of the change, shares in the new company appear to be less valuable than they would have been under the first plan. But those who bought the shares in the when-issued market have been told they will have to accept shares under the latest plan. 
The shares, which had traded for as much as $8 and still traded for about $5.50 after the first financing plan was dropped, were quoted yesterday at $4.25 bid.
The decision was made by the National Association of Securities Dealers, which regulates trading in the over-the-counter market. The winners are those who sold the ''stub'' shares that were to be left outstanding after the offer was completed, a group that includes many risk arbitragers. The losers are those who bought them, betting on the success of the newly leveraged company.
In when-issued trading, investors buy and sell securities that are expected to be issued, often as part of a pending takeover. But the trades are not concluded, with cash changing hands, until the securities are actually issued. If they are not issued, or if the terms are substantially changed, then all trades are canceled. Some traders sought such a cancellation, but the N.A.S.D. rejected it. ''Our basic underlying idea is that it was a common stock, and it still is,'' said James F. Peck, an N.A.S.D. governor and chairman of the organization's Uniform Practice Committee. ''We've taken the position that the relative worth of the two transactions is not the issue. The issue is the security itself.'' He said he had not examined the changes in the company's balance sheet before making the decision, and saw no reason to do so.
Had the security been a bond in which the interest rate and maturity were changed, that would have been a different situation, said Mr. Peck, the chairman and president of Wyoming Financial Services Inc. of Casper, Wyo. But, he said, the TW case was viewed as being equivalent to a company suffering a business reversal.
That decision angered some traders. ''There were going to be 60 million shares outstanding. Now there will be double that many, for the same company,'' complained one buyer in the when-issued market, asking not to be identified. ''What I find scary is you can do this and get away with it. I'm not sure I'll ever do a when-issued trade again.''
Some buyers have considered appealing within the N.A.S.D., but have not done so. ''It's probably an exercise in frustration to do so,'' one buyer said.
The new capitalization structure of TW Holdings, which will own the companies now in TW Services, reflects the inability of the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation to sell the ''junk bonds'' needed to finance the original deal. In the new deal, Coniston Partners will own more shares and have a larger investment in the company.
That will result in a less leveraged company with a better financial cushion should it encounter rough times, but instead of 60 million shares outstanding, the company will have at least 110 million shares, and possibly 126 million because of a convertible bond issue. If it prospers, the rewards will be spread over more shares, and thus diluted.
James Murren, an analyst at C. J. Lawrence, Morgan Grenfell, estimates 1990 cash flow, after interest payments, at $1.55 a share, down from $2.33 under the original plan.
For Coniston, the new structure leaves it with about the same percentage ownership of the company, but it has to leave more cash in it. Coniston's original plans had called for it to take out more cash than it had invested when it bought its TW stake. Now it will have at least $100 million invested, and possibly much more. Part of that is likely to be in the form of $50 million in bonds that may be resold to Japanese investors next year.
Current shareholders in TW Services are getting another option. For each share in the current company, they will be able to take $26 in cash, plus two new shares, or they can choose from the previous options of $34 in cash or $30 plus one share. Depending on their decisions, Coniston will end up controlling from 49 to 74 percent of TW Holdings, and Donaldson, Lufkin from 14 to 22 percent. Yesterday, the shares of TW Services fell 12.5 cents, to $33.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Whether the deal closes depends on whether the new securities are bought. The current talk is that $100 million will be raised from a convertible bond issue paying 9 percent to 10 percent and convertible into common at $6 to $7 a share; $320 million from a zero-coupon bond paying about 17 percent, and $200 million from a subordinated debenture with a coupon near 15 percent. Buyers of the latter issues are to buy 16.5 million shares of stock.

HEADLINE: Dow Rises 3.08 Points, To 2,635.66

BYLINE: By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

 BODY:
Stocks ended narrowly mixed yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average rose 3.08 points, to 2,635.66.
Declines on the New York Stock Exchange edged advances by 748 to 735. Volume on the Big Board contracted to 148.4 million shares, from 155.1 million on Wednesday. 
The Dow was initially buoyed by a Commerce Department report of one of the smallest monthly trade deficits in recent years. The department said a drop in imports and higher exports combined to narrow the nation's seasonally adjusted merchandise trade deficit to $7.94 billion, the lowest since a $6.79 billion gap in December 1984.
 
'A Mixed Blessing'
''The trade numbers were a mixed blessing,'' said Jack Barbanel, president of First Global Asset Management in Princeton, N.J. ''While they improved over all, the drop in imports was significant and caused concern about a slowing of the economy. The question over the next couple of months is whether investors are going to accept the 'soft landing' scenario.''
In the broader market, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index edged up 0.04, to 340.58, while the New York Stock Exchange composite index dipped 0.01, to 188.75.
Dun & Bradstreet was the most active stock, falling 2 points, to 42 1/2, on a volume of nearly 7.4 million shares. On Wednesday, the credit-services company said it expected its earnings next year to drop 10 percent.
Hilton Hotels plunged 5 3/4, to 96. The company said that it was uncertain about whether it could announce a deal by the end of the year for the hotel chain's purchase as it it had previously stated.
Browning-Ferris fell 1 5/8 points, to 40 1/4, after Bill Genco, an analyst with Merrill Lynch, changed his rating on the company from a ''strong buy'' to an ''above-average buy.''
UAL dropped 4 1/4, to 184 3/4. A spokesman for British Airways said his company was not holding talks with anyone on the possibility of joining a new UAL buyout and did not plan to be involved in any UAL buyout in the near future.
 
Earlier Deal Failed
A deal in which British Airways, UAL's pilots and management had planned to buy the parent of United Airlines for $6.8 billion was ended last month when the group could not obtain financing.
Unisys rose 1 1/2, to 14 7/8, on speculation that A.T.&T. was considering a bid for the company.
Active glamour stocks included Philip Morris, up 3/8, to 41 1/8; Bristol-Myers, off 1/4, to 55 3/8; I.B.M., down 3/4, to 97 1/8; Occidental Petroleum, off 1/8, to 30, and General Electric, up 3/4, to 57 1/2.
On the American Stock Exchange, the market-value index added 0.36, to 372.51, while in over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index dipped 0.56, to 455.28.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
An Outsider Is Named As Volvo's President

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
Pehr Gyllenhammar, who has repeatedly surprised the Swedish business establishment in his 18 years as the head of A.B. Volvo, did it again yesterday: He paired the announcement of disappointing third-quarter earnings with the news that Christer Zetterberg, the chairman of a state-owned bank, will become Volvo's president and chief operating officer in May and will eventually become chairman and chief executive.
There was no indication when Mr. Gyllenhammar, who is 54 years old and is Scandinavia's most prominent business leader, plans to step aside. Mr. Zetterberg, 48, will replace Gunnar L. Johansson, 61, who is retiring.
Volvo also said that Roger Holtback, president of its car-making subsidiary, and Sten Langenius, president of its truck operations, would become executive vice presidents and take seats on an expanded eight-member executive committee. 
In going outside Volvo's ranks to choose a successor, Mr. Gyllenhammar said he was seeking someone with a broad industrial background and executive experience. Mr. Zetterberg had taken the helm at PK Banken in Stockholm early last year with a mandate from the Government to prepare the bank for a more competitive era when foreign banks would be allowed freer access to Sweden. Before that, he had been president of Holmens Bruk A.B., a large Swedish pulp and paper company; Tibnor A.B., a metals and industrial equipment distributor, and Celor-Celsius A.B., an industrial pipe company.
Mr. Zetterberg said he was enthusiastic about the opportunity to return to manufacturing, describing the task of heading Volvo as ''the finest managerial post there is in Sweden.''
Volvo, based in Gothenburg on Sweden's west coast, is Scandinavia's largest industrial concern and employs nearly one out of every seven Swedish workers. Best known in the United States as a vehicle producer, Volvo is active in aerospace, the food business and financial services. It also owns more than 44 percent of A.B. Pharmacia, one of Sweden's largest drug companies.
Mr. Zetterberg's appointment is expected to add new dynamism to a management team that has been on the defensive this year. Volvo has recently jangled nerves in Sweden with the news that it had been discussing a possible merger or joint venture with Renault, the far-larger state-owned French auto maker.
Volvo is heavily dependent on its automotive business as a result of the failure of some of Mr. Gyllenhammar's more ambitious diversification moves, notably into oil. Its operating earnings, which were off nearly 50 percent in the most recent three months from a year ago, reflect tough competition in the United States, as Japanese producers move into Volvo's market for higher-priced vehicles. The company is also worried about the effect of Europe's economic integration in late 1992.

HEADLINE: Movie Theme Park Planned For Disneyland in France

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 16

 BODY:
The Walt Disney Company said today that it would open a second park, which will have a movie studio theme, at its Euro Disneyland complex near Paris.
The company said the second park, to open in 1996, would be called the Disney MGM Studios-Europe, and would be similar to the Disney-MGM Studios theme park that opened in May at Disney World near Orlando, Fla. The first phase of Euro Disneyland is under construction and is scheduled to open in 1992. 
Disney had previously said it was planning a second phase for the European complex. Analysts said the choice of the studio theme was natural, given the success of the studio park in Florida. Disney has already announced plans to double the size of the Florida park, and is planning a studio-theme attraction at the Tokyo Disneyland.
 
Working Studio
Erwin Okun, a spokesman for Disney, declined to say how much the company planned to spend to build the Disney-MGM park in France. Harold Vogel, an analyst at Merrill Lynch, said that the Florida studio park had cost about $500 million to build and that a European version was likely to cost somewhat more, especially after inflation was factored in.
''The company has shown its intention to expand Euro Disneyland in phases, and to draw on the concepts they have developed in other parts of the world,'' Mr. Vogel said.
Disney uses the MGM name under license from the MGM/UA Communications Company. Disney-MGM Studios Europe would contain a working motion-picture and television studio that would allow the company to increase its live-action and animated production in Europe.
''In addition to the already opened television and motion picture animation company in France, employing 100 artists, we are excited at the prospect of bringing additional full-scale movie and television production to Europe, while providing guests with the entertainment magic of a second Disney theme park,'' Michael D. Eisner, chairman of Disney, said in a statement.

HEADLINE: Re-evaluation Is Urged on Cutting High-Tech Aid

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
Officials in the White House who favor a Government pullback from financing advanced military research and development programs with commercial applications may need to re-evaluate their position because of the needs of high-technology industries and the political climate, a number of economists and legislators said today.
On Wednesday, a bipartisan group of legislators challenged the Administration to clarify its position, based on a series of reports that have circulated in Washington in recent weeks. Those reports have indicated that in the 1991 budget the Government is preparing to cut financing for a variety of high-technology programs that are viewed by many as the foundation of an American response to Japanese and other foreign competition.
Yesterday Administration and Pentagon officials continued to refuse comment on the reports. A Pentagon spokesman said the agency was engaged in setting its 1991 budget and would not comment until the new budget was released in January. 
 
'Trial Balloons'
The reports may represent ''trial balloons'' during the budgetary process, sent up to gauge reaction to potential cuts in Federal high-technology initiatives, said economists and policy makers who have followed the debate closely. But many said they were concerned that if the reports were accurate, the Administration had taken steps against such programs as Sematech, a Government and industry consortium to develop advanced chip-making equipment, and the high-definition television research program financed by the Pentagon's Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency.
Sematech officials said yesterday that despite a prior five-year financing commitment, they were concerned about losing financing in 1991, which would be the third year of that commitment.
In a letter to Senator Jeff Bingaman, Democrat of New Mexico and chairman of the Senate Subcommittee on Defense Industry and Technology of the Armed Services Committee, Senator Lloyd Bentsen, Democrat of Texas (where Sematech is based), said he was concerned that a big push would be made to cut Sematech and other advanced technology initiatives from the fiscal year 1991 budget. In this budget year, he said, ''we may need a broader effort to salvage these important programs.''
 
Division in White House
The White House officials who back a Government pullback from support for high-technology initiatives include Richard G. Darman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, and Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers. Yesterday, an Administration source said that John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, was also opposed to such financing.
There is, however, a contingent in the Administration that favors some form of Federal support for a number of high-technology projects. Secretary of Commerce Robert A. Mosbacher and the President's science adviser, D. Allan Bromley, are known to favor Federal programs that will strengthen United States industrial competitiveness.
Economists and legislators who believe that the White House may yet need to re-evaluate what seems to be its prevailing opposition to Government high-tech financing point to the fact that on Monday the White House is expected to release a long-awaited report by the National Advisory Committee on Semiconductors that argues for a multibillion-dollar program to restore the United States semiconductor industry to world leadership. Release of the report has been delayed twice in recent weeks while Administration officials explored its impact.
 
Argument in Chip Report
A cover letter that accompanies the report was released yesterday by Senator Albert Gore Jr., Democrat of Tennessee, stating that the document will outline a national semiconductor strategy and that it argues that the deterioriation of America's semiconductor industry poses an unacceptable threat to United States economic and national security.
''It looks a little like the left lobe doesn't know what the right lobe is doing,'' said Michael Borrus, deputy director at the Berkeley Roundtable on International Economics, a policy reserch center. ''It's possible that they're flying both positions to see which way the wind is blowing.''
Robert B. Reich, a Harvard economist and advocate of a national competitive strategy, said that while recently a faction of the Administration led by Mr. Boskin and Mr. Darman had systematically tried to roll back programs that appear to embrace an industrial policy, in the future the Administration will come under increasing pressure from United States business efforts to back such initiatives.
 
Demands of Business Noted
''The business community is beginning to demand action out of Washington,'' he said. ''American business is beginning to say things that would have been anathema five years ago.''
Mr. Reich also said that while programs financed by the Pentagon's Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency that have both civilian and military uses have been under attack recently, in other areas the Federal Government has been active in supporting federally financed industrial policy initiatives. He cited programs at the National Institutes of Health that have supported the nation's biotechnology industry as examples of such Government activities.
This week's heated controversy over high technology has also led to charges that the Administration is sacrificing international competitiveness for budgetary reasons and that Japanese lobbying efforts in Washington have effectively altered Administration policies. A Commerce Department official said yesterday, for instance, that the Japanese have made a concerted effort to influence the United States to cut off funding for high-definition television research. The Japanese already have a lead in setting an international standard in that technology, which provides much sharper television images.
 
Need for New Models Seen
Observers said yesterday that despite the bitter policy debate between the Administration and Congress, ultimately the United States must find a way to develop peculiarly American models for coorperation between the Government and private industry.
''The Japanese have a centralized style of organizing industrial cooperation,'' said W. Russell Neuman, director of the communications research group at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. ''I think that the awareness exists in the United States that something needs to be done, something that is uniquely American in style that fits the way we need to do business. But leadership has not come from the Bush Administration to develop these models.''
