HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Did C.I.A. Distort Soviet Outlays?

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
WITH the breakdown of the Communist economies, the United States is facing some critical choices. And a major issue is whether this nation can seize any opportunities to reassert its economic and political leadership without jeopardizing its security interests. Doubts about whether and how much the United States should scale back military spending have been compounded by analyses of the Central Intelligence Agency and the Pentagon's Defense Intelligence Agency, which indicate that the Soviet Union has been substantially outspending the United States on military programs for 15 to 20 years.
But a leading American analyst of Soviet military programs, Franklyn D. Holzman of Tufts University, asserts in a new study that the C.I.A. overstated Soviet expenditures by some 50 percent. 
These overestimates, he maintains, stem from three sources:
* From 1975 to 1983, the C.I.A. said, Soviet military expenditures rose by 4 to 5 percent a year. In 1984, though, the agency admitted that the growth had been only 2 percent a year, but it failed to adjust its figures.
* The Soviets introduced price reform in 1982, and in 1986 the C.I.A. switched its estimates to the new prices. That caused them to make a large upward leap for Soviet military spending. But in November 1987, the C.I.A. admitted the uncertainty of its changes. It said it expected Soviet weapon prices to rise more slowly than those of civilian goods because they were more closely supervised. Despite these admissions, the C.I.A. left its figures at the higher levels.
* The C.I.A. has used a category for Soviet military spending that includes civil defense, civilian space activities and internal security forces, swelling the size of the military budget.
The Holzman study maintains that when the agency's estimates are corrected for these and other factors, Soviet military spending as a share of gross national product falls from about 16 percent to 9 percent. On May 30, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev announced what he called a ''real'' Soviet military expenditure figure of 77.3 billion rubles, or 9 percent of G.N.P. ''It is difficult to understand why, after having admitted its errors, the C.I.A. failed to make the appropriate adjustments in its estimates,'' Professor Holzman said. ''It is the hypothesis of my paper that the C.I.A. was 'persuaded' not to do so by the Pentagon's research arm, the Defense Intelligence Agency, whose estimates have always substantially exceeded those of the C.I.A.'' He concluded by suggesting that the C.I.A.-D.I.A. estimates of the ''military spending gap,'' like the ''bomber gap'' of the 1950's and ''missile gap'' of the 1960's, have contributed to the unnecessarily costly arms race of the last 20 years. Caution within the Administration reflects doubts about whether the Soviet Union has really been cutting military expenditures this year, as Mr. Gorbachev promised. But this week United States Government analysts acknowledged that Soviet military expenditures this year would take a smaller share of G.N.P. And the analysts are still using the C.I.A.-D.I.A. figures as their base. If the approximate decline of 1 percent in Soviet military spending holds for the lower base numbers, it will decline to about 8 percent of G.N.P.
The lower base figures in themselves will not result in American military cutbacks. That remains a difficult strategic issue. But some American economic and military experts maintain that cutbacks in the military would actually enhance United States military and economic security.
William W. Kaufmann of Harvard concludes in a study for the Brookings Institution that the United States has strong international and domestic incentives for reducing military spending. He maintains that the United States ''has a stake both in ending the cold war and in fostering economic and political change in the Communist bloc,'' and considers that this would ease a transfer of Warsaw Pact resources from military to civilian purposes, ''even if the process lasts no more than a decade, and even if Gorbachev falls from power.''
The essence of a revised military spending plan, he said, would be to cooperate in ending the military competition with the Soviet Union and in reducing the resources both sides devote to that rivalry. But such a change could be achieved only in stages and would be a long and difficult process to negotiate. The process is likely to face obstacles from industries and regions that will see military cutbacks primarily in terms of lost income.
Basically, the United States has two ways to get the capital it needs if it is to play its full role in building a more stable and prosperous world: it can raise taxes or reduce military spending. As President Kennedy said, to govern is to choose.

HEADLINE: Korea's Trade Surplus Is Criticized

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16

 BODY:
The Bush Administration today increased pressure on South Korea to reduce its large trade surplus, warning of possible trade sanctions unless it acted quickly to liberalize its currency and financial markets.
David Mulford, Under Secretary of the Treasury, said Korea, and to a lesser extent Taiwan, must recognize the risk that a frustrated Congress will take tough measures unless they reduce their large trade surpluses with the United States. 
At a hearing of the Senate Banking subcommitee on trade and exchange rates, two Senators said South Korea was obtaining an unfair trade advantage by holding down the value of its currency, the won. ''There's no more tolerance for that here on Capitol Hill,'' Paul Sarbanes, Democrat of Maryland, said.
Mr. Sarbanes said there was a growing sentiment in Congress to resort to trade laws to offset the benefit that some exporting countries enjoy from currency manipulation.
Senator John Heinz, Republican of Pennsylvania, complained that Korean steelmakers had a competitive edge because of the cheap won. ''American workers and American companies and American communities are suffering,'' he said.
Mr. Mulford said South Korea's trade surplus had fallen by 63 percent in the first eight months of 1989 and that its surplus with the United States dropped by 25 percent, to $4.2 billion. But he traced the improvement to transient factors, like strikes. He said Seoul would have to let the won rise but that it had, instead, allowed the currency to depreciate slightly this year.

HEADLINE: Evans Making a Quick Exit From Supercomputer Field

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 16

 BODY:
A promising newcomer in the supercomputer business has decided to drop out only four months after introducing its first machine. The decision raises further questions about the ability of American companies to compete in the risky, costly industry.
The Evans & Sutherland Computer Corporation, which introduced its supercomputer with great fanfare in July, said this week that it would close its supercomputer division in 60 days unless it could find a buyer or a partner. 
The company, based in Salt Lake City, said more problems were discovered in the machine, delaying the date when it could be brought to market. Moreover, it said, it appeared that the machine's advantage over others was less than anticipated.
 
Over $30 Million Invested
The company has invested more than $30 million in the project over three years, and such investments dragged down its earnings by about 60 percent in the first three quarters of this year. Leaving the business will allow the company to concentrate on its core business of making computerized flight simulators.
The decision is the latest setback for companies that make supercomputers, multimillion-dollar machines that can perform billions of operations a second and are used primarily for scientific tasks and military purposes. American supercomputer makers are under pressure from Japanese competitors and from other American companies making smaller, cheaper machines that can run almost as fast.
Earlier this year, the Control Data Corporation said it would leave the business. The market leader, Cray Research Inc., has had declining earnings and has split itself in two, with its founder, Seymour Cray, starting a new company.
Such events, particularly the failure of Control Data's supercomputer business, ''have made many, many companies afraid'' of getting involved in the supercomputer business, said Oliver McBryan, director of the Center for Applied Parallel Processing at the University of Colorado, an early customer of Evans.
 
'Down in Flames'
The supercomputer ''could cause the whole company to go down in flames,'' he said. ''Or it could be their future. It's a big, high-risk venture, but I would judge it worth taking.''
Officials of the division, based in Mountain View, Calif., were said to be saddened and angered by the news, which was announced while they were displaying the machine in Reno on Tuesday. Management is trying to arrange financing for a buyout of the division. There have also been inquiries from several companies, including a large Japanese conglomerate, people close to the situation said.
These people said it might take $10 million more to complete the machine. Evans & Sutherland said it would take a pretax write-off of up to $14 million in the fourth quarter if it could not sell the unit.
